reviewText: We purchased this mount for use on a driving vacation, and it worked quite well for us. I couldn't get it installed properly, but my daughter rescued me and installed it for us.TIP: Look at the vertical angle of the back surface of your front headrest. If it's angled back or vertical, great! If it's angled forward, as mine is, you may want to put a small wedge of some sort behind the top of the DVD player to angle it more downward.This is NOT a fault of the product -- just variability in the way headrests are made.
summary: Works as advertised -- handy for long trips

reviewText: It worked. Now I have to add useless words to make up some goofy guideline to meet amazon's criteria for reviews. Seems to me I should just be able to say that it met my needs at a good price, but NO! I have to go on and on using up words so that Amazon's review process will decide I wrote enough words.This is why I hate writing reviews for commodity items.

Love the headphones and the sound quality.  Love the design and the dual cords provided.  But I don't love the extreme tight fit.  I can't wear them for more than a couple hours due to the squeezing of my ears.

Multiple separate WLANS lets you create a guest account, or dedicate bandwidth to separate versions b/g and n and ac can all have their own separate WLAN. I have my slower devices on their own network so the primary Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) doesn't have to drop down to the slower speed to accommodate them.

reviewText: I needed to replace my old Samsung 30 inch picture TV (it was a slim line HDTV 1080i) when it broke.  This went into my bedroom, and didn't need anything fancy.  The 40 inch TV is perfect.  The color and detail are terrific.  What is also nice is that it 'knows' when I turn on my Sony Blu Ray player.Well worth the price, although like everything else, prices continue to fall, and you can probably get a 120 Hz and even larger screen size for a comparable price.  I am partial to Samsung, and think it is a great set.  Color, sound, ease of use, internet connectivity, streaming over my network.  Nice.

The zoom ring is jerky but the auto-focus works quickly. I would recommend a used Minolta Maxxum lens over this one however.

My camera is an Olympus e520 so it is not a big camera and it barely fits, even with kit lens. Again, it is a sturdy bag and it seems like it will be a long lasting companion. Just wish it had been a little larger.

It works great on my i7 2600K.  Without overclocking, my idle temp is usually between 30-33 degrees and during load (load generated using Intel Burnin Test), the temperature usually in lower 50's.The heatsink is big but it does fits on a NXZT Source 210 which is a mid-size ATX case.  The default fan is designed as an intake to blow cool air into the heatsink so it will probably be seated right next to your RAM.  It might be a concern for people who has RAM that has tall heatsink, luckily I have a low-profile RAM so it fits right underneath the CPU fan.Overall I give it a 5 stars because it keeps my CPU cool and the fitment is perfect.

reviewText: I only use Western Digital drives so let my bias be known. For the money I've found no more reliable a vendor that WD. These drives perform well in my NAS, and I've had no issues to date but then I don't expect any issues anyway.

reviewText: This is my second SanDisk MP3 player in 14 months.  The first one I had simply froze up and quit working period so then I bought this one.  What a waste of money.After just a few months, the blue paint started chipping away (then again, this piece of garbage was made in China, so I shouldn't be surprised).  Now something is wrong with the headphone jack and the sound keeps going in and out of my earphones and I have to constantly jiggle the jack to get the sound back (no, it's not the headphones - I've tried 3 different headphones and it still does it and the head phones play fine in other devices).I'm fed up with SanDisk and I will not be buying their products anymore.  It really is true that you get what you pay for and I'd rather pay more to get something that's going to last longer.  I've never had an Ipod before, but I'm going to give Ipod a try this time around because this SanDisk garbage is worthless.  I'd also like to add that I was very careful with my MP3 player (never dropped it on the ground, never got it wet, etc).I'm not sure where all these glowing reviews are coming from.  I wonder if these reviews are being written by people who have only had their MP3 player for a few weeks.  If so, that would make more sense because I thought mine was great the first few weeks too.  But I wonder if they would still give these glowing reviews 6 months after their purchase.
This case is much better than the first one and costs 1/2 what the first one did. This one flips horz or vert to work some apps.

I was a little concerned about the software issues, but upon connecting the camera to my MAC, iMovie and iPhoto is able to import directly from the camera without installing a thing. It just works! I didn't install any of the Sony software that came with the camera. Looks like software issues are Windows issues. Solution: switch to MAC! The video and stills are excellent quality. The touch screen is easy to use (and I have big fingers). Manual focus works great. Night Shot is fantastic! Low light shots are good. I would highly recommend this HandyCam!

Some time back, I posted a review to Amazon saying that the GE Superadio III was the best radio I ever owned. Now, I find myself using only this radio. The main reason is the digital frequency display. You always know exactly where you're tuned. It's such a major difference. I like analog tuning; I like twisting the dial to go from one station to the next. With the S350, I don't have to guess where I am on the dial. The FM section is great; very little overloading in my very difficult reception area, with great weak signal pickup. The AM section is superb; there are Wide and Narrow bandwidth choices that are usable on both local and distant stations (a bandwidth switch lets you choose the best tradeoff between interference rejection and audio fidelity; on the S350, both choices are well designed--with the Superadio, the Wide setting is so wide that you can only use it on very strong, local stations). I find myself listening to a station 500 miles away in the Wide bandwidth mode most nights. The Shortwave section is a joy to listen to. The S350 is light, even with batteries, and produces a nice sound--not quite the same bass response as the Superadio, but very pleasant. If you like a slightly retro design (no station memories, no slewing buttons, but it does have a nice big tuning knob PLUS a fine tuning knob) and appreciate knowing exactly to what station your radio is tuned, this is what you want. There is no better radio, overall, anywhere near this price.

Got these for free. They were worthless. No matter what setting the device goes to radio stations. I heard my tv, then a radio station, then it switched again. If I sit three feet from the transmitter and with the headset turned just right I here the tv this might seem good. Sneeze and you'll be on a radio station, take a drink of your soda and toggle back to the tv, blink and you'll be hearing aircraft or wireless phone. People should be sent to prison for building and selling this type of junk.
summary: if I can't say nothing nice

reviewText: After 12 uses it still works as good as new.  It has already paid for itself 8 times over.  Seems well built and is made in the USA.  Very happy so far, hopefully it will last another 100 uses.

After reading many other reviews here I decided to try these and also a pack of the Sanyo Eneloops. They've both been excellent performers. I've tried them in several high drain devices (e.g, flashlights, my Nitecore EA4 searchlight, my Inova ultraviolet light,  battery powered reading lights, and camping lights) and can already see they're higher in capacity than the older NiMH batteries I was using. These are second generation NiMH and the improvements in capacity and power are noticeable. Sanyo explains one reason for this is the "super lattice alloy" used for the metal cathode, and I assume that Powerex is doing something similar. It also sounds similar to the glass mesh arrangement in more advanced lead acid batteries. But whatever it is it seems to work. I have both the Maha PowerEx MH-C9000 and Opus BT-C2000 chargers which are two of the best chargers out there, which help me to correctly maintain and get the most out of my batteries. The difference between the Powerex and the Eneloop is that the Powerex isn't a LSD, or low self discharge, battery. If you need LSD's you might want to consider the Eneloops. I'm very happy with the Powerex's so far and I can recommend these without reservation, especially for your high drain applications (i.e., flashes and cameras, flashlights, children's toys, game controllers, battery powered walkway lights, etc.)

Amazon Basics are a great value.  I've ordered a couple now and they are every bit as good as my Monoprice.  This digital audio cable was a great price.  The build quality was solid and packaging was first rate.  I can't tell any difference in sound quality between my premium Monoprice and this cable.

reviewText: I was given the task to find a replacement monitor for a system for under $100.  I did a search and this was price wise, including free shipment the best deal online.  I found a reconditioned LG monitor for about the same cost, but why buy recon vs New.  You are limited to the Video Card of the computer.  This computer is a business computer with an onboard video circuit.  The Video adjustments were very limited.  Out of 6 options I found one that came close.  Most Video Cards give you well over a dozen options especially for wide screen monitors.

I then alternated between listening from this set and my old set and the difference was huge.  These speakers had far less range.  It's probably because these only have one driver per speaker (my old ones have two - one for treble, one for mid-range). I ended up returning these speakers.

I purchased this waterproof case for the purpose of taking underwater photos and videos with my Canon SD850 on a scuba diving vacation at the Red Sea.  It performed wonderfully.  No complaints at all.  The case is durable and feels very well made.  I had no leaks and took the camera to depths of 25 meters.  The buttons are large enough to operate even with scuba gloves (1.5mm). It was so easy to use we just left the camera in the case even for dry land photos.  It did not fog up and performed great.  Other reviewers have commented that they purchased the weights to stabilize the camera underwater.  I simply used the provided wrist strap and had no problems whatsoever holding the camera still enough for closeups and video of sealife.  This is a good little case.  Highly recommended.
summary: Easy to manage, easy to operate, even under water

reviewText: After purchasing a new iPod, I found that it's a bit smaller/slimmer than my last one (3rd gen).  So I was on a quest to find a new workout band, one that would give a secure fit, be well-constructed, and be reasonably priced.This lil' number fits the bill for those aspects.  The silicone skin to surround the iPod is flexible yet sturdy, and it comes with screen and track-wheel protectors if you want to put them on.  (I elected not to, as I'm horrible at putting them on well without air bubbles everywhere).  Also, the skins come in really nice colors---I got a purple one to match my purple iPod.  So even though your iPod looks cooler without the skin, it still looks decent in its silicone armor.It's a simple design---once the iPod is slipped into the silicone skin, you thread the velcro armband through the slits in the back.  Secure it to your arm, adjust it for comfort, and you're ready to go.  The band is snug but not uncomfortable once you adjust it to your preference, so you don't have to worry about it slipping down.In the future, if I needed another armband, I'd buy products from Grantwood again.P.S. Although the product details say that you shouldn't be taking the iPod out and putting it in frequently---saying that you should leave it in even when charging---Apple says that you should take the iPod out when you need to charge it.  I would think it has the possibility of heating up too much in there when charging.  The silicone seems sturdy enough to withstand use, anyway.  Obviously, just take some care in pulling out your iPod and replacing it in the skin if you plan to do it frequently.EDIT: As of 3/7/2012, this is still holding up just fine.  I do take my iPod out when I charge it---I'm just gentle when I take it out and put it back in.  The silicone seems just as good as when I bought it, so barring anything traumatic to the product, it should hold up fine for a long time.
summary: Durable and comfortable---better and cheaper than stuff from Apple

reviewText: I was using a much smaller Lenovo remote for my HTPC but I like using this Logitech keyboard much better.  Trying to type anything with the Lenovo was a dread, this keyboard, though my larger, is much more useful.

As a writer, I take my laptop with me everywhere (never know when you can squeeze in a few minutes writing). The Case Logic is perfect for me, a Virgo who is obsessed with organization. I was running a Pioneer VSX-512K given as a wedding gift to my wife and it recently gave out. In search of a replacement I also wanted to get a unit with updated features and that didn't force me to update my speakers since I love them and see no need to replace them at this point.I'm now running this set-upINPUTS:* PS3 Slim* Direct TV HD boxSPEAKERS:* JBL Northridge E30 Front L/R (bi-amped)* JBL ES25CThere are some tweaks that some users may find aggravating to complete or tiresome to test, but that is the nature of the beast. Great sound from existing equipment will always take a bit of time and adjustment to personal taste. I have immensely enjoyed the sound of my new receiver and though I have no problem with Pioneer, I think the new Onkyo is better suited to my needs, tastes, and set-up.TIPS:The feature set of the TX-NR515 is only missing Apple AirPlay, but DLNA is all anyone actually needs. Personal tastes dependent upon the "cult of Apple" may dictate the "need" for AirPlay and the Onkyo option is theOnkyo UBT-1 Bluetooth USB Adapterwhich allows streaming from an "i" device to the receiver. Perosnally, I applaude Onkyo for removing themselves from the addition of $100 to the price of their units to claim "AirPlay" like other units with fewer audio benefits but greater gimmicky features. Many PCs and Macs can stream the same content via DLNA, so don't feel compelled to buy an Apple TV or the Bluetooth adapter to be compliant with AirPlay - you don't need it - especially since 'i' devices can plug directly into the front USB with the Apple provided cord.Onkyo has a wifi adapter for the networking to stream internet Radio (sort of redundant if you're just using the receiver for games and movies, and don't have a nice PC speaker setup). The wifi adapter has some connectivity issues when near other networked devices so as is suggested on the wifi adapter page, I ordered the TP-Link TL-WN722N 150Mbps High Gain Wireless USB Adapter for use in lieu of the Onkyo mini USB for the high gain antenna and placement flexibility. The WN722 is the same internal hardware found in the Onkyo adapter. I found that per the suggestion of several other users, this is both better in terms of streaming signal strength and cost efficiency (even with a 9' USB extension cable, the price was less than the Onkyo adapter, at the time of writing this).Unless you're an audiophile with high-end speakers (which then, why a TX-NR515 over an 818 or up?) or just can't get your speakers balanced by ear, Audessey2EQ is moot (but appreciated). I found having to tweak the settings after the alleged "auto" set-up, but I did learn a number of things about my set-up in the process and for that, the addition was worth it.PS3 users will notice that the use of "deep color" from the PS3 will cause display issues. Be certain to turn the feature off in the PlayStation system settings, as "deep color" is mandatory 36-bit colors to conform to the standard and the PlayStation outputs 48-bit, optionally - thus the problem and reason for; Onkyo didn't build the receiver to handle the 48-bit depth, only the 36.The TX-NR515 incorporated HDMI 1.4a, which carries Ethernet and audio return. If your TV does not accept audio return, you'll have to use the TV line out to feed back to the receiver. I would suggest optical out. The PS3 uses HDMI 1.3b-1.4 depending on the model. I suggest the purchase of 1.4a compliant HDMI cables (I got 3 and 6 foot blue rigger) to ensure cable fidelity and signal compliance between legacy devices.The Onkyo remote app is not the most comprehensive or robust app for user but it was intentionally kept simple and straightforward. Additionally, it is a free app. Personal choice was "O-Remote" because I can run through every option and set-up for my receiver from my iPhone or iPad, easily and effectively. For the price of an additional $5, I prefer "o-remote" on the grounds of flexibility and control.If I had to buy this again, I would... but if the Onkyo has the same build quality as my old Pioneer, my kids will be in college by then and a TX-NR515 will have gone the way of the Dodo.****UPDATE****As an aside, I've no idea why, nor do I much care why - but the network updating feature generally results in no joy across many features. The best method of firmware update is USB. It takes less time, and there are fewer reported errors. After updating, I suggest turning network notification "off." From past experience as a computer tech, when older computers used to have BIOS updates, or for the more modern person, game hardware updates - can result in undesired results. Best bet, sit on the update for two weeks - wait and see if people report issues. If so, wait for resolution before updating. If not, update via USB.Second, apparently HDMI cables are fragile. For some reason, after an update one of my three cooked. It may or may not have been the receiver, but the fact is the cable died. Be prepared to, at times, switch a cable out if there's undesirable result like loss of picture through HDMI out main.Many reports of failing HDMI Main Out can be found on the web. I can't speak for everyone, but after being hit with the same "issue," I discovered a workaround: Order of operation. I turn on my receiver first, then my TV. Because my TV switches resolution, frequency, and "mode" which accepting input, it seems to reset and adjust to what the receiver is attempting to hand out.****UPDATE 2****Onkyo has released a USB only firmware update that resolves the HDMI handshake issue. I have updated my 515 and for the past couple of months not run into a single handshake issue and my device performs as expected. Any potential buyers do not need to worry their device will be faulty or that the fix will brick the unit. Just remember that USB updates are better than OTA updates.

reviewText: I bought this charger to top off the NP-95 & STK equivalent batteries for my Fuji X100S.  It works fine -- as well or better than the Fuji original.I do note, however, that the batteries themselves have three electrodes. The factory original charger also has three electrodes.  But this charger, like most after-market chargers, has only two electrodes.I have read elsewhere that the third electrode in most camera batteries is for temperature monitoring so the charger will know to throttle back if the battery gets too hot.  I don't know if that's the case with the NP-95 battery. I merely mention it here as a noticeable difference from the factory original. Perhaps the manufacturer will explain why it doesn't matter.Best I can tell, this charger works just as well, and just as fast, at a price 60 percent less than the Fuji original. Workmanship is adequate. Certainly no worse than the original, which doesn't impress me either. The electrodes on both are delicate and wouldn't be hard to damage with careless use. And, as others have mentioned, neither grips the battery tightly. This isn't so much an issue with the original, which requires a power cord, and therefore can lie flat on a counter while charging. But with the STK, which plugs directly into a wall outlet, the looser grip might allow the battery to fall out. Keep a rubber band handy :)Aside from being much cheaper, the STK charger has another big advantage over the Fuji original: it's totally self-contained with built-in prongs for the wall socket so you don't have to carry a cord or transformer. And the prongs swivel flat for travel (see photos).On balance -- I don't think this charger would hold up to heavy use, but neither would the original. Both seem rather flimsy.  But the STK wins in my book because it's so much cheaper and doesn't need a cord. I'm just not sure whether the missing third electrode matters.
summary: No worse than the factory original, and in one way better

reviewText: Prior to this product, we used the Apple iPad Smart Cover (folds to make a stand).  While both covers are different, and I found the smart cover more useful at home, the folio was much more useful for transport and use outside the home.Pros for the folio:*Easy to place the iPad inside and secure*Excellent stand for the proper angle to easily read the screen*Easy access to all ports, buttons, and camera len*Includes a cleaning pad for the screen and a paper note padCons:*Closing the case does not always shut off the iPad, sometimes we had to give a gentle squeeze to hear the "click" indicating the iPad was off.

reviewText: It's pretty tough these days to find front panel/rear USB 3.0 Connectors that actually connect to the Motherboard USB 3.0 header. I shopped around for quite a while until I find the Biostar USB 3.0 Aluminum Front Panel CABLEUSB30 - Black. Most front panel USB 3.0 Connectors don't actually connect to the Motherboard! There's actually a cable that runs out the back of your case and connects to the rear USB 3.0 ports. Yes. I'm not kidding!The Biostar panel is well-constructed with a long cable. It looks nice and mounts in a 3.5" bay. If you don't have a free 3.5" bay it can be used in one of the slots for a rear expansion bay and it comes with the adapter and screws needed.I'm thrilled that I found this item and at such a great price!
summary: Actually connects the USB 3.0 Motherboard Headers. Sold quality.

reviewText: I really wanted to love these but I have so many other great headphones in this price range that I find them to be more average.Things I like1.  Music is fairly well balanced with the mids maybe a bit too forward but that can be addressed through EQ.2.  Sound levels are great with any device as these can easily be powered by an iphone or similar.3.  Cable is high quality (however there is a con for the cable as well)4.  Comfort is pretty good once they settle on your head.  Initial placement takes some adjustment to get the right fit but then they are comfortable for long trips.Things I don't like1.  Cable - The proprietary cable...Why???  Had they used standard connectors, the cable would be great but now you are stuck with replacing the cable with an Onkyo only if it ever breaks.  Plus, you cant use the cable on other headphones (I LOVE the V-Moda cables which I use on various non-V Moda headphones)2.  Sound - As mentioned that they are pretty well balanced but they do not stand apart from any of my other headphones.  Most of my headphones have some unique aspect to them which is why i keep them.  These fall under my "everyday use" headphones which, unfortunately for Onkyo, have been dominated by my Audio Technica M-50's which are suprior in sound to these.Not many things to dislike about these headphones (hence the 4 star), however, for everyday use there are better options out there in this price range (and even cheaper).  The At M-50's are great, V-Moda makes a bunch of different options and then you have cans like the Aiaiaiai TMA-1's which bring a very unique listening experience to the user.

I drive a Limo for a car service part time.  I have the need to bring my GPS along with me for the trips.  It is GREAT to be able to carry the "spare" cable in my briefcase and then "mount" it in whichever vehicle I happen to be driving.  The cable has worked flawlessly in any of the vehicles I have driven.  I don't have to "remove the wiring" from my personal vehicle every time I change autos. It is waste of money, when you attach it to the camera, the camera won't stand up straight. The pad goes kind of sideways on my arm and doesn't feel secure when holding the camera just with one hand with the strap on.I had it on for about 5mins after which i took it right down

I ended up having to purchase an adapter to mount the speakers in the doors (bought the Scosche SAHC634 kit, which worked fine with some modifications - see my Amazon review for that item). I'm far from an audiophile, and pretty much listen to music at "normal" volume levels, but the speakers sound fine to me.

I despise this Sony boombox. Hate it with a passion.The FM reception, as mentioned in many other reviews, is abysmal.  In fact, it's Worse than abysmal. It is horrendawfulific.When I try to listen to FM, there is a radio station near me that bleeds through to just about every other station I try to tune. When I finally get something tuned in (usually .1 or .2 away from the correct frequency), it doesn't last long. I'll finally get the antenna adjusted, but as soon as my pretty fingers release it, static and bleed through overwhelm.  Even when a station is coming in okay, it doesn't last. It goes back to static eventually.I contacted Sony, and their support was useless, as should be expected. They told me to move the antenna around, to make sure I was tuning to the proper frequency, to move the radio to a different location.  Attention Sony: stop trying to save 5 cents per radio by putting garbage components, because it doesn't matter what steps one takes to tune this piece of garbage, it is a piece of garbage.The stations I want to listen to are stations that I can get on every radio I've ever owned. I actually came on Amazon today to find a small radio that I can connect trhough the AUX port on this Sony boombox.God I hate this boombox.
summary: Sony is the Worst Name in FM Reception

reviewText: This is my third 2TB Essentials disk that I've bought (growing collection and backups).  Essentials are simple, small footprint and no frills added, and, they work and are reliable.  Works great on my MAC (formatted with MAC OS Extended).I'll continue with the series as long as they're available.

I bought this to be able to play my music collection in my F150 pickup.  I've had it plugged into my SYNC system for the past two months and no issues to date.  Access times seem to be good as there is minimal delay when asking SYNC to play a specific artist or song.the small form factor means no one in the passenger seat will hit it accidentally.  Much safer than the old flash drive I had in there.A great product.
Bought this as a used item but greatly satisfied with this item... Saved a lot than buying a new one.

I love the concept of this product - you are able to take your sound with you, without having to wear headphones (which can damage your ears). The main downside of this, of course, is that others can hear your music also, so it may not always be convenient.So I gave it a spin while doing some housework - rearranging stuff, a little vacuuming (a guy cleaning? Shocking, I know!). It clipped nicely to my belt loop of my jeans and it was so light I pretty much forgot it was there. It was nice being able to walk around and still hear the music clearly (as opposed to using fixed speakers in one room). At a rough guess, I would say that I was working for around 4 hours, and probably used it for another 2 the following day. I haven't charged it yet, so straight out of the box I believe I've used it for around 6 hours so far, and it still has a charge - pretty impressive. You charge it via a micro usb cord (identical to the Kindle or Android phone charger size), which IS supplied in the box. I was also just about able to hear the music over the vacuum, which was pretty impressive.Syncing it to my phone was a snap and took under a minute to achieve via the Bluetooth pairing button on the Clipster. Once you've paired it, it will automatically pair up every time both devices are on (and you have Bluetooth enabled on your phone). Aside from the pairing button, there is a power button, volume up and down buttons, and a play/pause button. The play/pause button worked seamlessly with my phone.The ONLY reason I didn't give this product 5 stars is because I wish they had added a back and forward button - having to unlock my phone and open up my music app to skip back or forwards seems a little cumbersome, and it strikes me that adding these buttons would be easy (I have 2 pairs of Bluetooth headphones, and both of them have this capability, so I don't see why this product couldn't as well).Other than that, I think it's a great product, particularly for teens (my son is already trying to get mine) and I highly recommend it.
summary: Lightweight, surprisingly loud but somewhat basic

reviewText: I found this 80gig model at Target in San Diego the day after Thanksgiving so feel lucky to have found one. I really like this mp3/video/radio player. I bought the first generation at launch but returned it a few days later because the battery didn't last long, had syncing problems and the computer software just sucked. This new Zune syncs wonderfully and the computer software is very good, comparable to itunes. I have not been able to sync via wireless for some reason. Maybe its the router but will call support and see what they can do. I've had this for a week now. The screen is very bright at 3.2 inches with the same resolution as the ipod classic and nano. Since the screen is larger with same amount of pixels, the picture is larger but more pixelated than the ipod. The feature I really like is the radio which works great. It will even display station name with song playing. The device is solid with glass screen and aluminum back so should be more durable than Zune 1. The battery is also better than Zune one. Microsoft really got it together this time around, I just wish it came in the other colors as the smaller Zunes.UPDATE: Battery life isn't as good as ipod classic, still can't sync wirelessly but other than that I really like this.
These have real nice sound for what they are. I used them as door speakers. Totally fine. Great price, good sound. All good.

Put this next to a D-LINK DIR-601 router.  Really did not see any significant difference in signal strength or throughput between the 2 routers.The DD-WRT interface has literally tons of configuration options, which is not the easiest for the faint of heart.  I kept trying to find where I can do DHCP reservations (to reserve IP addresses for my NAS and network printers), and finally found the setting under "services".  To configure DHCP reservation, you have to add "static leases" and manually enter the MAC address of the NAS and network printer (or whatever device you are trying to configure).  With the old DIR-601, I just look at the list of clients and select which one I want to reserve.  So the Buffalo WHR-300HP does require an extra step, though not too big a deal.(If you have network drives or network printers, being able to assign static IP addresses to these devices is critical so that mapping will always work anytime one of these devices or the router reboots.)The user manual is extremely skimpy from the BuffaloTech website.  Followed their instructions on how to set up the router as client and client-bridge.  I was able to connect the router to the AP (in fact, the router received an IP address from the AP's DHCP server and shows up as client list on the AP), but could not get internet connection to work (this is why I took stars off).  Again, the router's documentation really provided no further info for setup and for troubleshooting.  Perhaps Buffalo is depending on people to use other documentation for DD-WRT.In conclusion, if you are familiar with DD-WRT, this router presents a fair value and decent performance.  If you are not familiar with that interface, you are probably better off going with a D-Link or Netgear with a simpler user interface.  For me...it seems fun to tackle learning DD-WRT!  So, yes, you guessed it...I am keeping this to play with and experiment around.
summary: Range just ok, DD-WRT interface not for the average user

reviewText: BEWARE - THE NEW ONES ARE JUNK. The ones with black cords have a main button that has a hair trigger and doesn't click. I'm having to take them apart and unsolder the microswitches and move them around. Have wasted $100 buying many of these all from different vendors, can't find a good one. One was DOA, the ones with silver cords click but are way too slow.CONSIDER THIS A NO STARS REVIEW.
It was delivered as promised, but I haven't even taken it out of the package.  I also bought the Logitech Harmony IR Extender and have just set that up and it works perfectly.
Haven't had to use it but it is nice to know my camera is covered for accidents. Peace of mind.

This is so easy to use. It burns BD media quickly, as advertised. It is very light weight, but very well constructed. The output from this unit, so far, has been just beautiful with TDK or Verbatim media. The slot drive, for me, is a favorite. (Some prefer the tray loader, and those are even less expensive.) This drive is perfect for use as an all-media burner with an Apple or iMac. I am running mine with Mavericks OS. I have used it also with Windows 7. Really---FIVE STARS for this Pawtec!

Yes.Is the Kindle more protected from dings and scratches because of the case? Yes, again.You can access the volume and power buttons with no trouble at all, and it does stand up on it's own so I can set it down and watch a movie more comfortably on it.So, no complaints. reviewText: First off, let's start with what is included with the package. You get the JABRA handless speaker, a car charger, and a USB cable. The USB cable is about 4 to 5 feet.I have an iPhone, and the pairing of the device was plain and simple as pairing any other Bluetooth device.When a call comes in, just tap the speaker once to answer the call. In the event of a dropped call, you tap the speaker twice, and it reconnects your last call. Hold down the speaker for Voice Control.As far as sound quality, it's a mono-sound speaker, so don't expect THX quality or the idea of streaming Pandora to it.Other than that, there isn't a whole lot to say about this unit. It does its job, it does it well, and it provides quite an easy convenience.
When hooked up I got the error message "this accessory not supported by Iphone" The product description said that it was. So it does not work.
summary: Does NOT work On Iphone 4S as Stated in Product Description

reviewText: this six outlet wall mount surge protector seems to be of good quality and is very practical, it has really solve the problem of having a few electrical items in close proximity to each other, so far so good.

reviewText: I use this Velcro to tie up bundles of cables and large items. Solves many storage problems and ease of handling.

When I first read about the features/capabilities of the Carmen Car Audio Player I thought it would be really cool. I live in an area where the radio is limited to say the least. The first thing I did was install the software loaded in the units memory. When I got my first look at Carmen's software I was pretty disappointing. It seems like something that written 10 years ago.This brings me to the unit itself. The technology feels dated. Moving around the MP3 player is tedious. The remote control is virtually useless. Most of the radio stations don't even play the style music they claim to play. I thought to myself that I could just put some MP3's on here. I have only owned this camera for about a month now. It does everything as advertised.The only things I would mention to people upgrading to a dslr would be that the D5200 autofocusis built into the lens. Where as if you spend a couple hundred dollars more the autofocus systemis built into the camera. With the latter type camera you can use older lenses.The other thing worth mentioning is other than the shutter setting you need to push and hold down a button andthen rotate the setting wheel to change your ISO and aperture settings. This can become challenging whenlooking through the view finder.For the price, if you are on a budget you can't go wrong with this camera. The bottom line is the actual picture andthe D5200 takes an awesome picture!
Purchased in 2010. No audio on a MacBook and a Lenovo. Just bought 2 new adapters from different manufacturers, and HDMI audio works fine with both computer and adapters.

I purchased this set at a big box brick and mortar store for around $1,100.  This allowed me to compare against other sets on a side-by-side basis, and the analysis I kept coming back to was this: was there any set on the wall that was markedly better than this picture?  Figure the next 1080p set is priced at around $1,500 - $1,600, a 35% - 40% premium over this Westinghouse.  I simply could not justify the price premium for name plate alone.That said, I have a few quibbles.  I find the sound output "auto-recognize" feature to be a little finnicky: if there's no video, the set won't output any sound.  That said, the 4 HDMI inputs and multiple other imput options are a godsend; given my relatively layperson audio needs, I actually use the set as sort of an audio hub, outputting all sound via an optical cable to my home theater receiver (which is severely limited in its inputs).All in all, I feel I've gotten tremendous value for the money.  The picture is bright and wonderfully sharp, and when stations begin to broadcast in true 1080p (as opposed to 1080i at best), the set will continue to pay dividends.
summary: Tremendous value for a future-proof TV

reviewText: I bought this camera for my three year old daugther, it seemed like a pretty good deal: it's pink, little and waterproof. So I read other reviews that said it was a terrible camera, but hey, how bad can it be? I'm sorry to say it is really bad.I know it costs roughly $50 dollars, so it is likely that you wouldn't find any other camera with these features for this price. So I took a chance and yes, it is bad. The images are very blurry, considering that these are bought mostly for kids, and they move the camera a lot while taking pictures. Even an adult will have a hard time taking non-blurry images.Also the batteries die very, and I mean VERY quickly. You will definitely need to carry a lot of AAA batteries and change them every time you want to use it. It is also an annoying fact that when the batteries die you need to adjust the date again, because if you don't, your photos would always be taken in January 1, 2012 at 1 a.m. (that's the date to which it resets). I've also used rechargeable batteries, but they seem to die even faster.Other flaws: the colors on the photos are very different than the real colors, the flash takes A LOT OF TIME to recharge (around 14 seconds is my count) and every time you turn the camera on the flash is off by default, you have to turn it on (maybe to save power on the batteries).My daughter liked it very much at first, now she kind of lost interest a little bit. Maybe because she doesn't like her pictures to be all blurry most of the time.I gave it TWO stars just because it is really waterproof (I've tested at 1.5 meters underwater and had no leaks, yet) and also if you keep extremely still and take pictures with natural light, the photos are fairly ok (with different colors, of course).I don't recommend anyone to buy this product. It would be better to spend another 50 dollars on a better camera that you would actually use.
summary: How bad can it be?... well, REALLY BAD!

reviewText: Nice way to stream music to my speaker via bluetooth. Works as advertised, but it should be a built in feature rather than an addon. I assume newer models would have it that way.

After the laptop went sleep mode I was never able to get the 2nd monitor recognized again.  It may be the laptop configuration, the operating system, me or  the cable.  Luckily it was less than $8 so it was worth the chance.  If I can ever get tech support to help it may be that the cable is fine.
summary: Only worked for a few hours.

reviewText: I bought this TV the last week of November, and have had it for about 2 weeks.  The picture was phenomenal, right out of the box.  I'd give this 5 stars, based on the following:PROS:*  VERY nice picture.  Watching NBA and NFL was like putting on glasses for the 1st time.  I immediately noticed details that I've never seen before...and this was just on a 37" TV!  I've already had 2 friends buy one of these after coming over to see mine.  I can't get enough of the Discovery Channel's HD offerings!  I loved them before, but they are night-and-day better in HD!!!*  GREAT console.  The TV fits nicely in my living room, and has a very attractive black casing.*  VERY nice picture.  It' SO good, I needed to mention it twice!!!*  EASY set up.  The TV is packaged so that you can fasten the base onto the TV without removing it from the foam bumpers.  This prevents the screen from getting scratched while (alternatively) lying it on the floor during installation.  Great packaging!!!*  NICELY laid out jacks.  The TV has 2 HDMI and 3 Component jacks.  One jack has an S-Video-In which takes priority over one set of Components.  The back of the tv is indented and has 2 clips that nestle your input cables and channel them to the lower back-center of the TV.  This will help reduce the clutter behind your TV.CONS:*  Sound.  As mentioned by other reviewers, the sound isn't anything special.  Of course, you'll probably be hooking a TV like this up to a receiver...but if you don't, you won't be overly impressed with the audio.*  Volume.  In a less than ideal environment,(i.e. dishwasher running in the background, spouse talking in the other room...) the max volume setting seems a little low.  Again, this is solved with a receiver, but I would have liked a higher max setting.*  No side inputs.  The gaming version (appx $200 more) has a special gamer-setting, and includes a side input.  I can' imagine that they cost that much, and I feel that at least ONE side-input should have been standard...I love this TV!!!!  I don't know how I put up with standard definition and my old CRT TV!!!  I can confidently recommend this TV to you!!!On a side note, I bought this TV over the 780p model.  In case you're wondering, 'yes' you can tell the difference between 1080p and 780p on this TV!  Pay the extra couple hundred and get the 1080p!!!Also, I plan on using this TV for occasional gaming (Halo 3).  If you're looking for a TV PRIMARILY for gaming, I'd suggest going down to the 32" 1080p version (LC32D62U or LC32GP1U-gaming)
as a basic speaker wire value this is hard to find a better deal.  14 gauge instead of 16  is a bargain
Very simple hookup and sign up, and I was watching movies off of Amazon Prime in no time!  The Angry Birds game was a nice bonus!
This works well, is constructed well, and holds our very large antenna without any problems.  It was easy to install, and the screws seemed like they would hold very well.

I have a 4.2 stereo 'old school' audio system,assembled for quality music service above all else. I've pieced it together over the years to achieve the 'voicing'(sound) that i hope is accurate,clean and powerful. One of my subs is an old but good infinity,which I always felt delivered quality musical 'depth' but never enough volume. many sub-cables have come and gone, including monster (eh?) but never satisfied. Had to replace it by accident so mediabridge enters, need 35' looked good so I ordered. Wow! 2-days, here it is beautifully packaged ready to go,and free shipping! Plug it in..and WOW again!! My old infinity sub sounds AMAZING! Much better than EVER before. Feel like i almost have a new sub! this company rocks, and if i need ANYTHING in their lineup in the future its a no brainer!  GREAT STUFF!!!--------------PART 2------------ordered ANOTHER 35' sub cable--- makes my 2nd main sub sound GREAT!!  thanks MEDIABRIDGE!!!!

My SX10 was stolen with my card with the last year of my Grandchildren.  I was so upset words can not say.  I searched around and did some product reviews and replaced my SX10 with the new SX40.  The pictures are even sharper than my original camera which I thought were great.  I would recommend this camera to anyone who doesn't feel like using an SLR.  I also own a Canon A1 and and AE1 that are not digital.  They just sit in the closet now.  I love my new camera and wished who ever stole my other one would just return my card.  My name was on it with my address.  I bought it direct from Amazon and the delivery was so fast and just as described.  Love Amazon

I am not an audiophile, if I was likely would not even have seriously looked at a soundbar.I wanted something simple, easy to install and use that would dramatically increase the sound quality of my 40" Samsung tv, this meets all of those requirements.It is not surround sound nor did I expect it to be, it does increase the enjoyment of my tv, so I am very happy with it.I am 76 years old and so is my hearing, sound from those little tv speakers frequently seemed muffled unless I blasted everyone else out of the house. With this superior sound system I have been able to lower the volume and still hear better than I ever could with the standard speakers. A good investment!

I am pleased to write to all of you that this product not only has a fantastic price, unlike so many other products out there, but it also works as good as another product (heck, better) I bought not long ago for more than twice the price. A few months back I bought a Belkin product that was couple with a Blu-Ray DVD that "looked" like pretty good quality; thick sleeve, gold tipped ends, etc. I had it plugged into my PS3 and for a little while it looked fantastic. Then about several weeks ago I started seeing intermittent issues with the picture. I thought my PS3 was failing on me, great! and the warranty recently ended too! I went online chatting on forums to see if anyone else was experiencing similar issues and they did but a few had alternative solutions.An online vendor that repairs and sells refurbished PS3's said to me, "It will cost you $99 to repair your PS3's HDMI socket and another $25 for shipping and handling." Never once did they offer, "Did you try changing out the HDMI cable?"Guess what folks, it was the cable. This cable saved me over $100 and it did it with style and grace! It looks, dare I say, even better than the Belkin it replaced at a fraction of the cost.It just goes to show you folks, "sometimes" you get a lot more for what you pay for. Do a little research, save a lot of money- I did now it's your turn!
summary: Such a great deal! Works very well!

reviewText: Second time I purchase this. These sorts of things get accidentally damaged all the time so this is a great purchase. Two types of cable designs and you can experiment with which works best in different situations in your life. I have given away a couple to people who needed an auxiliary cable. I have headphones that don't have the cord permanently attached so I have one with my mp3 player and one at the computer. A previous cable I had which I thought was so high quality with a big metal connector actually broke my Sansa Fuze's headphone jack over time, so it is only good for heavy duty applications. These are lightweight so that they do not put a lot of stress on headphone jacks of small or plastic devices. Would buy again.

and has already saved my ipad from a run in with the ground.  Sturdy little case that acts as a stand too.  The velcro is starting to go making it a bit tougher to lock into stand position, but overall i'm very pleased with this affordable and effective case for my iPad.

reviewText: I like the Verbatim 96991 Easy Riser Bluetooth Notebook Laser Mouse because it is easy to set up and is very accurate. I have not had any problems with it as of yet. The Bluetooth is easily recognized by my laptop. Works great and at a decent price. If your computer does not have Bluetooth not to worry. I tried the mouse with a $1.99 USB Bluetooth adapter I found on Amazon and the Verbatim mouse works just as well with the Bluetooth adapter as my other laptop with pre-installed Bluetooth.

I haven't put this item to the major test yet. It took some time trying to get the unlock map codes from Garmin. So I've only tried it around our little town and haven't had a major trip lately to really try it. Gotta get a bank loan for gas on that one. I like my other Garmin's so this ought to be great. I got one for my son too, and he loves it.

This little speaker does everything as advertised. The sound is great for the size of the speakers. The bluetooth connectivity with my iPhone 5 is flawless and ranges through the whole house. The volume is good, again considering the size. My only complaint, and it's not worth deducting a start, is that it doesn't have the ability to run off of batteries. For my purposes though, I didn't need the extra mobility, but it would be nice for quickly switching rooms.

I made this purchase to use for work, as I work from home, and this is by far one of the clearest, loudest headsets I have ever used and I have used many headsets for work in my time. It was super easy to set up. I plugged into my computer at first and it installed on it's own and was up and running. I work in a Linux OS and I plugged my headset in before booting into my desktop and the headset automatically picked up and all I had to do was change the output to the headset and save the settings. The only con I have is mute. I can't seem to find a mute on this headset and working in a virtual call center-like environment that is a little annoying. I intend on Googling and updating this review with what I find in case someone else is having issues with muting. It's not enough to just lift the boom, so to speak, it needs an actual mute option. Overall I would recommend for anyone with a Windows 7 64 bit system as well as Linux. If you have issues try the following:Windows 7:Plug in the headset. When the headset is plugged in go to your audio options and make sure the Plantronics is what's selected as your input audio and your output audio. Play some music or go to YouTube and the sound should be coming through the headset.Linux:Plug the headset in. Click on Computer and go to Audio. Make sure the radio buttons for input and output are selected. Adjust the volumes on both. To save the settings hit Alt + S. You should be set to go.
As a long time Canon fan, I knew the 60D would be added to my collection. It was on my wish list for a year. The wait was well worth it.

I purchased this adapter to convert a Display Port video card built into a mini-form factor computer to HDMI so I could hook it to my flat panel TV as a Windows Media Center. The ones that did work seemed to work ok over the summer but once the temperature got down in the 50s, they hardly work at all.I bought another box hoping for better luck but all the batteries in the second box were weak or defective right out of the box.

i like nikon because they consistently make high-value products at a mild cost.  this camera is no exception.  it has GPS, up to 16 megapixels, macro, imaging options, and memory the size of the SD card that you put in it.  i saw it advertised in National Geographic as a rugged camera.  living up to its reputation, this camera has endured falls and scratches.  while i haven't tested its advertised water resistance, i will assume that this quality is part of the reasonable priced best camera in the price bracket.

reviewText: Made of quality material, good zippers, many pockets, This unit has been well thought out. Features strong, clever hardware with spring loaded snaps that are fun to use. Front pouch has room for lots of gear: memory sticks, smart cards, battery charger and even has an inside zippered pocket. A large pocket with snaps is present on the back of case. It hides a belly band to circle your waist and keep the bag snug against you when active. Main compartment has padded dividers you can configure to your needs. All in all a good piece of gear that I like using for the confidence it gives me knowing my camera are well protected and easy to hand. Should last many years.

reviewText: Purchased for work; have this same exact mouse at home with a wireless keyboard.  I love the quick access buttons on the side for paging back and forth.

The driver CD it comes with only includes windows 7 drivers.  No drivers for XP or Vista.  Their website's support page is 404.  Frustrating.It looks like others have been able to get it to work with Windows XP, but I don't see how to.  It might have been easier with earlier revisions.  But as of late 2011 it is not easy.

When I first got this TV, the first thing I did was hook it up to my PC to check out what some of my favorite games looked like on it. At 1080p, the image quality with maxed settings was breathtaking! I was so very happy with the quality of picture that I started looking into other ways to really flesh out my purchase. Thus began the assembly of my home theater system...After purchasing speakers, a receiver, and a blu ray player, I found out what I was missing out on. Blu Rays on this TV are just astounding quality! With the whole setup, it is quite the experience. Netflix HD is a must have to enjoy this TV daily unless you want to pay quite a bit for Comcast HD. I find that standard def comcast does of course look rather bad on it, but it will look bad on any HD because it is Standard Definition Signal.The inputs are lacking, this is very true. That is why I went ahead and bought a receiver so that it could handle all of my inputs and adjust them as needed instead of relying on the limits of the TVs settings. When paired with a receiver, this TV as a display is just about perfect to my eyes. It came with no visual defects nor scuffs. It now rests firmly on my wall where it has been mounted for almost a year. If you do plan to mount it, do all the measuring and drilling first and then get a friend or two to help you hang it as it could be dangerous to attempt alone.For the price, I would recommend this TV for just about any setup. The larger screen sizes I assume have the same quality panel and would work in a much larger room, but this size would probably be about as big as one would ever want in a bedroom.
summary: 46" Samsung LCD with amazing picture quality

reviewText: Very simple to fix using this item. Very reasonable price as well. Works exactly the same as the stock part.

BE WARNED......G19 owners ..and possibly new owners(but also read ALL below) please...Only when it happened to me did i search for similar problems and BLAM - what a lot of the same!!! (I have a possibly older "plain" G19)(IF a year can be called 'old'... what a parody!!)So it seems a for sure a Logitech G19 design flaw!!!!If you can RMA and don't mind wasting time and effort - your choiceBut like myself far away with pathetic local "agents" - what a joke - we have to import from Amazon. Great if the product worked for more than 2 years ..hopefully longer...Hoping Logitech has a plan to uphold their brand in other countries - else sending it back costs half a new one...no way!The problem - just Google "L" and "M" key presses:When I press the "l" key on my G19 it types = ,l8When I press "m" it types = M&A;When I press "p" it jumps to the top line.Is it nice otherwise?NO..perhaps.... unless they make the underutilized little screen more useful off the bat - out of the box. Who needs hours of learning to install whatever's from wherever to do basic thingsIT IS A DECENT Keyboard.I love Logitech products overall - thus my disgust in this situation...And *********** Does the ""new"" G19'S' address this "factory fault" ? ******************Personally i think so....  or am i just hoping aloud?Wish they would be open and honest......Perhaps condense all above into one sentence - before buying ask Logitech if the new G19S resolves the known plain G19 problem!Hope it helps some new gamers.....
summary: NB- Some G19 keys stop working after a while (L & M & P especially)

reviewText: I've been using a Canon 5D Mark II for the last 2 weeks and got this card to use with it. It has worked very well and kept up with my photo taking with no problems.  I've also used it to capture video and that has been problem free as well.  I have been satisfied with previous SanDisk cards that I have purchased and that is why I purchased this one. reviewText: This is a very good lens for macro and working in a studio setup, however don't count on the autofocus to work very well. I have a Canon 100mm macro and love it. The AF works reasonably well 50% of the time when shooting in a well lit area. This is good as you can free up one hand to hold a light modifier. The Tamron 180mm, perhaps its a bad copy, doesn't lock the focus with auto.  The 180mm is great because of the added working distance to the subject. Compared to the 100mm macro which works at about 4-6 inches from your subject from the front lens element, the 180mm is closer to 16 inches which is perfect for a flash or reflector to provide more light. I like the way Tamron shifts from auto focus to manual by shifting the focus ring either forward or back. It is convenient versus finding a side switch.  I give it four stars because it's well packaged with the hood, carrying case, and tripod ring and is very sharp when using manual focus. If you are fascinated with manual focus macro photography and use a sturdy tripod(required for the 180mm) and perhaps even some strobes, this lens is for you.
summary: Good working distance, AF with Canon doesnt really sync...

reviewText: For $150 this camera takes 3D HD videos that look pretty good. It's a great start on low end 3D video.It has a small screen that you can view in 3D with out glasses. Has a time lapse, slow motion, motion sensing settings.In 3D you have to pan very slow or shot makes you dizzy. Need a lot of light to get good 3D. The zoom is very jerky. But all in all it cost me $200 for camera and 64 gig mem card/If you want to try 3D this is the camera to get.I'm starting to look for a high camera now.

This review is for Panasonic TM60, which is the same camera with more internal memory. I am not a wannabe film-maker, just a guy who wants to film children and family activities. For this purpose the Panasonic is excellent and has exceeded all expectations. My old camera is Canon Optura PI, a mini-DV which was top of the prosumer line in its day. The Optura has become unreliable (tapes jam all the time) and the standard-def quality just doesn't look so great anymore. I've been looking at new Canon and Sony models under $1000 but did not really like any of them for various reasons, mostly ergonomics and user interface. But this Panasonic just "felt right" from the start. TM60 is the little brother of TM700 that Michael Reichmann reviews at [...] It is small and light, without being too small to handle. Wide angle starts at 37mm (this is very wide for a camcorder without attachments) and 25x optical zoom is very impressive. Optical stabilization is unbelievable - much better than my old Canon, which was the best in its day. I tend to film children following them around the house, or moving the camera around them Matrix-style, and the footage comes out very "fluid" without excessive shaking. Video quality is fantastic played directly on the TV through HDMI. It doesn't quite have the blue-ray sharpness, but looks like a good DVD upconverted to 1080. The acid test was shooting trees and flowers in bright sun, with lots of high-contrast edges. My old camera produced and annoying shimmer in these conditions, but with TM60 it is absolutely clean, with sharp detail and no artifacts to speak of. Little things add up. Camera doesn't really need a power switch - it turns on when you open the screen, and turns off when you close it. The lens cover also opens and closes automatically. You can adjust default sharpness, white balance and saturation for video. There is a built-in LED light for shooting in the dark, which is quite effective. There is also a duplicate start-stop button on the left edge of the screen, where you can press it with your left hand. The menu interface is touch-screen which I normally don't like, but this one is much less annoying than Sony's or new Canon's.It comes with Panasonic software for editing AVCHD that is kind of clunky but works OK. Pinnacle 12 handles clips from this camera fairly easily on a dual-core machine.I can think of only 2 downsides of TM60:(1) no microphone input. The camera is completely silent and the built-in mic is surprisingly good, plus the audio level is adjustable, but if you must have external mic then you need to step up to its "big brother" TM700.(2) manual focus is technically possible with touch screen buttons, but is not really usable. TM700 has a lens ring.
These were used in digital cameras and 3 of the 4 have failed and no longer hold a charge after about 20 cycles.  I expected 200 cycles or more like the 2000ma batteries.

I've rated this product based upon what matters to me the most: Picture quality. in this department this product is best in it's class, rivaled only by the Sony XBR line which comes in second place.Picture quality is simply..........Perfect. The best money can buy. If you're a gamer, this is your set hands down, if you're not a gamer, you could go for cheaper alternatives like plasmas, but why compromise? If you can afford it, buy it. Finest set on the market.  Creme de la creme. Cream of the crop. Period.I purchased this set for my secondary setup. In my dinning room. (My main setup is in my bedroom with the 52" version of this same set).I only have 1 minor gripe: The remote. Samsung tried literally to reinvent the wheel and failed miserably. For me, this is a non issue, since my dinning room setup is controlled by the satellite box remote but in case you're going to actually use the TV's remote, you should know the remote's functionality with the little wheel is just broken. I didn't consider this small detail a setback important enough to remove any stars from the rating. Doing so would be like buying a 50 million G5 airplane and saying the plane is terrible because you didn't like the cupholders. If the remote happens to be just unbearable for you, any Samsung LCD remote from 3 years ago or newer will work just fine. Just order a replacement remote off ebay for about 20 bukcs and end of story.  For 20 bukcs more you made an almost perfect set, perfect. Done. It's fixable.Have in mind 99% of your hard earned money is going towards picture quality here. And only 1% is going towards the hideous remote. Opt for a different set with a better remote, and there won't be any 20 dollar accessory you can buy off ebay that will get you out of that hole. You will be stuck with sub par picture quality for good. The same goes to people who knock stars off the ratings of TV sets because they don't have good speakers. The sound on this set is pretty good but if this happens to be your main set, where you will be watching your movies, or if you are demanding with sound, then you own a decent home theater, RIGHT?_____________________________________EDIT 04/29/09I recently came Across an Issue this TV suffers from and it's a split second lag when it comes to gaming content, specially first person shooters. If you want to read more about this, check my other reviews and find my review of the LN52A750 where I posted a video review comparing the 650 line vs the 750.To sum it up, if you play 1st person shooters, knock a star off this review. If you don't, this TV is as good as it gets in this price range.  If you want a lag free video game experience, go for the 750 series.

reviewText: Don't believe the bad reviews, this remote is excellent. Many of the bad reviewers simply don't understand the remote. It has a learning mode that is on by default. Also you would be suprised how many people don't realize that the remote has to be pointed at the device you are trying to control meaning if your devices are say on two sides of the entertainment center, the activity you set up may not work great because it will be trying to turn on say your dvd player on one side, While your pointing at your cable box to turn that off on the other side.This remote has a learning mode that is supposed to help but mostly gets in the way. If it realizes that your are turning things on or off outside of an activity it's AI will try and re-program it's self to more correctly reflect your actions. This feature can be disabled which would alleviate almost all of what people complained about in the poor reviews.This remote is geared toward nerds a little bit. It allows you to program the remote with delay times etc for turning on devices. It allows you to have custom buttons in the display of an activity. You can say make an activity to watch a movie. It will turn on the TV, HT Reciever, Blu-ray, while turning off your cable box. It's great! The remote has to be able to send a signal to those devices though.The remote can learn inputs from ancient remotes simply by pointing the old remote to the back of the logitech, and pushing a few buttons. Very cool!.I love this remote and suggest it to everyone. It is by far the best remote I've ever had ever! Simply awsome!
summary: Don't believe the bad reviews - Best remote I've ever owned

reviewText: I ordered this to replace my 2 year old Motorola Xoom.  I was looking for a model similar in specs and was pleasantly surprised with this model.  I do presentations and wanted HDMI output, not found on many tablets.HDMI Out works flawlessly and allows you to keep continuous charge supplied to the Tablet while viewing the Tablet on your tv.After receiving the tablet, I had a couple questions and contacted ASUS support, spoke to a live rep who answered my questions - tremendous!It also has a microSD card slot so you can add additional storage to your tablet ... something most alternative Android tablets don't have.I would recommend this.

This cover is excellent.  Easy on, easy off, and as others have mentioned the rubber grips prevent it from sliding out of your hands or off a smooth surface.  The charging port and headphone jack are both easily accessible and not obstructed.  And there's a single button on the side that covers the volume buttons on the iPod touch; if you're not looking for it it would blend right in.  My only disappointment is the effect this has on sound -- because the iPod's speaker is in the back of the device, this cover has a bit of a muffling effect.  You can still hear things (I just crank the volume), and I suspect this might be true of all covers, but I wanted to point it out.  Of course, if you're using headphones or it's connect to your stereo or something, then this won't be a problem at all.  Otherwise, it's a great choice.
summary: Great choice for a cover, but...
