I just got mine last night and I love this thing.  I have upgraded multiple laptops to SSD's, so I have a lot of 2.5" drives laying around.  This enclosure is literally so easy to swap drives, I now feel like I can use all of the drives with ease and only having 1 enclosure.  It takes less than 10 seconds to swap drives in this enclosure.  You slide a lock tab open, slide the plastic cover off, pull out one drive, push in the other drive, and replace the cover.  Done.I'm only giving it 4 stars unfortunately because of the construction quality.  One corner of the aluminum top is not flush with the plastic.  It is popped up slightly.  Not a big deal.  Also the flip out cable doesn't stay clipped in place after being straight for a few minutes.  The included sleeve takes care of it.  Those 2 minor things aside, I would not hesitate to buy this for the price.I'm glad I quit hemming and hawing and just ordered it.  I'm very happy so far.

My husband got this as a birthday present for me because he wanted me to have Bluetooth phone, and he knew I would instantly turn the display pink.  I was a little skeptical that I even needed a new car stereo (I was perfectly happy with my original one, and I rarely use the phone in the car), but I like a cool new gadget as much as anyone.Now that I've had my 8500 installed for a few months, I wonder how I did without it.INSTALLATIONI consider it pretty complicated to install a car stereo.  There are lots and lots (and lots) of wires to match up, and there are things you need to buy (like the enclosure that fits around the stereo, and, for my car, we needed an adapter to hook up the antenna).  I absolutely wouldn't have even tried this on my own.  But my husband didn't bat an eye.  He thought the installation was very straightforward.SOUNDThe sound is excellent. I thought the sound on my old system was good, but this blows it away.  There is much more "presence" without necessarily being louder.  If you like a deep, window-rattling bass, you can get that (no need for new speakers!), but for those of us who prefer a more balanced sound, it comes shipped at that setting.  There are lots of ways (maybe even too many) to customize the sound, so however you like it, and whatever genre you listen to, this Pioneer has you covered.DISPLAY & FEATURESThe colors are beautiful.  And yeah, I went with an all pink display.  Then I tinkered with having half of it lavender.  Then I turned it blue and red for Independence Day.  Can't wait to do green and red for Christmas.  Can't decide?  You can set the colors to slowly cycle through (they gradually morph from one to the next).  You can also set the colors to match the other lights on your instrument panel, no matter what they are.Unfortunately, the display is not very easy to read.  It's too dim during the day, and the dots of color are too big to make the characters clear even under the best of circumstances.  When the unit is on, under most display options the clock is so tiny that it is extremely difficult to read (and who wants to be leaning over and squinting at the darn thing while driving?).When using Pandora, if you choose to display both the artist and the song title, it forces you to give up the clock altogether and instead displays which station you are listening to. I finally got around this bit of idiocy by specifying that my default display be a large clock (which also includes the date; you can't choose to display only the clock).  By pressing the "back" button, I can see what the artist and song title are, if I wish.  But this whole thing just wasn't well thought out.Despite being too dim during the day, the display is too bright at night.  You can set it to dim when the headlights are turned on, but it makes very little difference.  This hasn't been a huge issue for me yet, but I don't do much night driving.Mixtrax is a joke.  It only works when playing songs from USB.  And why would I want my songs blended together, anyway?  The lighting show it's supposed to create synchronized to the music might be kind of cool as a novelty, but I doubt it's something I'd pay attention to after the first couple of songs (and you probably shouldn't be watching it while you're driving, anyway!).Speaking of Pandora, I absolutely LOVE listening to it on this thing.  It's easy to skip a song (you flick a lever) and to give a song a thumbs-up or a thumbs-down.  Changing stations is fairly easy, too (push one button to bring up your stations, then turn the volume dial to scroll them them, then push the volume dial to make your selection).PHONEThe phone function work GREAT.  The sound is excellent (both what you hear and what the other person hears; I have my mic attached to my steering column).  When you get a call, it doesn't just mute your music, it actually PAUSES it.  It makes a distinct, non-alarming series of notes to let you know a call is coming in.  You answer the phone by pushing a small, but clearly marked, button.  You push the same button again to hang up, and after a moment, your music will resume.  Making a call is a bit more complicated, but I do actually find it much easier than picking up my phone, even if I'm not driving.The Bluetooth connection for the phone works easily and smoothly.  Shortly after I start my car, I always hear a little beep to indicate that it has connected with my phone.  Once I paired the two the first time, they have never failed to pair on their own.  Even when I got a new car battery and the system was without power for several hours, it remembered my phone (some of my other settings were lost, including turning on Pandora, which is a pain to do, but at least my phone worked!).BLUETOOTHAside from the phone, using other apps via Bluetooth has been a bit spotty, at least when first turning them on.  Even though my phone pairs right away, the Pandora app on my phone doesn't work until I push the "try again" button on the stereo at least once (sometimes multiple times).  If I want to listen to music during a particular drive, I make sure I have Pandora going before I start driving.Once I get everything working, I can also listen to music via my phone apps for Rhapsody, Amazon, and my phone's native music player.  The song information for these apps isn't displayed on the stereo.Despite the slight hassle in getting things going, once they ARE going, the Bluetooth connection works great.  The stereo has never lost contact with my phone.CONTROLSThe controls are not at all intuitive, and most functions are extremely difficult to locate.  Every time I want to do something I don't do on a regular basis, I have to look it up in the very low-quality, poorly organized, difficult-to-follow owner's manual.To turn the stereo off, you have to push in and HOLD the "Source" button for several seconds until the display changes (yeah, I want to be watching my stereo for several seconds while driving).  If you let go too soon, it will change the source, instead, which, in my case, results in the tuner coming on, which is MUCH louder than Pandora, and, because I don't get good radio reception where I live, it's typically static.  I hate it when that happens!  I so much wish there was just a simple, dedicated power button.The radio does not have dedicated preset buttons, either.  You have to push multiple buttons to access your presets, then scroll through the display of them.  This is not something I would really want to do while driving.The initial set-up of the system (time, date) goes easily enough (it walks you through it automatically the first time you turn on the stereo), but changing anything else will probably require looking in that black pit of an owner's manual.Are you starting to get the idea that the controls are the worst aspect of this system?SUMMARYDespite its extensive design flaws, I really do like this system, anyway.  It's great for Pandora, the sound is fantastic, I love the pretty colors, and the phone works great.  These items were top priorities for me.  Because of the poor reception in our area, the radio functions aren't important to me.  But if your priorities include easily changing the radio station, this unit probably wouldn't be a good choice for you.  Nor would it be if simplicity and ease of use are paramount to you.  But if Pandora and the phone are all you care about, this is a solid choice.

I tried this antenna with a Sony HDTV with a digital tuner, indoors and in my windowsill, and it would not pull in any stations at all by itself, only 2 or 3 when amplified, and then the picture broke up into pixels and froze up at times.  A friend's amplified antenna from Radio Shack worked well in the same area, bringing in dozens of stations, so it's not the area that I live in.  Returned for refund.

The earbuds are of very good quality, producing very good sound even at high levels. They are comfortable in use. Sound isolation is only moderate, but there is some useful effect. Be aware that there is no volume control on the earbuds themselves.For most uses they are amazing value for money.For the use I bought them for (in the line-out jack from a TOM TOM GPS on a motorcycle) they weren't the best choice... But I removed the soft silicon ends, drilled a hole in the end of the foam earplugs I always wear on the bike, and zip tied the earplugs on to replace the original ends. This is now exactly what I needed - the ear plug attenuates the (very LOUD) volume from the line-out jack, and also provide the sound isolation I needed. They fit very nicely in my ears under my helmet. And for a very few dollars instead of $100 and up... :D

First - Love my Nuvi. We have traveled everywhere with it and we now travel with confidence. The speech-to-text is essential, in my opinion, and the Nuvi does it well. Don't know how we got along without it.Second - the caveat(s). Maps are slightly out of date in places as are the points of interest (which is a real bummer). The Nuvi takes awhile to link up. We loved it so much we bought a second one for our other car, though, and it crashed from the very beginning. Sent it back to Garmin and they sent a refurbished one that was worse than the first. Just got back another one today so we'll see how it goes. BUT - the service support at Garmin is very good. Nice, helpful people. Which is probably why - of all the GPS choices out there - I just bought a third Nuvi for my parents. It's good and it works (mostly).

This is my second Mouse 3500 -- this particular one is the Limited Edition Year of the Dragon version. It looks really cool. In case you didn't already know, this year is the dragon year in the Chinese traditional calendar. But I'm sure this mouse will look good and work well even beyond this year! Hohoho... I bought anohter 3500 because I found the first one awesome. It has precise tracking and unlike mobile mouses of yesteryears, it feels awesome in my hand thanks to the truly ergonomic design. It works on any surface, of course, and the two buttons and the scroll wheel all feel just right. It takes a single AA battery, a Durell included in the package. According to the packaging, the battery lasts 8 months under typical use. The nano receiver protrudes just a bit from the USB port, so you can pull it out. The receiver can be hidden in a slot under the bottom of the mouse itself! The mouse also has a power switch, a thoughtful design. Finally, I've used my first 3500 in all sorts of environment and never once did I experience any interference! This is an awesome mouse, and the price makes it even more awesome!
summary: Awesome mobile mouse for road warriors

reviewText: This is much better than having an ugly hole in your wall with wires hanging out of it!  The dual gang plate has a very large hole and you can fit as many wires through it as you can probably plug into the back of your HDTV.  If you only plan on having a couple HDMI cables going through your wall, you can probably go with the single gang and be ok.  I went with the dual gang just in case I need the room, currently, I only have 2 HDMI cables going through it, and its a bit overkill.  Don't forget to get a low voltage mounting bracket so you have something to mount the plate to.
summary: Nice touch to a wall mount set up

reviewText: I live in Tulsa, Ok and I guess the humidity and temperature swings cause problems with connections in computers.  Every few weeks I would have to disconnect and clean the connections, particularly on disk drives, but also video cards, etc.  It was particularly annoying when my automatic backups would fail and I would have to clean the connections and rerun the backups.  Deoxit products have eliminated these problems.

reviewText: I bought this camera after returning the fifty-dollar plastic 'indoor' model with audio.  This unit feels VERY solidly built and performs great.  The night vision is clear and bright at greater than 20 feet.  The picture is sharp and accurate (though I lose a lot of quality going through my Q-See MPEG capture card).  The wide field of vision is excellent (there is a bit of 'fish-eye', but I don't know how you'd avoid that with a nearly 90 degree range).  These do not look ridiculous or obvious mounted to my home.  One camera covers about 80% of my backyard and another mounted above my front door monitors guests, delivery personnel, solicitors, and occasionally nocturnal predators (lots of geckos in Florida.)  I highly recommend this camera, particularly for domestic applications where appearance might be a concern.  BEAR IN MIND; this unit did NOT include power or cabling.  If you are planning more than one camera I strongly recommend purchasing an AC adapter intended for 4 or 8 units, vs getting a module for each device.
summary: The one I should have gotten first !

reviewText: Like it for the price but wouldn't pay $40. Nice quality heavy dock. Not marked APPLE but seems good quality. Did not come with a cable. It uses the one that came with the IPOD and plugs into a USB on the computer. I bought a cheapie cable and it works with my IPOD touch 4.

Is there any other electronic industry where devices "Plug-n-Play" with each other so nicely? If not, there should be. This combo worked so well out of the box with my HP desktop computer that I had to recheck the logos to make sure they weren't made by the same company. No sooner than I had slipped the (single) dongle into the USB port than the computer began welcoming the pair and informing me that they were ready for use. Indeed.The keys on the keyboard are a very comfortable size, and tactile enough to give positive feedback for every stroke without feeling bouncy. The function keys along the top row are a bit small, but not so much as to be an irritation. The mouse buttons and wheel all have good, positive feels to them, and I love that the battery well on the mouse has a built in "pull-out" tab that you place underneath the batteries to make replacing them easier when that has to be done. Great value for the price.

This mailers worked great.  I had the same problem at the post office as several other reviewers and a worker at the counter tried to charge postage as a package.  It is a first class envelope 66 cents plus 20 cents for nonmachineable because it is stiff.  So 86 cents is the correct postage under 2 oz.  Two DVDs with paper envelopes in the mailer totaled 1.9 oz.  When I did the postage using the automated system it came up to 86 cents but I had to buy an extra stamp since the machine won't let you charge less than a dollar.All my DVDs made it undamaged.

reviewText: This was a great purchase. I hated how far my 27" Acer T272hl leaned back when it was sitting on my desk using its built-in mount, so I bought the Ergotron LX. One important note is that Amazon shows the LX (both normal and tall pole) as supporting only monitors up to 24". However, I went to the Ergotron web site and found that the LX actually supports monitors up to 27".I was a little concerned about the installation, because quite honestly, I hate difficult installs. But it was actually quite easy: I simply attached the back plate to my monitor using the four screws that were included (they even include screws that can be installed/removed by hand alone), figured out where to position the mount, and then clamped it on my desk and adjusted it. It may be advisable to have a helper during installation, but I managed just fine on my own.I did find that when I raised the monitor to its highest position, it sank a bit when released. I just had to tighten one of the adjusting screws a bit, and the problem was solved. (The documentation included with the LX shows how to do this, and the appropriate hex wrench is included.) The LX does accommodate 27" monitors without a problem, but they will tend to be at the high end of its acceptable weight range.Being able to move the monitor wherever it suits me is absolutely wonderful. It was totally worth the money and effort. The LX even looks good.Very highly recommended!

First,the seller was great! Got discs fast, but I do not blame them for the problems with these discs.I thought after two years Ritek who made these Memorex discs might have improved. Skippy city. Well they burn and verify OK but do not play video OK. You might have luck on some DVD players but if you actually watch the DVD through it most likely will skip at some point. I tried two Pioneer and one Samsung burners using Windows Vista and Ubuntu operating systems with same results and yes 2.4x burn. The bottom line is they either work or not. I have always used Verbatim discs after my fiasco with cheap discs two years ago and never had any problems. If you have had problems with Verbatim, I would think its your drive going bad or your burning software needs to be re-installed. Also, not all standalone players will play +R DL discs. I fell victim to the low price but if you look you can find Verbatim at reasonable prices. So after wasting my money on these discs those Verbatims look much cheaper. Do not trust these for your photo's or anything of value. Almost all of my Ritek discs eventually failed over time. It helps to look up disc compatibility on you burners website and of course update your firmware. I quickly checked a few reviews before buying these and saw several people saying these discs were great, every one else is just stupid. Check out other popular sites reviews, people are ticked and recommend Verbatim. I really wished I listened to my instincts. Stay Away!

If you would like to use this with a ATI Radeon HD 5770 on a Mac Pro, you need ALL your mini display to DVI adapters to be ACTIVE i.e. this product. Don't do what I did and buy one, and think it doesn't work, when the third monitor doesn't activate. I ended up buying 2 duel-link mini-display port adapters soon after I discovered it didn't work properly (I was using one active display adapter, and one passive one along with the DVI), then tried my Accell with a duel-link adapter, and discovered it worked. I quickly bought a second adapter, and returned the duel link adapter since they're $99 a pop. I almost gave apple $200 for an inferior product, I ended spending a little over $60 for both adapters, that ended up doing the exact same thing. Just remember, for every mini display port you have, you need active adapter if you would like more then 2 displays. Excellent product! Great price!

I have been using this lens for five years, and have probably taken over 1000 photographs with it, film and full-frame digital, with sky filters, colored filters for black & white film, and polarizing filters as appropriate. As time has passed, I find that I use it less and less, because I can almost always get better results with something else.I have often found a kind of harsh contrast to the photographs I take with this lens. When using it, I have to be particularly diligent about lighting as a result. Zoom is convenient for composing but the camera is not optimal for controlling distracting backgrounds; this lens is certainly not appropriate for portraits.Only once did I get pictures with this lens that were much better than I expected, when handheld photos at maximum zoom on slow film in a dark temple came out perfectly. That's entirely a credit to the image stabilizer.Nowadays, I regard this as a snapshot lens; as such, it's often superseded by a point-and-shoot camera which takes pictures almost as well and is a lot easier to carry around.
summary: Useful but not a great or special lens

Nope, not the E-bunny. Still going is my Boomtube EX. I'm a little late on my review, but I felt these little guys deserved some additional vouching for. This review comes as a result of me searching for a replacement for them, something a bit more mobile--seems to be a lot out there now. After some research I decided to try the X-Mini Max II and while it was alright, it was defective out the package. I heard only one of its speakers, and it was pretty decent, but would not be able to touch the Boomtube Ex. The only thing it had on the Boomtube was its portability--1/3 the size. I guess the other thing it could have possibly had is battery life(playing time). Regardless, that unit was defective and is gone!The first and foremost thing to note is, this Boomtube is functioning like the day it did when I pulled it out the packaging nearly 6 years ago--besides that unworthy crappy 3.5mm cable it came bundled with. It still looks and sounds great like the other happy reviewers posted. Yes, even the battery life appears to be nearly the same averaging 4-6 hours depending on volume.Just yesterday I decided to take it all apart to clean and feed my curiosity. Although it's stamped with "Made in China", nothing about it's design and assembly suggested "value engineering". The more I got to disassembling the more apparent it became that a lot of thought went into its creation. The speakers were encased in a neat looking "basket" like that of cool looking sub-woofers. All of them had a rubber gasket between speaker and casing. They had some pretty large and heavily soldered terminals to them as well. Inside the base portion, behind the sub-woofer, lay the PCB. I didn't get to pulling that out, but what I could see on it were two little aluminum heat sunken boxes. My speculation was that they were the amplifiers for the satellite speakers and the subs, however, it may have simply been what >>I<< wanted those little heat sunken boxes to be(lol!). I live by the slogan "I void warranties" so I've taken apart tons of stuff before and I was truly impressed with the design, technology, and quality of material gone into this little system.Couple things it could use: 1) A protected power button so not to accidentally turn the unit on in transport and 2) stainless steel exterior screws to avoid rusting(lots of beach use here).In regards to the statement in parenthesis in #2, "lots of beach use here", that just suggests its capability to play in open air with waves pounding and people sitting around conversing. It plays pretty loud. I really noticed it when we were doing some irrigation at our church and I found myself turning down the unit as I was about 40yds away, farthest in the group, and I could hear it loud and clear and I remember thinking "it must be a little loud for them" as I watched those that were closer talk over the playing music.In conclusion, I'm extremely happy I picked these up. And I forgot to mention that I picked these up after buying, then returning, my Bose Companion speakers(was not impressed) Despite having always used them to some extent, I've since found a new appreciation--enjoying my Boomtue EX.

I read a lot of reviews and debated back and forth between this and the nexus 7 from google. The specs were very similar when i bought this. I went with the Kindle for three reasons - memory capacity, amazon prime videos, and ability to root to install Google apps. Now that the Nexus 7 comes with 16GB at the same price, it's the clear winner and wish I could go back and switch.The Fire runs Android, sorta. Amazon's skin is so customized you'd never know it was Android. The UI is slow and clunky and out of the box you only get Amazon's app store. I can get over those. It's also pretty buggy. The screen cailbration was always off and even most of the default apps just hung or crashed frequently. Downloading some sort of task killer is an absolute must. I rooted and installed the Google Play store. The root I did was not a full root but I got an instant perfromance boost. Apps still lag and crash pretty frequently, but less so now. One of my deciding factors was I thought I could get the best of both worlds. This is only sort of true. Many apps are just not compatible with the Fire even when you have the Play store installed. I was able to get flash working pretty well. Gmail, YouTube, and dolphin browser all work fine. Replacing the default keyboard is pretty challenging and requires an additional app. SwitftKey works ok but not perfect. I may try to get a full root and just completely replace the ROM if a stable one is available.The only advantage this tablet now has is the video store. Buying this tablet started my free trial with Prime. I thought Amazon would regularly update and add new selections, but free videos are very limited and mostly consists of tv shows. Now the video feature is an ok option and I use it, but it is not worth the trade off of having a fully functioning tablet.Speaking of which, the video app frequently crashes and can be very laggy. Once the video starts performance is fine, but navigating around the video store is painfully slow and where the crashes most frequently occur. The web interface on my computer for videos is a little slow and buggy in many of the same ways, but not as bad as on the fire.I try to keep a clean tablet with only the apps i use frequently. I keep the half the memory free at any time, The biggest downfall of the Kindle Fire is the enormous burden of bloatware. Even with an task killer, there are at least 10 apps that I never use that instantly re-open. The Fire only allocates about 350MB for working memory. The unkillable apps suck up about a third of that. A better task killer or additional tweaks could improve performance significantly. Even options like preventing the book, web, email and video apps from auto starting would help tremendously.as frustrating as it is, the Fire has a great HD screen and I still use it almost daily. Battery life is pretty good, but I am already starting to see a decreased capacity. 99% of the packaging was recyclable so that was a bonus. Mine didn't come with a wall plug which i thought was actually good. I could have even skipped the micro usb cord it did come with too. They come with every other device and phone already and would just sit in a drawer. Once you turn off the ads in the UI you only see them in the lock screen so giving Amazon an extra $15 or so to remove them entirely is totally unnecessary. With enough tweaks, it's a decent tablet, but the nexus 7 can do almost everything the Fire can do plus much much more. I cannot recommend the Fire HD unless you really cannot live without the prime video app. If that's the case, you'll still be disappointed in the performance of this feature.
summary: even rooted, very limited options for apps. regret not going with Nexus 7

reviewText: First, this unit needs to have Internet access to download printer drivers. Second, I could not print if the ink level was "low" on an HP Photosmart. I plan to use this print server when I travel so that I can print from an iPad or iPhone to whatever printer is available. I wanted to test the unit first. So I turned off the wireless connection on my HP Photosmart Premium C310 as a TEST to see if the unit worked. This disabled the built in support in the printer for AirPrint. I then connected the server to my printer over USB and to the Internet over ethernet. The unit recognized the printer and downloaded the C310 driver. I could not print from my iPad or Mac Pro. Finally, I logged on to the print server using a web browser. I checked the firmware and the logs. The logs kept saying the print jobs had been canceled.  I went to Printers --> List --> Gear Icon --> Set Printer Options --> xPrintServer --> Check Supply Levels --> OFF --> Save Changes. Now I can print! Who would of thunk the printer generated low ink level warnings were the culprit. You should be able to log on to a factory set XPrintServer Home from a web browser at:Address: xPrintServer.localID: adminPassword: PASS

As a small and inexpensive speaker, I wasn't sure if I would find this useful-- frankly, I am astounded. It is so simple to pair (the instructions re even printed clearly on the bottom of the speaker), and the range is excellent. Today I left my Iphone 5c in its cradle, brought the speaker to the other side of our house and set it on the kitchen table-- the music was clear and plenty of base. The controls are simple-- on off switch, two volume buttons, and a pairing/phone button (hold it to pair, tap it to answer your phone).  Today also I used the Oontz to hold a hands free conference call. The mic is clear (it is on the back of the speaker but it seems to pick up well with the speaker in either direction) and the audio quality for our end was "good". If I could have given 4.5 stars it would be because I found the use for conference call purposes to add too much bass, and I'd like a button or switch to lean more to the treble for clearer voice usage. But we got used to the tone quickly and everything was clearly understandable on the call. Unless you are looking for super-high quality (e.g. Bose) room-filling sound, I see no reason to pay five times the price of this unit. I highly recommend it.
summary: Great range, great sound, easy to pair, solid unit

reviewText: While this unit isn't as nice as the Sigma unit, it's 1/2 to 1/3 of the price, and for my occasional use has worked great with a D50, D90 and D5000 and Sigma and Nikon Macro lenses.  My D50 required some flash compensation, but not a big deal, I just dialed in 1 stop or so of flash comp.  This is not the sturdiest, most fully feature unit out there, but mine has held together OK. Of course I've tried to not be too reckless with it either.I've now tried it on a D300, and it worked OK, but when the camera times out and goes to "sleep", touching the shutter release doesn't wake the camera back up.  Powering the camera off and back on re-enables the meter and shutter release, so if this happens just power the D300 off and on and it should be ok until the camera times out again.

I've been eyeing this device purely for the parental controls for the last 2-3 years, but I finally laid down the cash to pick one up a couple of weeks ago when my daughter got an iPod Touch.  At that point I decided that the PC-based parental controls were no longer sufficient since I wouldn't be able to filter any new non-PC devices on the network with them.Anyway, I ordered the DSD-150 and expected to just plug it into the network and configure it.  I've read other users complain about the setup process, but I didn't think that would really apply to me because of my networking background.  I won't go into the trouble-shooting details; except to say that it took several hours a day over a 3 day period to finally get this device working.  I probably spent 5-6 hours on the phone with the bsecure support people and I have to admit that they have great tech support (no wait times and very knowledgeable people based in Florida).  It was due to their help that I was finally able to get this working.As far as the functionality goes, this device does exactly what they advertise.  I have it configured to use just the parental controls, parental reporting, and firewall - and I've been impressed with the parental control feature.  It has over 80 different categories that you can either allow or block, and there is a parental override password if you need to get to something that is blocked.  If someone tries to access blocked content, you can configure it to send you an e-mail or a text to let you know what was tried.  The great thing about a hardware filter is that I can lock it in my wiring closet and be sure that everything in the house is automatically filtered!It may seem like I'm rating the DSD-150 kind of high based on the install problems I had, but I'm basing that on the bsecure tech support as well as the functionality of the device once it was configured.  I would have given it 5 stars if it weren't for the setup issues.For people who are using AT&T; uVerse for their Internet, here is the solution to my problem: it turns out the DSD-150 would not connect when using a non-routable/local subnet DNS address.  I use the AT&T; uVerse service and it gives my router a routable IP address and gateway with the non-routable address of the uVerse box as a DNS server.  The solution was to configure the device with all static IP info, even though I get a dynamic address from my ISP (AT&T;) - now I'll have to update the DSD-150 configuration every time I get a new IP address (but thankfully that isn't very often according my dyndns logs).One more helpful tip that isn't documented for the DSD-150, is that the configuration IP address is [...].  The username is admin and the default password is blank (although both those can be changed).
summary: Works as advertised (after painful setup process)

reviewText: Age and injuries have increased the range of situations where I can't adequate stabilize a camera in the position that the picture demands, and myJoby GP1 Gorillapodhas been a major aid. I was looking for a second tripod in this category to cache away for when I hadn't pocketed the Gorillapod.I often wrap my Gorillapod around a railing, post, tree branch, ... This tripod is substantially inferior for these uses because the pivot joints (vs ball joints) do not allow the legs to be as closely contoured to such objects. Because there is less contact with the object, there is less friction to hold the tripod in place. In many situations it slipped easily.I also use my Gorillapod to get low-angle shots, and I can flatten it all the way to the ground, boulder, whatever. This tripod has roughly a 3-inch gap between the top of the legs and the ground.The picture of this tripod shows flat feet vs the Gorillapod's ball feet, and I thought this would be an advantage on flat surfaces. However, the joint on the foot does not have enough adjustment range when the legs are spread a normal degree. And the bottom pivot turns not toward the center of the tripod, but tangentially. Thus, you must use the second pivot point to get the feet flat. Not a significant functional difference, but it is jarring to me (an engineer).With the Gorillapod, the quick release attachment on the camera is 1/8-inch thick flat plate, which I find to be barely noticeable. The corresponding attachment here is 3/8-inch tall cylinder with a bottom disk that seems to always be snagging things. Additionally, the quick release feature is not documented. That rod that looks like a handle that you use on a full-sized tripod to position the camera is instead something you pull to release the attachment. If you attempt to use it to move the camera through the ball head range, you are likely to break it.I did find this tripod's ball head a decided advantage over the head on the Gorillapod in situations where I had wrapped the legs of the tripod around another object. However, the better holding abilities of the Gorillapod would seem to more than offset this in most of these situations.This tripod is a bit larger than the corresponding Gorillapod in length, diameter and weight, and I initially didn't think it would matter. However, the small difference in diameter became a big advantage for the Gorillapod in taking it in and out of my pant pockets.-- Douglas B. Moran
summary: Substantially inferior to the Joby Gorillapod

reviewText: Folks, I'm far from an audiophile.  In fact, I have fairly low standards, but these Panasonic ear buds sound like I'm listening to a kazoo through a tin can. There is no bass.  Midrange is thin and the highs are about all that they have.  They advertise a frequency response of 20Hz-20,000Hz.  I think they are closer to 10,000-12,000Hz.  They are simply flat with no bass.  And that was the good part of my review.  What's with the weird earpiece shape?  The ear bushing (appendage) is off center from the actual ear bud, plus regardless of which rubber earpiece I use, it feels like I'm stuffing a PVC pipe in my ear.  If you try and push it in deeper, the stupid offset of the bud prevents it.  If you just causally plug them in, they fall out when you breathe. If these were in a $.99 box of crackerjacks you'd be better off stuffing the cracker jacks in your ears and giving these to your 6 year old to hang his hamster with.  They're that bad.

It is always a good idea to protect the screen of your Kindle Fire HD - but doing so without wrinkling the screen protector during application is a challenge.  The "Moshi iVisor XT (HD clear) No Bubble Screen Protector for Kindle Fire HD 7" solves that issue quite nicely.  Constructed of a semi-rigid plastic material, this screen protector need simply be laid on the clean screen and then pressed around the borders to make it adhere.  Even users like myself who always manage a wrinkle or two when applying clear plastic protective items will be able to get a smooth, wrinkle-free surface.The harder surface of the "Moshi iVisor XT" is excellent for preventing scratching of your Kindle Fire HD.  The clarity of your screen is not significantly affected by your application of the "Moshi iVisor XT".  If you, like me, use your Kindle Fire HD for reading because of the excellent contrast between the background and text, this attribute is a real plus.  Distortion was not an issue for me, and I noticed no rainbow effect.If you are thinking of purchasing a screen protector for your Kindle Fire HD, I highly recommend the "Moshi iVisor XT".  It may cost a bit more than other screen protectors, but your Kindle Fire HD is worth it!

I bought the OEM version 80G Intel SSD. The support from Intel's website is excellent. There is a utility for optimizing the system for SSD performance - tweaks that Intel offers. It changes some settings in Win7 automatically for best performance. The Intel disk cloning utility available on the website for free download is very helpful. I used it to clone my old hard drive over to the SSD and was able to switch over without a hitch - much easier than I expected. It can even let you do a clone to a smaller sized drive, something Norton Ghost did not let me do.The drive performance is faster, most obvious on start up which is now 25 seconds from boot compared to more than 1.5 minutes previously. MS Word and Excel launches instantly. Unfortunately with an 80G drive, you have to manage your space carefully, I elected to put my games on a different hard drive as it would fill the SSD pretty quickly. If you can, I would suggest going with the 120G option or bigger if you can afford it. This Intel drive is not as quick (read/write speed) as the newer SATA III SSD drives. However for the price range I was looking at, this was the best option.The rail adapter is not really needed, I used tape to secure the drive. The SSD is silent, has no moving parts and does not heat up. You could have this drive running without securing it with screws since there is no vibration to worry about. A recommended upgrade for anyone, even regular users because it speeds up the performance of windows and regular tasks across the board. No problems whatsoever with reliability for the month or so I've been using it.

reviewText: I bought this keyboard at the local wal-mart to assist typing after I bought a laptop stand.  I've read some reviews about these keys being "low, like a laptop's," but I don't think that's true.  The laptop I have has keys half as low as this one.  When I first bought it, I thought it was odd that I had to push down so far-- which hindered my typing at first (and still does, even though I've had it and used it almost exclusively for a few months).As for the noise, this is one of the noisiest keyboards I've ever had!  I normally find the sound of typing keys to be relaxing, but trying to type quietly is next to impossible.  It may be a defect of mine alone, but the space bar sounds like it's not resting on the actual button mechanism, so you get a click when it hits the button and another when you push that down to the sensor, as well as a click coming back up and then a vibration of the plastic key when you let it go.I think it's a solid product that does the job it was meant to (I haven't tried spilling anything on it, though) and it's at a good price, but there aren't any frills.  Since buying this, I've decided that I much more prefer "chicklet" keyboards and I've gone in search of another replacement.  I also dislike the font they used on this keyboard, though I may just be used to the narrow lettering of my laptop.

Found a great book on getting started with mac osMountain Lion Macs (Computer Training)

To be truly honest, I was a bit on the fence about buying these headphones. I had bad experiences with quality from Skullcandy's in-ear headphones (even the more expensive ones). I decided to give them a try because I really like the style and the color, plus the many reviews that appeared in several places. Now, I do own several brands like Bose, Beats, Sony and Seinnheiser, in many styles (in-ear, over-ear, etc.), and I consider myself a picky music listener. These are some impressions on these Aviators so far:LOOKS: 9 -At first, it took a moment to get used to the style but, after many compliments, I wear them now with pride.COMFORT: 8 -While they feel very soft and snug, after a couple of hours my ears start to feel hot and, since I wear glasses, they start to dig in because of the preassure (usually I do not wear headsets for that long). They are not heavy at all.CONSTRUCTION: 7 -The Aviators look sturdy enough (stainless steel over heavy leather headband). However, the finish on the earcups and the golden finish of the head support make me nervous. They look very prone to scratching. The support wiring for the headband feels like it would not take much bending. Only time (and care) will tell. The Mic3 cord is made of a nylon material and seems strong enough. My problem is that the cord itself creates audible feedback when rubbed againts something like your jacket. It's very annoying. The Mic3 seems made of cheap plastic, but the controls feel responsive.PORTABILITY: 7 -These headsets come with a very nice, good quality carrying bag. The Aviators fit very snug, although it can be difficult to put them in and take them out. Unfortunately, it is kind of a big fit to stash in a backpack or carrying them around, and if you do not use the pouch, they can easily get scratched.SOUND QUALITY: 10  -This is by far the most important aspect for me. I did break in the 40mm drivers for 40+ hours. I must say that the sound reproduction is excellent. The highs, mids and lows show up very clear. These headsets made me want to listen to my library again. From classical to pop, hip-pop, R&B;, rock and electronic music, the instruments, vocals, drums, bass, etc., were very distinctive. The bass may be lacking for people who love it, but for me, it was strong enough without being overbearing and the highs did not "bleed" over the the lows and mids.PRICE: 9 -Overall, I recommend these. With a $125-$150 price tag, it is a very good option to more expesive headphones.

One of my major gripes with computer cameras is their tendency to act like a fish eye lens or keystone and make my face look...well...let's just say...Bad. No one wants their first online impression to appear as it if it was transmitted using alien technology. Enough said. As noted, image transmission is good with no noticeable lags on video, though your computers speed and memory can affect these things. The software it comes with is very user friendly. You have complete control over color saturation, lighting, brightness and zoom and the auto lighting compensation works well. Please note that the zoom adjustment is located in the settings menu...a place most people don't think to look for something you will likely use every time you open the camera.I wasn't quite as impressed with most of the video effects. They offer distortions you will never use or look pretty bad and they only work on the 640 x 480 resolution. I haven't checked the available downloads yet so some of the those might be more interesting. My favorite is one that outlines everything in neon against a black background. Cool.This camera with the free Vid software can be used to talk to friends who download the software. I haven't used that feature because I don't know anyone who has it, but at $49 it is cheap enough to send to mom or anyone else you feel the need to see and hear from on a regular basis. I haven't tried the camera with many programs, but a freebie video/screen capture program called Debut, worked very well and showed up as a tab on the Logitech image window. Good buy with fun software.
summary: Great Little Camera for the Price

reviewerName: Nathan Andersen "Gadget lover and author of S...
reviewText: On first glance, this looks like a less expensive version of one of the Gorillapod tripods.  I've had one for a while that I'm quite happy with, but what appealed to me about this is it looked like it might allow for a bit of easy panning and tilting while shooting video in addition to working as a convenient small tripod.The problem is this just isn't all that flexible.  The Gorillapod tripods have ball joints.  This one has simple pivot joints that only flex in one direction.  The way they've tried to make it more flexible is to make each joint rotated at a 90 degree angle from the previous joint.  The problem is that doesn't give the same kind of control.  This works fine as a basic tripod on a flat surface, but it's hard and sometimes impossible to adjust the legs so this grips and mounts securely in funky places like a tree branch.  As far as panning or tilting goes, there's a little "handle" out to the side of the mounting platform, but when you loosen the platform with the tightening screw it still moves a bit jerky.This is obviously a copy of the Gorillapod and if you're going to knock off a successful product you need to cut the price and make it work at least as well.  This one doesn't.  It just feels cheap.  Not recommended.
summary: Go with the original Gorillapod instead - this one's just not as flexible or as handy

First of all, I have to subtract one star right off the top for this item not being completely functional out of the box, and I know that mine is not the only unit in a small volume of those shipped that was bad. Not a good sign. While it did work, the volume/power knob did not switch the unit on or off and did not alter the volume. It does light up with its nice yellow glow, however. It would be a solid three stars if not for that.It connected easily to the Windows XP computer I tested it on, and played right away with no need to tweak any computer settings (except volume). The sound quality is not bad for such small speakers, and for most people it would probably be adequate. It is definitely a step up from the "standard" speakers that come with most new computers. It was very crisp and clear in the mid and high ranges, but a little weak in the bass range,  which is understandable for small speakers. It takes a certain sized cone to move enough air for adequate bass response, and that doesn't happen until you get to 5 or 6 inch speakers, in my opinion, unless exotic cabinet designs are used.It was nice that they included a USB extension cable as the main cable is quite short. I did not try the USB hub for speed or function, as my time on the test machine was limited. The USB ports are pretty close together, which means you would most likely need more extension cables.The instructions are on a foldout page with multiple languages in each section. The directions were minimal but adequate, and I would have liked more detail about the construction and function of the unit. (Like the vendor was actually proud of it.) The power cord is about 5 feet long or so, and connects easily on both ends. The construction was pretty good for something like this, and felt very solid. It is stylish and will appeal to those for whom looks are important.While the sound was okay for computer speakers (I run my computer audio through a full 120 watt stereo system with 8 inch three way speakers, and have used 12 inch three way systems as well, so I am used to very good sound), I am not sure about the viability of this design. It is useful as a desktop speaker setup, but I wouldn't consider it very travel friendly, as it is not small. (A little bit smaller than three 18 inch aluminum foil boxes stacked together, two on the bottom with one on top.) However, it is one unit with only two wires, and that will appeal to some who get tired of the rat's nest of wires needed for separate speakers. Then again, one won't have the flexibility of placement that one would get with separate speakers. That trade-off is a personal decision.I also have serious questions about the functionality of using a computer to stand in for a much cheaper CD/mp3 player. While there are certainly computer audio uses (it might be great if you view video/movie files on your computer), I think that its actual usefulness is rather narrow. Headphones give greater privacy and portability, and a larger sound system would be more desirable for a fixed location.Also, it only takes audio over USB from your computer, so you can't use it for any devices other than a computer (for now at least). I would rate it higher if there were analog inputs for a CD or mp3 player. I also question the wisdom of using USB bus bandwidth for something that could easily be handled by the audio card and its dedicated ports (which is on and drawing power anyway). The idea that it is "digital sound" is pure marketing hype, as the sound will get converted from digital to analog one way or another before it goes to the speakers - either in your audio card or in this device's amp. These speakers have no advantage there.There are other devices out there that would do the audio portion of what this speaker does, as well or better. My preference would be a separate USB hub and a more versatile audio amp and speakers. For travel purposes, it is definitely too large and requires AC power (it is not powered by the USB line). I think this is more of a gimmick than a really useful item, but I'm sure there are those for whom it will work really well.I would advise really thinking about your audio needs carefully and researching well before you decide on this unit. I'm also not sure how reliable it will be given it was defective out of the box, and was not a returned item - it had all the original plastic protectors in place.
summary: arrived broken - would require a replacement

I found that speedlights works much better and does not strain subject's eyes. This light does however work well to highlight areas in the scene or fill backgrounds.The mounting location (not adapter) is very flimsy and broke within 2 weeks of light use. I tried to epoxy/glue the mounting nut back into place, however it did not work. I ended up opening the light and remounting the attachment bolt inside the unit.I do no recommend using this on top of your camera as it makes the camera very tall and top heavy. Even on my 5D, I found it very difficult to move around with this unit, especially since the mount was wiggly. Once I had fixed the mounting issue, I mounted it to a hotshoe base stand (typically found with speedlights).The unit comes with three softening filters. The led's naturally gives off a harsh white hue, even with the color modifying filters, the light still seems very white, not flattering on subjects.Overall, due to the quality and the lack of usage for portait photography, I'm rating this 3 stars.

I've been a Bose addict for decades. My two Bose CD/Radio players are still rockin' it out and the batteries (15 years old!)in the remote controls are the original ones. Now THAT'S quality.Including the above, I also own the original Bose Soundlink ($300) and Bose Soundlink Mini ($200), both of which I paid for directly from Bose. In addition, I also have 6 other Bluetooth speakers, through Vine.Which brings me back to THIS Bose speaker. I waffled between 3 or 4 stars for days, and finally decided that the Bose reputation demanded the four stars. Now, WHY 4 stars? It just seems that Bose is falling behind other companies, and resting too heavily on it's laurels rather then trying to upgrade their products. For $300.00, which places this speaker in the upper range of most people's budgets, I feel that the less expensive but superior Bose Soundlink Mini delivers more "Bang For Your Buck", and saves you an extra $100.00, to boot!TheBose SoundLink Mini Bluetooth Speaker, is far smaller, lighter (1.5 pounds vs. 3 pounds for this speaker) and to my ears, a crisper/lighter sound. I've tried adjusting the bass through my app equalizer but the bass is just overwhelming to my ears. The Mini is also a wonderful speaker to travel with because of the much smaller size and weight. My original Soundlink was bought for traveling, but the weight proved to my sore shoulders that it needed to stay home, on the desk!Since three years ago, I've bought and tried over 6 other brands of Bluetooth speakers: Some, for home enjoyment and some, for working at an outdoor job site. I finally settled upon theiLuv MobiAria NFC-Enabled Bluetooth Speaker with USB Charging Portfor my Home-use only speaker and theSimple Audio Go Compact Rechargeable Bluetooth Speaker (90B0001-US)for using outdoors. My Soundlink Mini stays INDOORS, in hotels and spas with me.So, now down to the nitty-gritty of "WHY?" did I give this speaker, four vs. five stars, which is still a high rating, in my book.Well, as a consumer, YOU must decide first and foremost: Will THIS Bose speaker or ANY Bluetooth speaker be the ONE & ONLY speaker that you own? Will THIS speaker be the one that greets you with music when you first wake up? Then, it transitions to a day at the beach or work site? Will you take only THIS speaker with you on holiday? If the answer is "Yes!" to all of these questions, than you'll probably love this 3rd generation of Bose Soundlink.But, if you decide that for the sum of $300.00, you'd like a speaker that sounds FANTASTIC in your home but a smaller, lighter, less expensive speaker for playing outside and traveling, then I don't recommend this speaker for your needs.This is why:1) Most of my newer Bluetooth speakers have "Voice Guidance" which I've come to really appreciate. They will state in male or female voices, "Discovering device", "Device connected", and/or "Good Bye" or "Device removed" when the Bluetooth connection is shut off.  I own $50 speakers and $300 speakers that have Voice Prompt; none of my Bose speakers have that feature.2)Touch screen panels. LOVE them! The iLuv MobiAria NFC-Enabled Bluetooth Speaker with USB Charging Port ($111.00) has a gorgeous, smooth, glass-like control panel that is completely touch controlled; no buttons to press/depress/or more importantly, have dust and pet fur get trapped between the controls. The Bose speaker has buttons that are covered, so cleaning is easier, but you still have that less than fun function to deal with of touch vs. depressing the buttons.A nice touch on the iLuv is an actual USB charging port in back, so you can keep your device plugged in and always ready to use without a drained battery.3) Less Bass, More Treble! I don't know if it's because of age or what, but I just can't handle bass-heavy speakers any longer; it's just either painful or I can't literally hear the music any longer. Same goes for my husband. No matter what equalizer app we use on our tablet/smartphone, we just can't eliminate the bass heavy Bose sound in this speaker. In my other speakers, including the Bose Mini, there's better balance and far less bass.4) Then there's the theft factor and your safety. With over 40% of the nation's thefts related to cell phones, in good conscience, I would NEVER bring such a LARGE TARGET as this speaker to an outdoor space to enjoy listening to music outside. Sure, in the safety of my back yard, on the deck, or at a friend's place, I'd feel safe. But a large, $300.00 speaker just BEGS a thief to "invite" themselves to your event. There are far less expensive great speakers designed expressly to be used outdoors that I would strongly suggest buying and using in public areas.So, this is what it boils down to: $300 (Soundlink III) vs. $200.00 (Soundlink Mini) vs. $111 (iLuv-NOT portable) vs. $81.00 (Simple Go Audio)....where do YOU want to spend your money? For the cost of THIS speaker, I can buy the Mini and either the iLuv or Simple Go, ending up with a kick arse home speaker and a kick arse traveling speaker for almost the same price.  Only your wallet and your ears can make that decision. If there's one thing I've learned in life it's this: You'll NEVER convince someone that YOUR coffee brand or speaker choice is the right one!  Some like it Dark Roast, some like it Light. Some like it Bass Heavy, some like it Light.So, I'm giving this speaker a 4 Star ranking for the name "Bose", the quality of the product but deducting a star for the excessive bass and my opinion that THIS Bose speaker just doesn't seem as "up to date" as other speakers I own, including their very own other product, the Soundlink Mini.

These are comfortable, not the most bassy (in fact, the sound could be described as a little tinny, perhaps) and they work reasonably well as noise cancelling headphones - especially considering the price.  Sound quality-wise a pair of Phillips noise cancelling headphones had richer tones both in bass and treble than these (and cancelled noise somewhat better - but that set got the cord caught in my elliptical and quit working) - but there are ways to mess with equalization/volume combinations to make me happy with these and I'm OK with these considering the price.  Replacing the Phillips was going to cost a lot more - so I went with these, based on reviews.The headphones are large and fit well over my glasses (this can cause some real discomfort for me with some models) - but I've had good luck so far with these.  The cord on these is long.I primarily use mine on a somewhat noisy elliptical or (sometimes) to drown out noise of a too loud TV in the household and use these with an ipod or as I watch videos during exercise.  If you're EXTREMELY discerning about audio you might want to try some others (and prepare to pay at least somewhat more).  However, as I said there are ways to mess with equalization/volume combinations to get a pretty reasonable quality of sound.  They work alright and are a good option vs. the headphones that go in the ear (which can also be noise cancelling but sometimes cause a "stethoscope" sound effect, which varies depending on the brand).
summary: Comfortable, not the most bassy, they work

reviewText: Snug fitting both ends with cord strain relief. No signal loss and connected items operate correctly. Amazon cord length options great.

My Dell Laptop Studio XPS 1640 says there is a "malfunction" with the charge cord so it will not charge the battery at all. It will only work when plugged into a wall. I am very happy with this product. It is large enough to fit my Galaxy Note 8 with the moko slim case on it. The neoprene sleeve is thicker than I imagined it would be so I am confident it will protect my tablet. The pouch on the front will stretch to accommodate pretty much any charger. I've used this keyboard (and sometimes the mouse, more on that later) at home and then at work for about 2 years combined.  I have a lot of time spent with it and like to review things if I can after serious use, not 2 days when I'm still in the honeymoon phase.I'll start with the keyboard - This is why I initially and only wanted this set to begin with.  I can type pretty well but the regular office keyboards will cause me to get carpal issues before I'm 40 if I keep using them.  I also cannot stand the split in half ergonomic keyboards either.  I was happy when I started to see this style released (MS has some now too that are pretty cheap and so so as do others).  The keys are spaced well, the layout works just as well as a regular keyboard that I learned to type on.  It has helped with my wrists and hands not hurting greatly.  I haven't had an issues using the keyboard.  The one complaint I'll say about it is the fact the calculator is right next to the power key.  I love the calc key (used it on other keyboards) and I've never had a keyboard with a power key until this one.  I've only done it twice, but I've accidently pushed power off instead of the calc key.  Put a power key by itself - not next to a frequently used key.Next up is the mouse - I wanted to like it and use it, but two major things kept me from using it often.  The first and most annoying is with batteries in this sucker, it's heavy.  I'm a big guy and all that, but I don't want to be pushing a rock around on my desk daily.  At work I go between 2 screens and large stuff, so flinging this mouse is a challenge.  The second thing are the buttons on the side.  Once again, I'm a big guy and this trend of smaller buttons frustrates me to no end.  I hated using them and I find if I don't have good side buttons on a mouse, I don't use it.  So, I've tried using the mouse here and there when I had to move and set-up my stuff again, but within a few weeks I put it away.  It also just isn't the best sensor or anything else.  Overall it's a so-so bare bones mouse that works, but you can do much better.Final impressions are generally positive.  The keyboard is the shining light of this set, the mouse is bare useable to me.  Other things are the receiver works well and everything connects without issues.  The battery life is stellar for both the board and mouse.  I don't know if I'd believe 3 years for the board, as over 2 years I've had to replace them once, but that's really good to me anyway.  So if you want an ergo keyboard that isn't split, this is the one to get.
it was already formatted and ready to go.  just plug it in and start recording - nothing more to say for a storage device - just want it to work with no hassles.

Great product...I love the color of it and it is very durable.  There were no holes in mine.  The only issue I have is that it wrinkles easily and also is very difficult to iron.  I think I'm going to get some PVC pip and stretch it over that.  I'm glad I bought this and would definitely buy it again.

reviewText: This streaming box is dope, fulfills all my hopes and dreams. I own a Roku 2 as well and this is noticeably faster and gets better reception. Get one!

reviewText: This is another micro-SD card for which the product image shows a Class 4 card, but the description states that it is actually a slower class 2 card.  (This seems to be a bit of an endemic problem among SD and micro-SD cards.)This isn't NECESSARILY a problem, if class 2 is fast enough for your needs.  There is no part number provided, so one would have to contact the actual seller to confirm whether this really is a class 2 or a class 4 card.  But if it's a class 2 card, you can buy SanDisk 32GB Class 2 cards from other sellers more than 25% cheaper than this one.  If you really need Class 4, search right here for part number SDSDQM-032G, which really IS a Class 4 card, and is sold by a number of Amazon vendors (oddly, including this vendor, Everything But Stromboli) for a lower price than Everything But Stromboli wants for this card.Bottom line:  There is no valid reason to buy this specific card, when you can get higher-speed cards of the same brand and capacity for less money even from the same Amazon seller.  Play safe:  ALWAYS check the actual part number, and if the seller doesn't provide a part number, pick a different item or a different seller that does.  Be sure what you're buying.
summary: Product image does not match item specifications in description.

reviewText: I often have a need for a boom during studio work. This mini boom is well designed, solid and of high quality. Although it does not extend as far as a regular boom it offers enough length for most purposes. Because it is shorter than a normal boom it is easier to transport. Highly recommended.

This sounds like it would be a great tool to use for the car. I could not get it to pair with my phone. In the packaging it suggests going to the website to find the configuration there. No such luck. The website got hung up. I tried a different browser and a different computer. Same problem. I had hoped to be able to give this a better review. There is a phone number I could call to get what I'm looking for but more than likely it will lead me to some call center in some third world country with a person who barely speaks English, so not worth it to me to call.

With shipping this thing costs nearly $8.00 for a tiny, little rubber cone and the bottom line is, when you shove it into your ear - it hurts! Attached to a Jawbone Era, the headset does not touch your cheek and so the noise reduction doesn't function. If you twist it enough in your ear, it will touch your cheek but the fit isn't comfortable. It is an awful lot of money for something made in China that costs about $.05 to make. Rather than sell one tiny piece of "gel-like material" on a card, maybe they should splurge and put three on the card for the $6.00 + shipping that they charge. To put it in context, Jabra sells you 6 eargels for almost the same amount and they fit better and don't cause pain after 5 - 10 minutes in your ear.

I use this product on my turbocharged subaru and it works quite amazingly as both a device to help you know what your gas mileage is.. but also as various gauges. I actually am using it as my boost gauge and it works very well in that aspect.This device always works as needed and I give it 5 stars because of that.

I am not a great photographer. I have zero training. I have never taken great pictures or really enjoyed taking them.So I loved this camera. Suddenly, I can take decent pictures. Ansel Adam's legacy is still safe but I can take pictures that are beautiful to me. That has been so fun. I have a ranch in the Rocky Mountains. We have some amazing wildlife around but they are always too far away and moving too fast to take good pictures. But with this camera I have gotten some amazing shots of elk and wolves that were so far away I could barely see them. The camera takes care of the distance and movement easily and quickly enough to catch the really great moments.I have actually taken the camera off "auto" and tried some different settings. I have been able to work with them and get some fun shots. I have looked a couple things up but mostly it is really easy to figure out how to use this camera.The camera is heavier than I expected. All of the components work smoothly and feel sturdy. To remove the battery cover you have to slide a button down while pushing the battery cover to the side. It is a little awkward. The battery lasts for the weekend.I could not be happier with this camera. I would recommend it to anyone.

Is the EOS 20D all it's cracked up to be? After using it a couple of days I have to say yes. What makes it so amazing?My top reason, LOW NOISE even at ISO 1600. At ISO 3200 it will create a photo that is ok if you run it through Neat Image. (a free noise reduction program)Here are some of the other reasons I love it. Excellent quality images. Virtually NO shutter lag, instantly starts up from standby, shoots 5 frames per second. I was able to shoot 32 continuous frames set at 8mp fine using a 1GB Lexar 80X CF card. It has simple to use menus. Very fast to focus (I used a Sigma 24-135mm lens.) The built in flash is good. It has a solid feel; it's light but not too light. Battery life is great; you can set it to go to standby after 1 min because it starts instantly when you press the shutter release.I have tried to find something I can complain about but I can't. This camera is great!!!! At the price it is in a class by it's self. This is minor but the camera raw software is so so. I'm sure Adobe will update their camera raw plug-in for Photoshop before too long.
summary: CANON EOS 20D Amazing?  YES IT IS !

reviewText: This is exactly what I needed for my old 80GB PS3. I had no room left on my system...now I have tons of room! The product arrived quickly, worked perfectly, and installation was a breeze. The whole thing took maybe 30 minutes and I can download whatever I want now. A must buy for the price.

The first thing I want to say is Amazon is great for its prompt shipping and return policy.  Now as far as this router is concerned it is worthless.  I tried for 3 full days to set a pair of these routers up as an AP and as a REPEATER with no success.  I followed the simple instructions and was able to set up the AP router or so I thought.  None of the laptops or desktops could connect to it even though they could see it with 5 bars.  The repeater was the real nightmare with following the "easy instructions" it would never connect to the other router and then when we tried to reset it and start over it would not reset.  Held the button in for a minute and all it did was flash the power indicator.  We let it do that for 15 minutes thinking it was going to stop, but it never did.  I have sent these items back to Amazon for a full refund and will continue my search for a good ap and repeater.  I will put back the old Apple G routers that were easy to set up taking only about 5 minutes.  Might have to with modified Apple routers to connect to the out side antenna.  DO NOT BUY THIS ROUTER SAVE YOUR SELF THE EXPENSE OF A BOTTLE OF ASPRAN AND WASTED TIME.
summary: JUNK!  Wish I could give negative feed back

reviewText: i purchased this drive for work. it is a bit slow when transferring files but i can live with that. when i want to eject the drive, it always has the message that it is not ready to be ejected yet so i will give it about 5 minutes and still the same message. i just have to remove it nevertheless. if i plug it into my work computer and then use it on my laptop, it won't ask for the password until i eject and plug it in again. When i get to work it will do the same thing. it could just be the way the drive is formatted for using a password but it is still annoying. Since it is one of the lower priced password protected usb drives, it will work for me.

It takes up too much tray space.  This little number is just right.  I always hated the external batteries with other models. Super simple and effective device that provides great macro functionality with any lens. I am new to photography and don't have the budget to spend on loads of lenses at the moment and this provides a more than acceptable way of capturing the details of life. I'm using with a NEX-7 and a Pentax 28mm/f2.8 lens (with Fotodiox adapter) with a 52mm ring. Since it is legacy glass, it is only manual focus so I can't speak for using this with an autofocus lens, but the macro experience with manual focus is downright delightful. Build quality is top notch, covers for both sides of the glass, and a plastic case with foam.Absolutely recommended.

They each have a cell phone and iPad so they should be good to go.  They won't have to worry about finding an outlet.

worst customer service and defective products

reviewText: First, can't say enough about the tech who helped me. Spent an hour, patiently, with me on the phone. My situation was unique (one of my two printers was old and required some custom settings and testing to connect), plus iOS7 firmware issues (which the vendor does publicize as a required post-purchase user update, but is easy), but newer printer did work quickly after firmware upgrade. I made the error of trying to hookup the two printers with a USB hub, not realizing i could simply use the existing network connections through the xprintserver. Both printers were already set up as network printers.Once i figured out the ip address of the old printer and experimented with a few drivers, it's working like a charm.Although not a star-deducting reason. Be aware that for iOS usage, you can't select options such as which pages to print, etc. for me not an issue, since i view this as a convenience to print off my iPad for info gathering, not production printing i'd do from my iMac where the various print options are important.Very happy with it for what it does (simple, basic iOS printing) and certainly better than buying a new air print capable printer that I didn't need, plus by using existing printers, i can get occasional color off my HP printer, and inexpensive laser b/w off my aging, but faithful, Samsung. If you have new printers, this device may truly be plug-n-play, but with older printers you made need to call their excellent tech support to walk you through a custom set up.
summary: Not necessarily for newbies, but works; needed tech support to set up

Well, I waited a long while to make the foray into dvd recording and missed years of using a vcr because I was tired of those tapes that were the size of a house. So I finally bought this thing at Best Buy for a pretty good price and I am satisfied.For all those out there who are going-What the heck is all this DVD+-_!@#$%^&**()":<>? R's? I hate that crap too. But all you need to do is buy DVD + R's from any store and they should work- JUST REMEMBER, THIS ONLY RECORDS ON DVD+R'S AND DVD+RW'S-ITS REALLY SIMPLE AND IT ALWAYS SAYS IT IN BIG EASY TO READ LETTERS ON THE BOX/CASE/WHATEVER...I read the earlier review and I havent had any problems like that yet. Although once it did freeze once and I had to unplug it once to get it to reset or whatever. If you understand that its kind of like a computer and freezes like one than its no big deal. I have only bought 1 set of DVD+R's by memorex and they have worked flawlessly. And yes you can record anything that a vcr can also. And if you still have your vcr and those Gigantic VCR tapes and you want to transfer to digital for good, you can do that with ease (If you need help dont hesitate to ask).It is a good looking gadget with pretty user friendly controls (except for that Phil guy! What the h@#$!)I record all my disposable shows (Seinfeld,JJudy,60 minutes) on my one supplied DVD+RW and I record and erase-just like a tape. And it says that you need to finalize your DVD+R's to play them on most dvd players(You cannot finalize DVD+RW's) but I tried to play the unfinalized DVD+RW in my cheap AMD DVD player and it played! I record on the lowest quality which is adequate for me and I get 8 hours of recording on one disc. This thing has 6 recording settings so you can adjust the quality accordingly-M1 for highest quality(1 Hour) and M8 (8 Hours) So far so good, and for the price you cant beat this deal if you are making the jump into digital recording. DONT BE AFRAID!_______________________________________________________STILL GOING STRONG!This is a 2nd review...Well, I have had this thing for about 5 months now, and I am pleased. I still cant for the life of me believe all that has been happening to the other reviewers, but perhaps a portion of these DVD recorders were just lemons. I have never had a disc warning problem, I have had to reset it once, and most of the other various problems have never happened either.If it is discontinued, I guess this review is moot, but I want to defend the reputation of this machine.Anyways, I have recorded hundreds of shows on Imation DVD+R's, and the one supplied Memorex DVD+RW-which recently stopped playing and recording altogether...but after I recorded dozens of favorites. If you do still find them new, you cant beat the price-I highly recommend it! You have to remember, you cannot expect perfection frow the lowest tier DVD recorders! But at this point it is close and I am still pleased.

Recognized by my Thinkpad T61 without issue, this drive appears to be as fast or faster than the 7200 RPM Hitachi it replaced. It is much quieter and uses much less power. I plan to add a second one to my ultrabay for a total of 2TB storage on my laptop!

Just disconnect one before firing up the other.This is a great inexpensive solution to marrying vintage equipment to the new sources of sound.

reviewText: I have both the Mohu Leaf (unamplified) and Mohu Leaf Ultimate (amplified) antennas, and both work very well. In my situation, in an urban location about 10-15 miles from towers, both antennas draw in 29 stations. The Ultimate does a little better for a couple of channels (both off the same tower) that sometimes pixelate, but not 100%. I would highly recommend either antenna, the HD picture is fantastic. The regular Mohu Leaf, which is less expensive, may be all you need.
summary: Excellent product, regular Mohu Leaf works about as well

reviewText: I had been using Trasncend Class 10 SDHC cards in both my Nikon D5100 and my Canon Vixia camcorder until recently a relatively new card failed on me and I had to get a fast replacement. I saw these and decided to give them a try. I had never used UHS-1 cards before.I was blown away by the speed of the Samsung Pro UHS-1 64GB in my Nikon D5100 compared to a Transcend Class 10 SDHC. The transcend had very long wait time between shots, while the Samsung was very little delay - almost what you'd expect from a film camera. I am sold on the Samsung cards and plan to replace all my Transcend cards with the Samsung UHS-1 cards.I also used 2 of these puppies in my Canon Vixia HF R20 camcorder and was able to get over 5hr of flawless recording with 2 cards and that was at max quality. Again, I plan to replace all my other cards I use for the Vixia with these Samsung cards. I never really had a problem using the Transcend cards in my camcorder, but after the failure of the one and finding these Samsung cards, I don't plan to use the Transcend cards again for these 2 important devices. I think I may just throw those out.I've since started using the 32GB Samsung UHS-1 cards in my point-and-shoot camera and have been happy with that as well.Overall, I am very happy with these cards.
summary: awesome in vixia hf r20 & nikon d5100

reviewText: Pros: The "Only" Pro I can see in the gps was when the mailman drove away with it, to Return to Sender.Cons: If you have never heard the phrase "When Possible Make A Legal U-Turn" then you should get this gps, the possibilities are endless.This thing attempted to direct me miles out of the way to go 4 miles.I don't know if it is the gps sensor or the software map since I don't do electrical engineering, but certainly not what I needed to get me aroundthe town, or anywhere else for that matter

No wires to get in the way, and I can play whatever I want on my phone, Not to mention, it comes with a mic that I hooked up in my car, so If i do get a call I can answer with the headunit and talk hands free..
