reviewText: The Archos Gmini 400 is great. I enjoy digital photography,and the CF card slot is great for digital photographers. It does everything the IPOD does and MORE. I mainly use it for music and photography. I recently used it on a camping trip, perfect for storing CF cards when there is no computer around. It transfered a 512mb in about 3-4 min... maybe faster. Then I hooked it up to a TV with the INCLUDED cables and was able to show a slideshow to my family.It is surprisingly small. The only downside is that it is not popular in the mainstream, so there are not as many custom accessories for it, especially compared to the IPOD.It is the perfect MP3 player for a digital photographer.

We're able to watch local stations on our large screen LCD TV.  Why not 5 stars?  The transmitter for one of our "local" stations is located on the fringe of the antenna's range (30+/-).  Check the distance to your stations.  BTW we hide our antenna by "Scotch-stripping" it to the side of a cabinet out of view but facing toward the majority of our stations (including the distant station).  It really is easy to hide.
summary: Works pretty well to get FREE local stations.

reviewText: My whole system of 5.0 uses about 44 watts playing. And this system uses double, in standby, than a charging Ipad.It sounds fine but is a little out of date. Amazon says it came out in 06...I would recommend a newer sub or a passive sub.

reviewText: Simply put, every Kindle should have a case as protection.  This cover protects the Kindle and has two surprise extras; it can serve as an easel for hands-free reading and has a strap that can be slipped over the support hand allowing you to carry without worrying about dropping the thing, and it's easy to install the Kindle into it securely.  There is even a compartment that can serve as a carry-space for small flat items like credit cards, bus passes, and dollar bills.  There is even an elastic strap that holds the cover closed when you aren't reading.  It's totally useful and good looking and worth the price.  Being on a fixed income, that last part is the most important to me.One negative: The keyboard space is rather tight when the Kindle is in place.  I use a retracted ballpoint pen to reach the keys, so for those with large fingers the tight space can be overcome.  No other complaints; I'm happy with my choice.

I use this with my Samsung Series 7 Slate (Windows PC), and hook it to a big, standard monitor.  Love it.  Now I don't need the connector base / docking port, b/c I just plug stuff into the side... which means I don't have to put the computer into sleep mode to remove it from the base... just pull out the side cords and I'm off to wherever.  This works great, and is way better than the adapter kind (which didn't work for me at all).  I also like it because it takes the pressure off the cable and the jack to some degree.

March 2010: I am terribly disappointed in this purchase. While it was a huge savings at 35 USD, the old adage "You get what you pay for" proves itself true once again.First off, as other owners have blogged here, the install booklet is horrible. There are part names mentioned by name (eg Lag screws) that are NOT named in the Parts Listing or Diagram.Secondly, and most importantly, the pre-drilled holes DO NOT ALIGN properly with a 16" or 24" stud distances. What I mean is my wall has stud CENTERS that are exactly 24" apart. Regardless, even if they were 16" apart, the pre-drilled holes in the Cheetah mount would FORCE ME to be WAY OFF center .. close to the edge of BOTH studs. While that might work, it's terribly close to the edge and therefore UNSAFE .. especially if the screw ends up not going in perfectly straight therefore coming out of the side of the stud.This is a HUGE oversight in the hardware design. This product appears to originate from Assai Photo Supply - browse to:  [...]/Assia-Photo-SupplyI am very displeased with this purchase. I would much rather spend 100 dollars MORE, to know that my children will be SAFE while walking under / near to the mounted TV.===========**UPDATED** See my follow-up post below. In short, the install booklet includes a diagram showing where to place the lag screws for mounting to the studs. The small holes CAN NOT be correct, as they do NOT align with 16" or 24" spaced studs. Instead, use the oval holes, despite that they aren't perfectly aligned either. Sadly, I got the idea from an image I found on some other 3rd party website.===========
summary: Cheetah mount APTMM2B - CONFUSING but worked it out

reviewText: Handy to have when radio reception is sketchy. Especially like the antenna adapter that connects to existing antenna for radios that do not have a plug in for  an external antenna. Having the full length of the Kaito antenna unwound and hanging in an array from the wall and ceiling markedly and dramatically improved AM and Shortwave reception. I was able to DX skips from AM stations in Europe and the West Coast! (I live on the Great Lakes!). So, there you have it, a great little antenna that really helps.

reviewText: Other than the price, what is there not to like about this cover? It is thick and very protective. It is sturdy. While it is thick, it doesn't seem to add too much bulk to the Kindle Fire HD. It has a lot of options for standing the case, both in landscape and portrait mode. It has a little handle for you to hold on to while it is folded in the back (granted, I never use it, but I know some people like that feature). And to make sure it stays closed, it has a little elastic strap to hold the cover closed. Also, when you open the cover, it turns on the device for you. I've got no complaints about this case and it is the perfect way to protect your Kindle. That only thing is that you have to spend some decent cash in order to do so. Right now, it is $55, which is a quarter of the cost of the device itself. But, you aren't going to get this much protection and features for less, and this truly is a wonderful case, so you have to decide if the cost is worth it. I decided it was and have no regrets with this.
summary: Protective, feels good, and I love the stand

reviewText: This little guy is awesome. Visually, it looks great, it's small and silent. It's got all the USB ports you need, HDMI, and card readers galore. You buy this for streaming and playing video. And it hits a home run in that area. I upgraded to 2 GB RAM, just to be sure it could handle the HD video I intended to play. It handles all video, full HD, flawlessly. I watch MLB.tv, Amzon Video, Netflix, all the Boxee Apps, movies from my Hard drive, etc. It plays all flawlessly in full HD. No stuttering, freezing, delays. It's simple, fast, and superb. The wireless mouse and keyboard are excellent too. Small and work great. I can't recommend this device enough.

These headphones sound relatively "flat." They're not the greatest for listening to MP3s, unless they're really well mixed and high quality. That's not to say that there's anything wrong with them, just that there are better choices if what you want is tons of bass or high treble or whatever. What these headphones are great for is use as monitors. They're awesome for recording audio for video, due to their clear reproduction of speech. They also work quite well as general-purpose PC headphones, great for movies, videos, and games.

I bought the Tom Tom XL340-S for my wife for Christmas.  Even though we have only used it for a few days I can tell that it's a decent product.  I've got a Garmin GPSMap 76CSX that I use.  The Tom Tom doesn't have as many features as my Garmin but is way more user friendly.I went with this model Tom Tom for her because 1) it got really good reviews 2) it has a good size screen and 3) it has text to speech so it can speak street names.  I like the unit, it does what we need and didn't cost a fortune.  Right out of the box it was easy to update the software and download the latest maps.  In comparison, Garmin maps and map updates are a PITA to download. The user manual could be more detailed but this is common with all the GPS manufacturers it seems. If you want help with your unit I suggest going to one of the Tom Tom forums where you will find all kinds of information from people willing to help. The mount was easy to install on the windshield and I think it is a nice simple and secure mount.  It also comes with a disc that will allow you to mount it to your dash instead of the windshield. It comes with the cigarette power cord for the car but no home power cord. I don't consider this a drawback as it comes with the USB cable for your computer and is powered through this when connected to your computer.Before you do anything (updates or downloads) with this unit make a back-up copy of the unit as it comes out of the box. This is easy to do as when you first plug it into your computer it installs the Tom Tom Home software which easily allows you to back-up your device. Tom Tom forum offers advice on what they recommend you do with your new unit to back it up and I think it is good advice.The map updates for the Tom Tom are considerably cheaper than those purchased for my Garmin. Overall I like the unit, my wife really likes it, and both of us would purchase one again if needed.UPDATE. I bought my wife's in DEC 09, we both liked it so much I bought the same model again for me but with lifetime map update.  I purchased mine in FEB 11 and they have dropped in price quite a bit.  Mine on Amazon with the lifetime map update cost less than what I paid for hers.  The computer voice on my newer version does a better job pronouncing some street names too.  This is a great GPS for the car.
summary: Bought a Tom Tom for my Wife, now, another for me.

This inexpensive little adapter allows you to charge your electronic devices while you are on the road. It plugs into the cigarette lighter socket in your car and it has two USB outlets on the front. One of the USB outlets is 1.2 amps and the other is 2.4 amps. The 1.2 amp outlet is used for lower powered devices like charging a cell phone, Bluetooth speaker or headset or a small tablet. The 2.4 amp outlet is best used or charging higher powered devices like an iPad. You can really plug any device into either outlet but higher powered devices may take longer on the 1.2 amp port. You can charge two devices at a time without loss of power. It has a built-in function that will automatically stop charging your device when the battery is full. This is a good option and not all adapters have this.The adapter is simply made and black in color. It has a light on the front that illuminates when plugged in so you know that it’s powered up and ready to go. The adapter plugs in tightly and doesn’t move around or lose connection and power. It’s a simple adapter but it works well and is very low cost. If you just need something simple and low cost then this is a good option.Sample provided for review.
summary: Inexpensive, simple and works well. Automatically stops charging when battery is full.

The player looks sleek with very minimal buttons in the front (power, open, play, stop). There is a usb port in the front and a HDMI port and RCA connections in the back. There is also an ethernet port for wired network connection. The player is wireless (wi-fi) capable as well. It comes with a powerful remote (batteries included). As has been in other electronic items, no video/ethernet cables are included.Set-up: There is an easy setup menu for language, TV screen type, quick start (on/off) and the network. You can choose wired or wireless connection. If you want to use a wired connection, hookup the ethernet cable "before" turning the unit on. Otherwise, it might have some issues detecting the connection. For wireless, there is an easy "WPS" connection mode if your router allows it (No need to type any password during setup). Otherwise, you may choose to type the password and connect - be warned - typing lengthy passwords with special characters can be a pain using bluray player remotes.Menu: The opening menu has setup, videos, music, photos and network options. Menu options are highlighted by a light blue flashing background (It is hard to see sometimes - not very good). You can use the navigation buttons on the remote to choose any of these self-explanatory options. The network menu provides access to internet media such as netflix, you tube. Unfortunately, the internet media options on this player are very limited compared to other models. For example, there is no viera connect menu which helps you access media such as Amazon video!! If you have a network player (or itunes server) setup in your home, the player can access it and play it as well. In addition, if you setup a DLNA media server (e.g. Mezzmo) on your computer, the player can detect it and play videos from your computer as well.One option available from the main menu is "personalization". not sure how much I would use it, but each member of your family (upto 4?) can have the main menu personalized (name, icon, wall paper etc).Performance: I tested a couple of bluray discs and several DVD discs. It played them all flawlessly. I am not sure if the quick start made any difference - it started playing about the same speed as my other player. It displays pictures and videos from usb thumb drives very well. I ran a slideshow which ran flawlessly (Do want to note that it does not zoom low res photos; you will see them smaller in size on a high res TV). The usb port is rated 5V 500mA - not sure if that means it can support usb hard drives that have such power requirement (I dont have one to test).The player also automatically searches for firmware updates and prompts you to update if one is available. There is a lengthy menu to navigate, but update is fairly quick. You also have the option of downloading the update on a computer, burn to a CD-R and use it to update.I didnot see the freezing problems (yet?) that other reviewers reported. I did do a firmware update as the first thing after starting the player up.EDIT: It did freeze a couple of times with youtube within an hour of posting the original review (not internet freeze, but menu freeze). I guess the disc freeze might be forthcoming.Bottomline: Despite the slim network media choices on this player (does not even have Amazon video), it plays bluray discs, DVDs, home videos and DLNA media (depending on your media server's ability to encode) very well.
summary: Plays discs well, but slim internet media options (No Amazon video!!)

reviewText: these lenses work fantastically with  any camera "they fit on" i had the ability to get as close to an object as i wanted with little distortion of the image. being able to choose how much zoom you want is a huge help.

I previously owned the version I (v.1) of this lens for almost 2 years. While v.1 had amazed me during my ownership, with IS, with speed, with color, with bokeh.....it does not come close to this new mk2 (v.2) version by any means.  I am glad I sold v.1 for 1750 and received 1550 in cash after all fees was deducted (2months ago).  Here is why:Mk2 PRO (vs Mk1):1) Super sharp at all focal length even wide open at f2.8 (now those 70-200 F4 IS fan boys can't complain about the lack of sharpness on the f2.8 big brother anymore).  The shorter minimum focusing distance (mfd) makes this lens even more usable indoor.2) The focusing speed feels more responsive and accurate.  It is also quieter, almost inaudible.3) IS is truly improved.  Although a tiny bit heavier, I still manage to take sharp pics with shutter as slow as 1/15 of a second handheld.  (You can put the mk1 on a tripod, and the pic you take with mk1 will always be softer than my mk2 handheld, especially at 200mm)4) Fluorite element: this is not a gimmick, and the reason it is inside all the larger L white lenses.  It really controls light better so images doesn't appear washed out or have unwanted light under extremely bright situation.CONS:Price? (Before you own the lens price can be a CONS.  Once you use it, it will be a non issue with regards to value/performance ration).  Just think about having one zoom from 70mm~200mm that gives you sharp picture wide open through out, that easily translates to 3 to 4 prime lenses (to offer the same sharpness at each focal length)...then think how much you would have to pay for those lenses and how much they would weight together, and how much time you will waste swapping lenses, while with this lens you just turn the focusing ring, shoot, and smile ^_^.I will post some pictures later on, but so far I am totally satisfied as you probably have seen from other owners.  If you can afford to spend the extra 7~800 for this zoom range you need or have always wanted, I guarantee you will not have any remorse.  Thank you for reading!***Similar products I am using include: Canon 40d, ef-s 17-55 2.8is, 100mm 2.8L is Macro, 200mm 2.0L is, 70-200 2.8L is mkII, Canon EOS 7D and tokina 11-16 f2.8.  Canon 180mm F3.5L Macro lens (already sold it due to lack of sharpness)***UPDATE:Still impressed with 70-200 f2.8L IS mkII. Although 200mm f2L is faster and sharper, better bokeh, color saturation...it does not replace this zoom, due to fixed focal length and weight.  I really like the flexibility of this zoom, with it's ultra sharp results and excellent color.  This lens will be in my bag permanently, along with 100mm macro, and my 17-55mm (my next zoom lens will be 24-70 2.8L...so I have full coverage from 11mm~200mm all at f2.8) You will not be disappointed I promise.

I can work on the computer and listen to my music or listen to an audio book on my android phone while I work without any discomfort.Pros:Great Sound QualityFits on the ears instead of over the ears muff style allows for your ears to breatheComfortable fitAdjust easilyFolds up nicelySturdy case to store headphones in when not in useCons:n/a -- I haven't had any in the 1-1/2 months I've been using these.

I recently received this subwoofer box, since I had to wait a little more cuss I live in San Jose, Costa Rica. Man was I exited while unpacking this baby, since I had long been waiting to replace my old sub box which was to big and the shape was not any good either. Well I was a little afraid to open it up and see some damage from shipment since it came a long way from here. So  I was so happy when I opened it and saw that it was perfectly packed and then after I oppened the main box saw that this product was plastic wrapped and with a carton paper stappled to it. I almost freak with this thick sapples, but when I saw the thickness of this box, I knew it was nothing to worry, and actually it helped to have this carton paper stappled to the box whole, so that it prevents the inside from getting al dusty. Well I examined the box thourougly and it looks of superb construction. Chinese manufacturing has improved a lot! Now when I see something made in China, like this product, I now know that, that old bad repp for chinise made stuff it's long gone. This is a really well constructed box. The 3/4 thinkness mdf material looks great. There was like about 8 screws or more spread all over the sub box inside, but that does not lower a star for me. I simply search all the box inside for no loose screws left, pick them up and put them in a little plastic bag to use them later for something else like screws for attaching the SUB to the box. The interior padding on the walls and ceiling of the box was ok, nothing fancy, it did look like home made, but I am sure it will do the job of cushioning the air damp of the sub. I have not install it on my car yet cuss I am waiting for the the rest of my gear to arrive. Sub, amp, ints kits, etc. But I can't wait to try my Pioneer Premmier TS-W1207D4, dual 4 ohm voice coil, 400 watts rms paired with a Planet Audio 500 watts @ 8 ohms, Anarchy AC3000.1 D class monoblock amp. Well will see how that goes when I received the rest of my gear! I will come back and tell you guys how this box performs with that, and I will be sure to review the other stuff which I bought all here at Amazon !!!***Update***So I finally was able to install my Pioneer Premmier TS-W1207D4, dual 4 ohm voice coil, 400 watts power handling, paired with a Planet Audio 500 watts rms @ 8 ohms. It sounds great ! This is exaclty the box I needed ! At first it looked to me like a non trunk box, but this box sounds great for a sedan/trunk subwoofer aplication. It actually sounds better with the trunk closed, and it also sounds better when you are inside the car. Before I used to have basooka style box, a kind of tubular one, the long ones that are like a cylinder, and I had to open one of the rollable back seats, in order to get better bass sound. Now with this box I get a great tight bass with the back seats normally (closed). I get an evenly spread great bass all over the inside of the car ! No distortion or crappy bass what so ever ! Pefect box for a medium to big trunk !17/08/2011Just wanted to add:Still very happy so far with this subwoofer enclosure. I wanted to add that what I did to get the most good quality sound out of it, was in the installation, where I did not used the speaker wire terminals that this box come with. Instead I took them apart and actually used a direct line of 12 AMG good quality wire/cable that connected directly to the subwoofer's terminals inside the box. Then I was left with two little holes on the plastic part were the terminal leads used to go, and I sealed one of the little holes with Loctite PL Polyurethane adhesive and the other hole I made it a little bit bigger by melting it around as small enough as possible, just enough for the 12 gauge wire to pass by and connect directly to the subwoofer.Highly recomend this as a subwoofer enclosure !!

I've had this TV for about 3 weeks now, and every time I turn it on I still get a big smile on my face.  We shopped HDTV's hard for several weeks.  When we started I was heavily biased toward either Samsung or LG, based mostly on reputation.  An online acquaintance talked me into at least giving a fair look at the Aquos and once I did, I was sold.  We looked at all the Samsungs and their 8000 series - at a price of several hundred dollars more - was the only one that had a picture that could compete.  On top of that, the silver trim of the 8000 wouldn't go with our decor at all.  One of the more trivial things I like about the Aquos is that the black bezel is stout enough to give the display real support and protection, while still being very unobtrusive.The native sound/speakers on this TV is better than any other 46" HDTV we looked at.  In my opinion, native sound is just horrible on all flat screens, but relatively speaking this is the best I've heard.  More importantly I think, is the fact that the TV is at a nice full volume when set to around 15-20%, unlike many we looked at that I could hardly hear when they were at 50%.Along the same lines, I dislike how most of the current TV's require their video settings to be at max, or close to it, in order to provide their best quality.  I've fine tuned the settings on this TV using settings posted in online forums by other owners, and virtually all the settings are between 50-65% of their range.  To me that indicates sound and honest design.I am absolutely in love with this TV and would buy it again in a second.  The ONLY thing I can ding it on so far is the fact that the supplied remote control only supports two programming codes for Sony Blu-ray players - and neither of them apply to my BDP-S570, which is not an obscure model. reviewText: There are 3 items that I do not like about this drive: 1) no on/off switch 2)IS NOT compatible with Window 7 Professional Back UP and 3)Included backup software is extremely slow. However, I'm using only as a backup or archive device so I want to be able to turn it off. 2) Window 7 Backup - I spent hours trying to make this work. Out of the box, I can map or use a network address (ie \\MyLiveBook\Public) to mount the drive to the PC. Speed is very good on file copy. However, Windows 7 Backup that comes with the professional addition did not recognize the drive. To the manufacture's credit, I did get very responsive customer support..but alas, could not solve the problem. Also tried answer forums on Microsoft. Nothing worked there either. 3) If the WD backup software worked, I would have kept the drive. However, it was extremely slow. After starting the backup for 350GB of day, it report a 4 day backup time. I was not a network problem as a standard file copy was speedy.

I've been carrying a New Trent battery pack in my backpack for almost two years now.  It has consistently, reliably charged my various devices - iPhone, iPad, keyboard, earbuds and MiFi have all gotten extra boosts of power from the battery pack.  It's getting a little worn out after two years of use, so I was on the hunt for another one.  Based on reviews and my positive experience with my current charger, I bought the New Trent PowerPak Xtreme NT120R external battery pack.I have to admit, the first thing I noticed when I picked up the box was not the battery pack itself, but the packaging.  The package has a flap, which normally would swing around and be generally annoying; this package, however, used two small magnets to hold the flap in place.  Nothing to do with the battery pack, but shows that New Trent is thinking about the details and consumer when they design things, even the packaging.The first thing I noticed when I pulled the battery pack out of the box was the weight - man, this thing is heavy for an external battery.  I carry my battery pack in a backpack, so it's not a big deal for me, but there's no way I'd carry this battery around in a pocket.  It reminds me of a tractor tread, not only in its color and design, but also in the way it just seems to be sitting on the counter and saying "I dare you to try to hurt me."  It looks practically indestructible!I found the power button on the side and turned the battery pack on - four small, well-hidden blue LED lights showed me four levels of power.  I was about to wash the dishes, so I carried my phone and the battery pack into the kitchen and charged the phone while I listened to a podcast.  While I was washing dishes, I accidentally splashed the battery pack with water - the battery didn't skip a beat.  The packaging claims the battery pack is waterproof, so I figured I'd test it with my full sink.  I unplugged the battery pack and dunked it in the sink - still didn't skip a beat!  Not that I'd normally toss the battery into puddles or swimming pools, but it's nice to know if I get caught in the rain with my backpack the battery pack won't die.The battery pack comes with a USB cable, but no wall charger.  Not a problem - if you don't have an extra wall charger from a phone sitting around, New Trent's got you covered with the NT90C dual charger.  The only thing I find even mildly annoying about the battery pack is the amount of force required to open the door covering the USB slots on the bottom.  It doesn't quite make me feel like I'm ripping my fingernails off when I open the door, but it is a little uncomfortable.  I understand it's got to make a tight seal, and I appreciate the lid is probably designed to not wear out over time, so I can give this a pass.All in all, I love this battery pack.  I'm prone to dropping everything, as the scuffs and cracks on my current battery pack and phone case show.  It's so nice to have at least one thing in my pack that I can drop with no fear of breaking it.
summary: This battery pack is great - tested drop proof!

I like these a lot, and they definitely beat out non UHS-1 cards by a lot in terms of speed. Sandisk has also been a very reliable brand for me in terms of data integrity.The read speed matters if you have a USB3.0 reader, it won't matter much if you don't.The write speed is determined by the class-1 destinction of UHS-1. This is the speed you need for 1080p video BUT, supposedly some Sony cameras prefer a 15MB/s minimum write speed. class-1 (This one) is only 10MB/s. I haven't tested but in my NEX-6 anyway this card works fine. In my NEX-5R, I have had some overheating issues that -may- be related to the write speed, not sure.Until class-3 cards become available (minimum write speed is 30MB/s if I recall correctly), which are for 4K video writing, this is about as good as it gets.Note that a higher speed where it says 45MB/s* or 90MB/s has to do with READ speed and it's a MAXIMUM value. It has nothing to do with write speed (that's the 1 inside the little U). Write speed is what matters if you're trying to speed up fps on your DSLR or trying to get better write performance for some other device.GL
summary: Fast, reliable, gets the job done!

The transmitter works great, the mp3/wma player works fine and has almost enough features, except for being able to shuffle over ALL folders, but, more importantly it doesn't have at least a 2 band EQ which would have made it a perfect product. I'm guessing this is why it's hit and miss for most people that are looking for the transmitter + player capability all in 1 unit. Some stereos may have just enough EQ ability but for my 2005 Escape's factory stereo, the end result needs a bit more treble to liven it up. Note also that the file encoding does make a difference. Initially I was ready to send it back but then I started to compare encodings on the same song and found my current WMA variable bit rate 135-215 encoding was part of the problem. After switching to WMA constant bit rate 192, this made a noticeable difference, however, still, if only the soundfly could boost the treble a bit I'd be a happy camper. So, it's a fine transmitter but heavily dependent on your stereo to shape the sound of the soundfly's built-in player.

I bought this card for use with BF3. It runs BF3 very well, it will run on high settings with excellent frame rates, you can even run it on Ultra but you will take a performance hit. I can personally confirm it runs excellent on high settings after 35 hours of playtime.However, it gets a hot under load, in my pc case the Hawk's temps get up to the mid 70's, this means the fan starts spinning at around 70-75%, anything above 60% fan speed results in a loud whining sound from the fans, when I bought this card I thought the heatsink/fan design would be pretty quiet taking into account the heatpipe design, I was wrong.Either way, you can change the fan profiles via the Afterburner software to help with the fan speeds, also a side panel fan should help, I'll be installing one next week.An otherwise perfect card. reviewText: I stream video from my laptop to my Smart TV over wifi. The router is about 50 feet and 4-5 walls away from the TV. Sometimes with HD files the video lags, stutters, or just won't work. So, I was excited to try this extender, as it seemed like it would allow me to overcome the problem.I was really disappointed with the product. First, the instructions for setup were extremely confusing. I'm pretty tech savvy, but they really made no sense and were totally unclear. Using common sense I eventually got it set up, and it worked fine for a while, but then over the next couple days constantly went out. It was very unreliable. I was pretty frustrated by it, especially when my phone, which I had set to use the extended Wifi network, went back to using data when the wifi flaked out.Bottom line, don't bother with this. I'm sure there are better options out there.

I've tried the Belkin and it really turned me off trying to use an FM transmitter, that is until I read about this one.  I knew it wouldn't be perfect, hence only three stars. I will say that it does work, I first used it with my Creative Travel Sound MP3 player and the hiss and high pitched whine was terrible. After disconnecting the player from the dc power inverter, the noises went away, must have been a ground fault loop or something. I use it now with my Zen Micro and it sounds great, although I do have to turn the radio volume up louder than normal. I do wish it had some sort of power off function like the iRock. I don't think any of these things are perfect, there are so many variables inside the car that can cause interference.  The FCC sets the transmit levels so they are all going to be fairly low power. I think this transmitter is one of the best on the market (...).
Sound  is great. But no wireless connection to iPhone/iPod yet, although it comes with a wireless-connection-port for some future add-on device not yet launched.

I really don't understand the people who receive this unit and are shocked there isn't a tuner in it.  It says so right in the description!  Don't knock the product because you didn't read what the product is.

reviewText: This is the best radio to have for power outages and weather alerts.  After the superstorm, I am buying another one for my aunt in Jersey City....she needs to be able to stay informed in a power outage.

You can purchase this product via the links above and special thanks to our friends at RAVPower. Show your support by hitting those sharing buttons.This device is different than any product that I have used in the past. It allows you to charge your devices using the USB 2.0 port, share media through the port and SD Card Slot, and share your Internet as well. Everything you want inside a device such as this one. There's four LEDs on the top of the device that shows you the battery level, WiFi Sharing, WiFi Connectivity, and Internet Status.There's a SD Card Slot, Reset Button, and USB 2.0 Port on the bottom. You will find your power button and Micro USB port on the left side of the device.Let's get deeper inside the review. I connected my iPod touch 4G and Lumia 925 to the device using it WiFi connectivity and find that speeds dropped lower than connecting to my WiFi Router directly. I understand this happens since it's sharing an Internet Connection and sharing data at the same time. Speeds are good but not the best. Not a deal breaker.You may be wondering how the heck does it share Internet, files, and charge your devices. Well there's a small 3000mAh internal battery that can charge your device between 1 to 3 times on one charge. I find that it don't drain fast even when sharing multimedia, Internet, and charging my devices. The battery is small so don't expect to charge tablets and smartphones many times.There's an iOS and Android app that allows you to access your files from your iPhone and Android-powered devices. This is great but only supported multimedia files can play on supported files. Otherwise, the app is great. At the end, this is the best device for sharing multimedia wirelessly, sharing your Internet, and charging your device at one time.
summary: Official RAVPower WiFi Disk Power Bank Review!

reviewText: This remotes is extremely easy to set up. It took me all of five minutes to read and set the controls for my onkyo receiver, samsung tv, sony blue ray player and comcast cable box. I have owned three Fuji P&S cameras.  Because I'm a gadget fan and since touch-screen cameras have been hitting the market for the past couple of years, I wanted to give one of them a try.  I like the touch screen because (1) the back of the camera has more area for the screen and (2) I really like doing away with the mechanical buttons and switches.  The Canon 500 HS has many of the same features as most other P&S cameras.  I especially like the face-detection and "wink" technology for taking photos using the timer.  The touch screen does take some practice to get used to.  It's not as touch responsive as I had expected and scrolling thru the menus can be a bit jumpy.  Perhaps I have been spoiled by my iPhone touch screen.  The picture quality of the Canon is pretty good but like all digital cameras, you get the best picture quality when using the lowest ISO setting possible.  Overall, I am pleased with this camera and I would purchase it again.  The small size and weight of this ELPH camera is also appealing since it easily fits in my shirt or pants pocket.  However, a belt case is handy for carrying a spare battery or SD card.  Give this camera a try.  The price is right and I don't think you will be disappointed.

reviewText: The Eye-Fi Mobile X2 memory card works just as promised. I had a few hang ups setting up initially and pairing it with my iPhone, but admitedly I didn't read the instructions at first. Once I read the online steps for pairing with the iPhone and realized you do the intial set up with the card hooked to the computer, it was a breeze to sink my wife's iPhone and our iPad.I use the card with my Canon Rebel T2i. It was eye-fi ready, so I can actually turn the card on and off using the camera's menu options. This allows for maximum battery life when I am far away from my computer, and also lets me not transfer pics I don't want trasferred. The card itself also allows you to choose how pics are transferred and lets you use your cameras lock function to choose what pics to trasfer.I find myself taking more 'quick shots' with my camera that I would have used my phone for in the past because it was easier for sharing. I am getting much more use out of my camera. Making this product worth much more than it's product value alone.

I recently purchased my first HDTV, the Zenith Z37LZ5D (great so far) and found the Zenith DVD upconverter (DVB 318) to pair it with, using Monster cable M850CV. The picture quality, while acceptable, did not impress me much. The blue color saturation was obvious. A reviewer at Amazon.com recommended the older Monster MV2CV component video cable and I ordered it (the player upconverts by component).Contrary to popular opinion that the cable does not matter it has made a difference in my case. The now much cheaper ($4.00) MV2CV) has given me a better picture with less blue color saturation, plus over all better picture quality than the DVD showed on the CRT TV. This is an excellent cable- well recommended.

reviewText: First, let me say the Anker has given me the external battery in exhange for my honest feedback.  The product that I am reviewing is their External battery pack (Astro E4).I will start my review with a description of the battery.It is 3" X 5" 1", weighs about 11 oz, has a cool looking glossy black exterior, 1 - 1 amp and 1 - 2 amp usb charging ports.  It also has a micro usb charging input port.  In addition, it came with a nice cloth carrying case and a usb cable with 3 different device ends: 30 pin  IOS style connector, mini usb and micro usb connectors.It is extremely easy to use, simply plug in the usb cable into the battery and the other end into your device to be charged and press the power button on top.  You will see the leds illuminate indicating that it is charging your device.The battery has another cool feature that is a bit unusual but very nice to have - it has a led flashlight.  Easy to use by simply pressing the power button twice and twice again to turn if off.This battery is useful for anyone you can use usb to charge their devices.  This powerpack battery offers a unbelievable 13,000 mAh.  That is an awesome amount of power.I love this battery pack and really appreciate Anker for trusting me to evaluate it.  I would highly recommend this product - I have used it to charge my iphone, ipad and camera.If I had one recommendation I would like to see a newer lightning adapter that would fit my iphone 5 and my wife's ipad 3.Look forward to more cool Anker products.

I bought this to provide protection for the Kindle (two, actually, one for me and one for my grandson; at this price I could probably have bought half-a-dozen but, then I'd have needed to buy a few more Kindles to go with them).It is definitely NOT leather (to be expected at this price level, still false advertising is false advertising).The plastic holder for the Kindle is two part - the back plate attached to the dustjacket and a front plate which holds the Kindle in place. They are cemented together at three or four (small, about 3/4in x 1/8in) attachment points along each side. The glue appears to be some form of rubber cement - not a particularly good idea. Some reviewers have noted that this "breaks" - the glue is probably just failing. It can be easily repaired using a plastic epoxy (plastic weld) - although a little more attention to construction would have removed this problem (the design would be much improved by using a locking mechanism between the two plates instead of glue).The latching mechanism for the Kindle is substantial at the bottom, somewhat flimsy at the top; I suspect that the ultimate failure will be the top latch breaking - so refrain from putting the Kindle in and taking it out on a regular basis, and be gentle when latching/unlatching the upper tab!The design is open (like a book) it would have been a good idea to provide a clasp to keep it closed  when not in use (like some of the old hefty leather bound books) - it would have improved the protection afforded in case of the Kindle being dropped.The use of this case as a bookstand has marginal utility IMHO. The case does not like to be laid with the front and back covers laid flat against each other (think of a book; this kind of mistreatment results in a broken spine, and/or separation of the leaves from the covers - NOT a good idea). I suspect that continued usage in this fashion will result in serious damage to the case.For my purposes (protection) it works well and you can't beat the price with a stick.Caveat: this is for 2nd generation Kindle (not current, 3rd generation).

Guess what? You probably already own an amazing machine that will connect you to thousands if not millions of media options! It's called a computer. You can't use a Rabbit TV without one, but you can sure use one without a Rabbit TV. This thing is less than worthless. Google XBMC. Watch a tutorial on YouTube to learn how to set it up. If you can figure it out, you have at your disposal a much more diverse and functional media solution than Rabbit TV, and you don't have to give anybody 8 bucks.

This bag is GREAT!  Great value for the money.  The strap connections and zippers are great.  The material looks great and seems very durable.  The shoulder pad is actually padded, which is great. And, the volume inside this bag is great.My 17.3" laptop has always seemed to stretch the corners of whatever bag I was using.  I was always concerned about minor bumps against objects damaging the case.  This bag is roomy enough to carry 2 computers, and the padding is excellent.  No worries.I will consider giving Everki bags as gifts to my friends and family.  (Five stars)Update December, 2013:The metal joint where the shoulder strap connects with the bag failed without warning.  (Ok, maybe there was some warning.  That joint never rotated smoothly like the other one.)  Any ways, my bag fell off my shoulder and the case on my $3,500 gaming laptop was damaged.  Fortunately, the computer continues to run.I have purchased the Everki Backpack (as a replacement.  I still think the company makes a good product.  Nevertheless, I am downgrading my review to 2 stars.  Catastrophic failure after 2 years is unacceptable.

I did some research between the Archos, Creative Zen Vision, and this A2 before I bought it. First things first, the Archos has some glowing reviews, and I've got no hatred against it, other than the subpar battery life (ofcourse, they offer a replacable battery). The Zen is slightly lacking in display quality behind the Archos and Cowon, but their audio quality is superb.Which brings us to the Cowon: the main reason i bought this over the Archos was a) better battery life (though it's not replacable) b) extensive file type support and firmware upgrades (definitely good because they can always add future releases for better performance and new file types), c) it's cheaper than the archos, and d) it runs on linux.Out of the box, they give you EVERYTHING. The cables are there for plugging into your tv, to use as a usb host, and ofcourse, the main USB interface cable. They include a quality case, and a little wrist band to hold on to the player (very useful). AC adaptor also included. the headphones are bass heavy, loud, and very clear considering they're standard inserts. i'm personally buying a more expensive pair, because i ride the train to work and need some decent noise canceling. you don't need to buy a separate pair of headphones if you're using the unit in a normal, not very loud, operating environment.that brings us to the player itself. the interface is very clean, and support for all different video and audio file types is extensive. the picture quality is superb, to say the least. the playlist feature is great, and the joystick functionality is different than the archos, but still very good, especially if you're used to that kind of thing. best of all, battery life is fantastic. i get about 7 hours of video plus an additional 1-2 hours of audio in before it decides to die. this is FAR better than the archos.sound quality is also great, really depends on your file type and how well the file is encoded. i watch some good quality recordings which really come to life on this thing.recording quality is decent too. i've converted some old VHS cassettes to divx with the unit, and it does the job very well.all in all, if you are looking for a great player with a decent price tag, and one that has all the bells and whistles included, this is the unit to go with.

reviewText: After reading the other reviews, I knew I would take a chance on this purchase. My Dell Studio would either recognize the charger and allow it to perform it's job and charge my battery or not. The charger arrived promptly, was packaged well, and was just as described. It was looked just like the Dell charger that came with my laptop. The sad part for me was my Dell wouldn't recognize it. I would have to take out the charge and put it back in quickly several times and have the laptop sort of accidentally recognize only twice to charge. Sadly I returned the charger. I used to do photography professionally, but sold my gear over the years as film became all but obsolete.  I've recently seen pixel ranges come up to near 35mm resolution and decided to get pack into it on a semi-professional basis - mostly for sittings rather than on-the-go stuff.  I use a Pentax X-5 for my shots now, a heavier camera than my older, lighter tripod could comfortably handle.  Toward that end, and because I'm cheap, I bought the Vista Explorer.  So based on once having had many different quality tripods in the past, I start out with five stars and evaluate it.I was initially very impressed.  The Explorer is heavier weight compared to others in its price range.  It looks smart, has a nice carrying handle and, once things are tightened down, doesn't wiggle too much.  It sets up and takes down smoothly and handles uneven surfaces well.  The pan and tilt grip is large enough to be useful but small enough not to get in the way.  The leveling bubbles are a nice touch with one on the base at the top of the tripod legs and the other on the head.  For greater stability, it has a hook on the bottom to which a light weight can be attached.  The tilting mechanism is relatively smooth.  The removable mount is convenient and easy to use, and not something you usually see on a tripod in this price range.On the down-side the working parts are almost entirely plastic.  It's an ABS plastic that doesn't seem light, but it gives the tripod a slightly cheap feel to it.  The screws are steel, though, which makes up for some of the plastic cheapness provided it doesn't come apart later.  The fold-down grip on the camera screw is very small, which makes putting on the camera a bit of a challenge if you have large fingers (like I do). Another problem is that the leveling bubble in the head is to the side, and covered by the camera.  You can't see it unless you remove the camera and adjust the level that way, or put in your camera "sideways".  I usually shoot based more on framing than on leveling, so it isn't that much of a consideration for me.But the biggest issue is the panning and that's where it critically fails.  While the tilting is fine, the panning quite simply sucks.  It's sticky, jerky and can not be made smooth with any lubrication I've tried from water to a petroleum jelly.  You can literally knock the tripod over from trying to pan with one finger if you don't hold on to it.  Tilting doesn't do that.  This causes gross over compensating in framing adjustments because you have to overcome the stick at the beginning of the pan, only to go so far to the other side it's literally easier to pick the thing up and turn it than it is to make fine panning adjustments.The ironic thing is that it does have a panning lock knob, which is utterly unnecessary.Whether or not the panning issue evens out as time and wear breaks it in remains to be seen, but as it is now, the panning issue is a major one if you need to do any fine side-to-side framing adjustments like panoramic shots, video or telephoto.So overall, while I was impressed with the feature set, the general "cheapness" of it is disappointing and the panning issue makes it a non-starter for a professional.  For each I removed one star.  Time will tell if the impression of the plastic's cheapness is offset by durability and if wear and use smooths out the panning.  If it proves durable and the panning issue eventually goes away, it will earn four stars (mostly because it wasn't 'perfect' out of the box), and I'll revisit this review and rating.For the average photographer who wants something a little better than a ten dollar tripod, this one will certainly fit the bill.  It has a good feature set at a good price.  If you just set it up and shoot and don't have to pan much, you'll be fine with it. For a professional, I wouldn't recommend this unless you need something a little more up-scale that you aren't afraid to break or lose.  For the price, the feature set makes it a viable "throwaway" for those riskier, outdoor or on the road shots, provided you have the patience, or lack the need, to deal with the panning issue.
summary: It has its pros and cons

Although I dislike buying something such as a bag online, the numerous pictures of people placing their expensive DSLR cameras into the top section with the lens attached made me comfortable with the idea. On the plus side, the compartments hold the individual units, extra batteries, lens covers, and just about everything I can imagine.I wish it came with an instruction book on what the best way to carry a tripod with the 'tripod' straps would be, since its internal structure is padded yet not armored to the point where I wouldn't fear a flexing or bending of the bag due to the weight of a tripod. Still, anything is better than carrying a tripod on a shoulder strap or in one hand when climbing a mountain to get a great shot overlooking the Valley Of The Sun or Sonoran Desert, and I imagine not falling over due to imbalance will pay off. I imagine that once I start obtaining additional lenses and extra doodads, the rest of the pockets will really pay off.The best part about it is the price! The price of a "camera only" bag from Cannon tends to be more expensive than the full backpack. I am quite glad to have bought this, although I admit I have not taken it out for a real test. Excellent optic. Requires an additional adapter on most cameras.It will NOT work with the flash units built into most cameras. If you are using this product with any flash, good luck. It is meant for very long distance work with the high zoom cameras. Your flash should be off when using it.You need to reprogram the Focus system on most cameras so that all focusing is done Thru The Lens. (TTL Focus.) For many models this means you have to dig in the camera settings and find the Accessory Lens item. Turn that on. For some reason Kodak didn't put this with the rest of the Focus controls in some cameras.These limitations apply to most lenses, hoods, and filters, especially on cameras that need an adapter to mount them. Accessory lenses and hoods frequently block the port hole used by the auxiliary focus system.This lens is rather heavy. You'll want a quality tripod and might also want to turn OFF image stabilization for best results. (Image stabilizing is not designed to handle the distances that this lens can deliver.)This lens is meant to be used at or near the maximum Optical Zoom available on your camera. (Digital Zoom that comes in After Optical is maxed also works.) If you go too wide, the image will become tunneled (Vignetted) and depending on the camera, you may not be able to zoom out very much at all before this happens.When combined with a 10-12X optical zoom and very ridged tripod, you will be able to clearly see things up to several miles away using this lens.

reviewText: I was a little nervous when unboxing this antenna.  I really wanted something that worked, but I thought a passive antenna wouldn't cut it. I originally hooked it up directly to my television downstairs with OK results.  I then moved it upstairs since I had a coax cable that went from the upstairs closet to my TV downstairs.  This really worked much better.  I can now catch every major channel from 15 to 69.  I'm getting some analog channels out of Mexico that are a bit fuzzy, but I don't need to watch them anyway.  However, I've been unable so far to catch channels 8 and 10, which are VHF.  These stations are actually closer to me than the UHF stations.  The antenna says it's made mainly for UHF but should be able to pick up VHF as well.  So far it doesn't.  I have a splitter joining the antenna coax to my main coax run, so I'm going to go find an extension connector to see if I can improve the signal strength.
summary: UHF is working, Still trying for VHF

reviewText: I bought this recently from another retailer.  I had it up and running within minutes.  I use a brush and air duster to clean the slides.  The quality of the scan is acceptable given that my slides are snapshot quality to begin with.  It's easy and quick.If you are looking for a professional-quality scan, you'll need to buy a pro unit, scan with a flat-bed scanner, or send out to a service.  But if you want a quick and cheap scan solution to view these on the computer (or in my case, I have a Panasonic TV with SD card slot), this will do the trick.  Actually, "scan" is a misnomer - this unit is basically a camera that's taking a photo of the slide, not a true "scanner".  Note the title calls it a "converter".One issue I have is that many of my slides are in 126 format which is square.  A few slides can't be scanned without cutting off the top of heads.  I got around the problem with some of them by scanning sideways, which works if there isn't anything on the edges that you don't want cut off.  Wish there was a carrier that did square format slides.Otherwise, I recommend this to anyone wanting to scan the old family photos.

I have bought a few screen protectors in the past and just get frustrated with them while trying to get them on.  A piece of dust of bit of hair underneath and then what a pain.  No way to get it off and then I just stare at that big ole bubble (looks big to me anyway) on the screen, get frustrated and yank it off.Well not with this product!  The easy to follow instructions and bottle of soapy solution made application a breeze.  Oh no!!  2 bits of dust underneath grrrrrrrr....  Well no worries, lift the edge of the protector use a bit more of the soapy solution, out the little dust devils went and in 12 hrs I had a PERFECT screen protector on my iPad.  YES!!I love it.  I always worry about the screen since I do have quite a few pets in the house and a few that think they should be able to use the iPad.  I wanted to protect the screen from little claws and this fits the bill.  I am so happy this has a lifetime warranty and replacements, great instructions and looks like great customer service.  I found the company I will always do business with when it comes to screen protectors.  Love giving good reviews!

I wish I had read the reviews before I bought them.  It is true about the cable noise.  The cables drape down around my collar, and the slightest movement sends a loud roaring sound to my ears.  Staying perfectly still: it's alright.All I have to do is turn my head slightly and it comes back.  Whenever the cables rub against my neck: noise.  When they rub against each other, noise.  They come in contact with my shirt collar, noise.  I shift my hair and my pony tail touches the cables: noise.  I reach to un-twist the cables (which love to knot themselves) and yet more noise.In my opinion they should have never let a product like this with such a design flaw out of the door.  These are $25-class headphones, not ten-buck cheapies.  I should have kept the receipt.
summary: Just-ok sound quality, horrible noise from cables

I bought this form my Toshiba Netbook to replace the stock 1 GM memory-price paid $30.  I am running windows XP on it, and 1 GB of memory is just not enough for multi-tasking.  Here is how I replaced the memory:  Turned the Netbook upside-down, used a phillips head screwdriver to unscrew the 1 screw for the memory cover removed the old chip noting the pin orientation of the old chip, put in new chip orienting the pins the same as the old chip, closed cover tight, flipped the netbook up-right, and turned it on.  The machine booted up, under device manager/system manager saw that windows detected 1.99 GM of main memory.  Time: 5 minutes.  I don't think it gets easier, or cheaper than that.

reviewText: I have a wifi only Android tablet device, and this gizmo is how I get online when I don't have a wifi connection available to me.  The Virgin Mobile website only lists Windows and MacOs as supported platforms, but I was able to configure the device and set up my account using only my tablet.  I do have a Windows laptop, but it has not left my home since I got my tablet.  So the table is the only device that I have used with this mifi device.  Virgin Mobile has changed its plans since last year; instead of the $40 per month for unlimited use they now offer 10 megabytes for 10 days, or 500 megabytes for a month, or 3.5 gigabytes for a month.  In my case the 500 megabytes per month for 20 dollars option has been sufficient because much of the time I do have wifi access.Speed with this mifi device has been noticeably slower than my home or office broadband connections, but a lot faster than I remember from dialup days.  Not suitable for video or voip, but quite acceptable for general web surfing to check email, read the news and weather, use online banking, etc.

Ok...let me say this...my system consists of a Windows 7 (64bit) desktop (with an attached ethernet cord) and a Windows 7 (32bit) laptop...I run an E1500 Linksys Powerboost wireless router...I need a wireless ethernet bridge for an older device and my new N wireless system...Now please read the rest to save your sanity...a)  PAY ATTENTION TO THE PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:  I didn't want to order a refurbished device but I did by accident...a new one will cost you the same amount...so...if after you read this...buy the new device...my bad...b)  THIS IS AN 'OLDER DEVICE':  The device's drivers are set up for Vista at the latest...so...hang in there...but...read on...b)  DO NOT GET THIS DEVICE IF YOUR COMPUTER'S SYSTEM ONLY RUNS WINDOWS 7 64BIT:  this device will NOT set up with the CD on a W7 64bit system...it will not recognize the set up CD and the is NO SUPPORT for a 64bit Windows 7 system for this adapter on the Linksys site....BUT...c)  THIS DEVICE WILL ATTEMPT TO SET UP ON WINDOWS a 32BIT SYSTEM (WHY - I DON'T KNOW):  I'm fortunate - I researched forums for this device and everyone stated a 64bit W7 system will not work for set up BUT a 32 bit will...I was fortunate to have a Windows 7 32 bit laptop...the setup CD was recognized...HURRAY...but wait...read on...d)  PLEASE READ MY SET UP ISSUES AND IT MAY SAVE YOUR TIME AND SANITY (PART I):  Ok, run the set up...it will ask you to give a password for your bridge...(please remember it for when your set up fails and you have to enter it again)...follow the directions through...use the connect button approach...if your bridge doesn't connect using the CD (they didn't work for me)...go to PART II (e) of my directions...e)  PART II IF THE CD SET UP FAILS:  Ok, your CD set up failed you and you have a Windows 32bit operating system (good)...and I tried everything to make it work, didn't think it was working...but oddly, I noticed the wireless signal was on on the bridge...hmmmmm...ok...You'll need to get into your web based interface for your router...I used my router's install CD to get me in but you can use the dedicated router's web address and it will prompt you for your router's security info....when you're in...click on your router's "Wireless" tab...Please read all the info. in the 'wireless' section...'cause it gives you a few options to connect a wireless device...and here's what I did...after you've tried to connect the device through the CD...now it's time to ignore the CD...keep the bridge's power ON...unhook the ethernet cable from your router and attach it to the device you want to use it with...ok...turn on that device...next...click the button (a symbol with TWO ARROWS) on the ROUTER's web control panel to search for a wireless device you want to connect...now...a message will appear letting you know you should physically push the similar button on the wireless device you want to connect (this ethernet bridge)...ok...push the button on the ethernet bridge and hold it until the blue light appears under it...it will try to connect for awhile...and...FOR ME ANYWAY...lo and behold......it connected into my wireless system...and it's running...celebration!!!Now, if you want to try any of the other methods on the router's web interface...the number registration key for the bridge is on the bottom of the ethernet bridge (next to the symbol with the two arrows) but you shouldn't have to use it because the ARROW buttons do the same thing...I can only guess that the difficulty of setting something like this up is because this device is becoming a bit outdated...the days of needing an ethernet bridge are coming to a close...most devices that can go wireless have wireless capability internally installed these days...simply detect wireless in your area...and ask for login to connect...given that the support for this device goes up to Vista...that would make sense.I posted this for those of us who need a device like this for an "older" device without wireless capability to hook into your system... (ethernet only)...my device is a BBQ controller that's only 5 years old...(I use to use a trusty and easy to set up Buffalo Ethernet Converter...with my Buffalo G-router - a great system)...the new BBQ controller they sell now has wireless built in...which is the way it's all going...but...I didn't want to spend the extra $$ on a new one...so...thank god I got this to work...:)...GOOD LUCK EVERYONE!!
summary: Horrific Set Up for Something So Basic

My very first impression of this router was that the range at 2.4GHz was not too impressive. Slightly worse than a much older/cheaper router I was using. And don't forget, while 5Ghz is faster, the range is much shorter, so I won't diss this router's range on that front.What saves this router for me, and gets me to recommend it to everyone, is the storage port. Plug a large external drive into this router, and you can stream media from it to the whole house, without needing a dedicated computer for the job. I can't emphasize how handy that is! You can also use it for backups with a little bit of configuring.There is also a printer port, for those without a wifi printer, who have previously needed a dedicated computer for one (hopefully the same one they used for media). Personally, I have a wifi printer, so can't comment on that feature.I found the user interface fairly straight forward and user friendly, however, for those that want it, people have been able to flash DD-WRT to this router. I haven't done it, and I haven't read if you can still use the external ports on it if you do. I personally doubt you would be able to, so if you can confirm one way or the other, please leave a comment.Pros:Storage port, for streaming media and/or running backupsPrinter port, for those who need itEasy interfaceWireless on/off switch, right on the router, is pretty handyAble to flash DD-WRT (Haven't seen anything on Tomato yet)Cons:Range is not very goodI saw this warning on OpenWrt "Security warning: unpatched http/tftp backdoor in original firmware". So I hope this is quickly resolved
summary: Range not amazing, but extras are very nice

reviewText: I bought these at $99.00 new on a shopping channel and I am glad I did.The sound is great and the bluetooth works well.  I used six  songs to testthe phones : The Sign ; Blurred Lines ; Tears In Heaven; Wake Me Up When SeptemberEnds and Gloria Estefan's  Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me and Maroon 5's "Nothing Lasts Forever". The latter has to be heard to be believed! These songs emphasize highs and lows and really test  the reproduction sensitivity of the phones quite well. For those who say there is not enough bass, listen to Maroon 5's "Moves Like Jagger" and then say that again.I love the sound and recommend it only if you pay no more than $150. At that price you get great sound and save money on premium phones. I would buy these again.Edit: The post on the left smaller metal band broke.  I couldn't use them any more because the larger band is too big for me.  Was able to exchange them since it was looked at as a "defected" pair. I also purchased the on-ear non-bluetooth version and I absolutely LOVE them! Got the JBL JB55A (Edit: the left cup just fell off one day due to poor design choice) set as well, and they have an over-all wonderful sound, far worth the $90 paid (free shipping on top of it).Addition: I purchased two on-ear ($54 @ ShopHQ), wired-only versions, and for some reason they have a different sound signature that actually sounds better than the BT version in either wired or bt mode. Go figure!

Ack! Ack! I thought at the cost of this keyboard, but let me leap ahead to my conclusion:For a Very Small keyboard which you can Always pack and use Everywhere wirelessly via Bluetooth ,this is one great keyboard. I also make the point below that your interface may be more important than the device you use this with.I have used a lot of keyboards, cussed at a lot of keyboards. Many hinder me to make a lot of errors, which I have tediously fixed. On the road with laptops, notebooks, or using a co-worker's machine, or trying an internet place in a foreign country -- I have pounded out many keystrokes on some strange keyboards. It's okay when the work gets out,  but most other keyboards really slow me down.  The worst keyboards have layouts that suddenly send you skiterring all over your work to some place you never expected to be. Mumph.At home I still use an IBM keyboard. At work we enjoy the best of the MS full-size keyboards. I love my expensive Think-Pad but for today it is too heavy and too valuable to go on the road. It is 2013. We use 64GB SD cards; we live in Tablet-Land (Nexus 7s with OTG) We are in a world of very cheap devices, very small light machines, solid state storage -- but we also want to work...So here's my first point:What if you had a very decent keyboard which you always took with you? Which you got reeally used to? So you were productive again? One of such quality it would last a very long time? That is what I found in this Motorola keyboard. The touch feed-back is very good. The pointer stick replaces a mouse quite well. The layout is very good. I never make mistakes anymore moving around material. It has Android function keys (which I  appreciate more because they stay put on this keyboard while my other smarty devices moves them around :)  This keyboard has Windows function keys (which I am used to)  It has Blue tooth. This KB  connects to all my computers. It has a Li-Po battery that seems to last about a month. The cover keeps stuff out of the keys when travelling. A $0.99 BT dongle I can plug into hotel computers that have attached printers. I enjoy working through my familiar keyboard.so I do not have to figure out  where is the foreign language "@" symbol...So here's my second point:The Interface is very important.You can have the coolest smart-phone, neat tablet, clever notebook or foreign computer and when you want to work -- just get stuff done -- between you, your mind, the web, your world -- then your personal interface makes a huge difference. In a world of hieroglyphics, cute ever-changing tiny icons, endlessly "updated" GUIs, the one Constant is my Keyboard. So I bring along my own: this keyboard.In that context, the price is fine.Is it as "good" as your full-sized keyboard? No, but what is better is the big one you don't have with you. This is the one you do, a very good & comfortable keyboard to work with  According to MS Word, I have written over 1,000,000 characters with this keyboard. It may well last longer than my several dropped smart-phones, broken computers, tablets or newer tools.This keyboard?  Grab one of the last few. It is a keeper for more years than I'll own any notebook or tablet.My last point:We should encourage manufacturers and Amazon shoppers to consider for road-warriors some serious "industrial" quality keyboards that merit a higher price by (1) reliably (2) delivering (3) productivity -- and that important intangible -- (4)  a superior experience.
summary: Yeah price, but a superb keyboard you'll  use for years with many  devices

I was a little skeptical after seeing some of the negative reviews, but after using the product myself, I fail to understand where those negative reviews came from. Just make sure to follow the directions closely and watch the youtube video of how to put the screen protector on. The process is not super simple, but it isn't hard either.The instructions ask you to turn off the tablet, then use the supplied solution to wet your fingers and both sides of the screen protector. Then it will ask you to use the supplied piece of plastic to push excess moisture away. If you make a mistake, it isn't the end of the world. You can try as many times as you need to in order to get it perfect. There is also a tiny screen protector for the button, which I think is a funny and nice touch.After applying the screen protector and letting it dry, I noticed tiny bubbles forming under the protector. The instrutions state that this is normal and the spots will go away in a few days. That is true. The spots went away in two days and now the screen protector sits on the screen perfectly.In summary, this is an excellent product. I highly recommend it. This may not be the cheapest screen protector out there, but it is by no means expensive and it is well worth the extra money. The screen protector sits on my ipad and I can't tell it is there unless I look at the edges closely. Thank you for such a wonderful product.

Years ago, All Pro Sound wired my house, but I found my receiver shut off when listing to the music in 3 rooms. Investigation in the attic found that they had wired 3 speaker pairs in parallel with 1 speaker output, dropping the combined speaker resistant to 2 ohms!  Separating the speaker wiring and 2 speaker wire drops from the attack to the family room later, and now 4 speaker pairs were ready to be wired to the receiver. Even though a little more expensive than some similar items, positive reviews on Amazon clinched the deal for this device. Installation was easy. Now all the speakers in 4 rooms play wonderfully at high volume, and the receiver does not turn off due to overload.

There is beautiful, pure  and unadulterated sound produced by these earphones.  The sound is bright and, in audiophile terms, has much brilliance, (not too much because the sibilance is perfect).  But somehow--for my ears, this accuracy and clarity lacked presence and seemed a bit thin--until I found the right type of music.Hard to explain, but it sounded like the music was being played in a void:  For a lot of popular music, it lacked the depth, lushness and warmth of other Brainwavz earphones in this price range.  But, I must admit, that after listening through them for many weeks, they do deserve their place in my box of earphones.There are times when I am listening to music that I consider, "pure and clean and crisp":  That is the time for these earphones.  But, I do not think they do an outstanding job on rock music.Their sound is "juicy", (which means it has energy and life), but the sound is also "liquid", (which means it is a bit texture-less); the sounds in the music really gush through the melody.If you are a "new" audiophile, it would be fun to try these first, before you are introduced to an earphone that pushes a lot of bass.  I do not appreciate a whole lot of bass, but I do like it emphasized a bit more than these do. So, these took a little while to get used to.  After the first rock album I played, I was saying "No, do not like."  After a week of playing a lot of different music through these earphones, I was saying, "Hey, these a really pretty decent for the price!"  After another two weeks of using these, I just happened to play an album of strictly tango music.  It gave me goose bumps, and I knew I had finally found their niche in my music world.  I played that album over and over and over.  (And was finally ready to write my review.)  And, now I know--in my own mind--what type of music sounds fantastic with these earphones.Not being very expensive, I think they are definitely worth a try.  You may find the experience worthwhile, as I did.  Plus, the earphones are very, very comfortable and light.  I never get tired of them in my ears.*I received a sample product from Brainwavz.
summary: If you like pure, liquid, juicy sound, you will like these earphones

reviewText: I saw a few negative reviews on this but I'm not sure why as I ultimately had no issue with this product.  I first had to overcome my own lack of knowledge of setting up two monitors with an iMac but a few google searches later (i.e. detecting the correct display resolution and how to position the Dock on the correct monitor) I was all up and running.  I'm using it at 1440x900 and 60Hz for an HP w1907.  The image quality is as good as it can get on this display so I'm very pleased with having saved >60% over an OEM adapter.  Bottom line, would do again.Update 11/28/2011:I had no problem using this on a HP monitor at 1400x900 resolution but when I used it on my ASUS monitor at 1920x1200 @ 60Hz it would not support that resolution.  The description does say 1920x1200 at "reduced blanking video resolution"  what ever that means...  Either way, for less then $10 I don't regret it, I was able to use it for over a month...

The cable works perfectly with my Ipod Classic. I am glad I got it for the price that I paid for the two that I ordered.

I bought this because it was the size I wanted for my main computer monitor. I was happy with it initially, so I also bought a 27" ViewSonic unit to use as a secondary monitor. After using it for a while I noticed that text is rendered very poorly on the 32" monitor. The 27" is OK (but not spectacular), but the 32" is unacceptable. It looks as if they took the pixels from the 27" unit and just placed them further apart and left gaps between them. On the plus side, this monitor is energy efficient, and the price is excellent. It is fine for movies and color photos; but when I work with text it is poor. I think I saw one comment in this string about the monitor being too large for the number of pixels and it not being the fault of the monitor. That may be part of the problem, but I just moved the input screen for this comment to my 40" Toshiba TV monitor and it is easier to read (but not perfect) with the same number of pixels.
summary: Images Good - Text Rendering Not Good

This shielded audio extension cable is quite flexible, even though it has a larger diameter PVC jacket.  The jacks are gold plated, and there is a short spacer at the base, so that the pin can still make solid contact even if it is inserted into the audio port of a device that is protected by a hard plastic case.From what I can tell, the cord does a good job of transmitting signals.  The larger size makes it slightly more bulky than an economy grade cord, which could be inconvenient in some applications.This cable was provided for evaluation.  It seems to be a high quality product, but the cost is perhaps three times as much as an economy grade cord.  Given its properties, it would probably be most useful in an application where the cord mostly remains static, like a home stereo system, or car audio system.
