I am waiting on the 32 GB to get to the old 16 GB price.  You will not be disappointed with this flash drive.  Good deal for the money.

I am currently a Lingo VOIP customer, and I pay about $25 per month for unlimited phone calling, local and long distance, all over the US, Canada, and about 17 countries in Europe. (Vonage, which is like Lingo costs a few more dollars than Lingo per month.) I have switched over to using Ooma, and now I pay $0 (zero) dollars per month to make unlimited local and long distance calls all over the US. If I had a cable modem, I could disconnect my regular phone line, and use Ooma exclusively. If you use DSL, which is what I have, it depends on your phone line for the connection, but you can strip down the phone line, still get your DSL through, and use it just for incoming calls, and place the rest of your incoming, or outgoing calls on the Ooma line. No more expensive local calling package, features which are all included with Ooma, or long distance charges.Ooma connects to your broadband connection right at the modem. It does not hook up to your computer. Your computer does not need to be running. It literally has nothing to do with your computer, just your modem. Your broadband modem is on all of the time, so is your Ooma telephone.When you use the Ooma phone you use it over your regular phone system, cordless, or wired telephone. When you pick up your regular phone that you now use to make a phone call, you hear a dial tone, and make a call, the same exact thing goes on with Ooma. Once you pop for the purchase price of the Ooma device, it is possible to say goodbye to your phone bill. Although it is recommended that you keep a basic regular phone line for making 911 calls for example, if in case the power goes out. If you lose electricity, you will lose your internet connection, and your Oooma phone usage.I talk to a lot of people about VOIP, which is "Voice Over Internet Protocol", and a lot of them don't have the foggiest notion of what I am talking about. I realize that I am in the middle of Amazon, tech savvy central, but for those who are new to VOIP, I started this review, very clear, and plainly. Now let's get excited about what this phone does.I love the fact that you are really getting 2 phone lines in one, although they operate under the same phone number. For the life of me, I can't see any reason not to classify it as a totally separate phone line. You can plug 2 different phones into it, 2 different people can pick up those phones, and make private phone calls, you can join those 2 calls together and make a conference call out of it, by simply pressing down on the 2 top buttons on the Ooma console hub, or scout, at the same time. So if I am on the Ooma phone, and another call comes in, the second phone will ring, or you can let the voice mail take it. Someone else can take the second phone call, on a separate phone. You need to buy an inexpensive Ooma scout, which is like a mini Ooma hub, with all the same features, and buttons in order to fully take advantage of all of second line features. Like using a totally separate second phone with it. The scout is like they took the bottom right corner of the Ooma control hub, and cut out the controls including the speaker out of it.Ok if I can I digress but just for a moment. I love the blue light. I have little red lights on my cordless phone console, and the Ooma sitting next to it, with the clear tab extending out the top of the phone, which glows blue is something that I get a charge out of seeing. It glows when the phone is on during any time of the day, but when I turn the lights down to watch TV, or off at the end of the night, and see the red and blue accent lights on the consoles, I get a rush out of that. Ok, sorry, back to the features.The other thing I like about Ooma is that you can send a fax with it. Lingo doesn't send faxes with there regular service. You do have to dial 99 before sending a fax, but that is a small inconvenience to being able to send faxes nationwide, without a bill, as in totally free.The sleep button is something that is worth the price of the phone alone. It may not be important to you, but if you have your Ooma hooked up to a wireless phone with multiple stations around the house like I do, and sure enough someone is calling you, and ringing the phone when you are taking a power nap, or at 7 am in the morning. With just one button, it silences all the phones in your house, and goes into voice mail mode.The other thing I like about Ooma is that unlike Lingo, which is really just a dumb terminal, you hook up to where it comes into the house, Ooma is really a professional workstation. Even though your voicemail is stored on the Ooma servers, something you can access from anywhere on the web, the call light flickers on the voice mail button to let you know you got a call. It is like having a fully functional answering machine console, even though the calls are stored by the Ooma service. Let's call this advanced technology.The biggest advantage to Ooma is the clear strong signal. I do not hear any difference between my land line and the Ooma line. With Lingo, I get very good sound quality, but it technically is weaker, so much so, that sometimes when asked to press 1, to get through the techno operators, it does not register, and I have to passively sit by and wait until it runs out of options and rings through to the operator. Not so with Ooma. Both of the services that I had that problem with in Lingo, work perfectly with Ooma.The console also has a trash can button, so with a single push, your saved message can be deleted while hearing it. (Plus Ooma stores deleted messages for 14 days for you, just in case you accidentally deleted another family members message, and want to retrieve it.) The Ooma lounge is the online web site, where you can access all of that, plus a lot more. It is Ooma central so to speak.This review is getting really long, because I am really excited about the new Ooma freedom. One last thing I want to share with you is that I tried to use this Ooma phone in conjunction with the Lingo VOIP service. Although it works, but because you are sharing the same modem to connect through, it creates a slight hum when the phone is in use. I don't know why but when I turn off the Lingo adapter, the Ooma is perfectly quiet, the hum goes away. So from my experiment, I am going to use the Ooma phone without the Lingo line.That makes the hookup something of interest. Normally you hook up your Ooma device directly into your broadband modem, then hook up your computer, or network router, into the Ooma device. So the Ooma takes precedence. I didn't do it that way. I have a network, and I want to give my internet connection the same priority as the Ooma hub, so I use an old Linksys router, and connect the modem directly to it, in one of the 4 middle positions, (not in the WAN port) so it strictly acts like a switch with no processing, and then hook the Ooma device up to one of the other 4 available connections on the router, and do the same with the network. So it goes from modem, to a splitter so to speak (switch ports on the router, or you could use a dedicated switch) then into whatever other devices I want. In this case the Ooma hub, and my network receive the same priority, and it works great. I do not realize any bandwidth speed differences using my 1.5 meg DSL connection with the Ooma device hooked up to it.I knew that the other reviews, and the Ooma description covers the features really well, so it was my intention to cover some of the other more interesting aspects of using the phone. Hope this helps. Get the Ooma hub, I understand they have a 30 day return policy. When you add up what your phone bills are costing you, it doesn't take long to recapture the purchase price, let alone that you may have free phone service for the next 3 years, 10 years, or a lifetime for that matter. This is a Wow.
This OEM disc is nearly essential for every PC-builder out there; not to mention that Windows 7 is leaps and bounds above the soon-to-come Windows 8.

Bought the R1200-1D to power two 400w Rockford P3D4-12's in a sealed box. Wired (externally) in parallel to a 1ohm, which Rockford's birth certificate rates at 1,337w RMS, giving each P3 just over 600w RMS of actual power. A bit overkill but powers them very cleanly without needing a whole lot of gain.My previous amp was the monstrous T5002 which I owned for about 7 years. This little Prime Class D amp knocks that Power amp out of the water! Has most of the same features, infrasonic filter and punch eq.Drawback to the R1200-1D are the weirdness that is the internal parallel option. The idea is that you can connect 2 subs directly to the amp independently at Speaker A and Speaker B and the amp would manage the bridge/parallel. I couldn't make it work properly. The subs would go out of phase. Worked fine when I bridged the subs externally and hooked them up to Speaker A.The other problematic feature is the external Punch EQ remote knob. I'll need to play with it a bit more to figure out just what is suppose to do, but from the first impression, when its dialed down to 0, the subs are basically turned off. Then when I turn it up it makes weird adjustments to the subs performance.The way I have it set up now is perfect and exactly what I want out of an amp:- Minimal Gain: set to 3 right now- Infrasonic Filter set high- Disconnected Remote EQ- Punch EQ on the Amp set to 0- Crossover set high and controlled from the headunit
summary: Huge power in a compact box! Easy to install and tuck away.

I have a Dell PowerEdge 2900 III.  In my apartment, that thing is just too loud.  I bought six of these fans to replace the ones inside my server since these are supposed to move the same amount of air with lower RPM, and thus, do so quieter.I had to remove the leads that came on the fans and solder the proprietary Dell leads from the old fans onto these, but that was easy.  These fans fit the Dell fan carriers, even though they weren't as deep.The BMC in the server had a problem, though.  It saw the fans running at a much lower RPM, freaked out, then ramped them up to full-speed before slowly ramping back down.  This would repeat every five minutes or so.  I had to hack the firmware in the BMC to tolerate the new lower RPM.Anyway, long story short, these fans are truly quiet and are worth every penny.
summary: Great replacement for loud server fans

reviewText: My Bose experiences with headphones have included the QuietComfort 3 for a couple months and a little time trying out SoundTrue in around-ear style.  These on-ear SoundTrue headphones are much lighter than the other 2 I'd tried out, and come in a more compact case.  For those who travel often, those 2 considerations may make the SoundTrue on-ear style convenient for packing.  I found the build of the on-ear style to seem not quite as sturdy.  In terms of comfort of the earpieces, the material is soft and headpiece doesn't pinch which is always a plus for long wear times.Sizing of the earpieces is significantly smaller than the around-ear style in SoundTrue line from Bose -- for those looking for a more streamlined look to their headphones, the on-ear ones fit the bill.Having been accustomed to the noise-cancelling QuietComfort 3 (as well as the more heavy-duty SoundTrue around-ear Bose) I found these SoundTrue on-ear headphones let a lot of ambient noise in while listening to music.  I can't speak to how much sound they may leak out to the area around you when in use.  For anyone looking to drown out the noise with music, the on-ear version will be somewhat disappointing.  However, if lightweight, compact and decent sound are priorities, the Bose SoundTrue on-ear headphones delivers all 3 factors and comes in a couple of color schemes to choose from.

I was looking for a reasonably price TV for the bedroom. I always go for the best of the best when making these kind of purchases. It was hard to wrap my mind around buying a TV that I hadn't seen and was not a Sony. The price however was right and it didn't need to have all the bells and whistles for a bedroom TV. The TV is awesome and I am very impressed by the picture. HD at 1080p through a Blu-ray source is perfect. The 1080i signal through Dish Network also looks great. I'm so glad I picked this TV. The design is nice and the sound is very good! When I decide to purchase a new TV to replace the Sony 57 inch projection TV Vizio will be first on my list. If they can make a "Cheap" TV look this good I can't imagine what there top of the line TV's look like.My dark room settings:Picture Mode: CustomBacklight: 60Brightness: 50Contrast: 75Color: 60Tint: 0Sharpness: 0Color Temperature: CustomRed Gain: 132Green Gain: 130Blue Gain: 130Red Offset: 128Green Offset: 128Blue Offset: 128Smooth Motion Effect: OffReal Cinema Mode: Off (Grayed out)Noise Reduction: OffMEG NR: OFFColor Enhancement: NormalAdaptive Luma: OffFilm Mode: AutoBacklight Control: OffAmbient Light Sensor: OffHope this helps, at least this will get you to a good starting point to adjust for personal preference. I think the colors and skin tones looks great, black levels are also very nice.

I have had several MP3 players and I like the Sansa M240 a lot.  I use it for both music and Audible files, and it works well.  It and the Creative MuVo N200 are the only ones I have been able to walk with for over 3 months and have not needed to be serviced.  Rio replaced my Forge several time and I have had to take the iPod (4th gen) in twice, but maybe it's because I racewalk at 7 to 10 MPH? (depending on how I feel and traffic lights)  Walking that speed is easy on the knees but hard on anything attached to you. :)Note to Audible users, be sure your player has Firmware 1.03 (highest available when I wrote this).  For a quick check, press the center button when an Audible file is playing and look for a "CH" in the lower right corner.  If it's there, then it's updated and will support chaptering (in Play only) and will fast forward and rewind correctly.While the Creative MuVo N200 and SanDisk Sansa m240 will both play Audible files, the Sansa is my prefered player because of the chapter support, menu support and better display.  For just music when walking, the Creative wins for size and weight.Someone asked about crackle with Audible files and Yes I get both crackle and dropouts, though I get a lot less playing Format 3 instead of format 4 files.  On the Sansa M240, there really isn't a lot of sound quality difference between 3 and 4 like there is on the hard drive players or the Rio Forge.The Sansa M240 is not perfect, but if you want a durable lite-weight player that is battery powered - it's the best I have found.  I like it enough to upgrade to the M250 before my next camping trip.  (I would consider an iPod Nano, but how could I recharge it in the woods?)

HP Bluetooth ExpressCard Laser Scroll Mouse with Laser Pointer.  Seller (BuyFromScott) packed item fine and arrived in new condition.  Bluetooth Mouse worked, but its built-in laser pointer did not light up.  Got a prompt refund from BuyFromScott (FulfillmentByAmazon).Update 02Mar2011:  Another reviewer posted that the mode button on the bottom changes the mouse to presenter mode.  I was able to get mine into presenter mode, but the laser did not light up.Update 08Jun2011:  I got a refund for the first mouse which had a defective laser.  I received a new one today.  The laser pointer and red LED work on this one.  In presenter mode, the red LED flashes about once every five seconds, just like the blue LED flashes about once every five seconds in mouse mode.  In my first one, the red LED and Laser pointer never turned on although it did switch from mouse to presenter mode.The blue LED flashes once per second when pairing.  The green LED stays on solid until the mouse is fully charged in the X54 slot, then it shuts off.I couldn't find a manual for this mouse from HP, but I found a manual for a similar mouse from id8-mobile.  The HP version lacks the nifty On-Off switch that the ID8-MOBILE version has. See my comment to this review for the link.Here's some text from the manual.MoGo Mouse X54 Pro Battery LifeOnce you turn on your MoGo Mouse X54 Pro with the slide switch, it doesnot need to be switched off. The mouse turns off automatically when chargingin the slot. The MoGo Mouse uses a number of hibernation states in orderto save battery power when not in use. Leaving the mouse untouched for 10minutes or if the Bluetooth signal becomes unavailable to the mouse, willcause the mouse to fall asleep. To wake up your MoGo Mouse simply movethe mouse to re-activate the connection. (Note: initially, you must pair theMoGo Mouse X54 Pro to the laptop before this can occur.)If the indicator LED turns solid red, the battery is very low and needs to berecharged. To charge or store the MoGo Mouse X54 simply close the kickstandand insert it into the Expresscard/54 slot. To turn on your MoGo Mouse aftercharging, simply move the mouse to wake the mouse up.Pairing Your MoGo Mouse X54 Pro with another LaptopFor further support go to [...]Multi-Mode OperationsYour MoGo Mouse X54 Pro features a mouse modeand a presenter mode.Mouse mode allows the same functionality asconventional laser wireless mice - scroll, rightclick, left click. Presentation mode allows the mouseto function as a wireless presentation tool. It iscomplete with a slide changer (forward and backward),a start/escape button and a laser pointer you can use tohighlight important elements of your presentation.Once the mouse has been paired with your computer, you can toggle through modesby pressing the "Mode" button on the back of the MoGo Mouse for one second.MOUSE MODE________________________Green: The battery is charging.No Light: The battery is fully charged.Solid Red: Battery is low.Blue: Bluetooth communication.Quick Flashing = Pairing ModeSlow Flashing = Paired and operatingnormallyLong Flash = Waking up andestablishing communicationPRESENTER MODE______________________Green: The battery is charging.No Light: The battery is fully charged.Solid Red: Battery is low.Flashing Red: Laser Pointer ActiveFlashing Blue: Bluetooth is on.
summary: Laser pointer in presentation mode may not work on yours.

reviewText: I've had a pair of Shure E2C in-ear headphones since about 2004. The cords were starting to fray, so I wanted to replace them with another noise canceling option that would be more comfortable, not to mention cleaner and less wasteful, than jamming disposable foam pieces into my ear canals every day.I also don't want to spend $300 for Bose headphones. So I decided to trust the Sony brand name and pony up the cost of these headphones instead. I've got other Sony products that I really like.On the upside, typical of Sony products, these headphones are very sleek and well-designed. A nice leatherette case is included, which holds the phones and an adapter, as well as a space for an extra battery. The battery holder does not detach from the body of the control piece, another nice touch for people who are prone to losing that sort of thing. The headphones fold up very small, and are very light. The earpieces themselves are very soft and quite comfortable, kind of feeling like "memory foam." The sound quality when turned on is pretty good - a little mushy and overly bassy, but vocals and instruments can easily be made out, and there is very little hiss.Now for the bad news: they don't "cancel" a heck of a lot of noise. At all. Not even a little bit. I tried these headphones on a Chicago city bus, a Chicago CTA "el" train, and outdoors in moderately windy conditions. These headphones canceled absolutely no talking noises, very little ambient droning, and very little of the loud sorts of noises you'll hear on a subway train. When I walked from my bus to my home, the wind overwhelmed the sound easily. I was, needless to say, extremely disappointed, especially having tried out the Bose product, and having used the Shure product for several years.I think the Sony's problems are three:1. The earpieces do not surround the ear, thus passively blocking outside noise. They are simply too small.2. The active noise canceling hardware is designed only to cancel out low frequency hums, not higher frequency loud noises (which basically account for 95% of the noise you'll encounter in the world).3. In the off position, not only do they neither isolate nor cancel ambient noise, they also sound terrible - power is required to amplify the sound and give it a relatively rich tone. Turned off, these headphones just don't sound very good.In the end, they just ended up being a decent-sounding regular pair of headphones which use up batteries in order to get good sound. Pretty lame, if you ask me. I knew there would be a difference, since in-ear headphones passively block a lot more noise. But I did not expect this much of a dropoff in noise reduction, especially for the price.I guess I'll have to stick with the Shure "earplug" phones, and tape up the cords with electrical tape. At least until I win the lotto and can afford the Bose headphones. Sigh...
summary: Underperforming noise "canceling" simply not worth the money

reviewText: I wasn't blown away by this camera but it seems to be as good and reliable as the others I've tried.  It seems a little unstable with the pan and tilt controls so I'm penalizing it a little for that.  I also noticed some fisheye effect.

If you wish to have longer battery life & want your camera to look more professional -this is the way to go. It's a convenitent way to carry two batteries. Super handy when shooting vertical shots.Only bad things.... it's a piece of plastic & is no way near in build of the D200. Still I like it a lot. My next camera (ordered the D300) will immediately, when available, have a grip - cause that grip is built much sturdier & will allow for 8 fps with stronger batteries. I really find myslef enjoying having a grip for my D200 & from now on will probably always get them.
summary: Handy & makes camera look very professional

reviewText: There is something disheartening about an advanced piece of equipment from an industry leader and having it largely unusable because of taking no care with small but critical details.  In this case, the mounting "hardware".  Well, as if you could call cheap vinyl suctionless cups hardware.These units need proper placement to be effective.  The windshield mount is below defective.  It is unusable junk.  I understand this is the entry-level model in the new line.  But for this much money, charge me the extra three dollars for something that works.  To have to spend another thirty dollars for a third party mount is a disgrace.  Having to wait another week to try it out was not so bad, but it still compounds the infraction.Furthermore, the dashboard "mount" was an insulting stick `em that was not even worth attempting.  It was like buying expensive hiking boots with cardboard laces.  Or a 25 quart copper stockpot with no handles, only to find that you can pay extra to buy a pair from another company.I also had the supermarket parking lot experience.  The doors drove the Cobra batty.  If I were to do it all again, I would move up three models to get the Intellishield false signal rejection.
Good, reliable product. Don't waste your money on high priced hdmi cables at Best Buy.  I bought these cables to work with my Roku boxes and they work great.

reviewerName: Bona   Na Croin ""Neither your collar nor...
reviewText: I bought the first Kindle Fire as soon as it was announced, and I pre-ordered my 7" Fire HD 32GB as soon as it was announced.  I played around with it quite a bit last night as soon as it arrived and am very impressed with how much better it is than my original Kindle Fire.  I tested music and video running from the Cloud, Netflix, HBO GO,  and from the device.  Streaming from the Cloud was smooth and consistent with almost no buffering time, runs streaming video faster than my Sony Blu-Ray.  There were no interruptions during the viewing to re-buffer either.  The combination of my own dual-band router, coupled with the dual band of the Fire HD presents flawless high def viewing experience. The external volume control is also a big improvement. Bothe the power and volume buttons are a bit hard to find by touch, however, but I am sure that aafter using it longer the locations will become second nature.  I do like the thinner profile of the Fire HD over the 1st gen device, looks and feels more like my Samsung Galaxy S3, easy to hold and light weight.Drawback so far for me are that the speaker, though an improvement over the 1st gen, still lack sufficient volume or bass.  There are currently no speaker dock systems available that I have seen for the Fire HD, but that would be a welcome accessory for the Fire HD.  I have not been able to test the front facing camera so this is more a critique of the Skype app, but you can test the audio using their Echo test feature, but I could not find anywhere to actually test the camera.  It is also a bit dissapointing that though I have 5GB of cloud storage that no longer applies to MP3 files that you have uploaded, you must purchase a seperate MP3 cloud storage for $24.99 a year.  With the 32GB of on board storage it may not even be necessary since you will be able to store all of your music  on the device itself, so I may not keep that beyond a year, it was just the quickest way to get all the MP3's that I had already placed in my Cloud to the new Fire HD.  I think that with the improvements that they made it is still a terrific value for the price.
summary: An improvement over 1st gen. but not perfect

reviewText: I received my TomTom 540S on Thursday.  On Friday, I unpacked it and immediately found a bit of problem.  The front of the box says in big letters TomTom 540S XXL.  The large screen version.  On the back of box in very small print it said:  In the box 530S (plus the various cables).Next I did the updates as suggested.  When doing this the screen said that new software was installed for the 530S.Immediately, I called TomTom to see what the problem was.  (I did get to talke with customer support quickly.)  They checked the serial number and it matched for the 540.  And said it would function as a 540.  The lady said she was 99% sure that there was a problem at TomTom's end on updating their own software names.I tried it out later in the day and it appears to work as a 540.  It does give the lane to be in...this along with the larger screen and route planning are the reasons I got the 540.  Time will tell if this in correct.All other features seem to be working correctly.This is my third TomTom.  Also have owned a Magellean and Garmin of compariably price.  I like the features on the TomTom much better.  It does better route production and it always seems to be the best route at a particular time of day.  Another feature that I like and use is being able to sit in my livingroom and plan out a exact route to use for a road trip.  I have done old route 66, the Lincoln Highway and several others.  With the route plugged in, I never had to refer to a map.  This is a big plus for several reasons...not the least of which is the co-pilot can view the scenery without having their face stuck to the map.I do have three complaints that could easily be corrected.1.  When you reach a waypoint or destination, it should tell which side of the street it is located.2.  More memory or SD slot for inputting routes or doing updates.  I am aware that there is another model of 540S (world model) that has an SD slot but costs about $50 more.3.  I was just trying to input a route that we are considering to visit all the lower 48 states in a continuous loop.  I had to break it down into 3 segments.  It would be nice if TomTom said there were limited number of waypoints that could be entered.4.  As I have said, this is the third TomTom I have owned.  The other two broke after about 18 months each.  The 910 (top of the line at time of purchase) had the hard drive go out.  The 340 had the processor fail after about 18 months.  It was just not economically sense to have them repaired.  It would really be nice is TomTom could improve their longevity.So far as Amazon goes (I bought all three from them), I have nothing but good to say about them.  The price is excellent and the shipping is great.  All arrive in less time than they project.ncpipingbob

I use this on my Nikon D700. It works great, and is ideal for landscape, portrait, and other still photography. Users may experience some lag when it comes to doing sports photography. Overall, this memory card is a great value, general purpose card. For action photography, you should consider a faster card.

My wife and I have shopped the smallest digital cameras for a few years and for one reason or another have never been able to take the plunge.  Maybe part of it is that we've been using higher resolution, more fully-featured digtal cameras and have been unwilling to accept the compromises of their smaller siblings.  But finally, I've found the camera for us - small enough to stay in my wife's purse or clipped to my climbing harness, yet flexible and high quality enough to not make us cringe when the images are printed.The D-40 shares the strengths common to Olympus cameras: excellent optics, flexibility of operation, high quality of manufacture and excellent image quality.  Unfortunately, the major problems common to older Olympus digital cameras are still existant: mediocre software, a non-rechargable battery and a tiny media card.The D-40 lens is excellent for a camera of this size and price, resulting in superior image sharpness, even at the wide angle limit where most consumer digital cameras suffer.  It's zoom range is equivalent to 35 to 98mm on a 35mm camera and the aperture is f 2.8.  The camera weighs under 7 ounces and it is tiny, easily fitting in a shirt pocket.  Standard AA batteries will work with the D-40 if the standard lithium battery dies and you can't find them locally.I'm psyched up that we'll be carrying a camera with us to more places.  We've missed too many photo opportunities since moving from film to digital.  Our bottom line is image quality and for a compact camera, the D-40 delivers.
summary: Finally A Compact Digital Camera Worth Buying

reviewText: Picked this specific model because i'm currently running 1.65v ram and the timings match up. And at $30 it's a great priceNo Cons

My wife had accidentally dropped her laptop off the couch onto the floor and "cracking" the LED screen in the process, rendering the laptop useless.  HP wanted basically the price of a new laptop to replace the monitor so I started looking on the internet.  I found this item on Amazon and for around $56 I was able to make my useless laptop just like new again.  In my research, I found a Youtube Video that had been created for my specific HP Pavilion laptop.  This instructional video offered step by step instructions that took me through the entire process.  I have limited knowledge of these things, so don't think for a minute that I am a techie with all of the tools of the trade and knowledge accorded them.  I was SCARED to DEATH of attempting this, but after looking at the video a few times realized that it was really quite simple.  I took me about 45 minutes from start to finish and I am typing this review with the same laptop that has worked flawlessly since I replaced the screen.  You will be amazed at how easy it is and inexpensive.  Don't throw the laptop away, fix it yourself!

reviewerName: V S "Developed a $6 OBD1 Handheld in 1986"
reviewText: I probably am not fully experiencing how wonderful this device is, as I'd tested it mainly on a WinXP Pro network through a VPN and a no-mans land VN.FINALLY no more interference from the neighbor's $6 cordless phone or from his 1986 10,000W unshielded microwave.Never got to test what was on which band, assumed it was all on the higher band.The only thing I didnt like were the antennas, but placing a sheet of steel behind the antennas (was on the wall anyways) I had no dead spots anywhere in the house or outside, even if one tipped over 30 degrees.Setup took a while to read, and couldnt figure out why the QoS settings didnt take. I forget now but either I rebooted before saving, or didnt hit an "apply" button, I dont exactly remember, but thats all it was. Yeah, remember to not have QoS disabled or in manual in services.msc either lol, oops.Great item for the price, but would like to see more control over security.I was able to gain access to this device using a not-so popular linux tool to discover the hardware PIN number, thus giving me the device password (password stealers are more popular, but take a while depending on entropy)ALL COMMERCIAL ROUTERS SOLD have this "flaw", which is nothing more than a $0.25 savings per unit, so I wont penalize them for this. There isnt a router I cant get access to in anyones home with this tool, so I wont blame them if they are equal to all other routers.
summary: Great for the price. Good for avoiding interference

reviewText: For those of you with regular hard drives, I highly recommend you upgrade to an SSD. It was easy for me because I have a desktop so I just used my traditional hard drives as internal storage. For laptops, it will be a bit more tricky since you will have to utilize the cloud or external hd to maintain capacity.If you are on a tighter budget, you can get one of the other samsung 840 series; I am sure they are just fine. The package comes with the samsung disk manager and I used that to clone my windows to the SSD. It is worth mentioning that when I cloned my Windows 7, I had boot issues (needed to insert the install disk). However after a bit of debugging I got it to work. It was my first time ever cloning windows (on a personal machine) and I know that is a common error. But everything is good.FYI - if you have a desktop, make sure you have a 2.5inch hd mount for your case.

I'll agree with all the other reviews here that this case is huge and has some very smart design decisions in terms of cable management, drive mounting, etc. This all adds up to a really easy build experience that's simple enough that even first time PC builders shouldn't have much experience. There's no need to tuck away every cord because there's enough space that it doesn't matter too much.However, where this case falls short is in build quality. Even at $110, I expect a case that will last for some time. Right out of the box, this case had a dented bottom and a broken foot as others have mentioned. I emailed customer service and it took over 6 weeks to get a replacement foot (which didn't fix the dent, so I just have to live with that). Furthermore, one of the side panels as a bit of a bend in one of its curves that makes it less than easy to slide it back into place. During installation of a blu-ray drive, I found that the hinge that's supposed to keep it in place was broken (it's made of plastic after all, and had to do some rearranging so that the drive was secure. Finally, today (the impetus for this review), I was cleaning a fan off and one of the blade snapped with the tiniest bit of pressure from a paper towel.All in all, I'm  sure Antec has some smart people that know how to design cases, but cutting corners on materials means they just won't last very long. This was my first and last Antec purchase.
summary: Great design ideas, terrible build quality and customer service

reviewText: Crazy title, I know, but here was why I needed this item. I just bought a Galaxy S4 right before Christmas, and recorded tons of video and took tons of photos on Christmas Day plus a few extra days. While assembling some Ikea furniture, a plank of wood fell on top of my phone and destroyed the screen. That was sad since it was a brand new phone, but I was even more disappointed that now I couldn't get my Christmas photos/videos off of my phone.If you connect a Galaxy S4 via USB to your PC, it will not show or allow you to transfer any of the data off of it when you have a lock screen enabled, until after you enter your PIN (my photos were on the internal memory, not the micro SD card). The touchscreen was broken and I couldn't see anything on the screen, and it took me awhile to finally come up with the idea of connecting a mouse to the screen. Luckily Android supports various devices like my wireless mouse. I purchased this MicroUSB-to-USB adapter so I could connect my wireless mouse's receiver to it. But I still had the problem of not being able to see my screen or where the mouse cursor was. So I connected the mouse to my functioning replacement phone, and mapped on a piece of paper exactly the route I had to move the mouse to enter my PIN and click 'enter'. I then re-traced this route on my broken phone and after a couple tries, it worked! All my files were saved thanks to this cheap little cable. Now I can send my phone to Samsung and not worry about losing them all (they state they will factory reset & wipe it before sending it back).tl;dr version of this review: Does the job it's meant for at a great price; no complaints. I did end up spending a couple extra bucks ordering it from Amazon itself instead of one of the third-party sellers, just for the piece of mind of knowing I won't get some crappy bait-and-switch like occasionally happens when you buy third-party.

But in my experience, and I received a different one than shown from Thememstore, it doesn't even want to hold the battery in place.  Thememstore assured me this was the correct model for my camera.  But every time I get it right in the charger, the battery pops out while I'm trying to plug it in or the charge light doesn't come on if I can get it to stay in.  I'm disappointed because I bought it to be able to charge the battery while away from home, but it has not worked out.
The screen protector works well but I have been having problems getting the bubbles out, after while I just said forget and most of the bubbles ended up coming out but its still a few on my screen.

This system is great! It's well configured with an Intel Core i5 processor, 8 GB of RAM (more than enough for most) and a large TB drive. It's standard size case is a benefit in my opinion as it leaves room for upgrades in the future. As always, Amazon shipping was quick (I purchased from Amazon directly) and it met and exceeded my expectations. Don't let Windows 8.1 deter you. It's not as bad as most people make it out to be.I would encourage anyone who does not like the new Windows 8 interface to install Classic Shell [...]. It will add the start menu back for you and allow you to setup the system just like older versions of Windows but with the performance enhancements of Windows 8!
summary: An well equipped and affordable upgrade for those with Windows XP or looking for a more powerful system!

reviewText: This appears to be exactly what my daughter needs to make her new PC connect to her TV along with all the other systems she has attached.  Product is of good quality.

My 15 month old Lenovo Thinkpad Twist got a bad case of terminal BSOD. I will be working to repair, but needed an IMMEDIATE solution - a local store was offering this one at about 2/3 the price here on Amazon as a special deal, and I grabbed it.Since it is local, I did not have the "battery problem" some have experienced on other Toshiba Satellites from Amazon. I was willing to take the risk knowing the local store would stand behind the sale. I tested all of the issues others have reported (including the DVD reader - no problems) it works seamlessly.It is about 2 pounds heavier than my other computer (full weight is 5.4 pounds), but that is because it is LARGER than the other one. I love the nice bright screen, and am enjoying being able to read "stuff" better than a smaller screen. Unlike some, I use my laptop at home most of the time, and 2 pounds isn't a big deal.My last one was an ultra - I love having this one where I can replace the battery myself and have a spare on hand for long trips. I really do love having the Superdrive, meaning I can watch a DVD, play a CD, import songs, burn CDs. You don't realize how often you want these features until you have a computer without it.It responds slightly more slowly than the Lenovo I had, but well within tolerable allowances. I notice it most on loading internet pages. But slightly means just a tiny bit. It takes about four seconds longer to start up following a restart.It has a full keyboard, with a 10-key pad on the right. The keyboard is "flat" without raised keys, but have a slightly raised point on the J and F keys making it easy to find your spot.The touchpad (I use a trackball because of carpal tunnel) is configured the way I prefer, with the two buttons on the bottom.I used the memory card reader to transfer some files (some by Drop Box) and it read the card rapidly and transferred the files quickly. I am happy with that.With three USB ports, I can easily keep my trackball at hand and yet charge my iPhone if I want, and still have room to pop in a flash drive. Only one of the USB ports is 3.0, and you can change the setting to make it into a 2.0 if you want to save battery time.The screen is bright, and I am very happy with it. It is NOT touchscreen - something I am happy about. A touchscreen also is an energy hog, and I seldom used mine. Glad to go back to simple.NOTE - if you haven't used Windows 8, you will have a hard time adjusting, but that isn't the computer's fault. :-) This one comes pre-installed with 8.1 which I had already wanted. It adds functionality to Windows 8, although it doesn't compensate for everything that is a problem. You do NOT need a touchscreen to run Windows 8. I have an iPad and iPhone and am very used to touch, but didn't need it on Windows 8.While I purchased it as an "emergency" fill in, I will likely keep it as my primary laptop ... it is that good. I took off the star because I felt it was a tiny bit slower, and because I feel documentation could have been better for new users. However as an "older user" of Windows 8, everything installed seamlessly for me.
Just what I wanted, very sturdy and durable.  Love it.  Would buy again, but I doubt I'll need to any time soon.

When I first received the box I knew this was what I had been searching for.  A plain white Pioneer box with the company logo, and the pertinent information of the head unit, and this theme continues into the head unit.  It does not have navigation, it does not have a 7" touch screen, and it doesn't have all of the flashy colors.  What this unit does have is seemingly endless adjustable features for your audio needs.  If you want TRUE control over your music, if you want sound quality, if you want to make even your stock speakers sound infinitely better, this unit is what you need.  When Pioneer designed this unit, they cut corners in all the right places, in order to bring you a real Sound Quality unit, available at this price.  The 2 USB inputs, along with CD, 3.5mm headphone jack, AND and SD card slot make this a true unit.  CD's died out long ago, however many of us still have them, so to have it is nice, however I may have used it once in the couple months I've owned this, as I got a 32GB SD card, loaded most of my music onto it, and just leave the card in it and search through the folders.  You can run a full 3-way active crossover straight from the head unit, set your crossover points, crossover slopes, 16 band EQ, output level adjustability, oh yeah and ALL this is adjustable between the left and right channels Independently!  Comes with the remote, Bluetooth Mic, timealignment/auto EQ mic, USB extended cord, and of course the unit and wiring harness.  This unit is a beast, a must have for any music lover!
summary: So many choices in such a little package!

reviewText: I'd like to split this review into different sections: The Camera, Implementation and Bundled Software.I'll begin with the negative impressions first.ImplementationOne of the driving forces behind my new digital camera purchase was that I'd outgrown my old camera's capabilities. My skills had reached the point where having a camera that saves images in a RAW format was highly desirable. When screening my choices, the C-7000 came in at a reasonable price while offering this feature.I must digress for a moment here. It seems that RAW format is not a universal standard. My present imaging software, PhotoShop CS, lists RAW formats from a variety of vendors. Apparently all are unique. While the C-7000 was not specifically mentioned, the C-8080 and C-5060 were mentioned, as were several other Olympus models. Additionally, Adobe has proposed an open standard for RAW formats, dubbed DNG for Digital Negative, and the same list of cameras appears on the list of supported formats that may be converted to the DNG format. Once converted, a DNG image may be read by any program utilizing that format.At least that's the theory. Olympus seems to have changed their specs for RAW from the other cameras in their line up as neither the DNG converter nor PhotoShop, with the latest RAW reader plug-ins, is able to read an Olympus Raw Format (*.ORF) image from the C-7000. Major disappointment! Other than ORF images, I had no trouble reading any other images.Bundled SoftwareThe inability of my software to read an ORF image lead to the installation of the included Olympus Master software. Installation is painless: insert the disk and an auto-install wizard takes over. Once installed, the software is ready to go.Personally, I felt the software was aimed at a first time camera user. The interface was so simple I found it almost insulting. I mean, come on, do you really need a wizard to help you e-mail a photo or print a picture? You also don't need the software to transfer images to your PC (see The Camera, below). I found nothing in the software, or advertised features, to warrant the expense of upgrading to the "full version" at a cost of almost US$20.While the software is capable, especially if you have no other image enhancement software, there are some serious shortcomings. I hate to keep harping on the RAW format, but it's a problem here too. You are free to manipulate the image, but you can't save it to another RAW format usable by any other product. You can save the image as a JPG or TIF, but there is quality loss involved. That's what the RAW format is supposed to avoid. Olympus, PLEASE sign on to the DNG standard or at least offer the ability to convert these RAW images to the same format as your other cameras that are supported by third party imaging software.The CameraNow we're getting to the good stuff! Ten minutes after unpacking the camera, I was off and taking pictures. It's that easy. The controls were different from my old D-460, yet intuitive enough there were no major problems. Even if this was your first digital camera, I estimate you could be taking your first digital photos in less than half an hour. The setup folder is easy to follow. I used the battery without charging it and got about fifteen exposures before I ran it down. Fully charged, I'd expect about a hundred exposures before recharging.Now that I had some test shots, I wanted to see them. Without reading the manual, I simply plugged the supplied USB cable into the camera and then plugged the cable to my PC via a hub. Windows 2000 showed a notice that new device was detected and in a couple of minutes I received a notice my removable drive was ready to use. No additional disks to insert for drivers, no Internet searches for drivers or anything more complicated than finding an open USB port. Windows Explorer showed the new drive and I was able to navigate to the photos, drag `n' drop to a temporary folder and I was able to view them with my graphics viewer of choice (JPG images only). I'd expect the same to be true for Windows XP or Mac users.The only customization I'd done to this point was selecting an image size of 640 x 480 to maximize the number of images stored on the supplied 32 Mb XD flash memory. During use I was impressed with the speed it wrote to the memory. On viewing the images, I was impressed with the evenness of the exposure, accuracy of focus and quality of the flash. Using a tabletop to hold the camera steady, I did some available light work with exposures of one to two seconds length. The resolution is impressive as is the contrast of the images. I don't have any objective data to back my results, but I'd match this camera against any other fixed lens digital camera on the market. Superb optics!Another major surprise was the camera body finish. The brochure describes it as Titanium. I don't know if Olympus is describing the color or the actual material, but it certainly isn't plastic! The shell has a nice solid feel in your hands and, while I wouldn't deliberately drop it, it gives the impression of ruggedness. Holding it you feel your money was well spent.ConclusionsOverall, I'm very pleased with this camera. I bought it because I wanted something compact and rugged, yet easy to use. I bought it for the quality of the camera and the picture taking ability of the camera, not the software. In time, I'm sure my problem with the ORF images will be solved and the image format in no way interferes with the camera's abilities. I would suggest two accessories to purchasers of this camera, both of which are based on common sense, not any shortcoming of the camera.1) Get an extra battery and always keep a charged spare with you.2) Buy the highest capacity XD card you can find. You'll use it!To Olympus I'd suggest offering some conversion of this new ORF format to DNG and perhaps marketing another package that is priced to include the camera and XD memory without the proprietary software. While the software may be useful to some users, it is an unneeded duplication for others.12/23/2004Adobe has solved the problem of reading the RAW format. There is a new plug-in for PhotoShop, RAW 2.4 Beta, that allows me to read the ORF this camera generates. I still stand by my 4 star rating based on the quality, or lack there of, of the bundled software. The camera by itself earns a full 5 stars, it's the total package that suffers.
summary: Great Camera, Questionable Software, New RAW Format

reviewText: I've been using the wireless remote (ML-L3, $17) on my D90 for about a year I guess, before I finally decided to get this remote.  Why did I wait! I do a lot of tripod photography and had been using the 2sec timer, or the wireless remote.  This remote is far easier.. just plug and click at the EXACT moment that you want the pic.  I'll still use the wireless remote for certain shots (family portrait or when I am not physically at the camera) but from now on I'll be using this little gadget a lot.I nearly went for the cheap copy (for as little as $3 on amazon!) but decided to stick with the Nikon product... seriously, how much did you pay for your camera?? Spend the $25 and get the Nikon accessories. I've got all types of after-market stuff for different cameras and camcorders.. some good, some not so good.  If this remote was $50 then I might have made a different decision, but why risk damaging your electrical port or having other reliability problems for the price of a few Starbucks visits? I don't know the $3 versions are necessarily inferior, but for the money involved I'm not willing to take the risk.
summary: Great remote... not sure why I waited so long!

reviewText: If you're looking for an external storage solution with eSata, this is a great solution for home offices and SMB. As a photographer and graphic designer, I've found myself going through hard drive space like cookie monster through chocolate chips (sorry, I have kids). This is also perfect for HD video editing and other video production purposes. If I had to knock the device at all it would be only for the fact that it does not offer RAID 6 (two-drive failure integrity) and there's no management console or anything of the sort. The only control over the device is what hard drives you stick in and what RAID option you choose with the dip switches. Other wise, I've found the array to be quite quiet, speedy, and seamless in operation when going in and out of sleep mode. You may notice a longer delay starting your computer while the device spools up the drives on power-up. The best external storage solution I've had.
summary: Large Capacity, Fast Transfer, Simple Design

reviewText: I have now been fortunate enough to own several digital cameras, including a Nikon KoolPix 500, which was a 3.1MP camera released in 2000, and up until recently I had a Nikon D70 DSLR.First of all, this is a great point and shoot camera.  There are plenty of features which cater to all manner of users, from the avid professional, to an amateur with limited knowledge of camera features and functions.  The camera is compact, durable, and feels small but solid in my hands.  6.1 MP is more than adequate to produce high quality images, and since I usually don't print beyond 8.5x11", there's no need to invest in the 7+ MP cameras.Battery life is decent, but I recommend keeping a few spares if you will be on long trips without access to a place to charge up.  NOTE: There is no battery indicator on the camera, which is frustrating if you only have the stock battery provided by Canon.  The only battery info that the camera will provide is a red flashing battery symbol when it's about to die.  That's not much help.  My advice is to charge up the battery before any extended use, just to make sure you'll get the maximum number of shots.  It loses a star for this; it's just a real pain, and it's a shame they overlooked such a simple, but helpful feature.Everything else is pretty much great.  Nice clear 2.5" LCD view screen, optical viewfinder.  Images get a little shaky when you go into digital zoom, but that's the nature of the beast.  If you're really concerned about camera shake and blurry images, either don't use the digital zoom feature, or opt for a pricier camera with an image stabilizing option.

This little solar charger is about the size of an IPhone and just as thick. The panel is on the front, with side USB connections, on/off/light switch and of course the LED light. As soon as the charger arrived, I charged it through the USB-in port connecting it to a wall charger laying around. It took 30 minutes to fully charge and I used it immediately on my phone. My Galaxy SII was at 50% battery life and the charger charged it for about an hour until it was fully charged. That only drained around 40% of the Solar charger.The next day I charged it back up leaving it by the window. Around noon the side showed a blue color. This meant it was at full capacity. So it took a while to fully charge using the sun but it works!  The LED light is bright and left it on for about 2 hours and it used up half the battery. On the back of the charger is a button that shows the amount of charge left in the internal battery.Great inexpensive charger, works well, holds a charge and does charge fully in the sun.
summary: The Little Solar Charger That Could

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I have never owned a pair of headphones this expensive in my life, but these were the best $290 I have ever spent.Most of my previous headphones were $50-60 dollars, with my very last headphones being some skullcandy hesh (go ahead and laugh). Anyway, I was looking to do a pretty big upgrade from those to something that was much better quality, but something that was also very portable, and over the ear.During my research I obviously looked at some Sennheisers', I saw a few that had good reviews and were under my budget (which was about $150 at the time). I went to a store and listened to several, including some AKGs but they were either open air headphones, too bulky, or I didn't like the sound.I eventually heard about B&W; making their first headphones which definitely caught my attention because I own home theater speakers from them. I was not so sure at first about these because they were on-ear instead of over-ear, which is what I was normally used to. I went to check them out and I was blown away by how good the sounded. On top of that, they were light, comfortable, and portable. I immediately decided to wait until I had the money for them.I finally got them today, and I literally cannot take them off my head. They are incredible. Im also very satisfied with the build quality, top notch leather and stainless steel. The highs and lows sound perfect to me, the bass is there but is not crazy overpowering.I think one thing people should know is that the ipod cable that is included might not be compatible with other devices. I tried using the cable on my Creative mp3 player and it would cause my player to shut down. I also used the ipod cable on my pc and noticed that something about the sound seemed slightly off, I switched out the cable to the regular one and the sound was alot better. I think it was the fact that the ipod cable has the volume/voice control and the tip of the cable has 3 black connections(for left, right, and controls) instead of the standard 2, so it was messing with the sound.I would recommend people to go check these out before you buy them, especially since its a lot of money, you want to make sure its what you really want sound-wise. These are built to last, and the sound amazing, just what I was looking for.EDIT: I would like to add that, to get the most out of these headphones, playing your music in lossless format is almost a must, or at least 320kbps, but anything below will probably not sound as good.UPDATE (09/16/2012):So my headphones still work very well. I just wanted to share a small incident I had with these. A couple of weeks ago I accidentally dropped my headphones from about waist height and one of the ear attachments fell off. When I tried to but it back on it would not re-attach (they attach by magnet). I realized that when they hit the ground they got demagnetized so it lost its magnetic force. I thought I had permanently damaged them but a minute or so later the magnet started working again and was able to attach it. I did realize that a very small piece from the headphone had broken off which kind of upset me (there are two small things that stick out that hold the ear pieces in place and one of them broke off). The earpiece still stays on the headphone but just wanted to share that these are not completely unbreakable as I thought. Other than that they still work great.
summary: After a month of research, these were the perfect choice. Recommended!

I bought this in late June because my Dell XPS laptop was rapidly dying. I wish I could have waited until December '12 or January '13 to get a new system, but this was the best in terms of price vs features at the time.The good: Optical drive, slim form factor, matte screen, zippy boot time.The bad: Samsung software. It's supposed to be helpful, but it's just bloatware that ultimately sucks. I have a multi-computer licence for Avast, so when I uninstalled the Norton Antivirus that came pre-installed, the software manager complained. Eventually I found the setting that shut off the stupid notifications. The "Easy Software Manager" failed for months to download updates, but routinely complained that the updates weren't installed. When it finally worked, the "Easy Settings Manager" killed something upon the last update, so the function keys to dim the screen no longer work. I had two recent BSOD shutdowns that I think were related to the most recent software update. I'm going to try and update everything or do a fresh install of Windows to see if I can get it back to working the way it was when I first received it, but right now I would not recommend this model.
summary: Meh. Decent hardware, but there's software issues

I live on a small sidestreet that the 8000 doesn't recognize, though the nav system in my Mercedes does..  Sitting in my driveway, the 8000 shows me sitting in empty space.3. Installed these two 8gb HyperX PnPs into my macbook pro 15 inch (mid 2012) 2.6GHz Intel core i7 about a month ago and have worked out fine. I just finished installing this Zalman fan into an older Dell Dimension 8400,a PC notorious for LOUD fan noise when the CPU is under anything more than aminimal load (a Google search will yield thousands of noise complaints).One suggestion out there is to reverse the existing fan so it blows into thecase.  DO NOT DO THIS, as it will blow the hot air generated from the CPUacross all your components, such as your hard drive and video card.  SpeedFanshowed my hard drives were cooking at 135 degrees Fahrenheit when I aimed thefan inwards.  Not good.The old dell fan had 4 wires, and this fan has 3 wires.  So I simply cut offthe plastic sockets and spliced the red, black, and white wires together,and taped up the connections.  Not the prettiest, but it works fine.  Theblue wire was left hanging, perhaps that was a temperature sensor wire to rampup the fan speed when needed.  The Zalman seems to run at constant speed, whichisn't silent, but produces a low "air moving sound" (even at 100% CPU load) whichis a joy compared to the loud vacuum cleaner sound of the original Delta faninstalled by Dell (Model # AFC0912DE).The fan includes a "Silent Mode" resistor, which made the fan run silently, butit then didn't move enough air cool adequately.  The "Silent Mode" resistor wasremoved and temps are now good (download SpeedFan to verify your temps beforeand after installing the fan).  Hard drives are now at 104 degrees Fahrenheit;Dell's lame motherboard doesn't support CPU temp monitoring.This fan moves 53 CFM (Cubic Feet Per Minute) in normal mode and 38 CFM in "SilentMode" using the included resistor in the wire.Noise levels are 20 dB in "Silent Mode" and 36 dB in normal mode.Also included in this "Plus" version are 4 silicon pins, instead of metal screws,to attach the fan to the case.  They're supposed to "isolate" the fan from thecase and reduce vibrations.  These seem to work OK, but make removing the fandifficult.  One trick is to wet the fat end before installing the pin so itslides through the snug fan and case holes easier.
summary: Nice Fan, Replaced Dell Dimension 8400 Case Fan

I take my USB drive to work every day.  I use it for both storing music to listen to while I work and to save any interesting news stories to look at later at home.  One of the weakest points of any USB drive is the moving parts.  You have either the swivel kind that will eventually get floppy, the kind that retracts that can get broken and no longer come out, and the traditional caps.All these moving parts will nearly always wear out or break before the memory in the drive would expire.  A great solution is to get one of these cases and then you don't have to worry about retracting, swiveling, or losing a cap.  Just leave them in the ready-to-use position and protect them with this case.Case Logic always made the best DVD cases in my opinion and they make the best USB cases as well.  They're a bit more expensive, though not that much more expensive, than competitors.  Honestly, I've had the cheap ones too and all but the cheapest will work just fine, but these look better and feel like they'll last longer.

Amazing is all I can say.  I shot a wedding on a boat with this lens as I knew the coverage will be limited.  I'm glad to have carried this lens with me (rented).  It's heavy duty and while it does make a buzzing noise it's not loud nor could be heard especially at an event.It's relatively small, compact like the 50mm f/1.8 lens but the hood is made of metal with metal mount.  Tiny but made very well.  The AF was spot on and came out sharper and kept more photos than my 70-200 f/4L shooting outside.Yes, there's a heavy distortion but it's not a circular fisheye either and can be corrected in post to a degree (I didn't heavily correct it).  I don't have to worry about a group of people dancing while trying to focus but let the lens do its job.  Few times I just blind shot behind me and from above with my arms raised and got some pretty neat shots.  The couples and their family/friends all loved the portraits from it.  With the subject being in center, the middle area of course aren't distorted like the outer.  Again, it can be corrected but for a different style to add to the photos this lens is a great choice.I would also use this for landscapes in area you want to cover more of.  Overall I'm very satisfied the lens will likely be my next purchase if not another rental for the next wedding!

Like the previous reviewer, I bought this for an Asus Eee PC.  Just remember that on certain models, the unit will not see the memory until you reset Boot Booster in the bios.  You do this by hitting F2 at boot, find Boot Booster, turn it off, and boot the machine normally.  At this point, the machine will see the additional memory.  If you want the Boot Booster though, you can go back into the bios, re-enable it and it should work fine with both now.

Review for Panlong 3x1 3-Port HDMI Auto Switch PigtailExcellent!  A great value. I purchased this to use with an HDMI monitor so I could switch automatically between various devices (laptop, Amazon Fire TV, 2nd PC) and it works perfectly. For less than 10 bucks, hard to beat this for value.  It seems reasonably well made and I have had no issues. I just hooked everything up and it works. I have two of the Winegard Company FL-5000 FlatWave HDTV Indoor Digital Flat Antennas .I wanted somthing  a little more powerful in hopes of bringing in more channels BIG MISTAKE!!!  So I got this Leaf PLus based on the  product information provided in the description and reviews.The range for this Leaf Plus Amplified Indoor HDTV Antenna is recommended for customers that live within  50 miles of the broadcast towers ( I am less than 40 miles away).The Winegard Company FL-5000 FlatWave HDTV Indoor Digital Flat Antenna - is rated for upto 35 miles away.That said I installed the leaf plus  on my SONY 46" HDTV  in my bedroom and it does not work anywhere near as well as  The Winegard Antenna!!  and it cost more than the Winegard!!It is simle to install. I hooked it up using a USB to the TV as per the  directions that came with the antennaI tried programming it several times, in the morning, afternoon and evening hours with no improvement.  I got 6 less channels with this antenna than with the Winegard! I tried relocating it  still no improvement.I reinstalled the  Winegard  and put the Leaf Plus in the guest room. Most guests do not watch much TV when visiting but at least they can get the  major networks and few other channels if they want to.I do not recommend!!

reviewText: I received mine yesterday.  It works fine.  For some reason it took serveral minutes to get a signal the first time though.**Just a warning if you are an impulse buyer like me.**The Amazon add has details on the product and it shows a color display.  That is the eTrex Venture Cx model.  The one here is the basic.  I was expecting color.  My bad for buying so quickly without reading.  duh.Also I expected a data cable. I bought this kit to go with my HP TM2 so I can be in tablet mode and still have a real keyboard handy. The setup and use was fairly painless in Windows 7 64 bit and I have had no issues with it. The use of the keyboard is quite comfortable as it has a curvature to maintain a more natural posture. It is also quite light and thin so you can throw it into a backpack if you had to. The numeric keypad is just that, not much else to say.I would have given five stars for usability if it had dedicated Home and End keys. Those keys are accessible via a Fn key combination but it would be difficult to strictly use the keyboard in order to highlight a whole line of text. But, it does have a mute and volume +/- keys. This is also nice to have when in tablet mode since those functions are not as easily accessed.As far as the wake-up time is concerned I have no issues with it. It could be that for a portable device that runs off of two AAA's that I expect it to fall asleep and require some key strokes to wake it. Never the less, the lag time to wake up is just a few seconds. But, at that time my laptop is also asleep and it also needs to wake-up so it does not bother me. I have not had it fall asleep while using it or while actively using it and stepping out to do something momentarily.
summary: Good keyboard if you want portability and ease of use for OTG

reviewText: Slid eight of theseSeagate Constellation ES.2 3 TB 7200RPM SATA 6Gb/s 64MB Cache 3.5 Inch Internal Bare Drive ST33000650NSEnterprise-class 3TB wonders into my newSynology DiskStation 8-Bay (Diskless) Network Attached Storage - Black (DS1812+)and configured with 2-drive fault tolerance.  Write speed is always in excess of 100 MB/sec and sometimes hits 123 MB/sec.  These drives are expensive and worth every cent!  Am also using the DS1812+ as iSCSI file storage for a VMware ESXi server and it's performing very well.  Very pleased with these drives and with theSynology DiskStation 8-Bay (Diskless) Network Attached Storage - Black (DS1812+).This DS1812+ NAS becomes a primary file server, retiring a power-hungry Dell server.  ASynology DiskStation 5-Bay (Diskless) Scalable Network Attached Storage DS1511+ (Black)that has been providing excellent service for about one year now serves as backup space (with 1-drive fault tolerance, the five 2 TB drives in the DS1511+ "only" supply 7.15 TB of file storage).  I also recommend the DS1511+ as a reliable and fast NAS.Set up of the DS1812+ was amazingly easy, including setting up the iSCSI file storage for a VMware ESXi server.

I have never used a mouse for my laptop, but when this arrived, I immediately installed the provided AA batteries into the mouse, switched it to "on" and plugged in the little wireless ("Unifying") receiver device into my laptop. The installation was a breeze and it began working immediately.The battery compartment is on the top of the mouse, under the logo and where your palm rests, which was unexpected but I think it is a cute feature. The batteries are supposed to last up to three years but I would guess with daily use it might not last that long. Time will tell. The "Unifying receiver", which plugs into the USB port, can be stored in the battery compartment when not in use. Very handy.The feel of the mouse is very nice. The top two button and palm areas are slick whereas the sides provide texture so you can grip it easily. The scroll wheel works beautifully. You can tilt it to the right to move forward one page while you're on an internet page and if you push the wheel to the left, you go back a page. I can get used to this! It also has a "middle button" which functions differently depending on your OS and the application you are using.The "Unifying receiver" is small yet it can connect multiple Unifying compatible devices. I like this mouse. Now hopefully I won't misplace it!
More than not it does not work. You will find yourself disappointed when the gps data is not available on many of your pictures. Maybe there are better options out there but this is not it.
No need to repeat what others have said again and again.Sounds great. Would definitely buy again!

reviewText: after putting google chrome os on my hong kong special (<$20 to get it to the door), i found that while i still had a usb drive, i no longer had an mp3 player.  wanted a player that could play music and serve as usb drive, all without a "world of its own".  the express does that.  interface with fedora linux was simple and seamless.  1gb is enough for me.  i load up one artist or one genre.  can't think of an artist that i need more than a gigabyte at once.  abandoned lanyard early on - not necessary unless you are at a nudist resort.  figured i would have to replace ear buds - didn't happen.  very clean sound with plenty of volume.

reviewText: I love these speakers.You get two.They sound very very good.They are made for year round outdoor use.But it should be mounted under an eve or awning according to the instruction booklet.I am using this pair outdoors on my deck...I would buy these again.

When I fist saw this at a major rental house in LA, I asked the salesman if it was useful. He shook his head like "Are you kidding me?" So I kept my $20 and moved on.Since then I've tested out a number of inexpensive stabilizers and makeshift rigs -- some useful, some crap. So while experimenting with some designs of my own I ordered this as an extra point-of-contact for possible a DIY rig in the future.When it arrived, I threw it on the bottom of my Canon 60D with a nifty-fifty to see how bad it actually was.Short review: I love it!Obviously it's not a Steadicam or a Red Rock shoulder rig, BUT with a little getting used to it DOES provide a very easy, low profile, highly maneuverable, inexpensive, handheld smoothing option. The grip is extremely comfortable and the pistol feel is much like an old Bolex.For WALKING SHOTS, I recommend only using a wide lens (50mm or wider) that's stopped down for deep focus.For STATIC SHOTS where a little organic motion is acceptable, I feel like ANY DSLR with pretty much ANY LENS would be decent on this little guy. There's nothing above to interfere with your racking reach and with a little grace the act of racking itself will give you another stabilizing point of contact.I also advise using a soft, stretchy neckstrap on the camera in the extended position to get another point-of-contact for anchoring & smoothing movement.So buy this & keep it in your kit bag. Play around with it and you might just have the touch to get smooth handheld shots with cool minimalism.***And if you can ride a skateboard, particularly a longboard with big soft wheels, this is remarkably easy to handhold for smooth dolly-ish shots. And if you bust there's still a high-chance of protecting your camera.Strong recommend.
summary: Surprisingly useful item for DSLR filmmaking

reviewText: Just finished installing the Skinomi screen protector on my Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 about 3 hours ago and it looks awesome. Im inpatient so I used a hair drier on it for 5 to 10 min to speed up the process. After this it remained a tad cloudy so I let it sit for 3 hours. Looking at the screen now I cant even tell there is a cover on it except for 1 little cloudy spot still left to go away which I'm certain will.Tips on installing:1. Watch the video!!!!! It was very helpful and showed you exactly how to install it.2. If you want to reduce the chance of dust install it in the bathroom with a hot shower running. The steam will help pull the dust out of the air.3. While they say only spray both sides on the cover and your fingers I also put a small amount of solution on the screen itself. This allowed me to move it around easier and place it exactly how I wanted.4. Once you have it positioned work your way from the middle out lightly at first to tack it down. Once it is tacked down in at least one spot start to push the solution out.5. Dont rush! Take your time and it will turn out perfect!6. Listen to them and let it sit! It will look cloudy at first which makes the screen look very pixelated but once the solution dries it will clear up. These people complaining about the cloudiness do not know how to read instructions.Not sure how much it will matter to some but the screen protector does have a rubbery type feel to it. Its not bad but is a slight difference between the feel of the glass and this.Overall Im very happy with the purchase and will be buying another screen protector from Skinomi when I get my Galaxy SIII soon

Everyone knows this lens. If you're looking for a 50mm prime, you know there are 3 choices from Canon. The almighty 50/1.2, 50/1.4, or this 50/1.8. The 1.8 is a natural buy especially for beginners b/c it's so affordable. Prices usually fluctuate from $90-120.I'm using a T3i/600D. My views of this lens:- For what I use it for, which is indoor shooting with available light, wide open at 1.8 is not terribly sharp. But the shutter speed gain is great, plus I don't have to boost ISO as much.- It's EXTREMELY cheaply made. Really, this thing is all plastic, feels very hollow and feels like a toy. It's also a bit big compared to some other 50 out there (i.e., Minolta's excellent 50/1.7). I would not be surprised if you found lots of dust and debris inside after awhile.- AF is very slow and noisy. Sometimes it will hunt for 5 seconds before finally locking or sometimes it will not lock at all.  At a recent housewarming party, I had to use it in manual b/c the AF just simply refused to lock in the majority of the shots. This is very annoying.But what do you expect for $100, right?  So as long as you can keep the expectations vs pricepoint reality check in line, I think you'll get great use out of this lens.  For how I use this lens, I find the focal length too long for indoors where I'm taking photos of people. I find myself hitting the walls after having backed up so much. Looking now for a lens in the 28mm range but I need to prepare myself to pay a lot more.

These cables have not had any issues. the 2 meter length seems a little long, that is until you try having the firewire plug on the back of a desktop machine on the floor and your firewire device on the desk on the opposite side from the computer. plastic cable ties, work well, not all are perfect, some break easy, some don't. I suppose it's sometimes user error!

I bought this considering the positive ratings given by many users. Initially, it just did not work. My PC was unable to connect to the network. reviewText: This Router will boost your 802.11g network even WITHOUT speedbooster adapters! Yes! Unlike Netgear's marketed "108MBps" Super-G and D-Link's advertised "108MBps", you need to buy their associated PC Card, PCI adapter in order to fully utilize the potential speeds. SpeedBooster (by Broadcom) technology doens't require you to purchase a Speedbooster equipped PC Card or PCI/USB adapter to increase network speeds. Alot of people don't know that but my 802.11G is NOTICEABLY IMPROVED with SpeedBooster router. I have the regular Linksy 802.11G PCI Adapter and a SpeedBooster 802.11G PCI adapter - both are FAST!Router is fast, reliable, stable, and the range is EXCELLENT. This is a must buy if you want a fast file transferring, and secure home/business network! I recommended my friend and he couldn't be happier - he's a programmer so he uses a 3rd party firmware which allows a TONS of features for this router since it's Linux driven.A+
