reviewText: So . . . . .as a  die hard runner one thing I found that gets me motivated to get back on the pavement or turf after a break (life gets in the way, don'tcha know) is buying something - maybe I'm shallow. Sometimes it's a new pair of shoes, sometimes it has been as simple as a new pair of shorts. Perhaps it's my Nordic upbringing, but if I buy someting, by golly, I'm going to get out there and use it. After a week I realize how amazing it feels to be fit an my love affair begins anew.So (after the longest preamble ever) it was headphones to get back me on track (literally) after a break (I used to hate running with music). I bought the Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones- Retail Packaging because of the cordless Bluetooth technology. They are unfit for physical activity - in fact they are unfit for most humans. They felt terrible on my head (think head in a vice) - returned them. After a little more research I bought these headphones and I absolutely love them. They are weightless and I can live with a cord. It's clear to me that the technology for cordless headphones just isn't there yet - don't waste your time. There's a big difference between lifting weights (for which they get good reviews) in the gym and a long run.So . . enough about the bad . . withSennheiser Adidas PMX 680i Sports Headsetthe sound is great - granted I'm no true audiophile. That being said, everything sounds balanced and true. The best thing is the fit and the weight. THESE ARE AMAZING! They feel weightless and secure. There's no pinching(!) and I don't even know that they are on my head. I also like the little volume control thingy.If you're on the fence, pull the trigger on these headphones, you 'll like 'em, but also, don't waste you money on Bluetooth headphones. In short, a great purchase that just works.
summary: What headphones . . . Oh these on my head I forgot about?

reviewText: With all the traveling I do I need a device that is reliable. I saw this and thought what a great invention I can charge my phone ipod and netbook all with one device. Well it was too good to be true. The first one I received was defective, energizer was great about sending a new one for free since I had registered the first. How ever the second one I received had the same problem they would charge but would not discharge. Do not waste your money on a product that you may or may not know will work when you receive it.
It's not low-profile enough to fit in any of the Pi cases I've purchased.

I know, I know, this is meant to be used on a tablet, most likely.  But I wanted a keyboard for my Moto X, since it supports HID bluetooth.  So here it is.  The function keys, I feel, are very smartly set up.  You have your volume keys, quick launch keys, forward/back and home keys.  You even have some keys that aren't normally in Android, but can still be used, such as the CTRL and ALT keys.  I use it to take notes in my Mobisle Notes program, and even to play my C64 emulator.  The reaction time on it is pretty good and actually makes emulators usable, more so than just relying on the touch-based screen controllers.As for the feel, it feels much like the bluetooth iMac keyboard.  In fact, it will work with a Mac or PC, so long as it's bluetooth compatible, except the keys don't include the Windows or Mac special keys.It has those nice smooth chicklet type keys.  The keyboard is almost precisely the same size as my iMac wireless keyboard, and almost the same layout, too.  The keys are smooth to the touch, with just enough texture to feel satisfying and substantial when you type.  Just the right amount of resistance.When I use mine, I occasionally am playing music with a worship group, and when I'm done playing, I'll just tip my music stand back a little, and put my keyboard up on the bottom of the stand, propping my cell phone up on top of it.  Works great, and is almost as good for such purposes as would be a laptop.  But it's also pretty much future proof, too, because when I do get a tablet, I can use this for full-blown office apps, rather than using some corny screen keyboard.Thanks Motorola, for a great add-on!
summary: Great!  Easy to use and works like a champ on Moto X

reviewText: Super easy to mount on the wall.  Comes with a wide variety of mounting screw sizes to fit any TV. I ended up putting the wall bracket a little higher than I planned because I miss judged where the TV would actually sit on the bracket.I would buy this one again, great value for price.

reviewText: you definitely get what you pay for.these speakers are a good deal; i checked out the klipsch promedia 2.0's, but went with the creatives.first...they look great, great design. bass & treble controls, rear input AND a front input.they sound...pretty good. good volume, impressive bass for their size.my biggest gripe: the top mounted port; it's a bass-enhancing port, but, ultimately...it's a hole. sort-of an invitation for dust. oh well...these are desktop speakers, not audiophile speakers, so for what they are:excellent!recommended.

reviewText: Seem to be pretty good headphones.  JVC usually makes good stuff.  They block out exterior noise and allow you to listen to your tunes uninterrupted.

I love listening to music with earbuds on my iPhone and have tried many different types. My preference is earbuds that have both good sound quality (and volume) and comfort. The sound is good and clear on these and I can turn them up loud, but I totally don't like the plug-like suction feel. They completely shut-of surrounding sound, but they totally do not feel good in my ears. More than that if I switch over to the phone on my iPhone they have that weird ear-plug muffled feel when I talk.I ordered black thinking it would be all-black. The cord/earbud wire and plug is bright red. The only black part is the in-line mic/button control, the ear bud part, and the carrying case.The carrying case is the coolest I've seen. The ear buds plug into holes in the side, then the cord feeds into two slots, then gets wrapped around the base when you pull back the rubber surround. It protects the eye buds, but even better keeps the cord from tangling. You can easily just toss it in your purse or bag with no worries.The rubberized ear plug-ins come in 3 sizes and easy to switch out. The medium size would work for most people, but it you have extra-small or extra-large ear holes, this is a nice option.FYI: The center of the ear bud is color-coded red (for your right ear) and white ear bud (for your left ear) according to another Amazon reviewer. I could not find it marked anywhere on the ear bud (like a printed R and L) or in the user's manual.These won't replace my iphone5 earbuds and unfortunately will end up in my electronic junk drawer because they are not comfortable to me.
summary: Good sound, but too much like ear plugs

reviewText: The size is perfect. I bought this for my son to be able to put in his motorcycle tank bag and it fits perfectly. But I had no idea it was going to be that good. The keyboard is just fine. Not what I expected on a little laptop. I get better WiFi in areas of my house then I do on my $2000 Dell work laptop beast. And that's only with the 802.11b/g and not the new "N" I can only imagine it be a little better. The LED screen is very bright. In doors it's fine even at the lowest setting. 4hour battery life is really great. I've never gone down low enough to be worried. I bought a Targus bag at Best Buy. I don't recomend buying bags online. Check them out first. I'm gald I did because I bought a laptop protector bag from Amazon and first it was the wrong color, had to return it and I'm glad because it was not good at all. Also I bought a Samsung external DVD/CD burner DL and it fit's with the MSI powersupply in the bag and still fit's in the tank bag on my bike. The samsung also is great since it didin't need an external power supply.The laptop is great. I'm thinking of getting another one for my wife! It's so light, robust, it doesn't feel cheap. 3x USB ports is a plus.Great battery life, Sharp screen. The price is right as well.I've not looked into the other brands, I got the good advice from my computer geek friends who have and said the MSI was the winner.It's perfect for email, webbrowsing, MS Office (Excel, Word etc...)I haven't done nor need to do anything else with it. It's GREAT.The web cam is a bonus that I may or may not use. I suppose since it's there I may have to try a web cam test.

30 feet at best for illumination, don't expect more than that.  I have 5 various types of CCTV cameras, all utilize 850nm wave length IR light for night vision.After the 30 feet, the illumination degrades considerably to the point it where you don't notice anything.  The housing of the unit is quite nice and sturdy. Just wish they would use a stronger IR LEDs. I am returning this product as it is advertised with misleading information. This is a nice all purpose home theatre system.  Works especially well with my new Samsung LCD TV.  I prefer all sound to come out of the home theatre system rather than the television.  Samsung's Anynet feature allows both units to be controled by the same remote.  The TV automatically knows when a DVR has been inserted.  The home theatre system automacally turns off when the TV is turned off.Originally I had purchased just a Samsung DVR player.  When I learned of the Anynet feature, I sold the DVR player to a friend and bought the home theatre system.  I am very satisfied with it.  Even the radio works great.  Have not tried the IPod connection.

reviewText: ALMOST ordered from Amazon fulfilled via Accessory Genie, but ordered from "Accessory Genie" direct, as I had a coupon code for their site & used my paypal (of which I had a credit).. so got a slightly better deal ordering via their direct website.DISCLAIMER: I wish I could give this 4 & 1/2 stars, but limited by Amazon Rating system! So my review should be rated at a 4.5 stars.*** BIGGEST REASON I PURCHASED THIS? PLAYS my AMAZON CLOUD COLLECTION SUPER DUPER! (I'm loving Amazon Cloud, take that iTunes!)***#1) Great price for a good solid Bluetooth speaker.#2) Good sound quality.  Projects sound & carries a signal through 1, 2 or 3 rooms with no issues (depending how loud I blast it and walls etc).  Sound quality not quite as good as my iPod "BOSE" SOUND DOCK system, but for jamming whist surfing the net or cleaning the house or just listening to good music, it is great!  Better than cheaper or smaller speakers I've tried.#3) SIMPLE.  Plug in, turn on, then set your Bluetooth enabled device to find and pair it up with.~ It reads as a "Bluetooth Headset" named "GG-BLUE-SYNC" on my Bluetooth devices that locate it~ virtual plug/play on these devices, all setup is from the device you are connecting to the speaker, there is NOTHING to do on the speaker. It just works!~ I've tested this out on my android smartphone (Samsung EPIC 4G) and my Sony VAIO L series touch screen PC, my kids phones & mP3 players with no problems connecting or transmitting via earphone jack or Bluetooth wireless.~ Its Bluetooth EASILY pairs with A2DP equipped audio devices#4) BASS projects VERY well (good speaker with a good bass level to go along with the standard sound projection).#5) Lighted indicators on front of speaker to tell if it is connected ("-" & "+" volume buttons blink when not paired w/a device, shines solid blue when actively paired)#6) Green light to indicate unit is on.#7) IF YOU DO NOT HAVE A BLUETOOTH DEVICE, IT IS STILL GOOD! As it connects with ANY mP3 player, phone, PDA or whatever that has an earphone jack connected via the back of the machine (no wire included for this).  Good sound quality there as well.#8) ON/OFF switch on back of device.#9) PORTABLE! Works where ever there is an electrical plug/outlet!#10) For the size, fairly light, but not so much it feels cheap.  Feels solid but doesn't weigh a ton.  Can carry it upstairs if I need to easily.#11) NO skipping, delay or hesitancy, just great playback via a device.  NOW.. if the DEVICE has issues, it will project that, but it is NOT the fault of these speakers!)#12 Compact, good big sound without a big price tag, takes up little space on a shelf, counter or dresser.#13) Plays whatever is being projected by the device, no risk of incompatible formats. Only limited by the device it is connected to.#14) NOT proprietary! It plays any/all makes, models & formats of devices and sound.  Again, take that certain iPhone & iPod products)#15) Found I can control the volume to a point on the speakers AND from the device itself.  Volume controls on a connected device can regulate to a degree remotely if connected via Bluetooth or earphone jack.  SO.. for the loudest sound, set the devices volume to HIGH, and the speakers to high... projects music well with good sound.CONS:~ BIGGEST CON: ....No Remote to adjust speaker volume, have to manually adjust front speaker buttons or the connected device, if I get a phone call or something that I have to turn it down quickly.  A separate remote for power/volume control would be nice.~ NOW Compared to my BOSE SOUND DOCK system, it is not as virtual 3D or super surround sound (*but comes VERY VERY close*) and didn't have to pay the $600 price tag for it.~ Wish it had a handle for easy carrying, but I just wrap it up in one arm if I need to move it, no big deal, but would have been nice.~ No instructions included in box, but you do NOT need any instructions! (some people may find this a negative, but I didn't once I turned it on, it was so easy) Since all the pairing and connecting comes via the projected device, the speaker is just a speaker.  Turn it on, locate it on your device and GO!~ Wish it had a capability to add another speaker to its connection to get better surround sound action if I wanted it in a big room.RECOMMENDED FOR: College students, kids, Moms, Dads, garages, homes, offices, where ever and whoever wants a great wireless device, or mP3 speaker.  I'm VERY satisfied, and hope this review helps.  I searched and searched for reviews for this device, and none were on the internet or Amazon yet, it was too new.  If you have questions, ask, as it looks as if I was the first one to take the plunge, and glad I did!!!!! :-)PS: for anyone that would post a con or bad review of this due to it doesn't have a battery option, this is NOT the type of speaker that could use batteries, it is a good piece of electronics, and not a cheap little thing that takes batteries.  My Bose SoundDock couldn't use batteries, and neither could this, as it requires more power of an electrical outlet to do what it does.
summary: GREAT Bluetooth wireless speaker for sound, portability, ease of use & connection options

This review is for brand new beginners. Disclaimer--I've never edited or captured video without this program, so I can't compare it to others. I bought Vegas Movie Studio because a friend told me that it was easy to learn and doesn't freeze up.I use the program to put together family video clips. At best, these might include a title text and a fade out at the end--I am a novice and proud of it! Occasionally, I'll add a few photos and some music but that's about it. I've used the older version "11" for a few years but recently upgraded to the newer version "13". My goal with this review is to let other beginners know that even technically challenged people like myself can use this program.For first time beginners, the instructions in writing are difficult to absorb. There is a webinar online but it's hard to find. Just go to sonycreativesoftware DOT com (I spelled this incorrectly on purpose because Amazon doesn't like listing websites in user reviews). On the bottom right of that website page, there is an item you can select called "training and tutorials". Once you select it, you will be brought to a new page where there is a tab called video. Select the "movie studio" option and a new page pops up with a bunch of links. Select "An Introduction to Movie Studio 13 Platinum". You can stream it but there is also an option to the right for downloading it to your hard drive. This is a 42 minute webinar that explains how to make the basic movies I described above. Another great way of learning the program is to use the "Show Me How" tutorials. When you start Movie Studio, a welcome screen has an option called "Show me how". This functions like a remote tutor sharing your computer. It instructs you step by step in how to use the program. Warning--you'll need a short video clip available somewhere on your computer for "Show me how" to function.So how hard is it to learn? If you watch the video tutorials and play around with some of your video clips, you're out about 90 minutes. But that's all you need to use the program the way most people will probably use it--to make cool vacation or family event videos that are five or ten minutes long. Most of the clips I take from my camcorder are less than two minutes in duration. Editing them together makes them much more watchable. In addition, you can toss the bad clips and edit out mistakes, such as when I forget to turn off the camera and end up with a two minute birthday party clip--in which the last minute shows video of my feet!!!Nothing has been buggy with the old or new versions of this program and my computer has not frozen or crashed. I'd bet that some people would like to know if this upgrade was worth the money. Sorry, I'm not good enough with video to provide the answer to that question.I tend to use high def video which comes out of my camcorder at 1080p. A nine minute clip is about a gigabyte if you choose "AVCHD" as the file type when rendering the 9 minute movie--it take the program about 20 minutes to render a movie of this length on my 2010 Windows 7 computer.Now for advice NOT related to the program itself: I no longer use the program to make DVD's. Instead, I play the finished movies on my TV using a WD TV Media player, which has a USB input where I attach a hard drive. I store the rendered movies on this hard drive, which gets plugged into the WD TV Media player for direct viewing on the TV. So goodbye to DVD's, which don't play with anywhere near the clarity of these files. Instead of a pile of DVD's, I have at least a few hundred family videos on a single hard drive.  I try to limit the final clips to not much more than a gigabyte so that the WD TV Media player attached to my TV doesn't get overwhelmed. To accomplish my self-imposed one gigabyte rule, I limit the length of my "movies" to around nine minutes.After viewing these videos using the WD TV Media player,  I feel safe in predicting that most of us will not be making family DVD's in five years. In terms of ease, playing movies through the WD reminds me of the comparison between a CD player and an iPod. A single iPod holds thousands of albums, which is much more convenient than using piles of CD's. Similarly, the hard drive//WD combination holds hundreds of videos. And unlike the iPod, there is no file compression. When viewed through the WD player, the 1080p videos look ridiculously clear. I think they even look better than blu ray. Plus, like an iPod, using the hard drive through that WD player allows for clicking on any of hundreds of movies instantly.This Vegas program is so good, I've decided to use Sony cameras to take video because the file interchange is seamless. I don't know if other camcorders use the same file types, but it wouldn't be worth the time for me to find out.  A good camcorder that would have cost a thousand dollars back in the day now costs around 400 bucks. The camcorders work better than cameras for video, because most cameras skip if you move the camera from right to left or vice versa while filming. In other words, I can use the movie function on cameras to film someone blowing out birthday candles but these cameras skip when trying to film your kids' soccer games because of the side to side movement of the cameras themselves. This is my novice experience speaking, but it has happened to me with several cameras and phones but never with the camcorders.I can't answer technical questions, but this spaz was able to learn the program pretty easily and wanted to give you the two year experience report. Maybe this review can save you precious hours trying to learn a more difficult program. I discovered this program, the Sony camcorders and the WD thing by sheer luck. Since I've been on the other end of trying to learn something and wasting hours and dollars, I chose to post this review to spare others the same fate. Finally, I should also add that video clips from the iPhone work fine, although they are not as clear as with the camcorder. Good luck!!Edit Update: 6/20/14: Movie Studio 13 only produces final videos at 1080p using the XAVC format but this format makes huge files. Four gigs for a 10 minute clip is too much. The old AVCHD clips were less than half the size. I contacted Sony customer support about this and they wrote me back!! They solved my problem, telling me that I can indeed make the smaller AVCHD clips that are 1080p at 59.94 frames per second. BTW, 60 frames per second is actually 59.94 frames per second. It's the industry standard.Here's how Sony instructed me to make smaller AVCHD clips as opposed to the XAVC gigabyte chomping clips: Select "Make Movie". Click on "Save it to My Hard Drive". Click on "Advanced Options". Make sure the filter triangle above the list to the right says "Filters Off". Select "MainConcept AVC/AAC" from the list on the left. Select "Internet HD 1080p" from the list on the right. Make sure these last two selections are highlighted in Blue. Click "Customize Template". This opens the "Custom Settings" dialogue box. Where it says "Frame Rate", type in 59.94. Where it says Maximum bps, choose 28 million. Also, choose 28 million for the Average bps. Click on the "Audio" tab on the bottom of this dialogue box. Choose Bit rate of 256K. Click OK. This closes the dialogue box. At the top of the list on the right, select "Internet 1080P(*). Make sure it turns blue. You are done!You might ask why you should do all of this-- the reason for me is that most cameras shooting in 1080P are using similar settings--I want to get the maximum video and sound compared to the files generated by the camera. This can be done with the XAVC files but they are way too huge. By taking all of the steps above, you can render a movie (Make Movie) in a format that is still 1080p and 59.94 fps, but is way smaller in size, about a gigabyte for 7 minutes. I might be a novice with video effects, but I think I've figured out the best file types for archiving and playing after reading a bunch of material on this subject. If you are a video expert, please post any critical commentary to get me to change my conclusions.Addendum--6-22-14:  I just got a new windows computer and I'm writing to tell you that video from iPhones won't work. That is, unless you install quicktime. This requires looking up quicktime on gooogle and downloading it.  For some reason, installing quicktime fixes the problem of iPhone videos not working, even if you never open the quicktime program. My guess is that installing quicktime brings in codecs to your windows computer that aren't factory installed. Good Luck.

I have had many camera bags over the years, but this is definitely my favorite. It is perfect for city living photographers/filmmakers. I generally use this camera bag for broll video shoots, and it has been great. It looks like a normal backpack so generally I feel more comfortable walking with it down the street. Cameras are an easy steal.. It also has two velcro straps on the zipper, which makes it harder for someone to unzip your bag without you noticing on a crowded train/bus.The theft part aside, this bag also has a great deal of space. I cary several lenses, flash, extra batteries, cards etc, and I generally use the side straps (tripod straps) for my monopod, which fits perfectly. It's also much more comfortable when carrying for a long period of time. No more sore shoulders at the end of the day. Having the quick access top is great for run and gun photo/video. The camera slides in nicely and all the padding inside feels very thick. I have no concern about my camera being damaged by a minor bump somewhere, and they are adjustable enough to keep accessories from bouncing all over. The camera, sitting in its cradle is nearly immobilized, which is great compared to my old bags, which I was always concerned about the camera shifting in the bag. Plus the accessories you put in there all sit under the camera so you never need to worry about something bouncing around and scratching up your camera, unless you hold the bag upside down... Lastly, when I was researching this bag, I read a few reviews that mentioned the rubber bottom of the bag making it hard to access the very bottom of the bag. I agree that the bag does not open completely so it's certainly in the way, but I have not found it to be difficult to access anything. I do generally have larger lenses on the bottom so they sit high enough to get access easily despite it. I suppose it depends on your layout. I like having the rubber bottom in the event something spills or you need to briefly sit the bag on a slightly wet floor. One last thing to mention is the great little computer section. It's great to be able to fit my macbook pro into the back and take it with on the occasional shoot. I've also used it to hold/organize release forms when on shoots as it nicely holds paper/folders/13inch laptops without any problem. I sometimes am concerned about the weight of the bag squashing my laptop in the middle, since it's held between me and the bag, but it is padded, and I haven't had any issues yet...Long story short, I am extremely happy with this bag. I will absolutely buy again when it wears out, but I've used this almost daily for 4 months now, and it still looks like new, so I am not worried about it wearing out anytime soon, not to mention I bought it used, and it was sent looking like new... My favorite bag yet!

The best thing about this strip is the low profile and the side power button; most strips keep the power button on top (where the outlets lie), so if you accidentally brush against it or have an oversized plug that hangs over the outlet, you can easily shut off the power if you're not careful. This one has a very functional and savvy placement, right on the side in a recessed molding. Great idea.-Pro: Cheap price, fast shipping, plenty of outlets, BEST power button placement ever on a consumer power strip.-Con: The outlets are not spaced out for oversized plugs, but most strips have this problem anyway.I heartily recommend, I got 2!
summary: For the price and form, it sure beats most other surge strips!

utter piece of garbage - after trying different mini speakers this one is the worst by far.  The button functionality is horrible and ends up meaning many times buttons are pressed by accident.  The main issue is the horrible sound.  Maybe mine is defective, but above a whisper volume it distorts so badly that I can barely hear anything at all.  What a huge disappointment.The rundown:Just tried a bunch of these:HMDX jam bluetooth - third place - sounds awesome, very loud and great bass and does not distort. However a constant buzzing/fuzzy noise made this a no go. reasonable price at 35Satechi bluetooth audio cube - not loud at all, tinny sound, very little bass, sounds muffled. expected more from the large size of the unit compared to others and the positive reviews. overpriced at 50Kinivo wired - not very loud but otherwise great sound. great bass, clear highs.  distorts a little at max volume. great value at 20Sharkk bluetooth - second place - a best buy at 28 bucks for sure sounds great, good bass and highs, not quite as loud as the jbl or hdmx.  Comparable volume to most of the others though.JBL micro bluetooth - my favorite - first place. great volume, clear highs and good bass. Very user friendly and uses a manual volume dial so each time you turn it on it is at the previous volume. most reset to 50% every time you turn them off and back on. Bluetooth connectivity through walls is not quite as strong as others, the only con. Also can be used as a bluetooth adaptor/dongle which usually costs as much as this speaker alone. The 3.5mm out can plug into any home theater system.  Nice spot to hang it up on a nail, making the sound project farther and louder. pricey at 60 but worth it.August bluetooth - good quality and bass, however distorts at fairly low volumes making it a no goSatechi BT wireless portable speaker - worst of all, distorts at the slightest bit of bass or volume. Instant no go and a rip off at 40 bucks. can also be used as a bluetooth dongle like the jbl though. stay away from satechi.Xmini - bluetooth drops easily. by far the lightest and smallest and has good sound for it's size but little bass and not too loud. pricey at 40 for what you get.Alpatronix bluetooth - sounds great, but distorts quickly with any bass heavy music.  Also "walks" across the table with bass heavy songs unlike the others due to it's weight/bass ratio.  Loud, like the jbl and hdmx.  Not worth 40 bucks.

I have 4 of these drives and one of them all of a sudden told me it was only 500GB.  I have a coworker who had the same problem.  Seatools allows you to correct this.  Not a big deal if you don't have any data on it.  However if you do, you will lose it all!!!  Two other coworkers have had to return these because of the drive starting to click and then losing sectors.  I am putting Seagate on my DO NOT BUY list indefinitely.  I suggest you look to Western Digital for any future HD purchases.
having misplaced my OEM Garmin mount, I needed replacement. This mount fit the bill quite well, and holds my Nuvi quite securely.

I've owned other HDTVs this one is the best I've owned my only regret is that I didn't get the LV46B650 which is basically the same set with a few more features.  This set has a stunning picture and 120 Hz.  The styling is unique the touch of red disappears in normal room lighting and just looks black the only time you notice it is in sunlight.  The base is made of heavy glass and not plastic like most sets it looks and feels like a quality set.  The menus are animated and user friendly.  I also hooked up a computer to the set and it makes an excellent computer monitor.  When it comes to HDTVs the are not all the same this is one of the best.  The only thing better would be a LED HDTV with 120 or 240 Hz but for the price this one get my vote.  Take my advice stay away from the Vizios (I own one) and proscans (nothing but trouble)of the world they don't even come close to Samsung.

First of all the price is higher than most other screen protectors.  But you have the peace of mind that you can get lifetime replacements.  If you are the type that takes care of you electronics this is a major factor that you must consider.  I have already asked for a replacement just after 4 months use.  I didn't get it replaced because the product didn't work but because it did protect my screen and the protector itself had a scratch.  I asked for a replacement and after a couple of e-mail with the warranty department my order was processing.  Yes you are paying for a screen protector but you are also getting great costumer service.  A must have for any tablet owner
Worked fine on a recent trip to Asia.

Considering that some folks are charging  over $10 per stylus for use use touch screens like tablets, these little gems are a steal, at less than $2/piece. They work extremely well and are very well made.

reviewText: I installed this in my android phone and proceeded to migrate all my pictures and other transferable items to this card. Thank goodness I did because I ended up getting the phone wet, and upon receiving my replacement phone all of my pictures were intact! I highly recommend this card. Also, I had about 3k pictures plus other items saved to this card and it wasn't even half full. It's a good capacity to grow with and secure place to store photos. I still recommend using Google Photos to back up your photos on wifi regardless. I know so many people that lose their phones and lose all their pictures as well. This can be easily avoided!

This unit is well made, not light, but well made. Once charged it is very slow to lose charge. It handles brief power outage needs without gasoline, noise or CO dangers. Unless you want to run your refrigerator and air conditioner, I suspect this is all you need during most 30 minute to 2 hour outages. Add in that it can start your car and you have a winning package.

Since I have Verizon FIOS with a Motorola set-top box, most of my channels are scrambled.  I bought this device with the primary intention of using the S-Video output of my set-top box to record, and I found that the device works extremely well in that mode.  Then I also put a splitter in front of my set-top box, and found that the picture quality is excellent for the unscrambled channels, as well.Just for the record, my PC is a Hewlett-Packard HPE-490t with an Intel I7 980X processor, and have 16 Gbytes of memory.  I am running the Windows 7 Ultimate 64 bit operating system, and have a Radeon HD 5570 video adaptor card.  I seem to be able to multi-task quite well when I am viewing or recording video.I have noted that other reviewers seem to have problems with the card when they use the Win TV V7 software supplied by Hauppage.  I have had no such problems with it, and it in fact seems to be ideal for my purposes.  Perhaps recent Microsoft updates to Windows 7 may have corrected the underlying problems?Regardless, I am quite satisfied with the product, and it is a bargain at the price.
summary: Works Great With Windows 7 and I7 980X Processor

reviewText: This is a tremendous camera with lots of cool features. Most importantly it takes good pictures. The zoom is special.

My car came with bluetooth handsfree-phone support, but not bluetooth streaming audio.  So the Griffin fills that missing feature.  The BlueTrip is extremely small and barely visible above the plug.  Music sound quality is excellent.  Volume level is perfect.So I really have no complaints about the product - it was exactly what I was looking for.
summary: Exactly what I was looking for...

reviewText: My wife is from Germany so she lives on skype to keep in touch with her distant family. This camera has allowed us to transition away from Macintosh to PC. We had to switch due to an issue with mac that could not be resolved by anything other than a PC. So reluctantly we built 2 desktop PCs. We needed a camera so we came here and did a search for some good ones. This one came up several times in our search. We decided to try it out and I must say we are very pleased.(+) The installation is very easy.(+) It has a much larger lens than some other cameras it allows more light in. This means it works well in low light conditions.(+) We have 25MBps broadband connection we are able to transmit at very high quality. Everyone we have connected to on skype has mentioned how good the quality is.(+) The funky foot thing allows it to be mounted in a variety of strange positions.(-) Video software tries to force you to use MSN to chat.Overall this is a great camera to get for any video conferencing you might do.Thank you for reading my review.
summary: Excellent camera for Skype on Windows 7 64

reviewText: As a technologically challenged person, I waited until my son flew in for a visit before trying these. I've had trouble in the past getting bluetooth to hook up! After rolling his eyes he showed me what to do and how to do it and I was like--'this is easy-peasy I can do this!'I have tried ear-buds from the cheapies to the more expensive ones--they basically hurt my ears. One of the things that attracted me to these were the way the ear-bud had a device to 'kind of hang' on the ear. I won't state that they were totally comfortable, but they were a lot better than many I've tried and Jaybird gives you three choices for the size and that really really helps.The sound is good both the music and the phone aspect. These are the first bluetooth headphones I've tried and I can't really compare them to anything else other than connected 'buds. I'm very pleased with them. The battery charge lasts the length for my needs which is mainly walking the dog three times a day for twenty to sixty minutes an hour. One of the things I really like about them is the ability to change the volume control quickly. I keep the volume low to make sure I am aware of my surroundings. I have an XXL dog and often little male dogs seem to think they have to show their macho-ness and challenge her, so the ability to become instantly aware of any challengers without ripping them ear-buds out is a wonderful attribute!

Very roomy and fits all of my gear nicely. I was looking for something that would hold everything in one case. This does the trick. Lenses, power adapters, lense hoods, battery packs, chargers, cables, books, cleaning kit, filters, and more. I have a small satchel style bag that really can only handle the camera with a lense on it, a spare lense, batteries and a cleaning kit. I had to use a second bag to carry all the adapters, cables, power packs/chargers and miscelaneous stuff in. I will still use this bag if I am taking select stuff for a shoot but it is more convienient to have all my equipment in one location so I know where it is, plus it frees up my hands for carrying stuff and opening doors.

I built a HTPC using the mini-itx motherboard. The motherboard was an Intel DQ77KB that uses an external brick. The case was a little bigger due to the internal power supply that came with the case. I removed it and this left empty room in the case. I thought the case could have been smaller for this reason but after the build was done, this extra room was used for cable routing. The end result, it I did not need to fight with cable routing. I used a slim ODD and 2.5" HD. Everything went together easily and quality is great. Although the general cost of mini-itx cases are high, this case was quite affordable and was actually on the low end of the price range. Could not be happier.
summary: Smal Mini-ITX case but not too small.

reviewText: tried many ways, but could not handle fax.  gets cut off.good sound quality if you try to make a phone call.

The price is right, the build is good, the slide surface could use some modding to get dialed in.It is definitely a starter item.  The enamel or powdercoating on the tracks does have some texture that is perceptible when sliding.  I can't really free slide with it, I need to have two fingers on the block, and two fingers on the track to create enough friction balance to keep the slide even.  I am not calling this slider faulty by any means.  It is a really good price point for those rare shots if you don't want to break the bank.  If you know you are going to be doing a lot of slidering, I bet there are good ones out there that make more sense.  The build quality is substantial, and it is something I can bring to all terrain and not feel bad if it gets dinged up.Worth a consideration.-R
summary: Solid starter slider, you may outgrow it.

reviewText: I originally purchased this two years ago to use with my Android. I found it impractical to use with a phone and that I was much better off using Swype or Swiftkey "soft keyboards" as my primary means of data entry. Fast forward to two years later and when recently got myself an iPad. Along with it I immediately purchased the $70+ Logitech Ultra Thin Keyboard. It has a great form factor. But it's one disadvantage is that it can't be used with a case on. Plus, don't be foolled by the claim that the keyboard itself is a case because, once you snap your iPad in place with the magnet, it only protects the screen.Being that I wanted a full blown case that offers all around protection, the Logitech Tablet Keyboard is a nice old school style of keyboard that works for my purposes at least around the house. There's a good chance that I'll use the Ultra Thin Keyboard at Starbucks, just to look cool, but if this is the ticket for me when I'm around the house with kids who can't keep their hands of my iPad. I need that case to stay on and this keyboard allows me to do it.
summary: Works great with iPad...with advantages over the Logitech Thin Keyboard

I don't like the fact that Samsung did not design the keyboard with a separate battery that can add a little more life to the tablet and it actually uses power from the tablet giving it a shorter battery life. reviewText: I bought this for a three year old because my tablet was just to big for his little hands.  It has three advantages for us: it is small enough for his hands (and he loves it), the cost is way below that of an Ipod, and the battery only last a couple hours so we don't have to worry about him being on it all the time.  He just plays till the battery goes dead then we put it on a shelf until night, when we charge it while we are asleep.  It works great that way for us.  I did not give it a 5 rateing because it is a little bulky compared to his sister's Ipod.  Herb

This combo is harder to find than one might expect.  3.5mm<--iphone/ipod ctrl+mic -->>3.5mm.  For whatever the reason you might use this cable, it's probably easier to buy several of these than find the inline control and the two ring 3.5mm jack as parts.  When I first connected this cable to my non-beats-headphones, the controls didn't work, as others have reported.  I popped the plastic cover off the control, moved the microscopically small wires around a bit, and got it working. Since then, when the controls have gone wonky (where the mic would work, but not the buttons), reseating the plug in the phone cured it. Since the phone plug is 90 degrees to the cable (which is a plus to me) I'm not positive the plug was seated correctly to begin with.  It's a snug fit against the case. Anyway, the controls now work as expected, and the mic works for phone calls.  The red insulation is not the same material as the actual beats cable, so for those that have beats 'phones, if you want that, you might want to keep looking. Otherwise, this aggressively priced cable gives that combo of 3.5mm to 3.5mm with a control in between..  I'll use it till it breaks, then consider the $$$$ beats cable.  In the meantime... handy.
does what it is supposed to, but didn't really cure what I was trying to accomplish.  Belkin is always a good, trusted name.

Amazing pretty much sums it up. I have a fanless netbook (Dell Mini 1012) with an internal TV tuner and HD decoder (Broadcom Crystal HD). With my netbook just sitting idle I felt it got too warm, much less with it accomplishing a task. And with an HD vid playing it got straight out hot. Viewing HD broadcast television and I am not exaggerating when I say the bottom was hot to the touch in places and the heat would rise through the keyboard! I tried a few things, one of which I reviewed here at Amazon which was not effective. I tried a friend's fan / stand that he gave to me because he said it didn't work. And it didn't! It just blew hot air all over.But this MS cooling base? I was cynical...but it works. That's all I can say. My Dell Mini fits almost perfectly (it fits well) and I don't know how they did it or what engineering tricks they used, but I ran the Mini on full HD broadcast television for an hour. It used to take just minutes to heat up, as the two components required to run the television in HD conspired to melt my poor netbook from the inside out.  But I checked the Mini after watching HD news for 60 mins, and it was not hot! Not even close. In fact, it was barely warm. I don't know if it's a combination of the cooling base AND the design of the Mini's vent system, but as said I tried a few other solutions with no results. This gave me results which far surpassed my expectations. I expected a drop in temps that wouldn't be felt, but rather just something to help keep 'em lower for the sake of component life. But this thing prevents my "hot as an iron" Mini from getting too warm, much less even a little hot. As said, amazing.Should note since it is not a "verified" purchase I ordered mine from w00t. Which is an Amazon owned site.
This hood fits my Canon 18 - 55 mm Kit lens perfectly and work well with no vignetting. Very pleased with the price and the quality.

This is kind of a cool idea but as others have stated, yes, it is just a piece of silver plastic. The little H beam thingy is what really jacks up your trackpad. It renders all but the bottom right square inch of the trackpad useless unless you exert Herculean strength. Hate to say it because I really wanted to like it, but this is overpriced and while it works very well at holding keyboard and trackpad together, it does so at the expense of usability.
summary: A good idea, but in practice...notsomuch...

reviewText: First off; I read all of these reviews and compared every other comparable option I could find before choosing this unit.  Wi fi set up was painless, the setup wizard is somewhat helpful.  Most importantly, I have a Bose Wave Music system.  This unit is no comparison to that whatsoever.  I can rattle the house with that little Bose unit, and this thing rattles and whines if you attempt to turn it up beyond half way.  Recommend you do not do this.  This is okay though because the Bose system is just an AM/FM clock radio with a CD player.  Shame on them for not upgrading their content and still charging significantly more than the cost of this.  I rate this five stars because I believe its the best all in one item like this available.  Adding speakers and wires is a mess for me, and I don't need to crank up the volume.  The sound is acceptable at half to me, and I am also a Led Zep station listener.  I didn't care about AM stations (never really have) but if you were ever into HAM radio's or knew someone who was, this thing delivers those thrills without the need for the fine tuning and antenna placement.  I personally prefer the Pandora option to avoid commercials though, and have closed my eyes and mentally transported myself back to the 70's when I was a teenager falling asleep to my clock radio.  That alone is a five star experience for me, and Iphone charging, and the record options now become the "gravy".

This is one of the best looking covers I have seen. You cannot really tell from the picture but it really looks like an old leather-bound book, possibly a journal, accenting the Kindle quite nicely. Out of all the covers, it has received the most compliments when I have taken it out. The texture of it is nice, feeling the part, making me glad I carried it sometimes after a long day's work.The design is basic, which is not a bad thing, with the four corner mounting doing its job pretty well. This type has extra thick straps which make me feel better about it, along with the cover which is not the thickest but that does the job well. Note that it is advertised as a Lite as well, so the case is not supposed to be brick hard. The inside has a small pocket on the inside as well, allowing you to stick a couple of sheets of paper or a receipt or whatever inside. This is kind of nice too, because i like taking my Kindle shopping but forget my lists if carrying too many separate things.You can stand it up to watch movies or play games if you want as well, which is pretty nice, and the look really highlights reading. The only thing I would say on selection is to make certain that you buy the right style for yourself, not picking it solely on the outer aesthetics.

powers a couple webcams with built in IR led lights and provides switching for other LAN devices in that area of the building.  all of my network gear is netgear so i know compatibility is never an issue.  the only issue ive had with netgear is with the power supplies.  i've had two fail, but they are cheap to replace.

I have a few of these cables (a couple HDMIs and a couple of usbs) and these cables are the jam. The reason is simple. These cables cost as much as low quality cables do, and they are made as well as the high quality cables are. There is nothing else you need to know.

Overall this is a very good radar detector with a good range for detection.My only complaint is that when the sun is low (which is often in winter in Mass), the radar detector annoyingly detects it as a laser alert. Other than that the false positive detections are less than I experienced on cheaper radar detectors.
summary: Reliable but laser detector confused with sun

reviewText: The seller advertises it as a "brand new" amplifier, not used or refurbished.But as soon as I opened up the box was possible to see several marks of use.The power supply has scratches all over and the amplifier had fingerprints and dents on the wire connectors.The volume control is bent, totally assembled out of center position (kinda hard to describe the situation).Well...I got fooled. The problem is I trusted on the seller and didn't check the equipment before get back to Brazil (my country) and now I can't return it! The seller is irresponsible and deceptive! I've been using Amazon's version of Apple's USB A to Lightning cable with a variety of Apple mobile devices, including iPhones and an iPad Mini, for both charging and syncing.It works without any problems or warnings from iOS. Amazon has built its cable somewhat differently than Apple, though. First, both the USB and Lightning plugs are longer, wider, and thicker than on Apple's cable. This may be an advantage for people who have difficulty grasping and pulling small objects or have mobility problems with their hands. Second, the cable itself is slightly thicker and heavier than Apple's. Finally, the finish on the Amazon cable is somewhat slippery to the touch while Apple cables have a rubbery finish.The only (inconsequential) problem with Amazon's cable is related to the Frustration Free packaging certification. While the cable is packed in a box that is easy to open, the plug ends come tightly wrapped in sticky plastic. Removing this plastic wasn't as easy as "Frustration Free" implies.Bottom line: the AmazonBasics Lightning cable is a seamless, value priced alternative to Apple cables, as long as you don't mind having the Amazon logo on both plug ends. And keep in mind this cable may not fit into device cases with a narrow or deep Lightning opening. Four stars.

Anyone that sees my wall mounted TV says they need to get one so.... I do love it. It's a bit of a beast to install. 2 people is better than but I've done it myself so it can be done. What else can I say if your going to wall mount it this is the one you'll want.

compared with the fans that come with the corsair case these do not help much, I recommend for a country where the climate is cooler than Venezuela because the average temperature in my country is 28 degrees celcius so needed some more power.

Is it the fastest? No.Is it a well priced SSD with a decent Sandforce controller? Yes.Software is nice, no problems with install. Not to much to say beyond that. It's a storage device I don't want to really have to think about it besides checking free space and running TRIM once a week or so.

I bought two of these on Cyber Monday as Christmas gifts (one to myself and one to my grandparents).We just set them up today, and they both run smooth, were easy to install, and are functional - quietly so.I have an LG TV, and I like the brand LG so I wanted to stick with it and I am glad I did, because these are great.I will update this if I have any other comments, but so far every feature works on BOTH bd players.I will stay loyal to LG for some time it seems.Also, some quick updates after having this running for the whole day:*********People have been saying that this does not resume playback, as in, it doesn't start back up from where it was stopped. I noticed this happened when I turned off the player from the pause state, because stop obviously stops the disc and I didn't want to leave it running when I left the house. However, another movie I had decided to just eject from the pause state, and after watching a few other discs, the ejected disc that was in a pause state started back up from that spot when I put the disc back in. I don't know if every disc will do this, but so far it's resumed playback this way.The other thing is, if you are a quiet person and have a quiet room or bedroom, you may notice some sounds from the player. Just a faint high-pitch hum during playback or pause, and you can pretty much always clearly hear the laser moving when you skip, pause, etc. Nothing too dramatic, but enough to drive you nuts once you focus in on it. Just a minor flaw, but this is still the best device for the money.

The Thermaltake V6 isn't the prettiest case made, nor is it the best constructed, but man, can this keep the heat at bay.  I've built systems since the mid-eighties, but this case seems to have the best cross flow of all of them.  The top comes with a 200mm draw fan, the back comes with a 120mm draw.  I installed a 120 intake on the front, and another on the side.  The 200mm fan sits over the CPU (i7 2600k with a 212 cooler),and the back draw is directly in back of the chip.  The CPU idles at 30degrees C, and it hit 62 degrees once when I played Crysis for a few hours.  The GPUs ( 2 bridged 560s) idle at almost the same as the CPU, and have gone up as high as 65 degrees C.  I do have to admit that with 2 fans per GPU, the chip cooler fan, and the four case fans, the noise reminds me of living in back of a turbo aircraft, but earphones solve that problem, and to heck with complaining neighbors.

This item, I had to wait 3 weeks to receive it.  I always buy from Amazon, and never waited over a week. I have a New HDTV, and wanted to just add a better sound. My TV has the standard red and white cable. This Sony speakers have the older red and black wire pop in. I went and bought the red and white adapter so I could plug it in the back of my TV.  After all that, the speakers would not come on at all. I wanted to call Sony, but the numbers given would not connect. I then decided to email them and this is when I found out that you need an amplifier or receiver. I guess the newer televisions do not come with this. I always just plug them in the back of my older televisions and it was done. The system does seem really nice, for the looks anyway. The wood is black and looks real. The other two speakers are not small as some of others I have had. I wish I could have heard how the system played. I just can't believe that in all the reviews, this was never mentioned. I surely do not want to add more money in this system. This is why I had to just give this a 2 star rating. If you happen to have a amplifier, then I would say try it out.

Pros:I didn't know what the track pad buttons would be like, but they are raised with little dimples so you can easily feel the 9 different selections without looking.Decent range, doesn't need line-of-sight.Light weight, feels solid.Cons:Wish it had a backlight keyboard, though that would probably drain battery pretty bad.It's a little large, I was hoping it would be the size of my blackberry, it basically requires two hands to type which isn't a huge disadvantage, especially since you don't have to hold it up and point it.Seems to go to sleep quickly, you have to wait a few seconds for it to wake up.You'll probably want to turn the sensitivity up if you have a large screen resolution.  This product is decent, not amazing.  If you own a blackberry, it is possible to use as an HTPC remote via bluetooth (do a google search-up), I prefer the size of something like a blackberry because the keyboard is easier to use.  This isn't a bad device, and for the price I can't necessarily say I'm disappointed.
summary: A few cons and a few pros.

reviewText: But this item does work well. With all the iPod type items this might have limited use but I like it. Off-on button isn't the best

I purchased two of the HGST Travelstar Hdd for use with an Atomos Ninja-2 monitor/recorder. This particular model is one of the preferred drives for use in the Ninja. You should be very careful when installing this unit in the drive carrier provided with the recorder. The drive carrier is made from plastic and if you tighten the attachment screws too tightly you will not be able to remove the carrier easily. (My advice is to snug the screws to just even with the plastic surface...this  IS  a big deal if you do not want to disassemble the Ninja to remove the drive)

I needed a battery that had more power for my camcorder needs, I decided to purchase this one, I'm glad that I did, it serves my purpose, get it if you need the same type of battery, I highly do recommend it!
Bought many of these to put into my Synology NAS at home, and they work like a charm !  One of them went bad early, but I got it replaced by Amazon and everything has been going smoothly.

This system is identical to the Tom Tom 140 S, so if you don't mind the smaller screen, I would purchase it instead. If you want the larger screen, which I prefer, stick with this one. I've used a few different GPS systems and this is my favorite, by far. Out of the Garmin, Magellan, and Tom Tom, it just performed the best. When starting up the unit, you can choose from male or female voices and language preference and there are actually many to choose from. You can also change the color and lay out of your map, etc. This system actually has a feature where the unit gets louder as you accelerate, to compensate for the noise the car is making. Miles and time left to arrive at destination are displayed in the lower middle of screen along with the current time and estimated arrival time. It displays the speed limit and your actual speed in the lower right corner, which turns red if you are going 5 miles or more over the limit. The limit changes almost instantly when you see a speed limit sign. I was really amazed by the accuracy of that. Keep in mind that this is only on interstates, highways, and main roads. It actually didn't display the speed limit at all on other roads. It displays the miles until your next turn in the lower left portion of the screen. With this large screen, they can display so many things right there on the screen along with the map. It's just so difficult to flip back and forth when you aren't familiar with the roads you're on anyway, so it's nice not to have to with this system. A Major plus is that the keyboard is layed out like an actual computer keyboard, the Magellan and Garmin we've tried were not. They were layed out in alphabetical order, which was aggervating, as we were fumbling through the letters every time we tried to use it. This unit also shows you which lane you need to be in when exiting the interstate, etc. There are green arrows and it is so very clear which lane you should be in. I am female and sometimes have real trouble understanding directions. So this thing is never leaving my dash board. Even my husband was impressed by this one. I will be adding photos of the different displays shortly, so please check them if you are interested in viewing some of the things I've discussed. I have 1 small complaint about this system. My problem with this GPS is the problem that everyone is stating about not taking any of the updates offered to me. I would hate to ruin my system, so I'm not doing any updates, but I would hope that they would correct such a widely experienced problem. I hope I never get mine wiped out that way. This isn't a huge issue for me and I would have chosen this one if I would have known in advance. I'm really enjoying it so far and am completely impressed with the Tom Tom brand.Note: There is a place in the settings where you can change your preference to make the gps system power off when you turn off your ignition. If you don't change this, it will stay on until the internal battery dies.
summary: My favorite GPS system, so far=)

reviewText: A while ago I purchased a Rokinon 85mm f/1.4 manual focus lens and while I love, love, love the quality of this lens it can be hard to focus. I installed an AF confirmation chip to the lens which helps but when shooting at f/1.4 the depth of field is extremely shallow. Nailing the focus can be very difficult.  I was almost ready to sell this lens and get the Sigma 85mm f/1.4 for the autofocus alone.  As a last ditch effort I decided to give the Neewer HD Viewfinder a shot. For the price I figured what the hey! I am so glad I purchased this loupe! Not only is focusing now a breeze I found the overall handling of my camera to be much better as well. I wear glasses and the huge eyecup is very comfortable. Looking at the 3x magnification makes if feel like you're looking at a huge movie screen vs a tiny LCD.The only thing I don't really care for is the attachment on the Canon 60D.  When taped to the LCD you can no longer close the articulating screen. It's not a deal breaker for me because the benefits far out way this one little problem. I know there are attachment plates you can get that attach to the tripod mount so you don't have to put the loupe cover directly on the LCD but I haven't seen one that works with a grip yet.If you're into video or even manual focus lenses I would definitely put this on the list of must haves to use with live view! It's totally worth the money and cost ways less than many other viewfinder/loupe products.
summary: Wow! What a difference when manual focusing!

reviewText: I am old and so I know that my ears are basically worn out . . .  So I asked my office co-worker ( two thirds my age ) to give these a test.  He said they were 'horrible' and the worst he'd tried in a long time.  I tried to defend the buds by calling them 'very accurate'.  He wouldn't go for that and said it ( the buds ) made the music sound like crap.  No bass to speak of.  He was hooking up to his ( third generation ) ipod.  He said apple's stock buds were great compared to mine.  He hoped I had not paid too much for them.  I lied and said that i didn't...

The first day I got the tablet, I was really excited to have it and use it. I installed all my favorite apps on it that night. Unfortunately, I powered it down overnight, and when I turned it on, it told me that some of my critical apps didn't work, and the entire tablet crashed several times. Furious, I tried uninstalling and reinstalling the apps, but to no avail.Finally, I got so frustrated, I performed a factory reset and only installed only a few apps, including the ones that didn't work before. After the factory reset, everything works like a charm. After a week of use, it has yet to malfunction on me, and the battery lasts for an incredible length of time.If you are initially frustrated by this tablet, try a factory reset. It completely solved my problems, you may have some similar luck. Don't give up on it right away.
summary: Needs some tinkering, but totally worth the price.

reviewText: Pros: Definitely makes a nice stand at any angle (thanks to the ingenious design with velcro feet). Can even have the power adapter plugged in, although at a flatter angle so as not to put pressure on and bend the cord, and cause a break... but in a pinch it works.  The design is nice, feels good to hold and you know it's not going to slip right thru your fingers.Cons: Could be just a TAD more fitted/snug, but not even really an issue. All cutouts are perfectly positioned. Nice (sarcasm) plastic smell, I'm guessing from the plastic outer wrap of the manufacturer.Glad I opted for this one!
Awesome! Used in a gaming computer and it worked no problem. Was a bit scary trying to put into my motherboard though, felt like I was going to break it.

I had not used a Wacom tablet in years. My first experience with them was with a very early model and it was not pleasant. I think that's why I waited to so long to buy the Intuos4. Now I only wish that I had bought it sooner. The tablet was a breeze to set up on my Mac Pro. All the software works perfectly with Mountain Lion. I have very poor eye hand coordination and I have found that if I zoom in tightly on an area of an image I am editing I can use gross motor skills which are easier for me than fine motor manipulations for editing. The customizable soft buttons are great. They basically map frequently used commands or key strokes to them. The wheel is also great. I have one on the functions of the wheel set up as step back/step forward depending on which way I turn the wheel in Photoshop. In this way I can quickly zoom back and forth between multiple levels of undo/redo. I chose the Intuos4 even though it is the older model because of all the reviews I read of the Intuos5 having software issues. I can not say for certain if those reviews are accurate or not. I do, however really like the tablet I have.If you are in the market for a graphics tablet, this is a great one, and at least when I bought it, it was a great price.
summary: So much easier than the old ones

reviewText: So far I like this keyboard. I bought to use in a dark room and it works well. Plug and play (like most [everything?] usb) now. It is an off brand but I was willing to take a chance. I have been using it for about 3 months now and no problems but time will tell. Give it a shot or buy logitech for more.I really like the fact that it is a WIRED backlit keyboard - I don't want to be changing batteries every few months.

I'm going to be brief...I like these speakers and they produce a nice sound quality considering what they are. If you're looking for great speakers producing a broad spectrum of sound these aren't going to make you happy. But for someone who just wants a decent set of speakers to use externally on a DVD/CD player (which has lousy internal speakers) this more than fits the bill. Excellent volume. I recommend them especially for travel purposes.

I was disappointed in the speed of the eSATA transfer using an eSATA HD bought at the same time as this unit, but otherwise it supports All 2.5" and 3.5" SATA Hard Disk Drives which I have used, Hot-Swaps Capability for Rapid Multi HDDs Access and Exchange (it's most important feature) and supports eSATA Transfer Speed up to 3Gbps (or less!)
summary: Does what it's suppose to do, but a little slow

reviewText: It fits snug and provides good power to my iPhone. I bought mine in 2010 and haven't had any problems with it.

A large battery with a handy flashlight as a bonus. It's 1800mah battery holhds more juice than most devices out there, will give you a full charge and have some to spare. It also supports all voltage outputs I needed, a problem I've had with other chargers. The small LED flashlight is fairly weak consisting of just a single LED with no reflective material to amplify the light like in most traditional flahslights, but it still has many uses I find myself pulling it out of my pocket at least once a day when I need a light and it was of great help when I lost a tire at night. On a full charge the LED light stayed on for over 24 hours(this was during a time I was trying to trouble shoot why it suddenly would not charge an Omnia 2 phone, turned out to be a problem with the phone not charger).But there are a few flaws... The included retractable cable while nice and with several different tips was overly large and bulky and stopped working completely after not to long. The power switch is very easy to bump or rub against and either turn off when you want it on or turn the flashlight on while it's sitting in your pocket. Frankly it should be able to autodetect whether a cable is plugged in like most other chargers can, but fortunately being an LED light it uses up very little power if you accidentally turn it on and leave it sitting in your pocket all day. Final gripe is that the USB port is very lose fitting it's very easy to accidentally pull your cord out with the lightest tug.I also do not like how it charges via a mini usb when the world around it has switched to micro usb, means I can't charge the charger with the same cable I use to my phone(micro usb). Wasn't a big deal during the short time the included cable worked as I could just carry both tips but after it stopped working I just replaced it with a retractable micro usb, and now it's becoming more and more difficult to find a mini usb cable at hand when it needs a charge(which fortunately isn't often).
summary: Good charger but with a few drawbacks

reviewText: EDIT April 2011:A recent comment on my review got me thinking about this product again.  After I tossed out the one that failed on me (I was just barely outside the return window), I bought another.  That one has been working just fine for over 6 months.  Based on this, I feel comfortable rating this as a 4.  Based purely on functionality/size/ease of use/price it probably tends toward a 5... but questionable quality/reliability (i.e. you might get a lemon like I did the first time), holds it back to a 4.EDIT August 2010:I have bumped my review score from a 5 down to a 2 for this item.  A couple of weeks ago, i.e. after just a month or so of use, I started having intermittent audio drop-outs... and then sparklies... and then complete loss of signal.  Even after dialing from 1080i down to 720p and then 480p, no signal.  After some troubleshooting, I bypassed this switch (keeping the rest of the LONG signal chain in place), and was able to get signal to my TV again -- implicating this switch as the culprit.I am confused as to why it died a slow/gradual death, rather than a sudden one.  There was a period of a few days where the switch was "usable," just with audio drop-outs and video sparklies before it finally gave up for good.  Going to see if I can return this and get it replaced, or if I just have to take it as a loss (if so... at least it was cheap).ORIGINAL REVIEW JULY 2010:I bought this as part of the signal chain feeding HD sources in my basement to a new plasma TV installed upstairs over my fireplace (see my HDMI extenders review for more details).  I selected it mainly because:1. It has 3 ins to 1 out, which is what I required for my system.2. It has IR control capability, with discrete commands for each input already present in the Harmony Remote database.3. Reviews stated it did not require an external power supply (in spite of the 5VDC in present on it).4. VERY reasonable price, and Prime-eligibleI now have it installed and it is meeting/exceeding all my expectations.  I had it passing 1080p with no problems; I eventually scaled back to 1080i due to the characteristics of my overall signal chain (again, I'll refer you to my HDMI extenders review for more detail... but in summary, it involves 27' of HDMI cable, a HDMI-to-Cat5e extender system, and ~80' of Cat5e cable) and it has been performing great.  It truly does not need AC adapter; it's drawing whatever power it needs over HDMI.  No A/V glitches or hiccups, no signal degradation, very quick switching between inputs, and it never misses an IR command (since I have an emitter bug stuck right to the IR receiver!).  Just a great little (REALLY little) switch.
summary: Works like a champ, takes up minimal space, and no wall-wart required.

reviewText: Great additional for my studio. I have the Manfrotto floor-to-ceiling stands and they work perfectly with it; attaching my lights to the pole. Very sturdy and easy to work with.

Bought this for my 8 year old after buying his older brother a 4'th gen, 32 gig iPod Touch because he'd been grabbing his brother's iPod on the down low and messing with his apps...lol I didn't want to get him a 'great' tablet like Galaxy Tab or Kindle Fire HD for two reasons, the first is that between he and my 5 year old they'd scratch, ding, dent and eventually break it, the other reason is that I might have taken it as my own, so the Coby Kyros it was. I didn't expect the overall quality to be outstanding but it turned out that the stock operating system is not "sanctioned(?)" by Android and so one can't use Play Store apps. I downloaded a "patch (again...?)" and the "official" Gingerbread OS which has worked really well. I did this a while back but I'll be posting the links & steps later. The screen is just OK, the sound is just OK, the battery life is `meh and the entire thing feels flimsy BUT!... I only paid like $90 for an Android wi-fi tablet for an 8 year old child so I'm content even with all the "flaws" I pointed out.
I like the fact that you can turn off parts of the strip independently.  Good construction, use it every day.  Lets see how long it lasts :)
1.2 swr out of the box. easy up in minutes and has great reception and talks great. Would buy again.

Purchased this board because my new soundcard wouldn't fit in my old board. Gigabyte makes good quality boards, I've owned three in the past and I have always been happy with them. LGA775 is being retired after 7 years now, so it's hard to find higher end LGA 775 boards now. I consider this board midstream as it lacks dual PCIe x16 slots and it lacks RAID capability. The layout is ok and unless you run a large graphics card you will be able to use all PCIe x1 slots but that's the case with most boards.The BIOS offers a plethora of options catering to overclockers and for the most part works out of the box with all options set to Auto. The only thing to keep in mind is to set the USB Keyboard and Mouse to "Enabled" otherwise you will not be able to do a new OS install.

At first I was impressed by the build quality. Unfortunately the housing has a little bit of give which seem to make the connections flakey. When ever I need to adjust the box, the HDMI looses its connection. It works fine as long as I don't touch it and the floor doesn't vibrate too much.

I can only echo the superlatives for this speaker/sub package. I've also got a set of the Take Five Classics, which I've used for years. The new speakers and sub seems to be a bit more refined, but it's a pretty close call as to which might be better. I'm running these through a Yamaha RX-V577 receiver, and couldn't be more pleased. I wanted to write this review, however, to commend Energy for its customer service. When I received the speakers, the center speaker was defective. I didn't want to have to pack up everything (5 speakers plus sub woofer) to return to Amazon, so I called Energy customer service. They asked me to send an email describing my problem, and include contact information and proof of purchase. Within a week I received a new center speaker. I didn't have to send back the defective speaker.

gals, i've used this on the very fine, thin hairs on my face and on my abdomen.... this thing works sooooo well!!! i was pleasantly surprised.  initially this was just for the abdomen.. but the day of my dentist appt i noticed the hairs above my mouth (i hadn't had a wax in over three weeks) so i used this and within a five mintues all of the hairs were GONE!!! i love this and will definitely continue to use this (i hope it doesnt get discontinued).  AND the shipping was pretty fast too!!!

Bought this amp to replace my 35-year-old Carver M-400 home stereo amp when it finally gave up the ghost.  Easy to hook up and great sound for about 1/5 of what I paid for the Carver 35 years ago -- plus I got an additional 100 watts of power.  (500 watts into 8 ohms -- 1000 watts into 4 ohms.  The Carver was pumping 402 watts into 8 ohms)  The cooling fans are quiet and don't make any more noise than a computer fan.  It drives my 40-year-old Kenwood KR-777 speakers to paint-pealing volume without even breathing hard.

reviewText: I had no issues with setup, including the network (both wired and wireless - I tried both - sticking with wired).  Browser is not useful without a wireless keyboard - the remote is useless as a keyboard.  I played around with the apps - not very useful to me.  I don't have a streaming plan on Netflix, so that's out.  Same with Hulu Plus.  Other apps are just useless (IMHO) - yoga, food, stuff I can get on my laptop or via my cable channels.  Sony's Crackle app is severely broken.  Not only does it not play the entire video stream, it locks up the 580 (I need to pull the plug out of the wall to reset it) when the video stops.  A quick peek in the Crackle user forum verifies my hunch that there is something very, very wrong with Crackle.  Streaming (in general) has a long way to go.I probably could have gone with a unit without many of these features, but the 580 was reasonably priced and not much more than the "lesser" units.FWIW - I also have a Samsung TV, with a Sony AVR.  I've connected all of them via HDMI cables, which suggests that the HDMI-CEC protocol should work...and it does...despite Sony and Samsung warning that the feature "does not work with other manufacturers' equipment."  Hmmm, isn't that the point of having a standard?My fingers are crossed that the video quality/performance is top notch, as this is about all I have left to use on this unit!
summary: So far, so good, with some issues

reviewText: I ordered this for our church because we lose power occasionally and it wipes out the daily sermon that is recorded on our computer. I now don't have to worry about losing any recordings when the power goes off. I have tested this power pack and it seems to be working fine. I am hopeful that it will give me many years of good use.
