The PC Clean Machine Personal PC Concierge Service (whose name is quite the mouthful) is a nifty little device. A thumbdrive, the consumer puts it into a USB port and it downloads itself into the computer, uploads a mass of data to somewhere (India, I believe) where it is scrutinized, analyzed and collated. A service call is scheduled (a virtual one...you could tell its out of the US, they literally scheduled mine DURING Thanksgiving dinner) and a variety of services are completed. The 'service log' is below. My comments will follow:Good Morning,This is the First Preventive Maintenance Service report from "PC Clean Machine" on the status of your computer (ARQF57TKD4).Please find attached to this mail the "live log" which is a special security log with information about the tasks done by the technician on your computer. This "live log" will show that the technician repaired and maintained your applications and operating systems files, but was not allowed to access or look at anything personal, including your data, photos, music, etc. It is part of our five part security process, the safest in the world.Apart from this, we log in and log-off on your computer using our own user account named "CleanMachine". This is done so that your desktop settings and preferences are not changed. If you find any difference on your desktop screen when you view it after the maintenance has been done, please log off and log in with your account.Attached as well is the "Maintenance Report", which will give you an insight on the list of all the activities our concierge has performed on your computer.Summary:  Performed antivirus scan using McAfee antivirus. No threats found.  Performed antivirus scan using Windows Defender. No threats found.  Windows update: Found to be updated with the latest Windows Update patches.  Performed Error checking on local drive to recover bad sectors.  Disk cleanup saved up to 5.29 MB of disk space.  Average broadband rate: 5.087 Mbps.  Download speed: 7816 kbits in1.52 sec.Comments: The service is a solid one for the non-technically inclined. Anyone who has been using their computer for a long time probably does most of these services automatically, either through Macafee, Windows update services or any of a dozen or so other applications.  Here, its done automatically. They scheduled my next call for Jan 28 2009.When I wrote them back to say I did all of that anyway, they replied that they are also available if I ever have any trouble and need help. Being the tech savvy one in my household, its good to know they're out there, in case I ever need them!
I'm using it in my 1st point n shoot camera, a panasonic dmc zs8 and it works just fine. hopefully it's enough memory lol

First off, this lens shoots amazing pictures with incredible color accuracy. That being said, hopefully there's a lot of light when you're shooting with this, because the f/4 forces you to shoot very slow in low light. The VR-II helps to maintain great shots at these low settings, but I find myself wishing this lens was at least a 2.8. Truly this lens just feels so slow (aperture wise) when compared to my 1.8 50mm. Of course... it is much slower, but when I'm shelling out this much money for a lens, I'd hope I'd be able to shoot at decent settings and not need a tripod all the time.That being said, when there's no clouds in the sky, this lens is a blast to use and produces amazing results. There are many shots I've taken that need no processing to achieve the original colors. I do have a little bit of buyer's remorse about buying an f/4 lens for as much as this beast costs; but I feel better about it every time it produces another perfect picture.

This antenna is a low quality item made in China. The material is super flimsy, disposable metal. It requires to be assembled with 2 bolts through 4 holes...sounds easy enough, except for the fact the holes don't line up correctly. When I finally got the bolts in after 30 minutes of swearing and finagling, one bolt was not perpendicular to the piece. It comes with an extremely poor photo copy of the assembly instructions. The quality is so poor, it is illegible.This is a cheap antenna at $24, but it is still priced too high for what it really is.
summary: You get what you pay for, but not this time

I have owned several iPods and I phones.  I recently purchased a previous model nano because I missed the feel of the click wheel on my original iPod.  Unfortunately, that nano went missing and so I had to decide whether to buy another previous model click wheel nano, or embrace the new touch model.  I took the plunge and fully expected to return this new model.  But then I opened it and the controls just work.  The new touch menu system is faster than the old wheel.  It's size is unreal.  The square screen is perfect for album art.  Yes, it did loose some features but I was ok with that because the video camera and microphone was always poor quality.  It also doesn't play videos, but seriously, with the small screen, video has always been useless on the Nano.  If you don't like the trade offs then look elsewhere.  But if you want an an incredibly small and intuitive audio player, this is it. I think this is really what the iPod Nano should be.

I've owned many computer speakers over the years, and the Logitech X-230 are one of my favorites for their combination of price and design.  They look modern and streamlined, and pack enough punch for most all desktop uses. I bought 3 sets of these x-230s over the last six months, to replace older, bulky, clunkier 3-piece speaker sets.  The new ones sound much better than what they replaced.Crank them all the way up, and you will notice the relatively weak middle range, but it's still very crisp and clear and hard to complain about at this price.  Also look for the "whitebox" OEM version of this product, which is somewhat cheaper and is the exact same product, minus the nice external box.The only minor drawbacks, that are addressed in Logitech's more expensive speakers, are:- the bass volume control is on the sub-woofer unit rather than on the speaker with the regular volume control- the fixed cable connecting to the two speakers to each other is relatively short. Not a problem unless you have an unusual desktop design (such as dual wide-screen flat-panels).But for their quality, these speakers are downright inexpensive.  Recommended.

first off let me say this type of adapter takes time to use on an iPad mini but will work. it is pretty cheaply made in construction and i doubt it will last long but you never know. the usb port works with my panasonic g5 occasionally and i even tried shooting some mp4 full hd 1080p 60fps video with my g5 on a 64gb class 10 at 29mb/s and used this adapter to import it onto my iPad mini running iOS 7. the adapter works better with just the sd card into it not going through the usb port and my camera. the micro sd card sold also works but is difficult at first to put your card in(make sure you line it up and be gentle) the cable is rather thin and the connections look weak. with all that aside however i do like the ability to import my dslm 16mp photos and share them on Instagram. the fact that i can get great photos and even videos onto my iPad mini directly is amazing.
summary: this thing is cheap but is totally useful.

reviewText: Just received my stand and love it already.  This one will work great.  The Kindle does not tip over and the stand remains in place.  I have another stand that I like just as much so I will have to share time with both of them.I did not have to assemble any thing for my stand (read some reviews that there was some assembly), it was ready to use right out the box. Only Bose can fool you with its name and be able to sell crap headphones for over $100. The sound quality is better than that of a cheap radio shack or walmart pair, but nowhere near of what it SHOULD be for the price range that it's in. My Bose headphones broke after not even a year of having them. The 3 tiny screws holding the speaker cup onto the bracket finally let loose once the cheapo plastic piece that they actually screw into cracked. Bose will not fix it. Every audiophile swears by Grado Labs, so I bought their SR80i and it makes me not want to touch any other brand ever again.

reviewText: I like it the sounds good but if feels like flimsy compared to sony E-series and the User interface is notthat friendly you have to familiarized the controls, but I returned it coz they send me a wrong item.

I have had my 1000HA for about a week and I could not be happier with it. I did a lot of research before buying and was convinced that ASUS offered the best quality for the money. I have not been disappointed. The build is excellent -- it feels very solid, but not heavy. WinXP runs very smoothly. I did buy the memory upgrade (2 GB), but I'm not sure I really needed it. I called ASUS tech support twice with questions and I was able to get through reasonably fast and the support people were friendly and helpful.The location of the right shift key is not a problem for me -- I don't use it. Although it's not always listed, the 1000HA DOES come with a case and a recovery disk.I highly recommend this unit!

Here it is in a nutshell...  expensive, but worth it.These are the truly the most comfortable earbuds I've ever worn and I can pleasantly leave them in for hours.Airplane-  I have a pair of BOSE QuietComfort 2 headphones that I've had for years now and would use on the plane.  The Klipsch earbuds do not cancel out as much white noise as the Bose headphones.  But, I would say they cancel out 50% - 65% of the white noise AND I can wear them for the whole trip.  I guess I'm a hot head because I can't wear the Bose for more than an hour without my ears getting hot.  The earbuds are also a lot easier to handle than the headphones.  I still take both of them on the plane, but I'm using the Klipsch almost exclusively.Car-  Driving down the road, I can't tell a difference between the Klipsch and the Bose.  Of course, there is a LOT less white noise than on a plane...  I use a Blackberry Bold 9000 and these work great with my phone except for the volume control buttons that don't work.  But the sound quality is truly awesome when talking and listening on these earbuds.I highly recommend these earbuds.

I am just starting in photography but realize the importance of a good lens. I bought this lens to try and capture indoor sporting events of my kids. Some of the pictures are great some not so but that is just a learning curve. I know this will be a great lens for the price. It is not weather sealed like its Canon cousin but I don't plan on doing much shooting in the rain. If you are on the fence, I recommend this lens.

It protects the glass.... But that's about it. To be fair I've only used the UV filter so far on my brand new 6D 24-105 lens. I normally, on all my other lenses I use a UV filter on at all times just as a protector to the glass. The first time I took it out for night/sunrise photography I had the UV filter on and was getting really bad lens flares from out of view lights. Only reason I gave it 3 stars was bc I haven't used the other filters. But the UV filter I give 3 stars.  Also used it to shoot a concert again got horrible lens flares and glares which once I took it off there were no flares/glares.
summary: Protects the glass but that's about it.

reviewText: A good cord at a reasonable price. Works well with our Samsung Galaxie Tab 2, and Note. Longer than the OEM cord, which is a big plus. We use them with Amazon Basic Chargers, and have never been disappointed.

reviewText: This is an item that might stay in your bag and not on the camera much of the time.  That is, if your shooting where there is shade to shade the screen of your camera.  But when you need this, you really need this.  I bought my GF1 because I only shoot in RAW, and I don't worry about JPEG.  I shoot in RAW, because I sell my work to magazines, and I need the best file out of the camera that I can get.  Lots of the time, I am shooting where the sun isn't directly on the screen on the back of the camera, and so I don't need the LVF1, but when you move to direct sun light, then you really are going to need this.  Works great, and you could keep it mounted on the camera if you wanted to.  There is a button on the side of the viewfinder that when you push, it moves between the camera screen or the LVF1 being what you view with.  What that means, if that you don't need to remove it to use the screen on the camera.
summary: I don't use this all the time, but when you need it you really need it.

reviewText: I had a 6 year old Apple SuperDrive that came from a 15" PowerBook G4 A1046 it w as 2X Super Drive with 16X CD-R Write Speed. I do a lot of work on computer repair I wanted to buy this since I got a lot of PATA or IDE DVD/CD Burners. It reads the disk and burn fine. Just this enclosure is Windows ONLY. I thought I try a Apple SuperDrive in the enclosure on Mac that was running 10.5.8 to see if it would pop up and I tried a Blank CD and a DVD Movie nothing. I tried on Windows 7 and booted up just fine. In fact I didn't have to install any drivers off the CD. See pictures above! This is worth the money!
summary: It Worth It! I converted a Apple SuperDrive to a External Burner for Windows!

reviewText: After reading all the reviews I finaly purchased the remote. The only flexible way to program the unit [as stated by many others] is through the Advanced computer USB Sync mode. Once you get over the hurdle of the first Advance programing of your various remotes the Sony remote will have to be updated for your paticular system set up. This is where the unit SHINES. You can amend your Advanced setups very quickly once you truly understand your systems needs. There is no way anyone would be able to set up the Sony AX 4000A and get all of your individual parameters figured out the first time. All my AV gear is from different manfactures, Projector, TV, Receiver, Cable Box, and a DVD Player. My kids use to laugh at me when I would line up the 6 remotes, eye glasses and flashlight to enjoy a movie. 6th remote is for a Hunter fan/light which does not use IR technology. Now I use the Sony Remote and the Hunter Fan/Light remote, no eye glasses the lighted screen is Great. Yes the first time to set up the remote can be very overwhellming but like any modern day computer based device given time you can become very proficient at it's use. I hope it works well for you maybe not the first time you set it up but maybe by the 4th or 5th time you will have this baby dialed in. Best of Luck

Power does seem to be an issue (ran out of juice after shooting about 50 minutes of video).My biggest peeve is the video capabilities. The software that came with the camera won't work on my Mac, so I've had issues trying to convert the AVCHD movies. You can switch to recording Quicktime movies, but they are limited to 2GB (which is only about 15 minutes of HD Quicktime).This is by no means the best camera I've ever owned. In the end I think it's overpriced for its feature set. Most users would be happier with something else.

I was having trouble with my laptop battery draining down even when plugged in with the charger. It would drain down and completely turn off. There would be a message popup that stated I needed to get a larger charger. Online were many "fixes" for this, most involving turning off the laptop, removing the battery, restarting the computer using the charger only, going into the tools and finding the battery information and deleting one of the files, power off the computer, reinstall the battery, restart and it would fix the "corrupt" file causing it. I did that, and it seemed to fix it but only for a day or two. It continued. I finally decided I was going to change the charger, so I searched Amazon, which is my shopping preference over all. I found this one which was actually a HP adapter. It was perfect, reasonably priced, and I have not had the problem with my laptop since. No more shutting off the computer, removing the battery, etc., etc., etc...... I would and DO recommend this product to anyone who has a HP laptop and suggest you get it immediately if your computer is doing what mine and others I read about online was doing. Sure saves you on aggravation.
My wife loves it! Multiple angles to view it at, removable bluetooth keyboaard, on/off switch to save the battery, and a LONG battery life!

reviewText: I have a 70" Vizio hanging from it.  It's a very sturdy and secure self adjusting mount that you can tilt and angle it as you wish.  You simply hold the TV in place for a few seconds and it stays.  You can also adjust the tension srews holding the tilting arm of the mount.  The Ollo was also great because it kept the TV far enough away from the wall for me to easily plug in cables.  You can also tilt the top of the TV towards the wall to help with cable installation.  This mount was about $75 cheaper then the flush mount I purchased a local store.  I would buy another Ollo.Downside is that it doesn't come with much instruction regarding the self locking tilt but the tech support was great.  They called back within a day of me emailing them and explained what to do. My only complaint is that in the universal kit I could not find screws that were long enough to fit my TV.  So, I had to take the screws from an existing TV mount that was used for my Sony 60".

These stands are perfect for those who live in apartments and cant or dont want to drill into walls.  They also have a slit down the arm that hides the cord and tie in perfectly to the Bose speakers for mounting.  Yes they're expensive but the height is great to create a home theater environment when sitting and they survived a move without scratches or bends.  The base is also nicely weighted so these things are secure!
summary: Great if you have Bose speakers

reviewText: I have had these headphones for more almost 2 years now. I am no audiophile but I can hear my 128 kbps mp3 files far better on these headphones as compared to my Creative I-Trigue L3800 (2.1) speakers. And by "light user" I mean AT LEAST one hour of use everyday. Because these perform better than my desktop speakers I have them plugged in pretty much all the time. The extra long, single-sided cord is useful even for home use (though its really a lot sometimes!). And I dont need to set my mp3 player volume greater than 25% of max (iAudio X5) to get excellent sound.Yes I agree they are not built that solid. Even though mine are in great condition, you can still feel its mostly plastic. But I have traveled with these headphones and I have also fallen asleep wearing them. I have also experienced no problems whatsoever with the ear cups/padding. Maybe I just got lucky!

Great accessory for my HP laptop.  Be sure you have a PC Express slot in which to store it because that is how it charges its battery.  It does not fit into a PCMCIA slot.  Bluetooth pairing was painless in Windows 7 - I didn't need to change any settings and it worked straight away.  The laser seems to work on any surface with no problems.  Other laser mice I've used have trouble on polished desktops.  The only downside was having to find the manual online.  A printed copy would have been nice.
fits snug & perfect like a glove. Makes me feel like I have a brand new computer now!
This thing has a 3 year warrenty. Mine went belly up after a year so I called Seagate. The support was awsome. They sent a replacement in 3 days.
Bought these as a gift for someone who doesn't have another set of over the ear headphones.  They are a good quality for the price.
Adapter works well-don't buy a zune hd without it!  There's not much more you can say!
summary: Adapter works well-don't buy a zune hd without it!

reviewText: Don't be fooled by the low price point or the small size.  This mini arrives in quality, transparent packaging that let's you know exactly what you're going to get insofar as the looks are concerned, but doesn't require the jaws-of-life to get the packing open like some of electronics I've purchased in the past.  The size is very convenient for storage and usage next to my computer without taking up too much space or having a tall or odd shape that makes it impossible to place under my monitor for easy access.  As far as looks go, it's nice enough to keep in full view on my desk without clashing with the color or quality of my iMac or looking like a cheap piece of junk.Enough about the looks, the selling point of this mini speaker is the sound quality.  Despite the demure size, the AX310 produces a rich, clear sound that doesn't deteriorate as soon as the volume is increased slightly.  I've put the speaker through a good variety of tests in different rooms while I worked on my never-ending DIY list, and the speaker sounded great in all circumstances with a good access distance for the Bluetooth signal and convenience of the access controls on the speaker itself.I haven't used the microphone feature yet, so I can't comment on that feature, but it's nice to have if I ever have a need for it.  Pairing the speaker with my iPhone and iPad was quick and simple, so I'd have to round out my entire experience with this mini speaker as a definitive 5 of 5 stars without a doubt.
For the money, these are some of the best headphones I have tried. They are light and comfortable.I am a huge fan of Sony, and these live up to my expectations and then some.

After much thought and looking at test reports I concluded a Mac Mini with a Thunderbolt display was the way for me to go. It is the only new Mac that you can upgrade with some ease.  I ordered straight from Apple with 4GB memory and the standard 1TB hard drive.  At initial bootup I transferred my older imac files, apps, etc. to the new unit and it went very smooth.  I noticed that it was slower than I wanted so I upgraded to 16GB memory which added some speed then I changed the hard drive to a Vertex 4 SSD.  Now it is very fast

I love my new mobile media companion. Previously I owned a Handspring Visor Deluxe and boy was this an upgrade! The color screen is very bright and easy to see, all your programs, system settings, etc are easy to find and use. I keep all my medical information on it for my doctor appointments.I would recommend this unit to anyone considering a PDA, just make sure you put a large memory card in it 1GB or larger.

I'll preface my remarks by saying this is merely my "opinion," or perception.  Others may have very different reactions (apparently more positive ones), which will be affected by source material (vocals vs. instrumentals, guitar vs. piano, combo vs. symphony orchestra).I have yet to find a "mini" speaker that delivers the audio my ears require for listening to jazz and classical music.  (I'm so fastidious, I'll disqualify certain recordings from consideration on the basis of a recording engineer whose representation of the piano is always a distorted version of a "real" piano.I want "real," full sounds, with "true" bass (not the artificially "enhanced" bass frequencies of the middle register.  I know there are speakers out their capable of passing my "test" (I begin with the bass of Paul Chambers on "So What" from Miles Davis' "Kind of Blue" and proceed from there to solo piano and then complete orchestra (from Bach to Bartok).  And I'm looking for a "traveling" unit that will slide as smoothly into my shoulder bag as an 11" Mac Air (don't use a cover for maximum utiltiy and lightness).I'm a huge JBL / Harman-Kardon fan, and I had high hopes that this product would be a notable exception to all of the other frequency-challenger, underpowered "mini" speakers that I had tried (look for a few soon on Amazon).  Instead, the JBL Micro was too weak to satisfy even my wife (whose musical tastes are more broad than mine).I don't want to carry a "box-shaped" unit on trips much less up and down the stairs.  But I found one small unit that slipped into my bag and delivered enough sound to fill the house: the Motorola EQ7 (made by JBL).  It has not one but 4 transducers along with a heavy magnet and Blu Tooth, and its flat, "omlet" shape makes it fairly easy to slip into a should bag along with a laptop.  Unfortunately, the speaker has been discontinued now for 2-3 years, so an interested party needs to search for good used or refurbished units.My only caveats about the EQ7 (don't even give a 2nd look at the EQ5, which I also happen to have) is that stacking 4 AA batteries into it for portable use requires some practice and patience.  Also, the BluTooth can be a bit reluctant to "pair," especially with equipment made after 2010.  Finally, after a couple of hourss, I definitely begin to feel its weight[---which must be twice as heavy as my computer.Consequently, I was quick to jump on to the comparable speaker not only manufactured by, but sold exclusively as, JBL itself.  It's the JBL On Tour iBT Bluetooth speaker which, like the EQ7, has a total of 4 transducers (2" speakers) but is noticeably lighter and thinner ithan the EQ7.  The bass frequencies of the On Tour iBT are not as strong and clear as those of the EQ7, but the sound of a piano is as "open," spacious and transparent, as the EQ7.  Although the user has to deal with the same "battery problem" and an extra button, the On Tour has become such a congenial "travel partner" that, when I saw that it too was being discontinued, I immediately purchased two more.  JBL would replace it with a subsequent speaker called "The Flip," which I immediately had to return after hearing its distorted (to this pianist's ears) reproduction of the sound of a piano.  It's a great, dynamic company, and it can be hard to keep up with their constantly changing products (though their Harman Kardon Soundsticks have changed little since their first appearance 15 years ago (thankfully!). Regardless, the JBL name has always signified "high quality"--at least since I bought my first speaker from them in the early '70s (a bookshelf speaker with a 14" woofer that I continue to use).Again, the above is merely one person's experience and opinion. For some reason, people tend to be especially passionate about their preferred speaker-even at extremely low price levels of under a hundred. I respect their opinions.  I've read glowing reviews of products that subsequently disappointed me.  But I never blamed the reviewer--unless it later became apparent that I had been misled by a paid hack's "promo" piece for the company's product.
summary: Weak and inadequate to my ears

reviewText: First the good : The audio is pretty good for an all-in-one unit like this. The fake surround effect doesn't get all wide and echo-y either - it's a feature you'd probably use. It certainly won't fool you into believing you have surround sound but it does enhance the audio reasonably well. For $99 you can't fault it. It's quite a sizable unit too - bigger than it looks in the photos. The 'feet' can be repositioned to become wall mounts too, but there's no wall-mounting hardware included. It's quite stylish. Others don't like the 'Vizio' emblem but it's a little satin-brushed metal panel that looks quite nice. If you don't like it, cover it up.The problem is that this unit is very clearly built down to a price, and like most Vizio products, the shortcomings are obvious within a few minutes of using it.So on to the problems:The IR receiver sits behind a textured grill on the front panel. The support frame for the grill is a plastic lattice that shadows the IR receiver on all sides so it sits in a recessed 'hole' if you like. It is extremely sensitive to the position of the remote like this. The only solution is to run the soundbar with the grill off (which is ugly) or to use some wire snips to snip away a couple of the pieces of plastic frame so the receiver can "see" more freely.There's no power light so you don't know if the unit is on or off. This is especially poor when you're turning the device off - without any indication, and coupled to the remote problems listed above, you'll end up leaving the soundbar on without realising it 9 times out of 10.There's no single-button input entry on the remote (or the unit). You have to hit the 'input' button twice to get it to the optical input for example. This alone wouldn't be so bad but it makes the soundbar incompatible with most universal remotes. Logitech Harmony remotes can almost handle it - you manually tweak them to hit the input cycle code twice. Problem then is if you switch activities, it cycles the input twice again and takes you to analog 2. Do it again and you end up at analog 1 etc). Logitech think there's a single input source IR code but the soundbar doesn't understand it.This is all compounded when you have a power outage. If you remove the power supply, the soundbar loses all its settings - which input you were on, the volume level and the settings for the sound enhancements. You have to set them all up again.Ok - not a problem if you have a reasonable electrical supply which most of us do. But if you're energy-conscious and have a current-sensing 'green' power bar that cuts off all the power outputs when it senses the TV turning off, the VSB200 is useless.It doesn't support compressed S/PDIF which makes it incompatible with a lot of Samsung, Sony, Sharp and Philips televisions. You'll have to resort to the analog audio out (if you have one). The only indication you'll get that this is the case is one of the 10 white LEDs flashing. The documentation that comes with the unit does explain this but it would have been nice to have separate LEDs for the input selection, volume and error codes instead of having them all glommed into a single multipurpose display that needs a manual to understand.It doesn't have an HDMI input. This was one of the biggest factors for me. For a set of TV speakers, the optical in is great but an HDMI input is almost a must-have.Ultimately I returned mine. I just couldn't get it to work properly. With it constantly losing its settings, the sketchiness of the IR receiver on the remote and all the other little problems, they all added up to "unusable" for me.
summary: Built down to a price - too many little problems that add up

reviewText: If you want more zoom than 3x (this one has 6x optical), if you want small size, if you want more than 5 megapixels (this one has 6), if you want a viewfinder, if you want good quality, this is the camera to buy! I have other VERY fine Nikon Digital SLR's but they weigh a TON. I travel a lot and want to take great pictures, this little gem fits the bill. As far as I can tell so far (I have had the camera just over a month) the only draw back is that it does not come with a rechargeable battery pack. (You can use rechargeable AA's) But given the other features, I will live with it! I am picky and I looked all over and this was the only camera that fit almost all my requirements.

Does well as a number pad, but not great as a multi touch pad (good for single finger, not multiple, can't seem to handle it - it gets confused). The multi-touch zoom is not accurate. It works well functioning as a number pad and standard touch pad, but all the other features it advertises don't work well.
summary: Ok as a number pad and standard touch pad only

reviewText: Seriously,for $150 you can't go wrong.. The lights look cool too,but I don't usually have them on. The bass these things put out are incredible. I have a 720 watt Kenwood pushing them.. No issues. I have a JL 12" power wedge sub in my other car and I think the Dual beats it hands down. Don't let all the haters persuade you from these. They aren't $1000 subs but if your looking for good quality for the price,you just found them!

I gave this S2 to my mom for Mother's Day. After a few weeks, the very fine speaker wire that runs inside of the headband somehow became unsecured and exposed. It was then accidentally pulled as my mother removed it one day and the fine wire tore, rendering the unit unplayable.It has been almost impossible contacting Sony for repair. When I finally reached them, the repair costs for this small repair were unwarranted and I ended up purchasing a new unit at a discount outlet. Sony is engineering is good but their service is terrible. This is not a good prospect for a consumer in the long run.

This clip grabbed the visor of my cap and never once felt loose. It's a must-have accessory for those not wearing a helmet or with other means of securing the camera. The Midland Visor Mount felt of higher quality than the camera itself!

this is a basic no thrills dvd player that does one things great: plays dvdspicture quality is excellent (heads and shoulders above PIONEER DV-220V-K which was returned).Analog sound quality also very good.small form factor.it has none of the usual gimmicks i never use (like usb capability etc).discs have to be very clean and in excellent condition otherwise it would skip/stuck (other players would just move on). loading time could be faster..I thought of getting another unit with an optical audio out (there aren't that many anymore) but the picture quality is so good i decided to stay with this one.

My wife and I have these in 3 different colors. We bought one and it works great so we order two more. We have had these on 2 different minis for 6 months and they have held up great. They are very thin, soft on the screen side, and vinyl on the outside.  I use this case and travel with my mini in my laptop bag and it protects it great. The only reason I took one star off is if you stand it up by folding the cover into a triangle, the angle is pretty high. I think all of these covers are the same including the apple one so it more a knock on the overall design as compared to this particular case.
summary: Case works great and has held up well

reviewText: The perfect size for couch surfing - a compact yet full keyboard.Wireless works well from ~7 feet with a clear line of sight. It has never once lost connection or flaked out.The touchpad works okay, but the touch-to-click functionality is horrible, causing frequent mis-clicks. I know it has been mentioned before in here but I'll mention it again, since it took me awhile to figure this out. To disable the touch-to-click function press the blue Function key and the left-mouse button at the same time. This will toggle the touch-to-click off while at the same time keeping the other touchpad functions, like two-finger scrolling (which actually works fairly well). After that the touchpad became infinitely more useable.

All the high marks regarding this excellent little radio are well deserved!The product not only looks great on a desk or coffee table, it is the perfect physical size to deliver portability while remaining just large enough to house a decent sounding speaker.  The lack of tone controls has not created any issues for us.  We have never felt that the hard wired tone settings on any broadcast was in need of adjustment.  In addition to the sound quality, the radio reception is also impressive and much better than I had expected!  We also own a 10 year old CCRadio+ which cost us twice the price but the reception capability of this Sonido radio is nearly identical with FM and Weather Band!  This fine radio actually does a little better job of pulling in our weak weather broadcast than the plus can in the same location.We live in the Sierra Nevada mountains so any radio reception up here is difficult.  We can't pull in any AM stations here on any radio without an outside antenna, so I can not comment on that aspect of this product.  We are not using this radio in a location where an external antenna is practical.  The FM and Weather are the two bands we bought this for, and as I said, it does both VERY WELL.I am 100% satisfied with this purchase and if our CCRadio+ ever fails, I think I will just buy another one of these instead!  With the external audio input as well as the audio output jack, this thing does pretty much everything the CCradio+ can in a much smaller footprint!  A lot cheaper too!5 Stars Easy!
Its light, moveable, and has amazing light. It is easy to use and have anyone hold while taking the picture. I also like that you can screw it into your tripod. I cant wait to buy another one.
I travel a lot - and a "light on a timer" doesn't hold a candle to this... I recommended it to my friends that travel (needless to say they just laughed, but i tried...)

reviewText: This case fits the iPod perfectly and is made of high quality material.  It looks like it will last for a while.The iPod goes in very easily and the case also comes off very easily.  Be aware that it only covers the sides and back, so it is not a full case in that respect, only a "skin" for the device. So, the front screen remains exposed and unprotected.I have ordered a set of protective screen covers as well. I may shop around for a small, carry case that fully protects it to drop this in.

Don't know why they discontinue these they were comfortable. The ear base was big enough to sit comfortably on my ear. I had not problem for a while it lasted 2 years. I think 2 years is good considering the purchase price was a deal.
I neede this because i had a scratch from not having my screen protected these are great and I like the service from the company

I hate typing on touch screens. It sucks, everyone knows it. So I was extremely excited to try out this mini keyboard. At first it worked great. Paired right off the bat. Opened up my e mail and I started typing and viola there it was on the screen. So damn easy. Loved it. Used it a couple times over a week.But then it stopped pairing. Said the device was incompatible with the Kindle Fire HD. How could that be? It worked all week. So I tried pairing it to my Android smartphone. NOTHING doing. At first it showed up in the Bluetooth menu as paired, but it would not connect. Then it stopped showing up at all. I am hoping that this was just a software glitch or a driver update problem. I will mess around with it, let you know.So...I have messed around with it, and it doesn't work. I am not a tech expert so I did not really delve into any software issues. (Really, why should I have too?)  But I did basic stuff. Hard reboot on both the Kindle Fire HD and my HTC One smartphone, Nope. Made sure the keyboard was fully charged. Nope.Tried about a dozen times to pair it with each device in different locations, Nope. (Some times it would pair, but never connected.) Finally tried again to pair it with another smartphone I have, LG Optimus, still didn't work. As a last resort I tried to pair it with an old laptop (which obviously didn't need a keyboard) and still nothing.All these devices have Bluetooth and have been paired before and since with other BTdevices. Shouldn't be this hard. Doesn't work.

I have had my 15.4" MBP for almost three years in an engineering office environment.  Great laptop, reliable, and i have had minimal compatibility issues, even though I am the sole Mac among hundreds of Windows PCs.  Mac OS X interface is intuitive and definitely superb compared to Windows.  The biggest issue I have had with my Mac is that it does not seem to do well speed-wise when multiple applications are open.  Sometimes I get the spinning beach ball for one or two minutes at a time when I try to access Finder or open a file.  The cooling fan really cranks up too.  All of this usually happens when I have more than three applications (such as Word, Excel, and Mail) open at a time.  I have 4 GB memory, so I don't think that is the issue.  Maybe Mac OS X is just not good at parsing out CPU power to several applications at once?  The overall bigger issue is Apple's wireless networking.  My MBP drops Wi-Fi an awful lot compared to the Dells in the office.  Same issue at home where I have it paired with a Time Capsule.  I often times have to switch to the main AT&T wireless router rather than the Time Capsule to get any speed and a consistent connection.  I will still buy another Mac, but it is quite ready for prime time in a typical office setting.  Five+ stars for home use, 3 stars for office use, to average out at 4 stars.
summary: Great laptop, but not a workhorse in an office environment. Wireless issues.

reviewText: No problems after 2 years of ownership and everyday use.The only minor annoyance is the bright blue power-on light -- it is so bright, it actually draws your eye away from the screen.  I remedied the situation with a small piece of paper and scotch tape.

I will spare you all the detail of prior reviews as I believe they have probably all rehashed the superb qualities of this lens.  It excels at portraiture and superb smooth bokeh that makes your jaw drop.  Even your out of focus shots hold a mystique from that dreamy bokeh that makes you go back and look at them over and over again.Where this lens is lacking is in its autofocus speed.  Moving all of that glass is not fast and this is certainly no autofocus sports lens.  This is where I knock 1 star off.  If Canon can improve the autofocus speed on this lens then it is without a doubt deserving a 5 star rating.  Even without it however, when applied to the proper subject matter this is a superb lens.BTW: I have given this lens the nickname of Glass Sphere.  When you pick it up for the first time the heft you feel makes it feel light you're holding a solid sphere of expensive glass...
summary: Superb bokeh but lacking in autofocus speed.

reviewText: These headphones has very good sound quality overall. I've always loved Sennhesier and they've done it again with these! The sound is perfect, the comfort is perfect, and the adjustability is perfect! No flaws at all! Thank you Sennhesier!

I had to reboot that old router at least once a day to restore the connections. This new MediaLink router is awesome - I have connected 3 laptops wirelessly, one IP phone and one PC with ethernet, and one Kindle, 2 cellphones, one TV (2 floors up) and one PS3 wirelessly, and I have not had to reboot the router even once in the last month of use. reviewText: I purchased this adapter to keep at work for the occasional times when we need to place a desktop computer in a location without an Ethernet jack. I just pop this adapter into a USB port and have a wireless network connection almost immediately. It's reliable, well-made, compact, and very affordable. I've only tested it on Windows 7 Enterprise 32-bit systems, but have had no problems getting it to work on multiple systems.

Earphones, adapters, a car charger, and a card reader are all included.  I really can't think of anything that they left out, and it saves the hassle of ordering all of these items individually.  Very happy.

I was looking for a nice sound upgrade but did not want to get a 5.1 system as i had to run wires around the room; secondly my place is quiet small and comfy so 5.1 would really not make sense. this one fits my pocket/requirements...1. very simple to setup and connect. wireless sub-woofer is definitely a add-on.2. watched blue-ray movies on PS3 and happy with the sound. it cant beat 5.1 but i'm happy with this one.3. Playing games on PS3 sounded more realistic than from the tv speakers.Note: If you are connecting to your PS3; you may experience sound issues while playing dvd's. just make sure your PS3 settings and play around with the settings. i had to disable all options under optical settings (dts/digital dolby).

But keep in mind, you get what you pay for and that 3rd party model didn't last long.So I purchased this Nikon model and what a difference it makes.  Go with the original - you won't be sorry.

reviewText: I bought two of these interlocking relay sockets for an alarm I was installing. I didn't have to have them interlock but it makes for a cleaner installation. Once two sockets are interlocked I found it very hard to insert the two relays. The sockets are too close together once interlocked. I feel the manufacturer should increase the distance between the sockets once interlocked. I used Tyco relays. The sockets were so close that the relays won't go straight down into the socket. So instead of having the relay bodies inserted at an angle with a lot of pressure on them and the interlocking grooves, I just left them as singles (not interlocked). The sockets are good quality, but the interlocking feature doesn't work well with Tyco relays. I had another brand relay lying around. I checked its dimensions and it was even bigger than the Tyco. So in summary, next time I would buy the non-interlocking version if cheaper, as that is how I ended up using them anyway.:-(
summary: It works, but needs a dimensional change.

reviewText: This things reads and write anything I put into it which is pretty impressive! no lag or jumping either I'd def recommend!
I installed it on my new Macbook pro and it looks great. I had one in my previous macbook, and after removal it looked like new.

I've had this running for 2 years now.  I lost one hard drive, but after I put the replacement in it rebuilt in under a day and has been working great.  I've even moved it around and shipped it a couple of times without issue.

PIPO "7" TabletSpec:Processor 1.6Ghz dual coreRAM 1Gb DDR 3Battery 3200mAhScreen Plastic (along with the case)MVA(multidomain vertical alignment)Rom 8GB Flash(claims)3G externalResolution 800 x480Review:This is a sub one hundred USD tablet that is rather surprising. The screen is 7 inches wide and seems a bit smaller than other 7 inch tablets, however it is TRUE to the its size. It comes preloaded with Jelly bean 4.1.1 and Google Play (USA) version which I have had no issue when it comes to syncing to my Google account and downloading apps, free and paid. As for the apps they all seem to download and work, except need for speed shift, however that could be something I've done when it tells me to update the game, but all other games and apps so far have downloaded and work. It comes with Google voice however I prefer Alice (AVIC) which works seamlessly on this tablet. Standard feel is good well built not very heavy compared to the Nexus 7. The screen resolution is not as crisp and pixel free as the Nexus 7 however it's pretty close and again over 100 dollars cheaper and the HDMI works well when connected to my TV's to watch Netflix's. The Wi-Fi seems to have good range as I can connect outside my house compared to my Galaxy S3 phone it has a little weaker signal but not much. I do not have a 3G dongle so I cannot comment on that but I assume like all of those it's carrier based that will make a difference.There are NO standard USB ports on this only 1 Micro USB which is not an issue as this tablet comes with a Micro to USB cable, so you can use flash drives and USB hard drives as well to load apps and watch movies. I have only hooked a 128GB drive to the machine so I could not tell you the full read capacity for the little tablet. When playing movies off USB there is no noticeable lag time. The Players that come preloaded are junk I recommended the free app MX player as it works in HW.SW and Fast SW mode to convert movies from AC3-Divix formats (Mp4 as well). When watching a movie if the screen brightness is all the way up expect to get through 1 full movie and a little of another movie. With the settings low to half way two movies should be within the spec of this tablet.Alright for web browsing, it comes preloaded with Google Chrome, which I've had no issue using. All my pages allow me to sync perfectly to them, along with all my book marks. The push to laptop function works well and no complaints. I've not used the YOU TUBE app yet as I just use YouTube in desktop mode on the Chrome browser with no complaints.I've not use nor do I have a need for the GPS function so I will skip that however Google maps worked well for me and it found my location at home just as fast as my Acer A500 and my Galaxy S3 did; when using share location or Find my Device it picks my location up within 500Ft of the device which is good for a FREE app. Again works well but never used the Driving part of the GPS.Amazon Kindle reading app works well although some of the text is hard to read without zooming it. Again it's not unreadable however if you wear glasses like me it could be a bit of a challenge for you. But as this is a true 5 point Multi touch all zooming gestures work well.Playing Angry birds or other games this tablet works well and does not kill your arms to hold it up. The 5 point Multitouch works excellent and the screen which seems to be MVA(multidomain vertical alignment) allowing you to see pretty good detail in the game. Not as good as an IPS but again price is a factor here. When playing with your friends everyone can see the screen as the off viewing angles are decent, they compare to most mid 2000's laptop's.Now the only bad I could find about this thing, is the Lack of space on the 8GB version, 8-16 GB of internal memory (storage) is really too little these days. But it does have an expansion slot that offers another 32GB of space per card you use, and remember you can save movies to USB as well as an external drive or Google Cloud.So to wrap up this review if you need a cheap Sub $100.00 tablet for use with work, entertainment or just to have to get into the world of tablets this is an excellent buy, as it supports most games and the movie quality is good (Worst being cheap Micro Cruz tablets, Better being Mid pad tablet, Good being Pipo-S1, Best being A500 and Outstanding being Asus /Galaxy S) Google Chrome is excellent and reading/watching daily news is not as great as a 10 inch but better than using most smart phones. I would give this product 9 out of 10 only due to small battery and low internal storage (they do offer a 16GB version as well). I will try to post an English speaking video (USA so I should say American version) soon to go along with my review. Again I try to keep this simple and semi short, but if you want something that works well and is not over priced buy one of these you will be surprised at this little 7 inches power.Side note: All 3-D games I've tried work well and the G-accelerator seems to be very responsive no lag. (Games played Need for Seed Most wanted, Mine Craft, Air Plane Sim (free version).

OK, third pair of buds.... I just cant wear a headset for an extended period of time, because I wear glasses., I have been a musician all my life as well as an Engineer by trade, so music is a big part of my life. I never accept second best, and always strive to buy the best. My experience has been that price doesn't always mean It's  the best.... Every bud I tried, after a brief time would slowly slide back out of my ear canal and I would lose the bass depth. I read all the reviews and because I have a JLab sub, thought I would trust the name. I like them so much that I bought a set for my mate. Both of us experienced the same fit right out of the box... They come packaged with a mid size that worked for both of us... no issues- even after hours of wear. comfortable fit.... OK, now to the sound- OMG- forget it- buy these... the bass is all there without boomyness, the highs are high without being harsh.... Joyce cooling "third wish" for instance The triangle was in my left ear and just so sweet !!  the bass in my right, didnt over color the rest of the guitar riffs. Everette Harp  "all for you" - I could even hear the echo of the sax. The snare was clear and crisp and the bells stood out in the background. I do a bunch of studio work and could see each musician in a separate room- Its THAT GOOD !... Ok, last but not least- Rick Braun  "Walk the Walk" -  I actually teared up- sounded better than my 30,000 McIntosh reference system. !! The horns, clappers, bells, and all the percussion were balanced and stood out as the engineer intended. I never heard it sound this good. It actually was all new to me. These are so consuming, that all background noise is eliminated and you have to mute them- (button on wire included) to hear a person talk. The cord really will not tangle- no matter how much you turn around. I am very pleased and well worth the extra price over what is supplied with my devices. A bunch less than paying for names like Bose, B & W, shure etc.... I find these brands to be overpriced and color the sound.... of course - all my gear is on "mid- position" , because thats the way the track was laid..... I hate colored- boomy sound... and its fatiguing after a few hours, anyway. No fatique in these--- OMG , I am listening to them right now and Joyce cooling - " The wizard" has timbales in there that are awesome... boy do I love these- Why listen to speakers??? Just buy them !!

I purchased this External DVD re-writer to copy a business program that needed frequent backup.This unit seemed to work fine playing DVD movies, etc, however this was not my main use I had intended for this machine.The problems I encountered were as follows;1.) When I copied the my program onto the DVD for backup purposes, I had difficulty recopying it back to my computer; it wouldn't do it reliably and frequently crashed.2.) When I tried to rewrite over an old program (i.e. update the same program but with new information) on the DVD it wouldn't (although it asked me if I wanted to and I said yes). So I had to erase the entire DVD before I tried to copy a new file on the DVD disc.3.) After I erased the DVD, that disc would not accept a new file being copied to it; the EZ-Dub kept asking me to put a disc in the drive, although there was one already there.(the one I just erased)I ended up taking this unit back as I could not seem to get a consistent working response from this machine.

reviewText: Works great! My wife uses it all the time to play her exercise discs. Some of them are years old and this player does a very good job of playing them.

These are some outstanding headphones by all rights.I have two other headphones to compare these to: the Playstation Wireless headphones that are priced the same, and Turtle Beach's PX51, which cost triple.I've used all three with my Playstation 3 and my PC.Of course, the main difference is that these are corded.  That's a big issue for me, as my PS3 is far from my couch and I fear my dogs snagging cables.But the cord comes with advantages.  These don't have to worry about being charged, and they produce sound on par with the PX51 (in other words, they sound excellent), but are much more affordable.I've taken to using these with my PC, as they are plug and play with the USB.  My PC gaming is done at a desk, so I don't mind the cord.These fell solid and well made, and they are also comfortable.  The detachable mike is a great idea, and my friends say I sound loud and clear both on the PC and PS3.  These work well for phone calls if you have a 3.5mm jack on your phone.  The control fob thing is simple and easy to operate.There are a lot of USB headsets to be had for a lot less money, and the Sony headphones are the same price and cordless... albeit they don't sound quite as good.  I think each customer will have to weigh what they want, but these are a solid purchase for the money, in my opinion.

I recently purchased this dolly and I have to say I'm very impressed with the value for the price. This isn't some cheap piece of plastic (everything is metal except the adjustment knobs and wheels) like you'd normally expect for around $35.The main body is a very solid slab of aluminum that will easily support any DSLR, even with a battery grip. I even cradled a full size professional ENG video camera (the big kind that goes on your shoulder) on the unit, facing inline with the wheels with the shoulder mount sitting between the axles. The platform held it with no issues and it rolled perfectly smooth across the floor. With my DSLR, I was able to use a monopod head on it to not only raise it up a bit, but allow me to angle the camera in any direction.The wheels roll smoothly, though the bearings aren't as smooth as they could be to allow the wheels to spin freely. They don't bind or anything, but you don't get that "infinite spin" that good bearings give you. The unit does roll smoothly, though I'm finding the same thing to be true with this as with tripods and full size dollies: more weight on it makes it move more smoothly, especially on carpet. During long moves, more weight allowed for more consistent speeds, too.With this dolly, you can turn both sets of wheels in any direction, so geometric arcs are pretty simply to achieve. However, this is where I subtract a star.While the base plate does have angle markings, they're only tic marks with no actual listings of the actual angle. While the actual angle may not be as important as what works for the shot, having the hashes labled with a numerical value would make it easier to quickly match the settings on both axles. As it is, you have to count how many hashes in one axle is set at so you can count and set the other one at the same spot.In addition, the unit could really benefit from catches at the 0 degree mark and maybe at every 5 degrees to make setting the dolly up quicker - especially when trying to return the wheels to the straight position. Doing so is complicated by the hex-shaped axles that obscure the hashes you're trying to align to.One nice thing about the unit is it appears (aside from the main plate), the hardware is pretty much off the shelf, so customizing or replacing parts should be easy enough. Getting the exact knobs on the unit might be harder, but I've seen that sort of thing in hardware stores. Since those have plastic grips, they would be the most vulnerable to breakage. The screws are standard hex screws, so you can replace them if you strip them.I bought my unit with the DMKFoto Heavy Duty Ball Head with Quick Release Plate for monopods (Fancier part number FT-001H) and a pack of 1/4" to 3/8" screw adapters to fit the head to the standard tripod screw on the dolly. The addition of the ball head makes the dolly far more versatile, so I really recommend it.Overall, the dolly is a great value and seems very easy to modify for individual uses. Aside from my gripes above, I'd definitely recommend it.
summary: Excellent quality and value, though not quite perfect.

reviewText: Hook it up a couple days ago.  Took about 2 hours, only because I had to find a place to put my AMP.  Tried two different places. For everyone who said that they had to buy extra wiring I would love to see how you wired them up? I had extra wire but zipped tied and placed under seat.  I do want to put a kill switch on the AMP to the battery.  Do not want the battery to die on me because I leave it on and the 3.5 is touching metal.Now to all the negative Nay Sayers.  You must of received a faulty AMP or dropped it.  My Speakers and AMP blast so loud  that I have to turn them down.  They sound great at 70, 80 or even 90. reviewText: This has the word "Amazon" emblazoned on it, so I wasn't surprised at how well it fit.  I was surprised at how well I like it though.  This is extremely light and only adds a few ounces to the weight of my KF HDX (named Sherman - he of the Wayback Machine that can take you anywhere and any time).  Sherman wakes up when I open the case, except when I forget to charge him, like now.  Grr.  There are magnets all over this case to hold Sherman in without covering up the sides of the screen with straps, which is great because I like to get Decal Girl skins to dress up my toys, and the magnets let me see the design.  The camera turns on when I slide Sherman up in the case, but I think it's silly to use him as a camera.And as advertised, the covering flap folds to use as a stand.  It actually took me a while to consistently fold it properly.  It's not hard - it's just that sometimes I'm not as smart as I think I am.I got this through the Vine program.  I probably would have given it 4 stars if I hadn't already gone through several cheap cases.  If I had bought this, I would have picked the red one, but the black one is super nice.  Turns out that at $69 (what it's going for today), this is a little expensive, but ultimately a good value.  I'm not going to intentionally test how well it protects Sherman from a drop, but if I accidentally test it, I'll update this review.

reviewText: My wife and I decided to purchase the Nikon D90 as an upgrade from our little point and shoot camera.  We were looking for better quality pictures and the ability to take pictures one after the other without a long wait time.  We are casual users and not at all sophisticcated, and it is this group of users that I want to address.  Though the Nikon D90 has many, many features and manual adjustments that are great for more sophisticated users, it also has the capacity to work superbly in its automatic modes.  We have been extremely pleased with the increased quality of our pictures and have been motivated to take a an introductory class on digital photography at our local community college.  This has been a tremendous help to us.  I would also suggest that the casual user purchase a commercial D90 manual which are much easier to read then the one that comes with the camera.  That said, on its automatic modes, we were able to begin using the D90 right out of the box.  The basic controls are intuitive and easy to learn.  I am also planning to purchase a Nikon SB400 SppedLight (flash attachment) with a Sto-Fen diffuser.  Reviews of those products are available on Amazon and everyone raves about how they imporve your indoor flash pictures.  So, if you are a casual user, don't be intimidated by the D90's many sophisticated features.  You can grow into those if you choose, but it also takes really great pictures using its automatic modes.

reviewText: I recently bought a used version of this case, since the new one costs almost as much as the Kindle itself.For the good:The case fits the device very well and snugly. I don't fill that the device will fall out at all.The light is very bright and has no problem illuminating the screen.The buttons are easy to press with the case one.The case does not add much bulk to the Kindle.The bad:The case is not the same material as the substantially better Paperwhite case also sold by Amazon.There are no magnets to held the case in the closed position.The front cover fells very cheap.The light is seems to be biased to one side, you can see it in the product picture, the light creates a band of bright light that goes down the screen on the left side, and the right side is darker than the rest of the device. It's acceptable, but could be more diffused.Overall this is a good case if you can find a like-new used one from Warehouse Deals, otherwise I can not justify the high price tag new.I originally bought a third party case for the device that was bulky, but did the job and used a book light for lighting, this worked pretty well. When I bought my wife the Paparwhite with a leather case, I was really impressed by how good that case was and the quality of material and fit. That convinced me to buy this case for my Kindle device and I was disappointed, that even with the much higher price tag, this case was substantially worst in materials and overall feel.I would not see this as a good investment if paying the full new price.

The only thing that I found a Tablet is much better than a Laptop,  is when it comes to E-READING......A Tablet will allow you to enjoy all kinds of reading material in a very comfortable way.  A Laptop, although it can download any kind of books or magazines as well, it does not have the maneuverability of a Tablet when it comes to use it as a reading implement.  But since I still love to handle my books or magazines in the old fashion way, all I really needed was to have access to the internet various Media shows without any glitches, just like my home desktop computer.  Well as I said, I was not happy with the performance of various  Tablets.  The Laptop is what I really wanted and I have not been disappointed. reviewText: I plugged this drive in and the drivers refused to install on Windows 7 64-bit (with all the latest updates applied).  I tried running the setup program directly from the drive as the instructions specified and as soon as the setup program runs, a dialog says "This application has encountered an unexpected error and is now exiting".  This was a dialog from the WD software itself, NOT Windows, which indicates that the software had an unhandled error in the code.I went to the WD support site and downloaded the latest software.  The latest software release notes instructs you to download the firmware update for the drive.  I followed the directions on the page for the firmware update: disabling anti-virus software, unplugging all other USB devices, etc.  The only USB device I couldn't remove was the receiver for my Logitech keyboard/mouse combo.  The WD firmware update wouldn't run because it kept instructing me to "remove all other USB devices and hit RESCAN".  I double-checked, and the only USB devices connected were this WD drive and my keyboard/mouse.  So then how would I be able to run the firmware update if I have to unplug my mouse and keyboard?!So in essence, the only way I'd be able to use this drive is as a standard drive without the WD auto-backup software.  Hey, at least it works as a bare drive I guess... hence the two stars instead of one.
summary: Software/drivers don't install, and updates can't be applied.  Works as bare drive only.

I need a wireless headset that would work with a standard phone, but not take up my entire desktop and not interfere with my wireless network.  This phone is the answer. You have to dial from your phone or PC (as I do) then pick up the phone with the button on the headset (works very smooth).  The mic and ear phone volume are adjustable, but the standard setting work very well.I have been using it everyday (workday) for about 3 months and have not seen any drop off in the quality.  If I have any knock on the product, it is range.  My home office is at one end of my home and I can't walk throughout my entire house.  I would say it is very effective up about 35-40 feet.  After that, I can still hear fine, but people complain that my voice is breaking up.  I probably could place the base a little higher and improve the range a bit.  It's a minor annoyance.Love the product and would highly recommend to the home office user.

reviewText: An important feature of this adapter is the locking lever's ability to rotate 360 degrees.  Often, the camera or tripod pedestal, or something else prevents full 360 degree rotation, therefore, the lever is spring loaded so you can pull it out, to allow free rotation without moving the screw. This allows you to tighten and loosen the grip even when you have limited clearance. Well, this often does not work, because the lever requires you to pull it out way too much to clear the hex head, it barely clears at all, so when you rotate the handle it is still engaging the screw. In my application there is not enough room to grab the tightening lever and pull it out to the very limit of it's maximum movement (also it takes a lot of effort because of the increasing spring tension). The brass hex screw head (only visible when you pull the lever out) which must be engaged to tighten or loosen the clamping is way too long!  I compared the length of the brass hex head to the one supplied on the Manfrotto MVH502AH Pro Video head. That one works just right because the screw head is about a fourth or a third the length, so with a much shorter pull there clearance to rotate the knob without engaging the tightening screw. Either this 577 was designed poorly, or the manufacturer failed to use wrong brass hex head screw.I swapped out the tightening knob/screw unit from the MVH502AH and with the one that came with the Manfrotto 3433PL 577 and then it works the way it should.I'm thinking of returning this for a replacement but I'm worried that the replacement might be just as bad. I might instead disassemble it and shorten the brass hex head. I should not have to "repair it".  Obviously, there is not sufficient Quality Control by Manfrotto. Someone should have noticed that this does not work too well in practice.The reason that this item gets very good reviews must be either that few of the reviewers have clearance problems (with the bottom of their camera or a mounting plate beneath the camera, OR that their sample came with the proper "short hex head" tightening screw.

Very Bad company, they have a website forum, then consumers start buying pogoplug and start asking for support, then the forum comes with a lot of question comes few to no answers and more bad post on their forum, since imo they don't even care about helping customers and don't want people to see the bad issue on the pogoplug itself, they REMOVED the entire forum site!!!Now you can ask support by ticket which they never answered any question. In my case made 1 ticket and its been 2 months no answer.With regard to the pogoplug device, their ios app is incomplete, you can backup your ipad, iphone photo and video, but you can only watch it thru streaming, there is no option to download it back to the ios device, so you always need to have internet connection, obviously no problem at home because you are connected to wifi to the pogoplug, but once you leave the house, you need internet, i mean highspeed internet, thinking about starbucks internet or hospital internet No No No, you are going to get crazy waiting for buffering on video and photo!They should have included a download feature on the app so you can easily download large stuffs when you are at home with wifi, no common sense on their part there.You can share your file via sharing option and it will generate a link, problem is every link you made will go to pogoplug server, probably them checking it or might checking who knows I don't know!  Leaks might happen you know, with their poor support I don't think they can protect our files, they need to stop making all files you share go to their server while they can just let consumer share directly from the device itself, this is what a NAS is good at, no more sending files to server every single time, share directly from your home wothout some server check every thing you do, NAS does it directly from your own home.All movies need to be optimized before you can watch it which takes 4-8 hours  for the pogoplug to optimized/convert ONE video so you can watch it, goodluck and all your 100 movies! And guess what not all movie files are supported great.You want features you need to pay monthly for additional features, which a NAS includes their subscribe feature for free.And you can't protect files as read only or put password to access a file, so if their server is compromised some hacker can delete all your back up and files.If they fix all this issues this would be a perfect product, but how their support works they need at least a decade to fix this problem.

Great little dynamo/battery radio all around. It has AM/FM/WX bands and they all work better than almost any other radio I own. The volume can get pretty high--at least 75-80dB measured from a distance of a couple inches from the speaker. The speaker does not have the greatest sound quality, but I've heard much worse too. The tuning knob has a satisfying soft click with each incremental movement. It doesn't come with an AC adaptor, but a lot of common 6 volt AC adaptors will work as long as they're positive-polarity and the plug fits. I used a cord from a Delphi Roady2 XM radio. I've also cranked the dynamo (before charging it on AC power). I haven't tried regular batteries in it, but I may never have to, given how long this radio holds a charge.I live almost exactly halfway between Milwaukee and Chicago, and while it might seem like I'd have all sorts of choices for radio listening because of two major metro radio markets, the truth is that it can be tricky to pick up stations here. Chicago and Milwaukee are each at least 40-50 miles away, depending on the exact location of the transmitters, so neither market comes in exceptionally clear without a great antenna (same problem here for over-the-air HDTV). Even my Midland weather alert radio has trouble picking up the 2 or 3 local weather frequencies. This little bugger picks up all of them VERY clearly; one of them sounds like it's broadcasting a mile away on this RadioShack radio, whereas the same weather station sounds like it's 30 miles from here on the Midland. FM is pretty exceptional as well, often getting stations in clearly that other much higher-priced receivers can't get.For those listeners in the same area (far northern Lake County IL), a couple such difficult-to-receive stations from Chicago are 98.7 WFMT, 96.3 WBBM, 100.3 WILV, 94.7 WLS and 93.9 WLIT. Although I don't listen to all of those stations, I sometimes use them to aim antennas because they tend to be harder to get. From Milwaukee, some I have trouble getting on more expensive receivers are 94.5 WLWK, 95.7 WRIT, 97.3 WRNW, 99.1 WMYX and 102.1 WLUM.For you DXers, where this radio really shines is on the AM band (most DXers wouldn't use an emergency dynamo-powered radio for that purpose, but this one is pretty good at it). For years growing up in central Indiana, I could easily receive two major NYC stations at night--770 WABC and 880 WCBS. However, after moving much closer to Chicago, I haven't been able to receive those two stations even at night because there are local stations right next door on the tuning dial: 780 WBBM and 890 WLS. This radio picks them up. I was able to clearly receive 650 WSM from Nashville TN, 700 WLW from Cincinnati OH and 750 WSB from Atlanta GA without even trying too hard. It's much easier to pick up  lower power local AM stations during the daytime with this radio because the frequency separation is that good. I haven't experienced any bleedover from stronger stations.The handy USB port on the back will charge my power-hungry Samsung Galaxy S4 (albeit not completely). You're probably not going to charge a smartphone's battery more than a few percent unless you want to turn the crank on this thing for hours, but it will do nicely in a pinch. I don't have an iPhone, so I don't know whether it will charge those--they seem to be pickier about the minimum amount of current required to charge. And forget about charging an iPad or tablet. I measured a stable 4.98-5.02 volts and 0.26-0.35 amps. I don't know how long the charge in the built-in rechargeable battery would last, but I wouldn't be surprised to get 5-10% of a charge to my Galaxy S4 out of it.The flashlight isn't the brightest--I measured a fairly dim 2500-3000 lux at a distance of about 1-2 inches from the bulb, perhaps about the brightness of an LED night light. If you take this radio camping (as it has a great weather band and the USB charger), the light should be enough to see the path from your tent to wherever you have to go to do your business. The handle is great too--makes it easy to aim the flashlight and/or hang it from a tree branch--you're only limited by your own creativity.I really must say that I'm impressed with the quality of this radio, especially for the price. No, I didn't buy it here on Amazon, but rather on a leading auction site. Sometimes the price is about the same, but at 11-14 clams, it's a great bargain. It might be worth double that to someone who appreciates an all-in-one radio/USB charger/flashlight or something that gets great reception during a power outage. Highly recommended!

reviewText: I have only 1 complaint about this product, for whatever reason when it is plugged into an AUX port for either speakers or into your car's head unit, the volume in the bluetooth transferred audio from your phone to whatever the Xtreme 51901 is plugged into is lowered. I purchased two of these (one through groupon for $15 including shipping, and one from Amazon for $23 including shipping), both of these BT streamers I purchased are great and I would have given it a 5 star rating but for whatever reason the audio us reduced in the bluetooth streaming process by (a guestimate) of around 20-25%, which sucks for the one I keep in my house; I connected it to my speakers I use with my iPhone as an alarm and the volume is reduced enough that with the speakers at full volume I sometime dont wake up to it the first time but 4-10x after it first goes off. The one in my car is the same way as far as audio reduction but it's an easy fix because the head unit I use has a "Loud" feature that makes volume 10 of 40 sound like 20 of 40 when that feature is off; so it's virtually unnoticeable in my car. Either way I would recommend it to those that are looking for some way of streaming audio bluetooth, for the price its completely worth it!
summary: Great for home and car use!!!

reviewText: I recently acquired this camera and it has received mixed reviews around the web and not so good reviews here on Amazon. But after having spent some time with this camera, I have a very positive impression of it. Instead of blowing up the picture to 500 percent and looking for purple fringing, I looked at it from the aspect of "how good is an 8 by 10 printout? And, "How good does it look on a TV or a computer screen? Real issues and not the technical aspects of the output.And to me, the photos it takes are excellent. Crisp and clean, with good color representation - not extreme or unnatural. The pictures have a decent amount of blowup range before becoming pixelated. Slightly ;less than a decent SLR, but still good. The flash is a bit underpowered, but still is sufficient for most needs. The touch screen is a superb idea. Most people won't bother with the manual comtrols of a point and shoot becasue they are usually buried in menus and difficult to get to. But the on screen system used here makes it very easy (and quick) to get to common manual controls. This is the first point and shoot camera that I felt like even bothering with the manual controls.The video also seems to work and look fine. The 320 by 240, 60 frames per second output doesn't look much different than the 640 by 480 30 frames per second movie, other than the obvious resolution difference. But the 640 resolution looks sharp and with good color and is playable on most decently powered computers.The camera also has a 1280 by 720 High Defintion (720p) resolution. It plays well on the camera, but you need a fairly powerful PC or Mac to play it on, and even then it's a bit jerky. But that's the fault with HD on a computer and not a camera problem. But the camera does not include an HD cable for connection to a TV (just RCA and USB cables are included) and that's a major downpoint since you must buy a fairly expensive dock to do that. A very bad call on Samsung's part. I also did not experience any lockups of strange problems that someone in Amazon have reported. Maybe a newer firmware?But overall, this is a good, durable (metal body) camera to take with you when an SLR is just too inconvenient.
