This is a great buy considers the amount of storage you get as a MP3 player and as a portable hard drive. The size of this unit is compact enough to fit in a pocket for easy carrying around. It produces high quality sound provided that you use a high quality set of head phones. You can manage your of collection of songs and data easily via your PC by using the familiar windows explorer. The USB interface setup is quite straightforward and I was able to get it up and running within a few minutes. There are quite a few things which I would consider as less than perfect. First of all, the user manuel is poorly written. Many valuable information is missing (most of it can be found, however, in the Archos support FAQ site). The battery compartment door is poorly designed. If you follow the manual's instructions to pry open the cover with a screw driver, chances are that you would damage the plastic surrounding it. However, you could easily open the battey compartment door by graping the 3 notches on the side of the cover with your fingers and lift it up. The control of the features on the MP3 player is mainly done by scrolling through an on-screen menu, which would be less convenient than having a separate dial control for the volume or for searching. However, there are many great features on the menus which allow you to control the sound quality and songs play back. The unit does not allow recording even though a line-in jack is provided. If you want to delete songs on the player, you would need to do it through the windows explorer on the PC. I have also tried to backup about 1.5 Gbyte of my work data. The unit ran into a few underrun problems and that not all files were backed up. I  found out later that the problem was caused by low batteries voltage. You definitely should connect the charger to the unit for data backup. When you disconnect the jukebox from the PC, I strongly recommend that you use windows to eject the hardware (for windows 98, click on My Computer; right click on the drive icon; then click Eject) rather than simply unplugging the USB cable. I suspect that many people who complained about hard disk errors did not follow this procedure. Anyway, this unit deserves a 4-star for the convenience of being able to store thousands of MP3 songs in a box and being able to use it as a portable hard drive.
summary: Great sound with heaps of storage

I bought a pair of these last year, and I haven't been disappointed.What good are binoculars in the city, you ask?  Well, I've found a number of uses for 'em.  I use 'em for casual birding in Central Park - I'm even on an internet mailing list that tells me when unusual birds have stopped through.I take 'em to the opera and the symphony too!  If you can't afford the $350 seats, these binocs help to bring the nuances of the performance into your range of vision.  Amazing to check out the sets and the instruments as well.And finally these are my constant companion in the nosebleed seats at Yankee Stadium!  I think Clemens keeps some kind of powder in his glove...I really appreciate the rubber eyecups and the long eye relief - I can use these with my glasses on without fear of scratches.  If you want to view with your glasses off, there is a diopter ring on the left eyepiece to dial in your correction.  Focusing is smooth and easy and so is adjustment of interpupillary distance.Lightweight, great optical quality (if not perfect, certainly fully adequate), and finally, the price is right!  I recommend these binoculars.

reviewText: Well so far it works. I was a little hesitant on buying this, since i've only used Linksys for the longest of time now, but for the price ( when compared to other gigabit routers) I figured wth I could always return it.The speed increase from my old Linksys 100mb is very noticeable. For anyone having issues with setting this thing up remember you need to reboot your modem so that it can re-acquire the new mac address. Using my old router as a switch ( being 100mb) I was worried that this router would default to 100mb like a few other gigabit routers out there that refuses to mix connections, but it didn't and my 1gb connections run at advertised speed. So far it hasn't had a hiccup, no random drops (wired or wireless).All in all for the price it works just fine and was very easy to setup. Only downside is no dd-wrt support at the moment ( well I haven't checked today so don't call me a liar).

This is an excellent tablet and I have been extremely happy with all of its aspects. First off this tablet is fast. It also is capable of performing well even when you have numerous apps running at the same time. It is a very slim tablet with a large 8" screen. The border is very small which gives you even more viewing area. It seem much larger than my older 7" tablet. The screen resolution is decent for a tablet that costs less than $200. The Dell Venue has large internal storage capabilities. It sports 32 GB of on board storage which allows you to download many apps to your device. There is no need to worry about running out of space. I found that if you put too many apps on a device with lower storage capabilities it tends to run very slow and sluggish. This tablet does have an external SD storage slot. This helps to eliminates having to store music, videos and pictures on the device itself. One area that could be improved on this tablet are the speakers. This is not the best tablet to buy if you plan on listening to a lot of loud music without headphones or external powered speakers. The speakers are a little weak. The only other area I would improve on is adding a HDMI port so you could hook it up to a TV and be able watch your videos and movie. I solved this problem by adding an app that just throws the video to the TV with no wires. I have tried many tablets under $200 and found this tablet to have the best features for the money. I would not think twice about buying or recommending this tablet. Look for specials and you can find this Dell for a lot less than $200. I choose this over the Dell Venue Pro because I already have a laptop that runs Windows and I wanted to run on Android. This tablet runs on Android 4.3 so it is still very current. Buying Android allows you to pick apps from the Google Play Store. The Google Play Store has so many great apps to pick from that you need an app just show you which apps are the best. Which I have. (Ha!!!)

reviewText: It is the Canon OEM lens hood for their EF-S 17-55mm f/2.8 IS USM lens. It fits perfectly and has three main advantages:1. Cuts down lens flair2. Improves contrast and image quality - two for one3. Offers some protection to the front of the lens.As has been pointed out in other reviews, this is an expensive piece of plastic and given the cost of Canon glass should be included with the lens purchase. But that is not the case. There are other options available. From some of the reviews I have seen of the knock-offs they do not always fit and/or work as well. So for me, given my Canon investment, I just bite the bullet and add the final piece I feel I get better results with. After all, I could buy cheaper glass.This hood can be reversed on the lens for storage on the lens, but it will require a larger lens case for storage on the lens, if you use that option. And finally, it is a little tight getting the lens cap on/off with the hood in place, but it is doable.
summary: A Must Have For Quality Pictures

reviewText: I don't know why I went for this after reading reviews, especially when they warned of the same things: this access point often forgets its settings, especially if it loses power. It does not have a built-in interface to reconfigure it, you have to find the CD (only works in Windows) and run the setup utility again. And on the crazy off-chance you're curious, that CD does not work in WINE. Lose the CD? You're screwed. There's no downloads on their site for it. Waste of $60

The A75 and A85 are Excellent follow-ups of the A70, and offer some very nice improvements.  The most noticeable is the larger LCD, scene modes for those who don't like to tinker with the settings, "C" dial position to save your custom settings, and the print/share button to make things easier.  For those who don't know, scene modes are easy-to-access presets of a combination of manual adjustments, optimized for shooting in different situations such as when you are indoors, at the beach, taking shots of kids, shooting at night, or shooting fireworks, etc. The camera features full manual controls over shutter speed and aperture, manual focus, saturation, exposure compensation, custom white balance, ISO, metering, and a histogram in playback mode.  I know most people think they won't ever use some of these, but when you have an important shot that just isn't coming out, you'll be really glad you have it (or wish you did).  For those who don't know, control over shutter speed means you can use a fast shutter speed to capture fast action or you can use a slow shutter to avoid using a flash or for taking shots of night scenery.The areas where the Canon A75, A85, and A95 really excel at are:Being fairly small(small price tag too!) for a camera with this many features and having picture quality this good.Creative shooting:  this is a great camera for those who want to do creative shooting but can't afford to plop down $600+ for a Canon G6 or more for a Digital SLR.  It's got all of the most important controls, and with your memory card, you can do all the creative shooting and experimenting you want virtually free compared to using film.  It's even expandable with telephoto, wide angle, or close up conversion lenses and there's also the waterproof casing.All Canon cameras also come with an excellent software package that lets you stitch panoramic photos, retouch photos or rescue those that came out wrong, add special effect, and view thumbnails of pictures so you don't have to open them up to see what the picture looks like (good for those who are using an older version of windows, I know there are still a lot of you out there).  The best part is that it's free!  It does more than Kodak's software(which is pretty decent), you have to pay $20 to get the better version of Olympus's software, and Sony's editing software is pretty much non-existent.  Those who already have Photoshop won't be excited.For those of you who are concerned that the camera doesn't come with rechargeable batteries, don't worry, it's really not a big deal.  Good rechargeable AA's, type NiMH are super cheap at around $10-$15 for 4, compared to $50 for Lithium Ion battery packs, and at that price, everyone can afford a spare set, which is really important to have.  I've seen people who bought much crappier cameras at the same price, just because they came with rechargeable batteries - not a smart choice in my opinion.Yes, there is the problem with purple fringing, but it's not a very common problem and most people either don't know what it is or don't even know think it's much of a problem when they see it.  Some people think it looks cool.  With full control over aperture, you have the ability to get rid of it or at least reduce it.  Compared to the problems that other manufacturers have with their cameras, I'd take a bit of purple fringing over noise, soft/fuzzy images, and over-sharpening any day!If you want 5 megapixels of resolution, a very useful rotating LCD screen, and Flexi-Zone (lets you choose an area that is off-center to focus on), then look at the A95.Please note:  my review of the A75 is the same as the A85 because they are pretty much the same camera with the 1 megapixel different.  There are some differerences between my review of the A95 and this one.
summary: A75 and A85: you can't get a better camera at this price!!

reviewText: This battery brought my APC UPS back to life immediately!  At a fraction of the cost of a new UPS.  Thanks!
summary: Got It, Installed It, Worked Great

reviewText: I'd been putting off getting a blu-ray player because of all the bad things I'd been hearing about them.  Well, I'm very happy with this player.  It's works great and I'm having lots of fun with it.No unacceptable slowness.  NO HDMI connection problems with my 4 year old Sony KD-34XBR960 TV.I'm using the coax digital audio to connect to my receiver.  The manual states that, the PCM signals, output from the DIGITAL OUT (OPTICAL/COAXIAL) jack, will be output as 48 kHz/16 bit instead of 96 kHz/24 bit if, the source is copyprotected.  An HDMI receiver would insure the best sound quality.  However, I've been experiencing really excellent sound.  I have a huge sound system and really notice the improvement in blu-ray sound.  I don't feel a need to get an HDMI receiver.The only problem I ran into so far was with some 4:3 aspect ratio DVD's.  To play these properly you need to set one of the player's settings to "Fixed Aspect Ratio".  Although this worked on some DVD's, it didn't work on others.  I found that if you just press stop and then play again, it would adjust to the correct aspect ratio.  I don't know if this is the player's fault or the DVD.  Maybe a firmware upgrade witll fix it.  The work around is not that big of a deal anyway.  UPDATE: The latest firmware did fix this problem.Blu-Ray picture quality is great, of course.  But I was impressed that even DVD's look better.  I did not expect this since I already have a couple good DVD players (Oppo and Sony).  My TV does a much better job of upscaling than my DVD players.  This Sony Blu-Ray Player seems to upscale as good or better that my TV.  Very smooth motion and all around picture quality.
summary: BDP-N460 Works Great With My System

Great for games, and other apps sped up quite a bit.  Also popped it into another motherboard w/ DDR3 1333 in place of 8gb HyperX Blu, and back; automatically adjusted fine. reviewText: I needed a bigger harddrive, did some research and landed on this one.  So far it's been great.  Superfast, easy to use (although, caveat, I'm tech savvy so am not sure if other peoples' complaints about needing more instructions are valid), high capacity.  I wish it had a standard port in addition to the 3.0 just because if this one breaks it's a pain to replace but that's a minor issue.  also, FYI, I had a hard time finding a case that fit but this one works perfectlyhttp://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004CJ8DNG/ref=oh_details_o06_s00_i02

I just received my product. Okay, I must admit I was nervous after reading some negative reviews, however, thus far the product is operating as stated. You have the three receivers, each takes two triple A batteries. The transmitter does not use any batteries or cords to operate, once you attach it to your camera shoe, it uses power directly from the camera. How will this affect the power source of the camera, I cannot adequately say, only time will tell if this receiver drains your camera battery. There doesn't appear to be any sort of delays between transmitter and receiver, so far my max distance has been ten feet.Update. The ability to have your flash attached to wireless and position it somewhere and you have the ability to manuver is priceless.  This product gives ypu the freedom to create portraits with amazing shadow contrast and detail as if using light setups just because you have the freedom to move and station flash somewhere else. Other ppl have complained about problems I havent had any, however I believe I may know why some ppl have problems. I have two external flashes...one sppedlight ttl 520 the other bower. The speedlight connects well and receives input quickly and since thecycle is quick you can get numerous flashes back to back. The bower however is slower and requires constant input by transmitter....I have to tap the button atop transmittet to have bower activate. The cycle is slow so I take a shot and wait a full second before taking another shot. So of tpu dont have speedlight flash you may have problems.The product feels cheaply made, so I recommend you keep the plastic baggy it comes with or find somewhere to store your receivers that has some cushion. Is this something a professional wants to use, I doubt it, but for hobbyist and individuals who are trying to become professional but are on a tight budget, this will get the job done. I hope that it last longer than some of the reviews have claimed. But, I will say this, the products that I've purchased here for my camera, most are not name brand materials, have yet to fail me and work flawlessly.As I always tell people, do your research and if you don't feel right about getting this product or feel iffy about it, listen to your gut instinct and shop around. Maybe shopping around will help you make a decision.
These SDD units will help me improve the speed of my old computer. Good to recycle and bring new life to old systems :)

reviewerName: Nosreves "-Just another face in the crowd"
reviewText: I've had this product for over 7 months now and have never been let down. Out of the box you get the New Trent iCarrier, a microUSB charging cable and the carrying case for the battery pack. As with most new external battery packs, it's recommended to charge it before using, to make sure it's fully charged, but straight out of the box, this one holds a decent charge already. I was able to charge my HTC One S from 16% to 98% and the battery lights still indicated 2 bars, so that's outstanding. Since my purchase, I've used this on many occasions to recharge my new phone, Nexus 5, for my iPod touch (sometimes at the same time) and a good amount of times my iPad 3rd gen. All devices start charging instantly and are well on their way when I check back on them. It's easy to use, just plug in the USB to the appropriate port 1amp for phones, 2amps for tablets(iPads, Kindles, etc.) press the power button and VOILA, you're golden. To turn off the charger you hold down the power button for about 3 seconds, the lights turn off and you put it away in the carrying bag. To charge the pack itself I use my PowerGen dual wall outlet charger and just leave it in while I'm charging my phone from the same outlet. It's perfect! I would definitely recommend this product to anyone that finds their phone running low on battery a lot when they're away from chargers and don't mind a little extra weight for an enormous amount of power.

Bought these to replace my much-loved and much-used JVC HAFX33 marshmallow headphones that were getting old and stiff and don't notice any difference between the 2 models other than the model number.While not as good in reducing ambient noise as an active noise-cancelling headphone like Bose, these are much much cheaper and much more compact, and do a pretty good job of isolating you from the surrounding noise when you take the time to "squish" the earpieces appropriately and let them expand in your ear canals.The earpieces are made of a material similar to but firmer than the disposable earplugs you get for free when flying long distances on some airlines or that you can buy by the bucketful at hardware stores. The disposable earplugs usually claim around 25-30 dB noise reduction, and the JVC marshmallow headphones seem to be a bit less, but are still noise-reducing enough that I can't hear the flight attendant on the plane without taking one out of an ear.I'm not an audiophile so I can't really comment on how "good" the sound is, but they fit my needs perfectly when I am listening to music in noisy environments or when I want to block out distractions such as in the library.Note - don't be mislead by reviews calling these noise-cancelling headphones - they aren't. Noise-cancelling is an active process that involves the headphones generating sound waves of their own to cancel out extraneous noise, which means that the headphones are big, expensive, and require batteries. Instead, these are noise-reducing or noise-isolating headphones - they work by tightly fitting in your ear canal and blocking a portion of the outside noise (like earplugs do) rather than by actively cancelling it.

reviewText: The keyboard itself is great. The color options are really nifty. The keys respond well. But the auto-sleep timer is a major major major issue and the keyboard sometimes decides to not allow you to type when you switch windows. It goes to sleep after 1 minute and will not turn back on for 2-7 seconds (really, I timed this). So if you're browsing the net and start typing in something to search... guess what? IT DIDN'T TYPE ANYTHING. At first this was a minor inconvenience but after 3 days of use it will drive you crazy. I asked SHARKK how to modify this. I could care less about battery life; I want a keyboard that I can actually use. Unfortunately, they immediately wrote back to say this is something they are still addressing... yeah, super ambiguous. This keyboard has a lot of potential but right now there are far to many technical issues with it for anyone to waste money on it.
summary: Has MAJOR technical issues still being addressed by manufacturer

reviewText: Does what it needs to. Works good enough to extend the length of the cable to my Z506 surround speakers.

I've had these just over a year and still find these speakers amazing.  I usually use them on my netbook and find they put out an decent volume of sound of impressive quality.I'm not saying they will satisfy audiophiles. These are, after all, relatively inexpensive USB speakers without a lot of bass.  But I was impressed today when I moved my Altec Lansing speakers from the desktop computer I'm using to write this to the computer I use with my music synthesizer and temporarily replaced the Altec on this computer with the Logitech USB.  It doesn't have the bass or volume of the Altec speakers, but it does have as much volume as I need in my small office and quite good sound quality.To get the best volume and sound quality, I open up the Windows Sound window.  Depending on how your Windows PC is configured, there will be one of two ways for you to do this.  First click the Start button and then Control Panel.  If you see a vertical menu list of items, scroll down to Sound and click that; if you see two columns of categories, click Hardware and Sound and then click Sound. Here you'll find options that should improve your listening experience with these speakers.It's on a netbook or laptop that these speakers really shine.  If you've been using a standard netbook or laptop speaker, these will be heaven to you.My only complaint is that the USB cord is short.  It's no problem on my netbook or on my ancient Thinkpad, but for some larger laptops, it could be an issue.  Otherwise, if you're looking for inexpensive USB speakers, it's hard to beat these.  I was going to add "portable" to that list, but after listening to them just now on this desktop and playing with the Windows Sound window to tweak it, they also make decent, though not ideal, speakers for a desktop.  The short USB cord can be a problem when using it with a desktop, but a USB extension cable can remedy this.I'll still order larger speakers, probably another set of Altec Lansings, to replace the ones I moved to the other desktop computer, but in the meantime, I don't mind listening to this Logitech, and I love it when I'm on my netbook.
summary: I don't often say "awesome", but these are... awesome

reviewText: When I received these ear buds I was impressed by the understated but stylish packaging as well as the large array of tips to facilitate  perfect fitting and the nice travel case.That was nothing compared to how I felt when I first plugged them in to my iPod touch and listened to them!I was not sure that they would be really good due to the very small physical size (which makes them amazingly comfortable by the way) but I was wrong. I skipped from track to track and from artiste to artiste trying to find a weak point. I've recently had minor ear surgery so I even checked them out on a hearing test website. All of it was pointless because I could not fault these little gems. They are by far and away the best pair of earphones I have ever owned.And, as an added bonus I don't have to peer closely to see which one is left and which is right (they are marked L & R just like they should be) because the earpieces are subtly different colors. Black and Red just remember Red for Right and you are good to go.To summarize: I can't fault these in any way, shape or form,  excellent value.

I was looking for a simple and inexpensive MicroSD card reader that would work with our Vizio TV for showing pictures. However, after a little experimentation, I discovered that the card reader included with the TopRam card just wouldn't work with the TV. I have been using this screen for about 8 months now and could not be happier.  I had a pull down screen that was slightly smaller that I had purchased a few years ago from Circuit City.  I was doing a bit of remodel and thought about getting an electric screen and found them not too expensive.  I had an electrician put in a recessed outlet behind where I had planned to put the screen ahead of time.There are a few options to switching on the screen, including a wired switch, an wireless remote and also the ability to hook the screen into your projector's trigger function.  I choose the trigger function.  Using cat 5 cables I could connect the screen and the projector through my attic.  The result is that the screen drops down whenever I turn on the projector and rises when I turn off the projector.So far the screen has worked every time.  It takes its time to wind down but in my case no longer than it takes my system to boot up,  So i am happy with it.  I also think the controlled speed should reduce the chance of binding during rewind.I don't have anything bad to say about the screen.  The mounting points are at the end of the screen which gives you a few options but it is possible to have a arrangement where you will not be on studs - like I was - and I think you want to mount this screen to the wall studsm it is not too heavy, I installed it myself,  I built a housing that would "hide" the screen and using basic baseboard trim pieces along the front and sides and a 3/4" thick piece of pine on top, I had it looking like it belonged just below my crown molding.  I attached the housing with some L brackets to the wall studs and then attached the screen to the pine of the housing.Very pleased with the result

Let me start this review off simply. BUY THIS. Is it as good as the more expensive alternative? It very, very, very nearly is. It's the right price, it has surprisingly good build quality, excellent recycle time (better than my Canon), and consistent results.This is my second Yongnuo unit (I have the 2 also) and unless I end up having more money than I care to count, I may never buy another Canon unit. Don't get me wrong, the Canon IS better, but $300 better? Absolutely not. My first Yongnuo was bought as a cheap second unit for a specific job that I didn't want to invest too much in. It has, since then, become my primary unit. I have two 430 EXII units that I use as backups now.My concern with most low price alternatives from China are usually quality related. This flash has taken several spills already (see my upcoming review of my new sandbags to avoid that) and hasn't skipped a beat. It's build quality is EXCELLENT. I can't say that part enough.So what do you give up from the Canon? For starters, ETTL. I don't use it, so I don't miss it. Canon 600EX zooms to 200mm, Yongnuo zooms only to 105mm. I believe the Canon trigger system used in the 600 are superior, but I used a pocket wizard type product anyway, so that isn't a deal breaker for me.At the end of the day, this flash can be delivered to your door for $85, versus $400 for the Canon equivalent. Imagine what you could use the extra $325 for. For me? I'll buy three more of these and take my girlfriend out for a nice steak dinner.. all for the same price as one Canon.
summary: Buy Four and a Nice Steak Dinner! (On Canon)

reviewText: Don't you hate that every computer comes with a 'free' 3 month subscription to Norton anti-virus?  Boot up and in about a month you begin to get dire warnings that your subscription is about to expire and reminders to go to their web site and get the key to unlock the full edition.  Note: You're better off getting a disk copy of whatever you decide to use for your anti-virus software, because you pay a good deal of money to download it, only to lose it sometime later (unless you want ot pay $10 extra to keep an archived copy out in cyber space for future use, when your computer crashes--possibly from the very viruses you've bought this miserable program to fend off).Why did I purchase this program? Because I've tried taking off Norton's programs and managed each time to take out something necessary to some other operational programs.  Amazon offered Norton CHEAP in a gold box special. If (unlike me) you can get rid of Norton altogether, I advise you go online and find something in the freeware.  Norton is a pain in the pocket book and a drag on the operating system all round.I put off installing this disk as long as I dared. It's never ever as 'simple' as the directions insist.  I had to install it, have it stall, uninstall it, and re-install before I got it functioning.  And as usual, installing this version further slowed down my computer's actions.The way it works is, you buy a computer which is blazing fast compared with what you had before. Over the years there are many updates automatic and otherwise, and there are re-subscriptions to antivirus programs.  Each change changes the computer, until 5 years later you can do just about the same as it does mechanically, with pen and paper.It's my theory that if we stripped our operating systems of all but the barest essentials in updates and anti-virus/system maintenance programs, computers would perform with the 'blazing speed' advertised in their spec sheets.If you are not a geek, and you don't want to pay for a geek, this may suit your purposes.  It's a rip off, but at least Amazon offers it for a better price than Norton or some of its distributers.  This is why I gave it the high mark of 1 star.  The stars really go to Amazon, and not to the program itself.
USB 2.0. Works as expected. Provides a thin plastic to stick to the underside of the drive where the PCB is exposed. Nice touch! Recommended.

I knew it was just adjustments, but Wally World wouldn't even let me have the remote to improve the picture, so I put my trust in Amazon reviewers and it has paid off, Thank You again!

reviewText: Trying to find a case for the iPod Nano 8G I received for Christmas, I found this "slap" watch at the Apple website first. Although Amazon only had the blue and I wanted a different color, I ordered the blue from Amazon anyway as it was less expensive than the Apple website price. Turns out the blue is a very nice medium matte color. So...highs: love the "slap" feature that makes the band fit perfectly around my medium-sized wrist. The case part is thicker than a normal watch, about 1/2", but not so thick that it interferes with regular clothing. It looks quite sporty, and I like that. All controls are fully functional and easy to access, and plugging in the earbuds was quick and easy. I can exercise while wearing this watch, and when not wearing it, open the band flat and lay it on a surface (like my desk as I type this review.) The watch is attractive and fun with a retro 80's vibe. Lows: it was a bit tricky to get the iPod into the case, and there is no access to the docking plug while it is in the case, so the iPod has to be removed to charge and/or sync it. Overall, I like the looks and functionality of this case/watch, and plan to use it as my regular iPod case.
This is a great device. However if you own Windows 7 computers on your network this device will not work! Otherwisw 5 star across the board.......

My router and modem are located in an On-Q Box in our utility room.  We got a strong wireless signal in all areas of the home except the master bedroom.  I could not connect to the router when using my laptop in the bedroom.  I installed the Netgear WN3000RP midway between the utility room and bedroom and now get a 5 bar (Excellent) wireless signal in the bedroom.  I also get a strong signal on the back patio.  I have been using the device for about a week and it hasn't dropped off line once.The WPS installation did not work but I have had trouble with it before with my Cisco router.  The manual describes how to set up the device with a web browser if the WPS doesn't work.  The procedure was very easy to follow and I connected the WN3000RP to my router in less than 5 minutes.  I read that the WPS has a security flaw so it may be best not to use it anyway.  If you have a dead spot in your home, I highly recommend this range extender.
summary: Solved my wireless dead spot problem

reviewText: I ordered this product in the hopes that it would end the constant harassment from the Mrs about having my PC turned off when she wanted to print. The product looked pretty good and seemed like a perfect solution. To my dismay, reality was much more painful. We have 2 PCs, one laptop and an iMac on our network and when I opened the directions to "Istall on a Mac" I found the following listed as a first step. (After physically plugging the print server into the printer and hub. Open your printer dialong and input the IP address of the print server.....well, just what IS the IP address this thing sets up for it self?Good thing I had a windows PC that could take their installation CD. I figured I would install on the Windows PC first and then move back to the Mac. All was going well with the install until I selected which printer was going to be used on the server. After selecting the printer I was treated to another extremely helpful message...and this is actually how it was written. "The printer segent that  was you selected is not the same as the print server". Nice error message, got it on the other two windows machines as well. Went the the manufacturer's web site and decided to check out the support/faq for this device. Guess what? There were zero articles about this device. None! I quick search of the web netted me the cause of this error. The printer I have (an HP Photosmart 8250) is not supported by this product. Would have been nice to find that out before I ordered.Amazon's return was as easy as ever, so I can't fault Amazon in any way. If you own any newer printer, aviod this thing at all costs. Firmware is dated in Feb 2006 and there are no updates for it at this time.

I recently upgraded from the Nuvi 760 to the Nuvi 885t, it's now more than a month since I played around with it and the more I use it the more flaws I uncover. For starter the POI are extremely slow to search beyond usable time, and at times the touch respond command on the screen lagged several times during POI search, the streets names on the map do not appear or at times lagged or every other street names pop up and some do not pop up and at times the street names pop up as I pass the street a block away, how useless is that? And the map settings are on Normal and tried other settings for the streets to appear but no luck just simply lagged on loading street names on View Map mode. One major down grade from the 760 to the 885t was the View Map mode at display on upcoming streets and fwy exits because there is none, the 885t only display the current street that it's traveling on. That should really be fixed to be able to switch to current traveling street to upcoming ones. I tried every possible setting and updated it to the current versions and it's still sluggish.  Lane Assist, Bluetooth, Voice Command, MSN Direct, Games, is great icing on the cake but the cake itself is poorly design.Bottom line is that it is not an upgrade from the Nuvi 760. The 885t is a 2 star rating at Amazon for me as it did little for my money.I hope there are some answers to my problems/hotfix.
summary: 885t needs hotfix first before it can be called an upgrade

reviewText: Why pay over $100 or even $70 for a simple shutter release?  If you need distance from your camera, wireless capabilities, or still be able to set functions on the camera from a distance, then get a more expensive remote; it will be worth it.  But if you are looking for a simple corded shutter release, save your money and get this one.  Sure, it doesn't feel as sturdy as the more expensive ones; but how sturdy does a simple button have to be to make a shutter release?  This one is just as good quality as the Nikon simple shutter release, but after using it several times I think it is probably better than Nikon's (I'm not a gentle person when it comes to remotes).  It has worked perfect on my D300 in both my studio and travels, and fits comfortably in my hand.  I use it for night shots (lots of night shots) and product studio long exposures.  As an example, I used this remote to make most of the photos used on CompassRoseGeocoin.com.  I could not have any camera shake when taking those photos.Update: I ended up losing the first one of these I purchased after using it for several hundred photos (It was much sturdier than I thought).  I wasn't too upset since the cost was so low, but I would have been livid if I were to lose one of those more expensive remotes.  After finding out of the loss, I did more research to see if there are any new options for remotes; but this remote still seems to be the best value on the market today.  Therefore I was happy to buy a second one.
summary: Save your money and get this one

reviewText: This drive is one of the few USB Drives that Windows XP will recognize at the F6 command during the XP Install. This drive worked flawlessly in Win7-64x so I could create a RAID Disk for XP. The drive also worked flawlessly during the XP install and was recognized by the OS at the F6 Command. So for many people who build their own systems this is a definite asset to have in your bag of tricks. I most certainly will purchase another just in case.
summary: Works with F6 on XP Install - Nuff Said!

I was concerned about this purchase given the great price (I did alot of online & retail shopping).  But let me tell you, this is one heavy-duty, clean designed hunk of metal.  Makes for a very secure and professional/clean installation.Although there are no photos, this unit tilts vertically (up / down), horizontally (back / forth), and can move up against or extend from the wall.  Essentially universal movement.An unexpected bonus was the inclusion of ALL necessary mounting hardware including 3-4 sets of TV mount screws (to fit any TV), heavy-duty wall mount bolts, wall anchors for installing into concrete, and readable instructions (not just a poor translation to english).The only reason I can imagine this would receive a negative review would be that it was installed incorrectly (which, of course, has nothing to do with the product).As with any mount at ANY price, you must mount this into a wall stud or solid (concrete/wood/other) wall and NOT into drywall or plaster (that's not what the included wall anchors are for and the instructions indicate that).Highly recommended product.

I snapped and backed-up nearly 50 gigs of photos. A few days after returning home to the states the drive just died (less than a month old). No response, no access. Total failure. I had never dropped the unit but maybe lugging it around in my camera/laptop bag was too rough? I contacted Seagate from their website and was issued an RMA with packaging instructions. In 2 weeks time I had a new unit.Fortunately I still had all my files on my laptop and lost nothing. The new unit has been functioning fine with a couple of notes: Running the Memeo software I noticed it was in a continious loop like mentioned in another posting, I had to reload the software to get it to back up completely. Also, it seems that the back-ups load over a previous back-up so that files are continiously written but not deleted, even when deleted from the drive that's being backked up. I move a lot of files around (photos) as I catagorize them for later editing. The Seagate drive fills up quickly with the same files found in many folders.All in all it's a decent package. The Memeo software works quietly in the background and causes no slow-down to my laptop.

reviewText: I was impressed with the quality of materials and construction of each component. However, it seems that the components were not originally designed specifically for one another. The light holder, for instance, is designed to mount on the top of a metal shaft by means of a screw clamp. But the top of the light stand has a screw that points upward, and the only way I could determine to mount the holder is by clamping it onto the threads of the  stand's screw -- it cannot be positioned lower, onto the shaft, where it would be more appropriate. It works, but not optimally. In another instance, the shaft of the umbrella is constructed of lightweight tubular steel. It is held in position by another screw clamp on the light holder. But when clamping it down, the screw will easily crush the tubular steel. I overcame this problem by temporarily removing the aluminum cap at the bottom of the umbrella's shaft and inserting a 15" long, 1/4" diameter wooden dowel into the tube. I can now apply adequate pressure to satisfactorily secure the umbrella.You might gather from these problems that I don't recommend this purchase, but actually I'm quite happy with it. Compared to other sets, it's an amazing value. The use of color-balanced compact florescent bulbs makes a lot of sense (unless you require intense illumination). And the entire package is very compact.If you're a professional photographer with an array of lighting options, this set probably isn't for you. But if, like me, you just need a simple, inexpensive way to light your subjects, this is probably as good a product as you'll find for the price!

A monopod is a great help in steadying a camera, and to have it double as a walking stick is a good idea.  This one is good quality; sturdy, robust, but light.  It extends from 18 inches to 59 (not counting the removable bulb), so your viewfinder will be around 5 feet high when you use it.The screw locking holds well, so you can extend it to the length you want for a walking stick and use it with confidence.The compass in the removable bulb at the top looks to be of limited use, but I suppose they may as well make some use of the bulb.If your hands are not as steady as you'd like, and you could use a walking stick, this is a good purchase.

I've had issues with Microsoft everything over the past few years and this controller just goes to hammer in my point.  I've typically bought used xbox controllers in the past but with the 360 didn't have much luck keeping them working.  That being said I have now purchased 2 of this particular product.  It being a new name brand controller I expect the quality and durability that I pay for.  Unfortunately, that is not the case.The first of the controllers I purchased back in October.  It immediately had loud squeeking noises when moving the joysticks.  Fortunately it is still functioning correctly so I can live with it despite the noise.Hoping that the noise issue was just a one time mistake, I ordered the second one to replace another failing used controller I've had for years.  Within the first 12 hours of gameplay, the X button has become very insensitive and tends to stick, thus I will be returning it as defective to get a replacement.  Hopefully it turns out better for the 3rd try...Sorry folks, the name brand Microsoft just isn't worth it anymore it seems.  I hope Sony and Mac keep up the PC and Platform battle because I'm coming over.12/9/11 update:I received the replacement to the controller I sent back due to the sticking button.  This is the third controller in a row that has some form of manufacturer defect.  Luckily, 2 of the 3 are still functional, albeit still defective.  This new one has a loose left bumper which, while the button underneath still functions, it results in a funky feel that is ridiculous for a brand new controller.  This is very sad, I almost wish Amazon would discontinue selling this particular product.
summary: Seems like Quality is a thing of the past for American products.

So, this is my second cradle point device and I have to admit, I'm less than impressed...AGAIN.  So, I have an MBR1200 which was plagues with problems from the start.  It eventually stopped working all together at only about 9 months old. Anyway, I decided to downsize to a smaller device and connect it to a faster router using the WAN port, and I went with cradlepoint again noticing that they changed the operating system in their new devices and I figured they might have eliminated some of the bugs from the previous device.  Now, I've had no "hardware" issues like my mbr1200 did, except for it not liking my data stick. I'm using the T-Mobile Rocket(tm) 2.0 Data Stick (ZTE MF691) which is on their compatibility list.  The MBR1200 hated it and this CTR35 is no exception.  Now, I've got 2 of these sticks and they both act the same so I'm pretty sure it's the router and not the stick. The CRT35 will ONLY see the data stick if it is inserted AFTER it's boot process.  Otherwise it will report in the logs that there was a problem detected on the USB port and it will shut it down.  It will ever try again from there. So, if you lose power, your connection will not come back up.  You have to pull the stick, boot, and put it back it.  This also works only some of the time.  I've occasionally had to reboot again, and re-insert the stick as once it starts reporting there is a problem with the port, it will always report it no matter what. A Reboot usually fixes it.Also, some of the cool features in the router don't work well with this stick. The MBR1200 was the same way.  There is a keep alive function that will auto detect if the device stops responding, and it will force a hard reset of the port and try to get it to come back up.  Well, it always detects a problem and will keep rebooting your data stick over and over on whatever detection schedule you have set.  The MBR did this too.  There is no difference between its detection and Aggressive detection. They work the same.  Constant resets.  You can also tell it to use an outside source to ping so that if it can't ping the site, it assumes it's down and will reset it.  This doesn't work either.  It still resets if even if you can ping from a computer connected to it.  So, all that said, if have all the special features disabled and as long as I don't have a power outage, it stays up consistently.  I've been running now for 2 weeks without interruption. So, it's working well, but it takes a little work to get it to this point. Keep it simple and don't expect resiliency from outages.

reviewText: Judging by all the various reviews for 50GB DL Blanks, it's really hit and miss if you're able to find a brand that works flawlessly.  I just recently purchased these disks after successfully using Verbatim 25GB (single layer) disks.I had reached the stage where I needed 50GB storage, as I have 36GB VM single files I need to back up.  So, I purchased the HP brand, wrongly thinking their reputation would keep me away from coaster hell, but I was wrong :-(.  I tried to burn a 36GB file using a new LG Burner BE14NU40 and Nero 2014 software on the 2 year old (USB 2.0) Dell i3 Desktop.  It failed when data was already burned to disk but being verified.I'm still troubleshooting why the "verify write" keeps failing after each 50GB burn while using Nero 2014.  One of the two 'failed' disks actually works if I pop it back into the Bluray tray and copy the single file to an area on the hard drive.  I was able to use the  file later when I had copied it OK and did some testing.  Put another way, the integrity of the write for one of the 2 disks is OK, but each time I try to repeat the same process for the second 50GB burn I did tonight, the copy process (from Bluray to Hard drive) fails at 66%, complaining of a bad cluster on the Bluray.  So, I guess this is my first genuine coaster!  It could be Windows and Bluray are not getting along, as the file is the largest I've tried to work with so far.Sorry if I am a little too technical for some of you.  Just be mindful that not all brands are created equal.  Not only do you have to consider the bluray hardware being used (with up-to-date firmware, etc.), but the transfer and read/write rates you can get via USB 2.0 or 3.0, as well as (of course) the media you use to burn the data.As soon as I have been able to figure out what's going on with my experiences, I will update this review.  I may even buy another brand, especially if someone out there can recommend ones that work with my LG Burner???
summary: I'm not having much luck with this Brand

reviewText: This attractively styled little power brick can be a real lifesaver. It's designed to charge your mobile Apple devices when you're on the go, and it delivers on that promise. It has a sleek look and a pleasant tactile feel to the rubberized center surface. It ships fully charged so there is no need to plug it in to your computer's USB port right away with the supplied included cable. You are supposed to be able to charge your mobile device about 5 or 6 times before it needs to be recharged itself, but so far I've only gotten 4 charges at most before it is empty (1 with the iPad). The Juice Pack itself takes about 4 hours to charge from my iMac, and the iPod Touch I tested it with took about an hour (a little longer for the iPhone). Another neat feature is that you can continue to use your portable device while the Mophie is charging it. You can see how much "juice" the pack has left using the 6 LEDs on the top face.I think this is excellent option for charging your portable devices on the go. It's small form factor (slightly larger than the iPhone 4) makes it easy to throw into a back for a weekend getaway. If I could make it work with my HP laptop, life would be perfect. The Mophie Juice Pack Powerstation is ideal for charging smaller devices but it's great that it can top-off an iPad as well. I wish it wasn't so expensive, but if it lasts the claimed 500 full cycles and all of its touted safety features work, then it will be worth the current price tag.

UPDATE from April 2nd, 2013:While looking back through my old reviews I've spotted this one and realized that it was a good idea to return this Roku. I've recently purchasedPanasonic DMP-BDT220 Integrated Wi-Fi 3D Blu-ray DVD Playerand am very happy with it. It is wireless, is able to play various discs (DVD, Blu-ray, etc.), and is able to play video files form a USB driver or various SD, SDHC, SDXC cards, and in addition it has Netflix and other streaming services. Plus looks great and one remote can be used for multiple functions.BEFORE you can use this Roku unit even for a second, Roku requires you to register an account with them and provide your credit card information! Why would I rush to do that when I have not even seen what this unit is capable of? Also, I don't really need streaming services and hoped to use it for playing video files from USB-devices. However, I could not even try that feature because I did not want to go through the hassle of all the registration and was especially put of by the requirement to provide my credit card number.Also, it is somewhat more responsive than Sony SMP-N200, but still in the same "waste basket" category. It took 7 tries before the unit connected to WiFi. Don't waste time and money. Go buy Mac Mini, bluetooth keyboard and a mouse and be happy!I don't need streaming, so I'll continue looking for a digital player that is user-friendly.The unit is packaged and is going back tomorrow (to a local retailer).
summary: Requires registration with a credit card BEFORE one can even try the player

reviewText: Longer and more detailed reviews abound, and this will be in the old reviews (page two) in a flash.  I just wanted to tell people that I bought this for one thing, and one thing only: watching my Youtube subscription channels on my 70 inch HDTV.  It works like charm, controlled by my iPad.I downloaded the Chromecast app on the iPad2 from App Store, free.I stuck the Chromecast dongle in the HDMI port on the TV, and the power USB cable from the dongle into a USB port on the TV.  I followed the onscreen instructions, and ten minutes max later, I'm watching Youtube on TV.  It's fantastic large, especially HD youtube content.  I watch many youtube videos that are 30+ minutes long--what a way to watch!  The volume is controlled on the TV remote control, but I select videos on the iPad, just like the Youtube app you have on there now.Phenomenal!
summary: I watch Youtube on my 70 inch TV.

reviewText: We have a big screen and four small TV's in a cabinet and keep most of them on all day. I replaced a 13 inch TV with the Coby which is about the same size picture but wider. The Coby is on cable (non-HD).The picture is very sharp and the wavy lines that our cable system cannot get rid of are cleaned up nicely. Graphics and closed captions are easy to read from 15 feet away. I try to average out the difference in tint from one station to another and this TV took a while. Likewise, if I tried to match the contrast/brightness to the nearby TV's, it was nearly impossible. If you see haze, start over. Bad lighting, harsh lighting really looks terrible on close-ups of faces. Comparing the pavement on a sunny racetrack seen on this TV to another TV looks just like what I see when I take off my polarized sunglasses riding down the interstate.Comparing the sound on this TV to every other TV is like saying Pee Wee Herman will never beat Hulk Hogan. No, he won't. But, comparing my four SMALL TV's, the Coby is the loudest and clearest. Turn up the bass and treble as much as you like.The remote is just the right size and well-organized except the "zero" is on the left side when it should be in the middle like a telephone. The menu used to adjust the TV does not cover the screen as badly as the ViewSonic I bought a few months ago.
summary: I think it will be OK

reviewText: Great cable for the price. I'm usually a monoprice.com cable guy, but I wanted this and the TV to come in at the same time (which they did). I had to upgrade my old 1.3 cable to 1.4a cables to take advantage of the 3D and ARC (Audio Return Channel). The ARC is cool ... essentially, if you are watching the TV's widget stuff, like YouTube, Netflix, the sound comes over your receiver, instead of just the TV. Great feature of HDMI 1.4a. Make sure the cables you buy now say: HIGH SPEED to take advantage of the newer technologies.

I was prepared to like this Sony BDP-S570 3D Blu-ray Disc Player even before I received it. Set-up and operation began really well, were quick and easy to effect and I was soon playing BDs. WiFi network setup was almost as easy and in only minutes I was connected and receiving Netflix and other on-line services wirelessly using WPA2 AES encryption. I had purchased the unit for BD and WiFi on-line reception from my livingroom, which was 2 walls and approximately 30' from my router; however, the WiFi link was beginning to fail almost as soon as I started, even after I brought the unit within 3' of my router. I contacted Amazon and was happy to find out they had a quality returns process that resulted in rapid replacement of the defective unit at no-cost to me. I received the new unit only 3 days later but after set-up noted the WiFi link range was very sensitive to the orientation of both the router antennas and the Player. However, once I raised both my WiFi router and BDP-S570 about 5' above the floor and aligned router antennas for maximum range, the connection stabilized and the speed was very satisfactory. I have had no problems since.
summary: WiFi connection is a bit sensitive and short-ranged

reviewText: I cable works great with my mobile devices. I arrived in a timely manner after I placed the order and I have been using in for 3 months now without any problems.

OK. First off.  This is not a Takahashi Sky 90. It isn't an Obsession UC22" Dobsonian. I own both of the aforementioned scopes.  Plus a Tak FSQ106EDXIII. I am an amateur astronomer.  Heck, I even have my own domed observatory in the back yard. So I didn't expect this little scope to afford views like I was accustomed to.I bought the scope for my neighbors 8 year old son. But before I passed it along to him, I decided to try it out on the Heavens. Out of the box I was far from impressed. Sure, it is only a 3" reflector. But the optic problems it was plagued by were enormous. The eyepieces are crap, sad to say. But worst of all, the optic train is even worse, at least my model.Most reflectors have the ability to collimate the optics. That is, align everything with respect to the eyepiece.  This scope does not. No way to move the primary mirror, and only "fake" alignment screws on the secondary mirror. On top of all this, the secondary mirror (the mirror that reflects the image from the primary to the eyepiece) was installed crooked.  This definitely didn't help any.First thing I did was remove the secondary (small) mirror from the focuser and re-glue it so that it was lined up better.  This was done by "eyeballing" but it made a vast difference in the view. Easy to do with some contact cement. This is about all you can do to help the optics in this little scope. This may have just been my scope, but I didn't have time to send it back.Once I made this change, I was impressed.  Remember, you're not going to get Hubble views out of this scope.  Even after the fix there was a lot of astigmatism and coma in the eyepiece.  Stars showed lots of pincushion artifacts just outside of the center field. But when I trained the scope on the Orion Nebula, there it was! With a bit of averted vision (not looking directly at the object, but sort of off to one side) I was treated with the classic nebulosity. The Pleiades were brilliant, and I was easily able to make out the shape of the Andromeda Galaxy. Jupiter's four big moons were obvious, though the cloud bands took some imagination (but there was light thin clouds disturbing my view from Earth). The Moon was very impressive.  Even when I changed to the 4mm ocular, the Moon showed lots of detail that should make any kid bubble with joy. The craters were very impressive. Though I did not see myself, I am sure the rings of Saturn would be easily visible.I remember, as a ten year old, looking at Saturn with my brothers 60mm Sears refractor. I was enthralled and it set the stage for a life long desire to explore the Heavens. Since then I've owned an Edmund Astroscan and 6" reflector, two Celestron C8's, a C11, a home made 13.1" Dobsonian reflector, and my current Takahashi refractors, and my new 22" Obsession scope. All of this because of my first back yard views with a Sears piece of junk. This scope is far better in my opinion. Remember, you're not necessarily getting a top notch telescope. The build overall is impressive however. A finderscope would be nice, but I had pretty good luck just sighting down the tube and hunting. But a scope like this might just be the one thing to spark curiosity in a young mind. And there just isn't much of that going around these days.If you have a youngster that you think might like an introduction to the night sky, this is the perfect little gem. Sure, far from perfect, and might even need a bit of tweaking if you are brave enough.  But even out of the box it gives descent views of the brighter celestial objects, plus the Moon and bigger planets. And it is easy to carry and a breeze to set up. Go for it!
summary: A fantastic first scope to intrigue young minds!

Bought this SMC router on the strength of a CNET review to replace my old, failing Netgear for my home office with four laptops and four desktops. Had some difficulties with installation but a call to SMC tech support helped resolve the problems (SMC tech support is fast and excellent - best tech support I've found in years).  Unfortunately, I have to contact Lenovo to have them re-configure inbuilt wireless card in laptop running Vista (adding to my growing distaste for Vista).  My Macbook and other laptops running XP connected with no difficulty.  My two desktops running Netgear cards will not recognize the router, so I had to call Netgear, but they wanted $36.50 for a half-hour of support b/c my cards were out of warranty.  So, that sucked.  Looks like I'll need to get SMC adapter cards for the desktops.  I suppose I should have just purchased a newer Netgear router.  I think the SMC router is very good overall -- I'm getting a strong signal and fast downloads.  My problems are probably not the same that other users might experience, but I just wanted to save another user from the same hassle factors that I've had to go through with my setup....UPDATE:  3.5 years later and still running strong with no hiccups/problems.  This router has been extremely reliable.  I'm satisfied with it overall.
summary: Good router but not without some hassle factors...

I had two old-ish speakers laying around and a variety of mp3 players that I cleaned up and populated with some of my favorite tunes. I figured the only place left in my home that doesn't have an audio jack and some speakers, was my bathroom.So I installed this puppy on the side of bathroom cabinets, it came with pre-drilled holes all you needed to do is screw it on. The speakers hook right in via speaker wire, no sockets, no adapters, just good ol' spring-powered wire harnesses.The amp is pretty darn good for what it is, gives you two options, one with no EQ, the other with the two EQ knobs activated. The knobs are a Treble and Bass knobs. Very helpful for finetuning the sound to your liking and the speakers as well. And the amp is LOUD.There's two ways to input sound, standard red/white RCA for Left and Right channels, and the 3.5mm (iPod/Mp3 player) jack that works with anything that has a 3.5mm jack. That's what I use.This thing is great for garage projects, or just anywhere where you need loud sound for NOTHING... seriously.. they might as well be giving this thing away.
summary: Works as intended, a great little amp!

reviewText: I'm coming from a Logitech Harmony One remote, and I couldn't be happier with my decision to ditch the One and go with the Smart Control.I was actually surprised by how little I missed the One's touchscreen.  I always thought it was a great feature, but looking back I now realize that all I ever used the touchscreen for was as a glorified button.  I don't miss it in the slightest.The Smart Control remote is very potent, allowing me to control all of my Activities ( I have 5 of the ) with ease.  There's three activity buttons on the remote, but you can activity a total of six activities by long-pressing each activity button.  I've found this solution to work very well.  The remote is also significantly lighter and smaller than the One remote.I can also control all of my devices and activities from my smartphone, which I've found to work very well and with little-to-no perceivable lag.  I set up all of my activities with ease from the Harmony app on my phone and didn't have to use the desktop software at all.My favorite part, however, is the Harmony Hub.  I positioned it under an end-table in my living room and it controls all of my devices flawlessly.  It's so nice to no longer have to stand there pointing the remote at the TV for 40-60 seconds waiting for all of my devices to turn on.  Now I can just start an activity from the remote and forget about it.My only gripe is that it's currently incompatible with my PS4.  Come on Logitech and Sony!  There's no reason this shouldn't work when both devices support Bluetooth connectivity.

The speaker itself is quite good overall but I want others to know that the item they are buying my not be a retail package. To some this may not matter but to me I was a bit shocked as I got one for someone as a gift. And as a gift its nice to have full retail packaging and graphics.I will do a quick review to compare the IM-237.The unit is almost identical to my IMT-228 the 228 has a more modern color with black and orange that looks pretty slick, while the 237 has a gray and silver body, BOTH COME WITH CASES.The differences I note are in construction the 237 uses what appears to be an aluminum speaker mount, TOP  BODY, where the 228 has a plastic speaker mount, now this may be what makes them sound slightly different due to the materials each is built around. I feel that the 237 has just a little bit solider bottom end but not a lot.They both sound quite clear and defined for the size of the driver, although the driver is no bigger then what most clock radios have in them, This does not in any way sound like a cheep clock radio speaker as one may expect. It actualy has nice clear shimmering highs with pretty good bottom and excellent vocal quality, again for its size it is quite impressive in my opinion.My reason for adding my review with the following info, is based on the fact I also own a IMT-228 that did come in full retail packaging from a different seller also fulfilled by Amazon.The item I purchased did appear to be brand new but only came in a uline corrugated shipping box not with full retail packaging. Nowhere do I see it mentioned that this is a warehouse type deal and does not come in full retail packaging.Note to Amazon please verify that if a seller fulfilled by Amazon is selling the item without full retail packaging, I feel this should be noted. I see no mention of that at this point. Again if it's a gift one may care about this, if not I am sure most will be fine ... it does come with the case, batteries and everything it should.I hope this will help others decide what Orbit to buy :-)

I've had the Acer One 10" for about 3 weeks and just love it!  The size and weight are perfect for biz travel.  It handles all the software I need on it very well.  Display is great.  Keyboard works fine, but I do have to slow down just a tad to let my pinkies get in place.  Still, the keyboard beats typing on a cell phone by a ton.I added a USB mouse, cuz I prefer them over touch pads.  Added a no-name USB CD-ROM to load software, easily found on the Net at $20. And added a $25 Zoom brand USB mini-modem as I occasionally stay in motels with no wireless.  The Acer One has 3 USB ports, so these add-ons all work fine.I've used it for video chat and video conferencing and the built-in camera and mike do just fine.The result is an invitingly portable computer that does everything I need to do on the road for about $400 in total.  A heck of a bargain, IMHO.

I like to use a mouse so then there is no extra USB. A second USB on the tablet would have been good. The blue tooth keyboard is great; no problem at all and the battery is lasting a long time because of the auto shut off feature.The screen is outstanding. Battery life seems a little shorter than advertised but still good at about 6 hours.The biggest negative issues have been associated with IE 10 crashes and other browsers do not work properly on the tablet. I have tried  google chrome and several others and they freeze up.Overall a great tablet/computer but still needs a little tweaking to make it optimum.

I considered Time Capsule a couple years ago when I needed a new router to replace an Airport Extreme zapped by lightning. I just didn't want to spend the extra money, and so I got a new AEBS. When looking for a new backup strategy last month, I read the reviews here and decided to get the Time Capsule for the wireless capability. I had tried to use Time Machine with a 2T My Book drive networked via the AEBS. It didn't work. Now I'm backing up my husband's MacBook Pro, my iMac and my external video drive all via WIFI in the background. If you love the ease of use of Time Machine, it's even better using Time Capsule. Setup took 5 minutes and my settings were automatically transferred to the TC. Now my AEBS is working as an extender on the network in a hard to reach part of the house and I will have a backup router if lightning strikes again.
summary: Very glad I decided to buy Time Capsule

I love my Edge 305. I have the Cadence and HR model.They loose a star for the software though, at this price the unit should come with a full set of maps. Considering you can't ride a bike on major roads and highways, why is that the only thing shown on the maps? All my rides end up in the middle of nowhere on the included mapset. So count on spending another $100 to add maps if you want to plan out your bike trips.Another beef is that it is possible to accidently hit the release button and have the device fall off your bike. Again, at this price point, there's no excuse. It should be IMPOSSIBLE for the device to fall off unintentionally. Some form of a double lock is called for here.In the end, it falls short of perfection, but not by much. I'd buy it again and I can't imagine riding without mine. if I were a mountain biker it'd be even more of a neccesity. I love it.To the people complaining about battery life. Get an Energizer USB phone emergency battery available at any Walgreens or Publix. The GPS runs fine on any USB power source. The down side is duct taping the external battery to your handle bars.

reviewText: Cap string is not elastic. Seems to be designed to be attached to the camera, which is not really practical for MFT cameras unless all your lenses are 52mm. Maybe there is a way to wrap it around the lens, but I didn't really try.Microfiber is of very good quality.

I have had this camera for about two weeks and the second time I took the battery out to charge it, the latch broke that holds the battery in place, so I had to ship it back to kodak for repairs!!!The camera review: (separate from my complaint about the cheap plastic chassis)This camera takes great indoor shots with good white balance, great skin tones, and vibrant colors and has an ample flash.Having said that, here are the things I don't like,It doesn't come with the charging base or a power cord that plugs directly into the camera so you must take the battery out to charge it and hope the latch that holds the battery in place doesn't break off like mine did.The outside shots come out dim most of the time. I tried slowing the shutter speed down and opening up the aperature but most of the pictures I took came out blurry, unless I used the tripod. Sometimes even then as in outdoor shots, most of the time the camera would not acheive focus lock.  It would give me the warning symbol tellimg me it couldn't lock focus and sure enough, the pictures would come out blurry.No manual focus.  This would help when the camera doesn't achive focus lock which in my experience was most of the time I was outside.I wish I had more to say and rate this camera on, but it broke after two or three uses and about 2 weeks time.Seriosly folks, my little casio Z4U does a much better job of achieving focus than this camera.  Not that it is perfect but I would expect the Kodak to do a better job than my little casio camera any day and in most any way.  A very poor performer!!!Experience:  Casio Exilim Z4U, Olympus D-580, Fuji E550, and the Kodak DX7630
summary: Cheap piece of junk! Really, read on please.

reviewText: I'm sold on rechargeable batteries.  Use them, plug them in, use them again.  The only issue is storing them.  This completely takes care of that problem for me.  Plus, since you can store the batteries up or down, it makes for an easy way to store the spent batteries so that I can recharge the maximum number at once.If you need to travel with a few batteries, this is about the best way to do it.If you need to store a lot of batteries, think Costco blister pack, a big bore ammo case (MTM brand works great) is a better option.
summary: Great for rechargeable batteries or travel

reviewText: I waited a LONG time to get this, I wish i had gotten it earlier.Pros:MUCH cheaper than other Qi ChargersEasy charging, as fast or nearly as fast as the factory plug-in charger.Input voltage is 5v and 1500ma. Thats compatible with a high-output USB Charger, making this easy to adapt to auto use (in theory)Attractive designQi Standard, so hopefully I can use it with my next phone too.Cons:So useful it should have come with the phonenot a CON so much as a wish: Since the input is the same as a lot of MicroUSB charger's output, it would have been AMAZING if they used a MicroUSB port for the power.Ive had my DNA since they first came out and I always wanted a wireless charger because plugging the DNA in is a pain (It has a little plastic cover that is super annoying) and because the DNA is a bit of a battery hog. Being able to come home and just put my phone down on the pad is great. Even better at night if I get a call, I just pick it up when I use it and put it down when im done. No more plugs to fiddle with in the dark.My only regret was not buying 2 of these the day i got the phone. One for work and one for home. Qi Charging will be a significant factor in the decision to buy my next phone.

So I read the other reviews for this product, all dismal, before I set it up, thinking that I could be the contrarian and get it to work, lauding its simplicity and ease.  Bottom line, the other reviewers are right -this thing is NOT READY FOR PRIME TIME.  It's full of bugs after a very easy set up process.  Instead I recommend the FoscamFoscam FI8910W Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with Two-Way Audio and Night Vision (White)which is a great product, half the price, provides pan capability, and works with a variety of apps.Pro's:- Smaller than Foscam- Extremely easy set up - easier than the Foscam- Good picture when it works- Easy set up on iPhone app.  Ability to register new camera and new account on app.  Don't need a computer at all.Con's:- Wifi works intermittently.  App keeps "losing" camera with "please wait wheel" spinning.- App has ADS.  Seriously?!?  Ridiculous.- Current price is almost double the superior Foscam product (above)- Ability to email videos doesn't work - sends you a blank email with an ad for parent company.This product is total garbage for now.  Perhaps future updates will fix this but I got this for free as a demo version.  Why would anyone pay $$ for a camera that is this buggy and unstable?Sorry, friends, cannot recommend.
summary: Buggy product, ads on your iPhone, unstable, expensive, better options out there

reviewText: Got 75-80Bucks and want to Buy a Sound card? Don't know what to do , where to Go what to Buy...Well here is what u should do, Go and get the X-Fi Xtreme Music.It's the best piece of X-Fi Creative ever manufactured.Make no mistake of it being a very old card or costly or that better options are available...Trust me there is no alternative to this card.All the Sub 125$ cards are no match for this one.This card has got better features then other X-Fi's and some more which are only available in 200$ cards..3 years have passed since i purchased this card,Works like a charm..Sound is so exhilarating,It makes u listen to songs again and again...Music, Movies or Games Nothing is spared..In Call of Duty 4 - IMO the Greatest Game ever made..I can hear footsteps halfway across the map, that's the advantage this card gives u...Even the much hyped X-Fi Fatality edition doesn't have this power...Don't be fooled by the marketing gimmicks of other cards.If u want a card and can get this one easily, Go for it...As creative has stopped manufacturing this card, u won't find it everywhere. Why they stopped ? Well as they say Good things end early...It had everything...So Creative now has distributed all the features in diff cards so as to earn more profit and target specific customers , i.e Music goes to Xtreme Audio..Gamer goes to Xtreme Gamer...Enthusiast to Fatality...This card contains all the features packed into 1 and costs 50 Bucks less...And moreover it is supported in all the Operating Systems 32/64Bit Don't matter...!Believe me,this will be your best Purchase Ever...I Disadvantage tho..u wont be able to connect your front panel to this card....For everything else there are about 30 odd pins on the card to connect everything from "spdif to Aux" and god what knows what else...Advantages1.Spectacular Sound2.Extremely Reliable3.Awesome Value for Money.Disadvantages1.No Front panel Connector2.Not Easily Available5 Stars - Highly Recommended...!!!!

Do you remember her on that somber summer day, when she sat below the willow trees and plaited your hair with the fresh dandelions of summer.  Do you see there beside her, in the grass, those terrible AudioQuest K2 Terminated Speaker Cables -- serpent-like and full of foreboding coiled evil.Water the fields with your tears, they will not bring her back.  Listen to the crystal clear sound of mountain bells reverberating against your eardrums.  That clarity is AudioQuest K2 Terminated Speaker Cables sounding the death knell to everything you have loved, and will ever love.As the salt water wells in your eyes, cradle these $6000 cables close to your slowly fading heart, and gnaw rabidly on its rugged rubberized insulation.  Nothing can stop the inevitable rupturing of your sanity.  Feel the last vibrations of hope fade from your soul as you dangle these premium cables from the willow branches above.  Swing now from your neck, pendulous, as you mark time for the approach of the next idiot who would spend $6000 for a god damn pair of speaker cables.
summary: Reminisce with me of days of yore when our beloveds walked in somber glades

reviewText: I have larger P&S cameras like the Fuji X10 and the Nikon P7100 plus my DSLRs.  I wanted a newer camera to replace my Canon S90 and chose the Nikon P310.  I am glad I did.  For one thing it starts up faster and is faster between shots even using the flash than my other P&S cameras.  My granddaughter is almost four and moves very quickly.  I still miss a few shots but for a camera that easily fits in my pocket the P310 gives me a high rate of great photos on the go.  The zoom range is fairly short but that is compensated by the faster f-stop lens.  So it does a better job in low light with the faster lens.  All in all a very useable P&S at what is now a very good price.  Well worth the money.

edit:  Well, after a few hours of working.... This unit stopped working as well as my other (netgear) HomePlug devices.  Once I reset the TP-Link, everything worked well for a few minutes and then they would all go down again.  The problems with my other (netgear) HomePlug devices disappeared once I removed the TP-Link from the mix.  I sent this one back and got another identical TP-Link.  This one exhibits similar problems... but it will only render my other HomePlug devices useless once every 3-4 days (once my TP-Link is reset, my other devices come back to life immediately)edit #2:  Okay. So I ditched the all of the netgear (mixed homeplug) units and I'm now running 5 of these TP-Link units in the house.  Zero issues in 6 months.  HomePlug devices *should* be compatible, but apparently they are not.  Don't know which one, netgear or TP-Linkm are causing the compatibility issue, but my guy instinct wants to blame the netgear units for the incompatibility (netgear has a model that version1 isn't even compatible with version2)  Upped the star rating for this model.
