I received this as a gift about a week ago.  I've used it in both my cars with my simple LG cell phone, not a smart phone, and also over BT with my 2nd Gen i-Touch.  It's done everything I've hoped so far and I still have options to explore.  To this point I have not used the line-in feature to link the Touch, but honestly, the BT works so well, I don't know if I ever will.  I really like that this unit has a USB charging port on the side so I can charge my phone or Touch when using it (not both at same time, unfortuately, there's only one port).  Some of the reviews here complain that the FM reproduction is not as faithful as line in.  I guess you could say that, but I've gotten in the habit of balancing the volume levels of the Touch and the stereo until it sounds good to me.  This sort of makes up for the tiny bit of loss I hear.  But honestly, it's barely noticeable on my stereos.It seems like most of the 1-star ratings on here are surrounding the construction of the unit.  I've not had any problems yet, and haven't noticed any potential ones approaching.  I would rate the overall construction as a 4 out of 5.  The only complaints I have are minor - the pause/play, FF, and RW buttons are a bit clumsy.  Also the volume/channel control knob is super sensitive.  Half the time when I go to tweak the volume, I end up changing the channel a bit.  It's no big deal, just something I'm getting used to.  Once I make the habit of setting the volume on the unit and leaving it alone, I expect this problem to go away.  It feels like a substntial item, not a cheap plastic toy.  No problems to report there.  The BT link is as simple as any other device I've ever used and considerably more-so than some others.  It also re-links effortlessly once it's set up properly - which I really like.  No fumbling with buttons, it does it automatically every time - something I've had trouble with other BT things.I was hesitant to order this because the picture makes it look sort of clunky/goofy.  With it installed in my car, however, I think it blends in rather well and even looks sort of cool.  My truck has plenty of room for this, and my car is small - the unit works well in both areas with no complaints.  Oh, one other slight negative I discovered.  At night the red digital frequency readout on this thing is BRIGHT, and I haven't found a way yet to turn those bright red numbers down a notch.  Not sure what to do about that, but it's still totally something I'm willing to trade off for the overall awesome-ness of this unit.
summary: So far so good.  I love it!

reviewText: PICKED UP 3 TIMES AS MANY CHANNELS AS THE RABBIT EARS I WAS USING BUT I HAD TO KEEP MOVING IT EVERY WEEK TO KEEP CHANNELS CLEAR , SO IF YOU DONT MIND MOVING IT AROUND GO FOR IT

When purchasing a used power supply it should be noted that the purchased power supply might be larger than the one in your PC.  You might specify the dimensions of your supply to avoid major cobbling of your case.  I was fortunate to have enough room to package the larger power supply with minor case modifications.
summary: This is a used power supply, not refurbished

reviewText: I connected this to my MacBook Air and backup my photo library in short time. It was 108GB so this 128GB USB 3 thumb drive was just the thing. Sure I have external drives that do the job--and even have an Apple Airport with "time machine backup" but I wanted to be able to copy my photos to something that I could quickly grab, plug in and transfer. This is a perfect USB thumb drive--can't wait for the 512GB version (speculating).

The Mighty Bright Xtraflex2 Clip-on Light is a excellent reading light. It is styled to look, and work nicely with an Amazon Kindle, but it's usefulness does not stop there. It  works equally well as a table lamp using it's stable base, and it can be clipped to any book paperback, or hard cover providing a  light weight  portable lighting solution.It uses two LEDs as it's light source, but using the top mounted switch you can change between using both for extra bright or just one for normal reading. Battery life is really good I have owned this unit for about a month and I am still using my original 3 AAA batteries. For under $15 you CAN NOT beat this light! I would be lost without it.
summary: Wow! This light is the real deal!

reviewText: worked great only worried me about the extra wires from the factory radio , but I didnt need to hook them up ! sounds great !

We were looking for something different which sounded good and worked with the new iPod touch. We found it in the Macally Flat Panel Stereo Speakers. It's a dual alarm clock with radio and some neat high tech speakers that look like mirrors. We've been more than satisfied and happily recommend it. At this point, finding devices that work well with the iPod touch is still a bit of a challenge but this product fits the bill nicely.
This is a very well-made cable, it feels like it will last a long time.  My results have been excellent attaching a Note 3 to an ASUS monitor using the Samsung MHL 2.0 HDTV Adapter.

reviewText: Balances out the grey tones and makes the whites really much better than setting them myself or even using an auto balance. I like the lanyard that comes with it.

I gave the Overnight Nimh Family Battery Charger 4 stars instead of 5 stars only because I haven't used it yet. The charger appears to be very sturdy and well made. It is compact and can be packed easily for travel. However, I see this item as becoming extremely functional, well used and worth having because it charges almost all sizes batteries!! Having bought batteries for two house phones and several cameras I look forward to using this time and time again.

Worked okay for about a week, then started freezing up. Finally got to a point that whenever I pressed the Stop button, I would have to unplug power from outlet, and reinsert power cord to get back to play. I don't think this item is available anymore (which is no big surprise) but if it comes back on the market, save your money and buy something that works.
My wife wanted a camera for use on-line.This product does exactly what she wanted.I know she is very happy with it and would recommend to others.Install was done seamlessly.

I bought this to replace an old athlon 64 on a gateway OEM am2+ mobo. It would not support more than 95 watts so this was the best phenom i could find for 95 watts. It made great improvement in my games, boot up and multi tasking. the price is awesome too! I run skyrim, rage, empire total war, warhammers, swtor, city of heroes with a radeon 6870 and 6 gigs of ddr2 on mostly high setting with no problems. if you need a good, cheap 4 core for an old am2+ mobo, this is for you. I popped it in, placed the stock heat sink that came with it,turned the computer on and it detected it immediately. I do recommend that if you buy any processor add some "Arctic Silver 5 Polysynthetic Silver Thermal Compound Paste 3.5g"....it is said to drastically lower cpu temperatures alone. good luck!

I have owned a IOGEAR 4-Port USB 2.0 Automatic Printer Switch GUB431 (Black) for almost four years.  Although it looks quite sleek and attractive, it has caused me countless hours and years of frustration to get a decent print.  We have three people in our family who share a laser printer and a multifunction unit using both Windows and Ubuntu.  I cannot describe the countless  hours spent trying to wait for the other persons job to cue and print let alone try to scan a document successfully.  The software that controls the printing was a joke in itself.  Sometimes it work and other times it did not.I am very pleased that the EEEkit is a 4 port manual switch that does the job well and correctly the first time.  No software to activate with special keys etc. in hopes that it will work.  So elegant, simple and downright effective at an unbeatable price.However, the best thing for me that it works well with Windows and Ubuntu 12.04 without any additional drivers.Highly recommended.4/27/14:  Just ordered another one for my son at school.

This bag is really strong and has a lot of cushion for laptops. But it's very heavy and big I wouldn't like to carry it around without my laptop. It occupies a lot of space even if there is no laptop inside.
Nice texture on the outside, feels comfy but really lacks padding on the inside, a laptop will most likely not survive a drop!
summary: Not as I thought it'd be

reviewText: I've owned mine now for about a year.  I've owned several different brands over the years.  I use mine in flight combat simulators.  This is, by far, the best I've ever experienced.The sound is well balanced.  Nice balance of base and treble tones.  I can hear things clearly.The microphone is crisp and clean.  I've never had any complaints from others when I've used it in games.  Always get compliments.Love the inline volume control and on/off switch.They are very light weight, the ear pieces are comfortable.  I've worn mine for extended periods of time and sometimes don't remember I'm wearing them.

Still available. Not even worth the 70 it's sold for now.Maybe I had a dud but the battery never lasted more than 10 minutes on a full charge. After 6 months it wouldn't last more than 60 seconds. Always needs to be plugged in.Has taken us to the wrong destination many times. It's really a disaster...using it is like playing russian roulette. Very disappointed overall.

I purchased this Hitachi 1TB SATA drive to replace my failed TIVO HD factory drive.  I selected this drive by researching what type of drives third-party vendors were using in their "TIVO upgrade kits" which extend the recording hours by using a larger drive.  I found this, and its cousin, to be one of the most popular drives used (AV-rated).  I guess Amazon must have been running a special, because I purchased the drive and overnight shipping (+$20) for around $100.  The drive has now been in continual use by TIVO (recording a dozen programs or so per day) for two weeks, and is fast enough to record two HD shows while watching a third HD show (lots of disk I/O) without dropouts due to HDD bandwidth issues.Purchase this drive as your replacement TIVO HD drive!  Use the InstantCake software (hint: google is your friend) to format it to work with TIVO.  It really is a piece of cake!

I have a Canon MF4150 which does not have networking. I was trying to use this switch to solve my problems but the printer usually won't connect after I switch it. I have to fiddle with it for ages to get the printer to connect. Or, plug the printer straight into the computer and it works instantly.I'm giving up on this thing. I should have saved the cash to put towards a printer with networking. I also bought a long USB cable, so I spent 20 bucks or more. And no the problem occurred with shorter cables too and on two different computers so it was not from trying to use too long of a cable or something.

The Good: Great picture, very bright. I use eco mode all the time and have no issues with the lights on.Of course the picture is better with the lights off. 3D is close to the best out there. It's not just a fun thing to look at for a short time; it is entire movie fun. The lamp last 4-6k hrs on eco mode!The Bad:  Reduced or even no mounting options. Light leakage (the most I have ever seen by far). Fan noise is only average. HDMI source searching does not work at all. (I have to select the source manually)I think all the energy was put into the picture quality and they cut cost elsewhere. That's fine by me. I mounted the projector where I had to and I will select source when I need to. This projector is good enough to be used as a main TV.I love the picture quality and brightness of the BenQ W1070 1080P 3D Home Theater Projector. It didn't start out this way. When trying to mount this projector, I wanted to throw it out the window. The projector needs to be mounted or placed exactly in he middle of the screen up very high or very low. Low was impossible for me because it would have to be mounted under the couch that I sit on in order to fill my 135-inch screen. That and I would have to get rid of my coffee table because it is in the way of the picture. The only place possible for me to mount it was directly above my head where I sit. If this was in my living room, I would not be able to use this projector at all due to its MAJOR mounting limitations. Cabling is a bit more forgiving in my basement. Once the projector was mounted perfectly, and I saw the picture, I decided to not throw it away. This is my 1st DLP projector. I have used projectors for about 10 years. All of them were LCD projectors. This projector has the clearest and brightest picture. The 3D is such good quality I will actually use it. I bought (SainSonic(TM) SSZ-200DLB 144Hz 3D IR Active Rechargeable Shutter Glasses for 3D DLP-Link Ready Projector) they work well. They even work with those who wear glasses. They are a bit heavy though. They take some getting used to.There are several problems with this projector, but the good outweighs the bad by far.
Very cheap, that's what you're paying for I guess.  Wish I could return it. save your money and get a real one.  Depends if you value your TV

Just used these on our twelve hour drive to San Diego and back.  We have a five year old and eight year old.  They watched movies together.  They watched different movies.  It was perfect.  Not one fight.  The cables can get in the way when you stop to get out of the car, but once the kids were used to it, it was not a big deal.
it's a decent cover, but the camera is obstructed.  I read the reviews, and when I got it, I have to pull the tablet out to take a picture.
Perfect fit couldnt ask for a better fit. item was receieved in perfect timining. Will be back for more soon.

This is a little loose on my ipod, seems to come off easier than i would hope.  Other than that, it does a good job of protecting the edges and back of my ipod, just wish it had a slightly snugger fit.
I'm using this product for video transferring. Very nice... I recommend it.

A positive bargain at 2x or 3x the price. The pull-out tab is very securely designed and attached. This size works perfectly with an iPad Air and Anker TC930 bluetooth keyboard, which is how I use it.  I am a gadget nit-picker, and have to give this item a very soild 5 stars. Looks very good quality.

I do like this rolling bag and considering the limits airlines put on carry on sizes it solves the issue. Who checks camera gear? I have managed to get two bodies, a 300mm F4 with extender, a 70-300mm, a 18x55mm, a 24-135mm, a EX430 flash plus 20 batteries, a USB hard drive and all the cables, plus my Phottix Odin and trigger in. The handle has two positions and slides beneath a zippered cover set below the top of the bag. Four wheels means it can trolly and the rear two wheels are larger so it rolls like a standard rolling suitcase. There are no outside pockets on this but it is very well padded and the perimeter around the bag is very sturdy. The double zippers will allow for a TSA lock if needed. The only down side is that the interior space is compromised somewhat by the sliding handle space so you could not have a gripped camera body flush with the top in either direction. All in all I am pretty happy but as with anything related to air travel, you need to pack with a plan.
summary: Good for my domestic air travels

reviewText: Durable as hell these things!! i must have yanked them through so many different holes over and over again. It was constantly out of this hole and right into the other one. I was stretching each one of these out with each and every tug and tight fit. Sometimes i had to spit on the fat part of it so it would slide all the way through, but after that no worries!Helps keep the noise down, and i used a 3/16" drill bit to expand one of the plastic holes i needed it to fit through.

I give this 4 stars as it is great for what it is but it doesn't quite feel as secure as a grip-strap (that has 2 points of attachment on the camera and fits snugly around your hand) HOWEVER it is smaller and has the quick release that you can't get in a grip strap (you win some, you lose some).This is excellent for roaming around with 'shorter' lenses. If you are carrying around a sizeable camera with a large telephoto lens, do yourself a favor and keep the neck strap on your camera.All that being said, I do appreciate the 'quick-release' ability that this provides and overall (and for the price), this is a nice little item to have in my kit!

Great price.  Although it adds a little 'girth' to the Nook it does make it easier to grip.  So its a trade off - thin and light then leave the silicone cover off - thicker and grippier then slip the cover on.  It's easy to take on and off.  Does tend to pick up lint and crud.  Also very easy to clean, run water over it and its like new.  Water beads up so it dries really fast, a lint free towel speeds the process up.  I have the black model so I can't comment on the other colors but I was a bit leery of getting some funky color that looked like a faded gummy bear.  Am a Prime member so shipping was free.  If you have a Nook (or any type of ereader) you should also check out the Arkon foldable stand. Awesome must have accessory.  Available from Amazon also.

... but for the price and some "hiccups" with my Canon 5Mark II, I had to return in. reviewText: I have been using the Flexpod 2 for about 4 months or so. I am writingthis review/feedback based on reviewing this product in bothurban/rural areas as well as testing it on several cars and SUV's.As far as the hands free ability of this device goes, it's awful. Themic on the iPhone is on the bottom of the unit where the phone plugsinto to charging port ok the flex2. This has nothing to do with yourphones ability in receiving 4 or 5 bars but it is due to the mic beingblocked by the charging base.  What that said, the hands free isuseless.Another problem I'm having is that my iPhone 3GS will say that theflexpod 2 is not compatible with the iPhone and it will not charge.This is on and off. It is not consistent. If I turn the power off onthe flexpod2 and then Turn it on, most of the time it will startcharging despite the message. Other times I have to shut the phone offand then turn it on again before it will start charging.As far as the fit goes of the grip holding the phone it is ok. I saythis because the phone may become loose if you hit a big bump on theroad. The other thing is that you MUST remove your case before usingit with this product. It will not work any other way. This is anotherbig design flaw. More than 90% of iphone owners use skins to protecttheir investments and this device prohibits the use.The FM transmitter is choppy. A links background noise. On the expressway away from big cities and buildings it's much better. But if youlive in a big city forget about not hearing static. I tried this inChicago, NYC, Miami, & Orlando. Of all of these cities Orlando was themost clear. The rest of the cities too much static.The other thing with this unit is that I you have an SUV or aMinivan  it will be lower down for you to look at as the lightercharger is usually  quite low on these types vehicles.  In a sedanIt's usually much higher so it will be much higher and easier to lookat while driving.Bottom line I do not recommend this product for those who want to buythis as a hands-free device and audio transmitting purposes. If youwant it as an expensive charger knock yourself out. Keep in mind youwill need to take off the case to charge and risk scratching yourphone.

This is a nice little (very small size) radio with dual band capability. It is programmable by PC, Mac or Linux (I have successfully used Mac and Linux) using the Chirp program and a special cable. The programming makes this radio much easier to use. You will need special drivers for the cable for mac or Linux. These are available by searching for Baofeng uv-5r linux or mac

I bought two pair of these. One pair came apart almost immediately (the pink front loosened from the back), but it was an easy fix with super glue and I haven't had any issues since. The product is not ideal, but so far it is the best I could find on Amazon.You have to lift up the pink front to manually wind/unwind the cable. It is not difficult, nor does it take a lot of time, but for a somewhat lazy person this becomes too much of a hassle. I usually just leave a part of the cable hanging out and wind it outside the case when not in use (the length needed  to use the iPhone in my waist pocket). The exposed cable is still fairly short and I don't experience much tangle.The clip on the back of the cable holder is one of the reasons why I chose this one. I hate to have the cable hanging loose when I use the headphones. I used to have a pair of ear buds with a retractable cable. Loved how easy it was to pull the cable out and slide it back in with a short tug, but not the sound quality, so the Belkin is a compromise.

I got this item to use when I exercise.  I read all the reviews checking to see if it would fit me.  I have a 17.5 inch arm and it fit me ok.  It pinches but I am able to stand it.  It stays on my arm and does not slip down.  Like others have said, if you put it over your shirt, it will not pinch as much.  It does start to get uncomfortable after about 30 min of continuous wear.  There aren't many options out there to carry your Ipod Classic with you when you exercise, other than holding it, and that is never fun.  I have had some success with working the dial through the plastic.  I cannot change the music when I am on the go.  The classic barley fits in the armband, I have to force it in.  There is two places you can thread the velcro through.  I have a hard time threading the velcro through because of my big arms but it works, barley.  I don't know how people with bigger arms does it.  I would buy again, but only because there are no other options.
summary: Belkin Dual-Fit Armband for Ipod Classic

reviewText: Can't say too much...It's a PS3 controller in a pink color haha.  I do think that the back trigger buttons should have had some lip to it.  I mean let your middle fingers be able to rest there rather than just slip off.  I guess you can think of it more like a dreamcast trigger.  Now that hugged your fingers.  I don't know what the intent was for the back trigger buttons on this PS3 controller, but it could have been better if there was a lip is all I can say.  The battery actually lasts pretty long.  I think they claim it lasts about 3 hours, but to me...it seems like it lasts a lot longer than that.  The feel of it has a good grip I do like the way it holds.  This controller was for my girlfriend, I'm just happy that she plays games sometimes and I do use her controller every once in awhile that's why...haha I have the black one.  I just thought I might throw that in there.I don't know whats up with rating "this game" but...okay?

We bought two of these literally hours before travelling to London.  We took over 7,000 pictures on that trip alone.  Easy to use.  Clear pictures.  Battery life is awesome and easy to charge in a hotel room.  Really love them!

reviewText: I've had this little guy for around three years and I've never had a problem with it. Upgraded the memory and storage. Dual booted Windows 7 and Ubuntu.It's got more ports than most of the stupid ultrabooks that are popular right now, including ethernet and VGA. The screen's a little smaller than is comfortable for multitasking, but that's to be expected. It's tiny and extremely easy to travel with. The battery doesn't last all day, but it's never run dry when I was trying to use it. Something like 6+ hours no problem.The processor/graphics are fine for everything. The only time they struggled was when I tried to slice a model for 3D printing. Took a really long time, but that's the sort of thing this netbook wasn't expected to do.
summary: Awesome little netbook. Tough and capable.

reviewText: This is a cheap mount. The paint on the metal parts are all chipped. One nut missing, one bolt extra. It feels sturdy, the construction is solid and I am hoping that the metal parts are aluminum and will not rust, and so are the nuts and the bolts. Aside from these, I think this is a good bang for the buck.[Addendum: June 19, 2012] Don't buy this thing. The mount rusts! Apparently it's not aluminum and the mount rusts. It looks really terrible, so cheap. And that's a shame, because the rest is perfectly fine, it stays in place, hold the Garmin, solid construction. Why oh why, why would you sell a motorcycle mounting bracket that rusts?!?

reviewText: I was given a computer for parts at one time from afriend. As I looked the computer over I noticed it hada light scribe DVD drive. I thought of using this i myquad-core machine but it was IDE.Thankfully this little gadget will allow me to connectthe Light scribe easily. Im glad I found this!

So I bought this with the highest hopes. A slim case, magnetic "smart" switch, ability to stand up on own.However this case is full of flaws.Firstly the cover flap is ill fitting once the device is inserted. It doesn't line up with the magnets and doesn't want to stay closed.Next there is a tab of metal on the opening edge that can rub against the glass of the tablet.Third within a few day the flap began to separate at the seams and fall apart.Even at $10 it isn't worth it.UPDATE:After the supplier read my review they contacted me offering a free replacement of the item. Very good on their part! Good to see a company looking to make good a defective product. So If the features seem to be a fit for you go for it knowing that any defect can be resolved with the supplier.

Controls:The new touch screen is not like the smooth glass of an iPhone, just a plastic, resistive panel that feels hollow when tapped. I could live with it, but my left hand fingers keep getting in the way and end up changing the focus point. Also, if you are changing a setting with the buttons, try not to touch the screen. I need to investigate if the touch can be disabled.Another issue with the controls when using the zoom lens is that my right thumb tends to hit the playback button frequently since it is closer to the thumb-pad now. It was not in this location on the GF1. My ZS7 and FZ35 have very nice controls and Q.Menu button works well in those cameras. The control pad buttons also seems to stick out more than other Panasonic cameras, which cause inadvertent presses. This camera is basically uncomfortable to hold with normal size hands.Lens:The 14mm pancake kit is still made in Japan with a metal mount, but the new 14-42mm is all plastic with cheaper build quality. The 14mm kit lens is very sharp edge to edge. Very compact. The 14-42mm seems to have soft focus at the wide end (14-20mm), but is pretty sharp at the tele-end out to 42mm. It's not made in Japan so maybe this creates a bias, but this lens cannot compete with the older and sharper 14-45mm that came with the GF1.Flash:The GF2 appears to have better exposure when using the built-in flash in indoor lighting. The GF1 tended to underexposed when using the flash. Perhaps this is a result of the GF2 flash moving forward.IQ:Overall IQ seems to be similar to the GF1 with some improvement when using the built-in flash.The IQ seems to best when keeping it below ISO 400. I did notice more yellow colors in shots taken with interior lighting in comparison to the Canon G12. My ZS7/FZ35 seem more red. Nothing really too noticeable. Overall I find the 14mm a bit too wide whereas the 20mm seemed just right. In good lighting (outdoors) it can match IQ of a DSLR, but not in low light.Conclusion:Panasonic took a great camera (the GF1) and made the next rev technically better, but paired it with lesser glass and forgot about the user experience when handling the camera. Sadly, the F in GF no longer stands for fun. The GF had a place between care free point-shoots and the serious DSLRs, but with the issues I noted, it doesn't make sense for me if it's not enjoyable. While I have a lot of Canons, I really enjoy Lumix cameras and one of my favorites is the DMC-FZ35. I would recommend you find a store that carries the GF2 before buying.
summary: Good camera but with poor handling and cheaper lens system.

reviewText: I almost paid a lot more for this model.  You see they had it at SAM's, and I hadn't seen what the costs of these combo units were, so I thought it was a good deal. Thank goodness for the web when comparison shopping.  Now Samsung makes a more expensive model at near twice the price, and it does have features that are supposed to support those high def. sets.  It took a bit of deciding, but ultimately why pay for something that's not really set yet.It's kind of interesting all the schemes you get for devices that tell you they are ready for the future, but really are not. I had a Sony big screen (two piece projection model) TV I won in a contest back in 1981. Stereo TV was just in its infancy then, and this model was listed as "stereo ready".  It's not unlike all the companies that sell people HDTV ready which really means: "we neglected to include the HDTV tuner to save cost." The TV I had accomplished its Stereo ready, not by having some special magic that would receive and play stereo when it was broadcast.  What it had was separate monaural amplifiers so you could play the right, and left side from some other stereo device.  It really wasn't stereo ready, it just couldn't afford to market itself as mono, being an expensive big screen and all.It seems Sony along with the other companies, are still arguing over the standards they will ultimately release to the public for High Definition DVD.  I'm guessing recording, playback and compatibility issues will be the order of the day when its finally announced. Plus with Sony now a major player in the property rights theater, I expect copy protections to be quite stringent.  What this means to you and I is that a High Def recorder bought today will be fairly useless when the standard comes out.  Most current DVDs play at about 480P on progressive scan, so they're not bad.  The higher definitions will come later down the line, so there is no reason to spend the money now.As for the model here at hand, I complement it for the nice display they have on the front.  It has reasonably simple operation, you are gonna get some complexity with a device of this type. Perhaps it was simpler for me since the remote looks like a near clone of the Sony WEGA remote.  I think remote control companies must be making for several manufacturers these days, I doubt Sony and Samsung have that much of a connection.  This unit does a nice job of direct copying of VHS cassettes to DVDs.  I bought it for that primary task, as I have a lot of home movies and other stuff to shrink down from tape.The process is not well suited for DVD copies off TIVO or some other digital recorder.  I recommend using your computer to perform those tasks.  Computers have much more memory, and likely a faster DVD recorder than these stand alone models, at least at this price.  I believe it will take much less time that way. Still for a stand alone slave, this is a decent unit. The VCR is a four head model, and of fairly high quality, so the copies come out fine if the source is up to par.This device is nothing really especially innovative so it can't get that last star from me, but for what it is I couldn't expect too much better for the price.  One more thing that shouldn't escape your attention.  The price on this is lower than many player combos have been the past few years.  It's play quality is quite good, so even if you rarely take advantage of the recording capability, you're buying a darn fine combo player too.
summary: Too Early to go for the High Dollar Models this works fine!

reviewText: high quality product. A little stiff but with some maneuvering it'll fit just fine! Highly recommended for those who want an alternative for pass through cables

Most of you who get your KIndles are unaware of the cost of the components that go into it. For the e-ink versions, for example, the e-ink screen actually costs MORE than the lowest priced devices, by perhaps 30% more.  Unfortunately, this most expensive component is also the most fragile. I've been unlucky enough to have broken one before.On first impression, the screen protector seems fairly solidly built- well enough that it will offer some protection from minor impacts. I hesitate to  test it with any major impacts, though... not if you want to still be able to use your Kindle.The instructions for installing the shield are clear and concise, and installation takes mere seconds. Unfortunately, it is fairly easy to get some air bubbles trapped underneath, and these aren't very easy to get rid of. The package comes with a little cardboard "smoothing" card for bubble removal, but that particular part is next to useless. You're much better off using a credit card for this step.In all, though, I give this shield 4 stars. Anything that adds protection to such a beloved device is a must in my book.  While I have no intention of testing its protective qualities, it at least adds a little peace of mind that it is probably protected from minor impacts.Oh, and while it says it's for 2nd generation kindles, the touch and the keyboard, it's also a perfect fit for the screen of the 1st generation kindle as well.

I have a 19" monitor I wanted to place on top of a TV to have some extra viewing space (I do not have cable, only use my computer). This worked great. Although I do not touch it ever (Stays in same position since I installed it), it has not caused any problems so far and seems very sturdy.

These things are way better than the ones you get in stores that cost like 47 bucks for 3.  Highly recommended if you have cables that need wrangling.  If you're a 100% wireless household (you could be reading this in the future) then you might not find these as useful as I did.
summary: I'm Velcro gripping myself as hard as I can!

reviewText: I recently purchased a pair of the Klipsch IMAGE S4s and have been using them for about two weeks now.  And I must say I am very impressed by this product.My previous set of earbuds were made by V-moda and, although I enjoyed them, I felt there was a bit to much bass for my liking.  When the V-modas's bit the dust I based my purchase of the Klipsch on the fact that the stereo system in the office where I work has Klipsch speakers and I liked the clean open sound of them.  I figured I'd take a chance that the earbuds had that same quality.The IMAGE S4s seem to me to have a wider soundstage than the V-moda.  What I'm hearing more clearly now is the rhythm guitar in some songs and the background instrumentation in others that I'd never heard before.  The best part is that the Klipsch buds do not skimp on the bass response. It's there.  It's noticeable.  And it's clean. I enjoy anything from classical to country to jazz to classic rock and these buds do justice to them all.My only problem is with the silicone tips.  I can't really blame Klipsch because I've never come across a tip that was "really" comfortable.  For me the large tips are too big, the small ones too small and the medium ones not real comfortable.  I've ordered a set of the Comply Tx-100 tips in the hopes it may be the solution.Great sound separation with excellent bass response.  Great buds for the price!

summary: Beyond blown away by how good this is

reviewText: It does exactly what it says it does.  This thing can hold a lot of energy and would be great for hiking/camping.

Works great for the PS4.  The shorter battery life on the PS4 controller means you will need a longer cable to keep playing and this works great.  The connection is a little wiggly at the controller, but it hasn't come out.  Well worth the price!

reviewText: Think of this as a hobbyist type keypad. The keypad as a unit is very flexible and without mounting on a stiff backboard, is practically unusable. The keys have what seems to be a metal dome embedded in the structure which makes me believe they're apt to las longer than the membrane switches that rely upon elastic of a plastic sheet to separate the contacts after closure. Colors are bright and the characters quite legible.

I bought one of these when I purchased my Cannon sd1000 at a good price from Amazon.  It took a while to get it from the shipper, and I wound up buying a second one from a local store at the same price (seemed they went on sale everywhere while I was waiting for delivery).I have had no problems with the memory card in either the camera, a SanDisc card reader, or an Epson PictureMate printer.  It is nice to turn on my camera and see over 2,000 shots ready to take.

I'm updating my review and raising my rating to 4 stars. It has now been about a year that I have been using this backdrop, and for the price I am very satisfied. It has a sewn-in fold-over full-length "pocket" along one edge that allows you to slide a 10' long pvc tube through it to hold it up. Nice touch. It also comes with a storage bag which is also nice.Another BIG plus is the responsiveness and customer service of the seller, CheetahMounts. If every seller were this good and responsible, the world would be a better place.Initial review:Nice neutral black, but I wish it were more photogenic. Some cloth wrinkles "artistically", but this one wrinkles ugly. If you can adjust your lights so that no light directly hits the backdrop, the wrinkles will not show. But in cramped quarters when light spills directly onto the backdrop, the wrinkles show.
This comes in a pack of three and its pretty handy to have.  Its not as small as I hoped it would be but it does the job nonetheless.  The wrap itself is pretty light.
summary: Does the job but it is big

reviewText: Quality product, though the included wrench is very dinky and I opted to use an adjustable wrench I already own.

First, the Pentax K-30 is a fantastic DSLR.  I highly recommend it, and for the price and features it cannot be beat.  It easily keeps pace with the Nikon D7000.The 1-Star rating is directed at the Amazon vendor 'Electronics Basket.'Where to start ..I ordered the K-30 BODY ONLY, which came in a 'cannibalized' K-30 w/18.135mm WR lens kit box, minus the lens (of course), and other key 'new product' components removed from the Pentax manufacturer's K-30 box.I paid $30 for expedited delivery and got the camera 9 days later.I received a 'cannibalized' Pentax K-30 WR 18-135mm kit.  It was missing the camera registration, camera manual, and the K-30 startup CD.I called Pentax America regarding the camera being shipped without the warranty registration, and was informed that no new Pentax cameras should be shipped WITHOUT the original (new) owner's serialized registration.Then I called Electronic Basket and asked for the original (serialized) registration and was informed that their standard practice is to NOT send it with the camera because THEY (Electronic Basket) registers the camera FOR THE PURCHASER!After inquiring on several of the national Pentax forums, it was obvious that Electron Basket was outright misrepresenting the facts.  I asked for the original warranty registration be sent to me, so that I could have the K-30 covered under the original purchaser's manufacture's warranty. I was informed that if the camera became defective, I would have to SEND IT BACK TO ELECTRONIC BASKET, who would then send it to Pentax for repairs!!I still have yet to receive the K-30 I purchased warranty registration card, or any other means of registering it online or otherwise.EB did offer a discounted price on the WR 18-135mm lens, which I considered purchasing.  I then learned that EB does NOT accept credit card payments, ONLY PAYPAL.It is not known if the K-30 I received was a return, a defect, or what, since the original (serialized) registration was not included in the (cannibalized) kit box.  It's hilariously unprofessional behavior.  Whoever cannibalized the kit even left the WR 18-135mm lens hood in the box!The K-30 is a precision camera that takes wonderful pictures, with features that will delight any photographer, from beginner to Pro.Electronics Basket however should be avoided.Select another vendor from Amazon.  Amazon customer service bent over backwards for me, and I greatly appreciate their professional and thoughtful assistance in this matter.Buyer Beware!
summary: Camera is fantastic, Electronics Basket AMAZON Vendor is not ..

reviewText: I was pleasantly surprised by the Panasonic 37" picture quality and even happier that the available cable High Definition channels were found without the aid of a digital or HD cable box during the channel setup search. reviewText: This item is advertised as being made for NP95 batteries. When it arrived, I tried to place a standard N85 battery made by and for Fuji's X100 camera, and it does not fit. There are plastic notches on the charger that prevent the battery from fitting. These notches are not customer-removable. DO NOT BUY THIS ITEM FOR N95 BATTERIES.
summary: NP95 batteries for which this charger is made, don't fit in it.

reviewText: This is a must-have for anyone who is on the phone at all and does anything else at the same time. Be it calling computer supportor the bank or what-have-you, there is nothing like having both hands free. I buy either a Panasonic or V-Tech phone exclusively(and one MUST note as to whether there is a headset jack input) and I buy either the Panasonic or Hello-Direct head sets.I prefer the Panasonic cordless phones and the Panasonic head sets.I just LOVE the new Panasonic cordless home phone that links to Blue-Tooth cell phones.

reviewText: I bought it for connecting my Raspberry Pi to a screen.Quite a long cable but it does the job.

This neoprene sleeve is exactly what I wanted and needed for my new 15.6 laptop (standard model with cd/dvd bay and battery). It's not terribly snug; laptop & cord fit perfectly inside and still remained relatively slim. Interior of sleeve is slightly padded, not bulky, two zippers. I could see this taking a little weather, but I wouldn't leave it out in the rain - incidental sprinkle stroll to the car would be fine. Very very pleased. Priced right. Arrived very quickly. Only wished they had other colors and designs available. Got the 16in because I've read several reviews on those supposedly designed to fit a 15 - 15.6 and people be disappointed with the fit.
It's just great and perfect for my new pc I just built.  I recommend this processor to any one who try to built a gaming computer.

reviewText: Durable. I have plugged in three computers into this 5 port switch and all of them work fine. With the Ethernet cards installed in all my systems, I found the installation to be a cakewalk. The configuration is so simple and it just takes a few moments of your time. I just had to plug in the power cable first then connected the Ethernet cables of all the comps and it was ready. But it needs an external power supply chord and does not have a power on switch. The metal casing makes this device quite heavy. Not that I carry it around all the time but it could have been of lesser weight.The LED lights and the Ethernet ports are on the same side. This is a major disadvantage for me because the wires flow on my desk. Had the ports been at the back I would have had some control in keeping my desk uncluttered.My FS105NA also gets warm after continuous usage for more than an hour.
summary: LED lights and Ethernet ports on same side causing problems

reviewText: A very robust case, works with model B, but has tabbed covers if you have a model A (even though I can't think of a good reason to have an A).  The light pipes for the LED's look great and make the LED's useful!
These bookshelf speakers are fantastic!  Easily driven by a small class-T amp they make a compact, superb listening experience!  For the price these really cannot be beat.

There is not much to add to all other reviewers here, it is a good camera and takes fantastic photos, and quick. Battery last quite long, and build quality is also very good. The design is also mostly OK, but a little more grip wouldn't hurt. Kudos to Canon for they went with just 12 megapixel, and didn't push in more pixels in this relative small sensor.Just a few quirks which I'd like to point out:The LCD with over 900K pixels is razor sharp for photo viewing, but too bad that Canon does not take advantage of that to redesign the menu interface and the fonts / icons which appears on the LCD and they're still pixelated and cheap looking.1080 HD video recording is stunning, but the 24-fps is sub-par for today's standards.The zoom ring (and shutter button too) is way too small and difficult to control.One flaw that I still have with all my Canon cameras, that is some lighting condition (mainly florescent), some colors are not accurate. Purple shows like blue. And it's difficult to correct, even with white-balance control. I must do it in Photoshop.I also don't like the mega-strap that is included with this camera. While it might be useful for some, I wouldn't mind to have a regular smaller strap thrown in as well. (I bought this oneNikon 25770 AN-CP19 Black Strapfor myself, and I love it).Otherwise, it's a beautiful piece.
It is really good stand for Garmin.Locked for stableRecommend for anyone who has Garmin.Only little bit heavy to carry when I travel.

This product works well and really comes in handy when you need it.  I was looking for a wide lens for my G11, and didn't initially want to spend that much money.  That search led me to this product.  I saw the price and figured I would at least give it a try.  Can't expect too much at $30.  I received the product and was immediately impressed with the quality of construction.  The fit and finish on the lens is excellent.As has been mentioned, the lens comes with a wide/tele adapter as well (again, only use the bottom portion with this lens).  I did not use it, as I already had a lens mount adapter. If you aren't trying to capture a particularly special image or something that requires critical IQ, this lens is a great asset when you need to get as much in the picture as possible.Using DXO optics with the G11 module, the CA and barrel distortion issues I've experienced are all but completely corrected.The Macro attachment when used on its own is great too. While the G11 already has fantastic macro ability, I was able to magnify even more when using it. For the price, this is a great addition to your G10/11.

And this Manfrotto over delivers. Coming from a cheap $30 tripod I couldn't be happier with this purchase. Was very hesitant to spend almost half a grand on a tripod/head set (paired with Giottos MH1000-652 Ball Head), but am now very glad I did.Changing the angle of the legs is very quick and easy, close them slightly, push in the metal tab and pull out to desired angle.The Q90 column is amazing, great for getting right down to the ground or extending out when needed.Fully extended with the column down, this tripod is almost eye level, (I'm over 6') and more stable then my cheap tripod was at it's lowest setting.Still kinda heavy at 5lbs(pod and head combined) so I'm glad I went carbon.

After seeing so many great close-ups, I got this macro lens because I wanted to take some too.  Macro work has a learning curve, which I'm only starting to master.I had read about focus breathing issues with this lens, but have found it to be no issue at all for me.  Getting a subject still enough and enough depth of field are far more challenging for me.As a bonus, I find that this lens does great as a medium distance portrait lens, where the VR and f/2.8 aperture really help.  This lens is weakest at distance, where sharpness can be a little off, at least in my sample of this lens.Overall, the macro works great, and the medium distance capabilities are a pleasant bonus to this great lens.
This is one of the better made products coming out of China. It is fairly slim and has a  solid feel. The switch is conveniently located at one end. The eight foot cord is very useful. Works well.

This is a great addition to my photography studio. This product is light weight, whern broken down, and portable. It supplies both a black and white, nutral color, backdrops which photographers use most of all. It even comes with its own zip up carry bag.
My goodness, I waste $45 and lot of time, this BD-R set is totally UNUSABLE, stay away at all cost. I'm going back to the Sony or TDK family.
Love the fact that it comes with an adapter for computers with larger slots.  Works great or what I used it for.
When you need it, you're gonna wish you already bought it!  Plugged it right into my MP3 player and it worked... and a good price too.

This very inexpensive universal remote is just the ticket. It will help you organize and dominate up to 7 components. After taking the remote out of the packaging, it only took me 10 minutes to set everything up. The instructions are very easy to comprehend and the remote responds wonderfully. Keep this one in mind as a replacement or if you want to consolidate multiple remotes.

Like all the other reviewers I too had a problem playing reguar dvds. The noise was unbearably loud. I didnt have any skipping issues though. Two days ago I noticed that there is a new firmware update on their site. So I donwloaded this update and burned it to a disc. Once the disc was burned I poped it in the drive and the player updated itself in seconds. This unit now plays without any problems. I am extremely satisfied with this player now. It is just too bad memorex took almost a year to come out with an update to fix this issue. Shame. So guys, If you do decide to purchase this item remember to update the firmware and you will have no problems with this player. If I were to have reviewed this when I first bought it I would have to agree with all the negative reviews. But now I have to say this is an ecellent player for its price tag of under 100 bucks. I gave this a minus star for having to wait for the firmware fix.
summary: Ecellent player once you update firmware

reviewText: I already own the previous model, thePanasonic DMP-BDT100 Full HD 3D Blu-ray Disc Player, and have had no problems with it. The only thing that was missing was the wireless. I decided to move that unit to another TV, as future proofing in case I decide to get another 3D set later on, and bought this unit for the upgrades. Both units do "checkerboard", and work perfectly on my Samsung 6187SAX DLP set. I had no trouble connecting my wireless, and upgrading the firmware within a few moments, and was able to log on to Netflix right away. The  interface is similar to the Roku box, and is easy to navigate. The picture is very good, and in my opinion is as good as my PS3. Setting the unit to "quick start" makes it very fast to start up, and I like that it automatically changes the TV input to the correct hdmi setting. If only the PS3 did that as well!

It does what it is supposed to. It gives a mirrored display of whatever is playing on my iPhone 5. But it is just ridiculously expensive. Apple needs to bring the price down. They make enough money off their devices!

The item is being shipped to me on time and the product is as expected in a factory sealed package. After using for 6 months I can say its a good product and the seller is trustworthy.

They do not make you pay for return shipping, and they respond fast.I am disappointed with the quality of the connectors on this cable. Perfectly cut, great texture, manly style. Did not expect it to have the auto-sleep feature. Yet it does.Built-in stand does not compromise style. It's simple and it works.If I spotted a lawyer with a Vintage Brown case on his iPad, I would assume it cost him hundreds.Thank you, Bear Motion <3

I have had an aging 10mbps linksys hub as the core of my small home network for several years.  Even though I was happy with it, I bought one of these, primarily because it was cheap and thought having a 'spare' couldn't hurt.I had no idea how much that aging piece of equipment was slowing down my network!  Almost everything I have now is 10/100, so dropping in this switch made my whole network a heck of a lot faster.  Furthermore, as a switch (as opposed to a hub), it is much more efficient with the use of the network - traffic isn't broadcast everywhere, only to the nodes that need it.I am VERY happy with this purchase.  Cheap, fast, and drop-in simple installation to my existing network.  I decided to purchase another as a 'spare' and donate my older hub to history.
summary: Drop it in and see the speed boost

reviewerName: Dr. Sam Beckett "Hoping for that last leap home"
reviewText: These are decent IEMs in their own right. They're great value for the money in terms of the quality of both sound and build. But in the end they weren't for me. Even after over 20 hours of burn-in, they still sounded too "warm" and lacked clarity on most music. And as an iDevice user, I've been spoiled by 3-button remotes, so the throwback to a one-button control unit was painful.Beyond that, however, there were a couple of quality issues. The ear tips started slipping off the "nozzles" of these headphones, an unacceptable situation I encountered on theUltimate Ears SuperFi 5vi Noise Isolating Earphones w/ Microphone(and no other IEM). And the control unit only worked about 2/3 - 3/4 of the time. The product description on these says "Improved Mic New Production," but I'm dubious - buyer beware.Finally, the units are just a little too big and heavy. They definitely "drag" on my ears after a couple of hours, which is no good, for example, on long flights.I returned these (thanks for making this easy, Amazon) and since bought theNocs NS400-001 NS400 Earphones with Remote and Mic (Titanium - Black), which really hit the nail on the head for me.
Bought these for the Plantronix headsets because the cords on the headsets were to short.  They are working great and the sound is good.

The Zagg shield has a nice feel to it.  It really helps me keep a firm grasp on my iPad.  Installation was okay, but you have to be patent. I ended up removing the front shield because I found the Zagg took a little away from the ability to use a stylus and I'm not sure I was retaining the full benefit of the retina display.  Note that the rear shield does NOT protect the corners.  Those are wide open unprotected. Zagg says that is so that it can easily accommodate a case.  But another reviewer got this from Zagg:"I am sorry to hear that your ZAGGskin is discoloring. The ZAGGskin, with the invisibleSHIELD on top is porous and can absorb colors, and if the case you were using is blue, then that is what may have happened. I am sorry to say that the ZAGGskin only has a 45 day money back guarantee and it has been over 45 days. I am afraid that is why you are not able to order a replacement. We typically do not recommend using a case with our products."So which is it?  I think they do not have corner protection because that is the first part of a shield to start to give way, resulting in a warranty replacement issue.So Zagg is okay, but be sure to look at Ghost Armor and Best Skin Ever (BSE) on the web as well.  I had Ghost Armor on my iPad2 and it worked well.  Have never tried BSE, but have heard good things.
summary: Good protection for the back, maybe not the front

I'm mostly satisfied with my Over The Air (OTA) DTV setup except that the signal for CBS drops out occasionally and because the OTA signal is in sight with a train line, when a freight train passes by, the signal causes pixelation on some channels.I've used an RCA rabbit ear antenna, but with that some channels (such as CBS) wouldn't pick up.  After that, I built my own DTV antenna with coat hangers (many build plans are on the internet) which is a big improvement over the rabbit ears.  Yet even with the coat hanger antenna, my reception still gets the issues described earlier.  I was hoping that The Leaf antenna would resolve the problems, but it did not.  I suppose the reason may because CBS by me is on VHF and  that The Leaf is better for UHF signals. Also, even the UHF stations that The Leaf pulled in still encountered the pixelations when a freight train passed by.As a result, I decided to just return The Leaf and stick to my old, bulky, yet effective for the most part, coat hanger antenna.What I like:- simple design. Almost the size and weight of a laminated thin cardboard- reasonable priceWhat I dislike:- doesn't handle VHF as well as UHFAlthough The Leaf antenna didn't fix the issues I have with my DTV reception, it still is a great design.  It's a nice upgrade from rabbit ears if that's what you are looking for.
summary: Nice Antenna, But Didn't Resolve Reception Issues For Me

reviewText: OK, I have to admit a prejudice towards Lowepro. Their bags are simply the best.  Period.  I have NEVER had any issues with them, and I have owned quite a few of their bags!Back in 2007, I purchased a Lowepro 300AW Sling Bag, and immediately felt comfortable with it.  The bag was easy to use, had more than enough compartments for me, and was so good, I quickly sold out of them at the retail store I worked at (I worked as a manager for a local camera shop from 2007-2009).  Everyone felt my enthusiasm for this product.In 2009, my girlfriend got into photography with a Canon XTi, and I had an older smaller Lowepro bag laying around.  It was fine for her until I upgraded to a Canon 7D, and she inherited my old 50D.  Now, she needed a bigger bag to accommodate the larger camera and battery grip.  So, after looking around, I ordered the SlingShot 302AW, thinking it was just a slightly bigger bag.Well, I was wrong - in a good way!Lowepro kept all of the great features of the older model, but added some more pockets, improved the interior layout, and beefed up the bag.  All in all, it is a vastly superior product, and at an incredible price.  My bag holds my 7D with battery grip, a 4 lenses, mis accessories, a 580EX flash, manuals, pens, survival stuff, and even some trail mix!  It is comfortable to wear, easy to access without taking it off your body, and very secure.If you are an advanced amateur or budding pro, grab this bag - you will NOT regret it.
It is a basic cover, the hinge for horizontal stand can be better but still protects the device very well.

I have purchased two USB hubs previously, one just wasn't big enough the other fell apart! However, I am thrilled with this one. It is sturdy and easy to insert and remove the USB cables.Having multi front and back ports makes it so convenient to use long term ones on the back and the shorter term ones (and long term, when necessary) on the front. And the two pop-ups are super - I use a headset for phone support and it is so easy to access the pop-up, I can get it in and out in a flash when I need to jump in and answer a call. The other is used for my wireless keyboard/mouse receiver, which can be a bit "picky" if it is horizontal, but works wonderfully being vertical.It is truly plug and play and the speed is as described.

Installed several of these cards in machines with PCIe 1.1 and 2.0 slots after picking them up on special at a certain big box electronics retailer. Configuration does require the CD on Windows 7 but installation was trouble free (a great relief for those wary of evil beasts like Netgear's driver installers) and indeed trivial. Leaving out the bloatware and custom connection managers was also made very easy. Performance is exceptional for a cheap unit and connections are made pretty much instantly. I'll be buying more of these to put in machines for which N300 is sufficient.
I combined this product with Logitech Surround Sound Speakers Z506 and it is the best purchases I made to have in my college dorm room.

reviewText: "Designed by the world-famous Porsche Design Agency"LOL that was always so funny to me, like what kind of "design" time and effort actually went into an UGLY rectangular BOX anyway?I have two of these I'm getting rid of shortly as I replace them with Macally aluminum ones that look like a mini MacPro which I've used for  afew years now and love.This "brick" enclosure comes with a MASSIVE wall wart that is about half the size of the enclosure itself, an ungainly thing you have to plug IT'S cord into the A/C and then run it's other cord to the enclosure, leaving this huge block of a power thing dangling- a really lousy design there.If you want to swop out the drive inside, it's a whole other process itself that requires prying the case open, bending these little metal tabs that hold the drive in, and then trying to get the drive out in the 1/4" of space left to do it- there's NO space in these things and the drives tend to run quite warm since they are packed in so tight, no air space, no fan either.Only good thing about this "brick" is at least when I bought mine- they used a quality WD drive in them.
summary: A BRICK, designed by the world renowned Porche!

I purchase the Zune 120GB 11/08/09 from walmart, the player died 12/07/09 used it just a handful of times,  filled out a service request that day to get a replacement player. Jan/24/10 no shipping labels so I called Zune CS. I learned that since I have a PO Box address they can not service their warranty can not send me shipping labels nor send a replacement player to a PO Box address nor will they use Fedx or UPS which is the only way to use my residence address since the USPS does not service the rural area of my residence. I am glad I purchased an extended warranty from Walmart, they will replace my player in Aug 2010.. after my Zune warranty is expired and the Walmart warranty starts... Microsoft is no help for the Zune product, only dealing with Zune CS so feeling exhausted after hours on the phone and online and not finding  a CS rep of Microsoft or Zune that can resolve this, I will have to wait until Aug 2010 for Walmart to send me  a new player.So Buyer beware, I was informed by Zune CS they do not recognize PO Boxes as Valid addresses... just incase you may need warranty service.The zune player it's self, felt the software was a night mare for not being easy to organize what you put on there.. 60 audio books that you had to scroll through everyone of them to find what you were looking for,, Online manual on how to use the zune player, was endless you would get lost if you didn't know what you were looking for. I did not find it user friendly for a first time MP3 player user.. I am not a film expert, but I do have about a decade of photography experience.I've used this film primarily for landscapes, both in bright daylight and in dim twilight. The sky, trees, and ground all look amazing. In certain situations, this film will bring out pinker tones than expected, but this is just a characteristic of this film, and not a drawback. As most people reading a review of slide film probably already know, slide film is more prone to over and underexposure than negative film (and digital), and this film is no exception. I've posted a landscape shot on Provia 100F on this item's customer images, for a sample.The roll of film itself was perfect -- no issues at all.Overall I was very happy with this item, and have already purchased more.

reviewText: I bought this as a gift for my wife.First I'll tell you what I like about it:Sounds great.Easy to set up.Easy to use.Gets Radio Stations, Pandora, and streams music from my computer.The only downside is that there are some questions that aren't quite answered on the Sonos site.So here they are:1)Do I need a Sonos bridge?Kind of.  At least one of the Sonos products needs to be attached via wires to your router.  It can be a bridge, or any Sonos product.You cannot have a system where all Sonos products connect wirelessly.2)What Sonos do I need?This item (the Connect:AMP) has a built in amplifier, so this one needs speakers.The Sonos Play:5 and Play:3 are self contained and need nothing else (except perhaps a bridge as per 1 above).The Sonos Connect needs an amp, and possibly a bridge depending on your set up (again, see 1 above).You do NOT need a Sonos remote.  Sonos has software that runs on Android and Apple products, as well as your PC or Apple.  Personally, I think the sonos control is overpriced, and you could get a dedicated android phone with no contract for about 1/7th the price.I am frugal (cheap), I'll usually use more difficult software, or take a more difficult set up to save some money.  The money I spent on this is well spent, and I would recommend it to anyone who's looking for a stereo.

I've had various Caselogic laptop bags over the years, starting in 1997.  In fact, my case from 1997 is still in good shape and I use it to store an old laptop.I'm hoping this new case lasts as long as my old one.  It seems to have the same build quality as my old case.  The handle and arm strap are firmly affixed to the case itself.  Plus, the nylon material of the bag also feels sturdy.The laptop compartment is nicely padded on one side.  The other side is less padded, but still seems to offer ample protection.  The other main compartment has room for a fairly decent amount of folders and paper.  It also has two pouches, each about the size of a DVD.  I would not put anything fragile in these pouches since there isn't much padding around them, but I would feel comfortable putting something such as an inexpensive laptop mouse.One note about this case is that it doesn't open all the way.  You slide your laptop in instead of opening the case all the way and placing it inside (meaning you can't just open the case on your lap and use the laptop while it's still in the case).Also, when I first took this bag out of the bag is was sent in, it had a very strong chemical smell.  I received a review copy of this case, so I'm not sure if the bags are normally wrapped in plastic.  If your case does smell, don't worry.  After a day, the smell dissipated.Overall, this case seems nice.  It doesn't have all the frills other bags have, but this bag does a good job of protecting your laptop.

As much as I enjoy the games for the Wii and Wii U...- As interesting as the Gamepad is, I absolutely hate the way it is implemented. First of all, it is an absolute requirement. You cannot set up your Wii U without it, even though most menu screens on the TV just tell you to look at the Gamepad. Few games seem to be able to make any use of the Gamepad, but all Games I tried require it to be used as the first player controller and you can't turn off the screen. That makes it VERY distracting. (well, you can turn the screen off, not while using it as a controller. The moment you press any buttons the screen comes back on.) Even the game this came with, Super Mario Bros. U, which is capable of using it as a 5th player (very nice idea!), still requires you to use it for the first player in single player mode. The irony is that in single player mode none of the touch screen features are active, so there is no point requiring it. (This makes it distinct from the old complaints people had with Wiimotes, which were required because they were used. Since the screen isn't used, why it is required? And at half the cost of the entire console... )- The largest problem with all of this isn't mere annoyance though, it is poor battery life. The Gamepad only lasts for a few hours, which might work for kids with a curfew, but not for adults with a day off to play or a party. The lights blink red when it was about to die, but how often is anyone looking at that when focused on the TV screen? Turns out this was actually by design though. The battery that ships is a reduced capacity battery. If you spent an extra $30 to Nintendo directly they will ship you the original capacity battery (they call it extended, which is hilarious since that's the size it was designed to have) it will last more than 12 hours, which is more than enough time for my needs. When the power finally does go out the game just hangs. No pause button, no home button. You could be in the middle of something and suddenly your character will just die. Couldn't they program it to pause when the power goes out, like literally every other wireless console on the planet? Even the GAMECUBE would pause the game when a wireless controller dies! Huge step back, Nintendo!- The ability to break away from the TV is a very interesting option, but the range is too weak. The most I can do with it is play in the same room next to someone else on the couch playing a different game.If they could build an NFC repeater to extend the signal it would solve that problem and make it usable anywhere in the house, at which point I would love the feature, but as it stands I never really use it.- I found it interesting that you could use the Gamepad as a TV screen for the Wii games to point the Wiimote at, but unfortunately you can't just pull the Gamepad off the cradle and load it up while someone is using the TV. At some point the Gamepad will tell you to look at the TV to make a selection with a Wiimote there, which makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. Who came up with that? Also, Wiiware games in Wiimode that require a classic controller still require it, so breaking away from the TV is extra impractical. You would need a Gamepad, a Wiimote, and a Classic controller all working together when it would make more sense to allow the classic controller to be emulated by the Gamepad controls. That ability right there would have been amazing.- Definitely not a party console. At least not yet. There are a few games with party appeal, but when I host a game night I would fully expect everyone to choose the Wii games or PS3 arcade games. Not the Wii U. Where's it's niche?- I hate hate HATE!!! WaraWara Plaza! It's always on! You can't turn it off! The most you can do is switch between which screen sees it, the TV or the Gamepad. You also can't shut it up! Even in parental controls, which is supposed to block it, Nintendo advertisements keep running. So ya, Nintendo is pushing game ads in my face all the freaking time. Even as a social network it's useless because they are overly restrictive on what you can do or say.- I didn't like how it requires your old Wii console be wiped first. This is a major problem because if the Wii U breaks or needs repairs or even if you want to return it you are stuck. To avoid this I backed up the EmuNAND and restored it after a system transfer.- I didn't like the loss of Gamecube support. The Wii U is physically capable of running Gamecube games, but they cut out the hardware that holds the Gamecube disc in place along with the memory card slots and controller ports. All they would have to have done is sell a slot loading mini DVD case, allow other controllers to take the place of the Gamecube controllers, and emulate the memory card and it would work perfectly........I really do like Nintendo's attempt at innovation, but overall it's as if they never stopped to consider how people would actually want to make use of those innovations. Maybe if the Wii U becomes a party console again, fixes the NFC range issue, and fixes the Gamepad use requirements, I would love the Wii U, but right now it's just... well, I never thought I would say this about any Nintendo console because I have been a Nintendo customer since the NES and original Gameboy and owned them all... but... It's just an "OK Console". Not great, just OK.

Belkin excels at making cases for iPads.  I don't think I have ever had one that fits less than perfectly, or that doesn't align with cutouts.  The Dot Cover is no exception.This case fits the iPad Mini snugly, snapping into place at each corner with four rubber-like retainers.  The inner lining is soft material so as not harm your device screen.  The case secures "portfolio" style with a magnetic tab closure, or, when open, the tab helps hold the cover open.  PLEASE NOTE: This is a plan magnetic latch, not the kind that wakes up the iPad when the case opens.The exterior is a synthetic material with a leather-like feel.  Overall, the case does not add much weight or thickness to the device.  Does it add some - yes, of course, it is a case!  The case has a cutout so that it does not interfere at all with the iPad camera, and you can easily access the power and volume buttons.As far as viewing, you can position the case as a stand in three modes for different viewing angles.The case presently comes in two colors (gray and black).I would recommend this case.  It does add a little bulk to the device, but not too much.  There are thinner cases out there, and you have to weigh protection of an expensive device against "keeping slim."
Went to a big box store where they wanted $40 for this cable. This one works like a charm and was so much less.

Thank you Kinivo for providing me with ZX220 Portable Rechargeable Twin Speakers, free of charge, for review on my blog Ahh~Mazing Reviews. These are my own honest opinions.Kinivo continues to amaze me with how they can pack such big sound in such small, affordable speakers! I've tried a few of their speakers now, and they are all amazing, and totally affordable. They recently sent me their ZX220 Portable Rechargeable Twin Speakers for review.I've been using them as computer speakers, since they are wired, but I occasionally plug my phone into them as well. They are compatible with any device that has a 3.5mm headphone jack or audio out port.These speakers are rechargeable, making them a good portable set of speakers. They have one cord to connect them as well as charge them. Each speaker has an expansive resonator feature which gives the best low frequency output. The speakers don't sound great with low frequency music at first, but then you twist them and open up the expansive resonator and they will blow you away!The base of the speakers is magnetic, for easy portability. Just stick the two speakers together and stick them and the cord in the included pouch and take them on-the-go anywhere!This is a great set of speakers for people who want to take their music with them on the go, and really great for those people who don't have bluetooth devices. My mom is still in the stone ages and doesn't have a smartphone, and uses an iPod Classic, so this set of speakers would be great for her. My son has used them with his cheap little MP3 player too. Or they're great as computer speakers, like I am using them!
summary: These little speakers pack a lot of sound!

reviewText: I spent a ton of money picking this up after my Garmin 305 fell off during my last marathon. So I went with the 410 hoping to get the same enjoyment and life out of it.Nope.First off, this is not easy to set up and use like the 305. The interface is NOT intuitive at all. And the whole touching the bezel idea just got annoying. I know, you can turn it off, but I didn't find it helpful to begin with. Then I ran my first race with it on (a duathlon). It died about two hours into the race. TWO HOURS!?!?! So disappointed.I've loved the Garmin brand, but I'm starting to consider other alternatives.

I needed a good pair of noise-cancelling headphones as it can get loud where I work and these helped save my ears as I did not have to blast the volume to use them. After about 1 month, the switch on the left side began to show wear and tear. If I turned on the noise cancelling option, I would have to wiggle the switch around ait to get the sound in both ears. Now I can barely get it to work on both ears. I've wiggles the cord, but that doesn't affect it, the problem is with the noise-cancelling switch. This has been really disappointing as I thought these would be decent headphones. Now I have to find new ones and hesitate in ever thinking of using A.T. brand. Is there anything anyone can do to help me? Any suggestions even???

reviewText: I have purchased and installed several of these routers. If you are planning on using one of them as a simple router, it is a great device; powerful, reliable, great range and lots of features, including the ability to enable/disable the 2.4 or 5Ghz spectrums, as well as enable/disable a separate guest network.The interface is pretty clean and easy to use, and I like that you can have the device check for firmware updates itself right through the configuration interface; no need to go to the manufacturer's website, figure out exactly which model and hardware revision you have, manually download the file, manually upload it to the router, etc. etc.Updating the device firmware on this Netgear router is far easier than with most other brands, as the router handles it all itself and defaults to checking for updated firmware every time you login to the device, which is nice, and can be disabled if you need to frequently login to the device.Speaking of firmware, that brings us to our big, gaping flaw and the reason I only gave this device a four-star rating:The repeat function absolutely does not work. Do NOT plan on purchasing two of these routers with the intent of using one as a base station and the other as a repeater to extend the range of your wireless network, because as of Nov. 2010, there is a firmware bug that simply doesn't allow this feature to work.After driving myself insane messing with it, I did some research online and on Netgear's support forums, it is clear that there's a known bug that prevents the repeat function from working.This has gone unresolved for months - I don't recall the exact dates of all the threads I read, but Netgear, through their support forums, has been aware of the issue for many months and still no new firmware, at least not as of Nov. 2010.That's a real shame as Netgear is one of the only companies whose networking products I trust, the other being Linksys/Cisco.I do hope they will address this big issue very quickly, as this seems to be their flagship consumer router.Anyhow, again, if you are looking for a single, simple router, this guy is great, just don't plan on buying a twin to use to extend the range of your network, as it won't work. If you need to do that, Apple's Airport actually does that quite well.

This runs Linux really well.  You can get to a command-line prompt just fine.  There is quite a bit of software that can be downloaded to run on it.  It connects to my WPA-secured 802.11g network easily, and it can also connect to unsecured 802.11 networks all over town.  You can install an SSH client and also a server.  It plays MP3 music out of the box, but for some reason you have to install a separate OGG music player.  It would be nice to have a newer Flash player so that YouTube videos could be played - I understand that there is a "beta" version of the OS that does include a newer Flash player, but I'm not happy putting anything beta on a product that I use as much as I am using this one.  I bought this one and am quite happy with it, but if I could afford it, I would probably get the newer n800-series unit - This is a good product.  Recommended.
