This camera is awesome. I mainly got it because I want to have a nice camera that I don't have to be extra careful with. I work with kids and take a lot of pictures, and they inevitably want to use my camera to take pictures and I usually let them, but I tend to hover to make sure it doesn't get accidently dropped in the sandbox or in a tub of water. Now, I'm happy that I won't have to worry about this anymore. This camera can withstand a 5 foot drop onto concrete or into water.I don't have much use for the tap feature, which is designed to be used with gloves, because I live in southern California. It's more annoying to have it activated when you don't need it but I'm sure it's a great feature for when you are bundled up and you don't want to take your gloves off.I really like the portrait modes the stylus has because it makes it east to quickly switch to different modes. The screen helps you switch to different modes too, it is pretty bright and it is a lot easier to see in daylight than previous cameras I have owned.I have yet to really take it on an underwater excursion, but I have tested it out in the sink a few times and in the bath and there was not any water seepage into the battery compartment or in the USB port.I love the ability to do in-camera fixes with red eye and lighting. The camera also automatically saves the edited picture separate from the old, so you don't have to worry about it replacing the original picture, if you don't like the new effect.I love the fact that this camera has a built in memory. You can only a take a few pictures with it, but you don't get that "No memory card" error anymore. It's a good feature to have in a pinch, especially when you first get it to test out the features. The camera also tells you in the corner how many pictures you have left and how many minutes of video you have left on the card or in the internal memory. No more snapping away pictures only to hear the beep! beep! and see the "memory full" words pop up on the screen; then there's the scramble to quickly delete pictures. You'll never have to guess how many shots you have left.I've only had the camera a few days and I haven't tried out all of the features, and I am looking forward to that and I will update my review. I have yet to use the in camera panorama feature, I am pretty sure that you have to have an Olympus card in order for this to work and I am using the micro SD card adapter and using a 2 MP card.The program that comes with the camera is also pretty good and user friendly. It has the same feel as Google's Picasa, but I haven't played with it much yet because I really like Picasa!There are a couple of things I don't really like about the camera. One is I wish there were more features for the video camera, it pretty much has an option of 15 fps and 30 fps. My older camera has about 10 different video options. Two, is that I don't think picture quality is as great as a Canon with the same number of mega pixels. The picture comes out looking a little more digital and not as crisp. But I will gladly give up a little picture quality for a camera that comes with all of the underwater, freeze proof, etc features.So, I think this camera is definitely worth the price, and if I had $100 more to spend I would have definitely gotten the 8000. I love its versatility with being a real outdoorsy camera, and I would recommend it to anyone who wants a high end digital camera that can withstand some drops and some water.
summary: love the versitility of the camera

reviewText: I'm using the new BT keyboard to type this review and it works fairly well.  The keys are a little close together, but, it's way easier to touch type than the virtual keyboard on the iPad.  Given that I'm a touch typist, the Return, Delete (Backspace) and Tab keys are placed where I would have expected them.Some of the keys don't really "do" anything - like the "fn" key with the "spacebar".  The "fn-lock" keys work well to put the iPad to sleep.  I was even able to "awaken" the iPad and actually type in the screen lock code to begin using again.  Copy and Paste keys work as expected.I turned off the BT keyboard and then turned it back on, expecting the iPad to reconnect, but, it didn't.  I had to manually reconnect via the iPad Settings app.As far as the case itself, it will certainly protect the iPad from general bumping and unintentional rough treatment which may do damage to an iPad.  The extension stand on the case "lid" (which holds the iPad) takes a little getting used to as its a bit awkward in manually adjusting the iPad to workable position.  Though the overall case is thicker than some, it isn't too bad.  It is well made and sturdy.  It should stand the true test of time.All in all, I would say that this is a fine BT keyboard case for those needing an in expensive case for their iPad.  I've tried other, more expensive BT keyboard cases and find them to be more to my personal liking.
summary: New Trent Airbender 1.0 - Wireless Bluetooth Clamshell iPad Keyboard Case. Compatible: iPad 4, 3, 2. (upgraded version)

reviewText: If something changes, I will be fair and edit or amend this review.I have an Insignia TV/computer monitor with HDMI ports and 1080i resolution capability.  Recently ditched my iPhone 4S for a Galaxy S4 because I needed a phone with a larger display.  Was very happy with my iPhone being hardwired to my Insignia TV using an iPhone HDMI adapter and never had any problems whatsoever.  Used it mainly to AirPlay video podcasts from the phone to the large TV screen.Recently, I bought an Apple TV, however, using an Android phone with so-called "AirPlay beaming apps" to beam content from the Android phone to the Apple TV has sometimes been problematic; have to use multiple apps depending on what content I want to watch.  Also, for some strange reason, most PBS video podcasts will not play directly on the Apple TV or from PBS using the beaming apps on my Android phone, which is very weird.  I have Apple looking into that issue.Anyhow, back on topic, I was going to get the Samsung AllShare Cast Dongle (wireless), however, after reading about all the problems in the Amazon reviews that many people had with that (especially setup and lag time with videos and video quality), I decided to go hardwired, especially since I only paid $16.00 (with free Prime shipping) this week for the hardwired MHL 2.0 adapter.  I was hoping to return my Apple TV for a full refund, but since it appears that the $16.00 Samsung adapter isn't going to work, I have to keep the Apple TV or be without a way to do what I want to do.  Stuff simply shouldn't be this difficult!I have spent the literally past three hours (that I really cannot spare, and will hang up with tech support if not resolved in next 30 minutes) troubleshooting with Samsung Tech Support chat and am on my THIRD telephone support employee (a senior technician, who I am holding for).I followed all instructions implicitly, read all the negative reviews on Amazon for tips (which I also followed), but it simply doesn't work (with or without the power cord being plugged into the adapter, which is said not to even be necessary with the Galaxy S4 phone, since the adapter is said to be MHL 2.0).I guess I will have to relent and keep the Apple TV (3rd Generation) device, so that I can watch podcasts on the big screen.  One thing is for sure, at least I have a direct line into Apple where I can spend 5 minutes sending an email and not spend hours on the phone with them like I am with Samsung!In any event, one Samsung tech told me "We only guarantee the HDTV Adapter with Samsung TVs," which I think is very very lame since that isn't in any of the marketing materials when they sell these products.  Since this MHL 2.0 is new as of March 2013 (according to the date on the back of the teeny-tiny instruction booklet that comes with it), the one-star reviews on Amazon will only grow as many consumers will discover that this product simply might not be compatible with thousands of HDTVs on the market today!I do not believe there is anything wrong with a new factory-sealed adapter sold to me directly by Amazon (or at least fulfilled by Amazon), if memory serves me correctly.  They will be receiving a major complaint from me, too!This really sucks, because BeyondPod app for Android does such a nice job with podcasts on the Galaxy phone and all I want to do is see it on a bigger screen; is that too much to ask?  Apple TV (3rd Generation) does a cr*ppy job with the podcasts and the device keeps freezing on me, so it looks like nothing is designed to work the way it should!

reviewText: The EH50S is my second Panasonic DVD recorder, the E80H I got 18 months ago worked so well that I decided to buy a second unit for my other home.I won't repeat the comments you can read elsewhere, but I will discuss the couple issues that have not been mentioned before.If you plan to perform editing on this unit (such as editing out commercials before archiving to DVD), you will need to do a lot of fast-forward/fast-backward/pause/play maneuvers to skip over the unwanted parts.  In the EH-50S, each press of the fast-forward will take you to a higher speed, and there are a total of 5 levels (2x,10x,30x,70x,200x).  Naturally, you want something faster than 2x or 10x while searching forward/backward (30x and 70x are good choices) to seek out the commercial breaks to edit them out.  The typical key press is to hit fast forward 3-4 times successively to get to the higher speed, and hit play/pause when the unwanted part begins/ends so you can locate the specific points to begin/end editing.That is where the problem with this unit lies - when you press fast-forward/backward multiple times successively, it queues up your key presses and it can take over 6 seconds after the last key press to get to the speed you want.  It will not execute any other command such as play/pause/stop until it is finished with the queued commands.  So it is a guarantee that you will always overshoot the point you want to stop if you engage high speed search.  6 seconds may not sound long when you read this, but if you are in 70x speed, even 3 seconds is overshooting the stopping point by 3+ minutes of programming, I can assure you that you will swear at this recorder more than once per edit.  As a result, if you edit often, you do not want this recorder (Interestingly, the old E80H, with the latest firmware, provides almost instantaneous responses).  Unfortunately, Panasonic never released a newer version of the EH50S firmware since its release.This problem is not related to the new hard-drive "sleep mode", as the drive is already spinning at full speed when you edit.  I work in computer hardware/software for 20 years, I believe it is the result of poor firmware design.  Hard drive sleep mode as a way to improve durability is a marketing gimmick, its true value lies in reduced power consumption and heat generation.  A typical consumer-grade hard drive provides a 600,000 hours of mean-time-between-failure (MTBF), that is 68 years of 24x7 non-stop operation!  You have other problems to worry about if you are still using the unit in 2073.  (The commercial grade drives is in the 1.4+ million hour range, but surely that's not what Panasonic put in the unit).In LP mode, very fast motion of contrasting color objects (like a person dancing in colorful clothing) can cause an image breakdown: the affected area turned into big blocky shapes.  This is rare, but the problem was not in the older model.  The LP mode in the EH50S is supposed to equal the SP mode quality in the E80H, but it is perhaps only true in programs with little transitions.  With sports program, LP is useless.  You should only use LP mode for something that you don't plan to archive. I definitely consider this the second show-stopper for this recorder.On the bright side, the dubbing speed is very fast.  In LP mode, it can dub a 60 min video in less than 2 minutes (assuming you have the right disks), which is up to 8 times faster than the older model.  It also allows you to view regular program during dubbing, while the E80H forces you to watch a blue status screen until dubbing completes (which can take a long time depending on the length of the dubbing materials).Panasonic took some cost cuting in the EH50S, the control on the units is fewer than in the older model, the display is cheaper and less sophisticated.  The brush metal overlay on the older remote is gone, replaced by a full plastic design.  But the unit also costs a lot less, so you get what you pay for.I have cable without a cable box, TV Guide works as advertised.The recorders is sensitive to power interruption, it displayed a U99 failure message intermittently after a power outage.  I reformatted the hard-drive and the problem disappeared.  In this respect, it is no different than a computer.Overall, the flexibility to archive to four disk formats is a big plus for me.  I hope Panasonic will release a firmware update soon to fix the image breakdown issue and improve the response of the fast forward/backward keys, as well as the general key press responses.  If they fix these two issues, then I would recommend the recorder wholeheartedly.  In the current state, I believe the EH50S is a couple steps back from designs that is two generations older, which is a huge disappointment.However, if you rarely edit and just use the unit to record/time-slip programs, then you shouldn't be concerned about the slow key-press responses.If you edit, I give this recorder 1-star, you will learn to hate the EH50S, so look elsewhere.  If you don't edit and records at SP or higher speed, I give it a 5 star.I bought the EH50S because of the positive experience from the older E80H.  Now with the sluggish EH50S, I will not buy another Panasonic recorder unless they can prove that the future model is indeed better.After the release of the EH50S, Panasonic came to a screeching halt in releasing new hard-drive-based recorders since early 2005.  It became the only new model with a hard disk drive, a far cry from the previous lineup (their two higher end models are of the previous generation).  I wonder if Panasonic realized the flaws in the EH50S and is delaying the release of newer and higher-end models.
summary: Issues you don't see in previous reviews

reviewText: Battery died after 2 days will not recommend it to any one. Of you buy it and plan to return it, returning would cost you more than the price of the battery

If you are looking for a usb 3.0 compatible hard drive enclosure, look no further. This enclosure is absolutely amazing, although I've had it for less than a month. The usage has been great, except the fact that I overlooked the measurements and shoved in my samsung 840 pro ssd in there, and could not get it out without some rough-housing. With a traditional 2.5 inch hdd, this enclosure is exceptionally great because harddrives are easy to swap out as it is pushed out automatically, when the latch is opened, and it can lock your hard drive once you put it in to reduce movement. The included usb cable has a thick wiring, which is great as other enclosures I have owned, had thin usb wiring which seemed flimsy and cheap. I had not tested the speeds yet, but with a usb 3.0 interface, the only limiter would be your hard drive. If you want something with a good build quality, this one's for you.And as always, you get what you pay for.

This TV is quite amazing. So amazing, in fact, that I will probably get my dad one to replace his buzzy, obnoxious standard. I use this as a computer monitor, a PS3 screen, and a regular TV set. The picture and sound are amazing- very little to none of that "tinny" sound.As for the Smart functions, they can be handy, but I only use them as needed. The TV is great on it's own.

reviewText: You can't boot off of this device - and that's not anywhere in the specs.  Still trying using the workarounds on the net.  It's a shame, because it otherwise seems like a reasonable flash drive.  Transcend's support web site could stand to be a whole lot faster, too.
Works as advertised and is a huge help when I need to plug in multiple devices to my MacBook Pro.

Having reviewed a similar Hard drive before--Seagate Laptop Thin 500 GB Solid State Hybrid Drive SATA 6Gb/s 64 MB Cache 2.5 Inch ST500LM000--I will add a few of the comments from there because it compares very evenly with this drive. The points I will edit will be data from the actual Windows install and Crystal Disk Mark Benches.[---Difference between this drive (The 'new' Momentus XT) and the Seagate Hybrid Hard Drive (mentioned above)---]Honestly I the hard drive mentioned above, the Hybrid, has the exact same specs, except for being 500 gb, however it posted slightly better read/write speeds. Other than that slight difference, which may not be a difference at all, this drive and the above are both 64mb cache and 5200 RPMs with 8 GB of SSD storage.[---Review (some copied from my earlier review on the Hybrid drive)---]The purpose of this hard drive is to mimic a lot of 'computer' configurations where someone will install a smaller full SSD (anywhere from 32 GB to 256GB) alongside a bigger 'mechanical' or platter hard drive (1TB or more). The latter is to have great performance while also saving a bit of money. The most expensive configuration you could have, with maximum speed, is to have just full SSDs in raid array. The least expensive is to have just mechanical hard drives. Obviously with all of the previous configurations you are sacrificing something somewhere in each of them:1. With a configuration of all SSDs you are marginally sacrificing reliability, to a point. I say this because there is a chance of an SSD failure (most businesses still use mechanical hard drives for this reason) though in all honesty, I trust my SSDs more than a mechanical hard drive.2. With a configuration of all mechanical hard drives you are sacrificing speed (a drastic loss in speed compared to SSDs) with the advantage of having much more space at a lower cost (a 1 TB SSD costs around 550$--crucial--whereas you can find a 1 TB mechanical hard drive for 80$ or less).---Review of Drive---With the lead-in aside, this superspeed drive is basically made to mimic a balance between 1 & 2--which a lot of people have a combination of already in the form of an SSD for the operating system and a big mechanical hard drive for data. The Seagate Superspeed drive is to eliminate space, and put it in 1 form factor and designed for a laptop/ultrabook. I installed this on my laptop in the SATA III port and installed Windows 7 via a USB 2.0 Flash Drive.Seagate Superspeed specs:64 mb cache5400 RPMMLC NAND Flash MemoryStorage Specs within the Seagate hybrid:1TB (the actual literal storage made up of:8GB of SSD MLC NAND935GB of space on the mechanical hard disk (5400 rpm)As you can see from above, you have minimal SSD space. A typical, non-sale, 1 TB platter drive is around 80$ or so. Here you are paying the extra 40$ for 8GB of SSD space. That is roughly 5.00$ per SSD GB. Currently, pure SSDs can be bought for about 1.38$ a GB (Crucial M500 240GB SATA 2.5-Inch 7mm (with 9.5mm adapter) Internal Solid State Drive CT240M500SSD1). With this drive there is a bit of a markup--for the convenience of owning a 2-in-1. The question now is, is this drive worth it?The short answer is, yes, only if one of these reasons:1. You have to have more than 900 GB of space and are on a budget of around 100$**If you have the ability to place 2 hard drives in your laptop/desktop here is a possible configuration for you that will cost just slightly more (20$) than this hybrid drive:1 x 1 TB Harddrive 54$Seagate Barracuda 1 TB HDD SATA 6 Gb/s NCQ 64MB Cache 3.5-Inch Internal Bare Drive ST1000DM0031 x 32GB SSD 44$ at 1.375$ per GB ADATA USA Premier Pro SP600 2.5-Inch 32 GB SATA III MLC Internal Solid State Drive ASP600S3-32GM-CTotal: 94$ - Note that the bigger SSD you get the better price per GB you receive where to tapers out to the 'sweet spot' at 250GB SSDs2. Your laptop only fits 1 Harddrive and you do not always want to use an external storage device.3. You strictly want faster boot times and opening a few programs very fast e.g. an internet browsing/Microsoft office only computer.Now to important part--Speed (SATA III port):Windows 7 64 bit Professional Install (From a USB 2.0 Flash Drive):13 minutes from install to desktopAfter install:Shutdown from desktop : 9 secondsStartup after POST (motherboard splash screen): 24 secondsCrystalDiskMark Speeds:Seq (round up):Read - 96 MB / sWrite - 115 MB / s512k:Read - 37 MB / sWrite - 66 MB / s**Samsung 830 256GB SSD Numbers comparison:**Shutdown from Desktop: 12 secondsStartup after POST: 14 seconds[---Important Mentions---]I have noticed that, after several weeks, that the startup times remain the same though there are certain slow-downs/hangs when going from desktop to opening a program. Though it boots faster, the mechanical hard drive kicks in with the majority of tasks when you use the computer.This drive is very appropriate for the light user who does not do more than internet browsing and opening constituent programs. You can also do other things on this but if you make this your dedicated workstation you will see slowdown as appropriate to a normal mechanical hard drive. For those that do not want to transition to a sole SSD but have the boot-times of one with the storage of a mechanical hard drive, this will give you that type of production. If you can spend the 170$ or so for a 250GB SSD, then that would be the 'perfect' balance of speed and storage.
summary: Not an SSD Substitute--SSD Sampler/Storage Drive

The last card I had, the 8400, lasted two years, and that's good considering all the use it gave me.  The 210 is definitely an improvement.  I can say with no doubt that I now have better definition on my HD monitors.  They are the same monitors and the whole system is the same, so the 210 shows a significant upgrade.It was easy to install the card in the box and install the drivers with the CD.  I had to set up my monitors to the 16:9 configuration because upon installing this card, the monitors defaulted to 4:3 (small squared-shape screen).Considering the value, I would not hesistate to upgrade to this 210 card even if your old card is still working.
summary: Outstanding video card, very enthusiastic about this card

reviewText: I bought this item because I was adopting a kitten.  I live in a one hundred year plus house with uncountable,I hope there is such a word, places to hide. I put one of the key ring "beepers" on my new kitten and let her have at it.  I was able to find her in a matter seconds.  She is now nearly two years old and she knows my house better then I do. Now my grand-cat, yeah, I said grand-cat, will be visiting with my daughter.  I have the beeper already but I had to get new batteries but no biggie. The price was pennies compared to calming my daughter's fears of her cat possibly getting lost in my cavernous house.I also use the stick on beepers to help me find my knitting needle box and crochet hook box. I had to hide them from my grand kids.  I could have them sword fighting with my Pyrex needles.I'm contemplating the possible of ordering another Click 'n' Dig.  My 92 year old father is slowly declining mentally and I think the Click 'n' Dig will be helpful for him find his key even though he can't drive and can barely walk.  He just likes to have them where he can put his hands on them.Thank you for making such a wonderful device!

After ordering 2 touchscreen monitors that I had to return because they did not work with my OS so when I received this monitor I had my fingers crossed. Happily it works and works very well. The screen adds to the experience of using Microsoft 8. For me the price was right and Dell is a name I have trusted for over 15 years. I recommend without hesitation.
